\n
\n I was informed that Gunboat games have restricted admissions, which may keep game 5 grounded. So Game 6 is available for anyone wanting to play.
The game is SG League Game 6.
And the password is sgleague.

Mel

    \n Well, there is nothing preventing one from making a game gunboat without enforcement, is there? Game #5/6 could be gunboat by the simple expediency of everybody agreeing to keep it gunboat. In fact, my own preference would be for public messaging only - that is, allow public speaking here but disallow private messages.

    I'll be available for the gunboat, not sure about a normal game. Let's see whether there's interest from other comers.

    \n
    \n
    \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n As noted, deadlines are 24 hours for order, retreats,and builds. Basically, something every 24 hours. Sometimes a player won't have anything to submit--if, for example, you have no retreats required in the retreat phase. So each year will take 3-5 days. A sampling of recent finished games indicates they ended between Fall 1907 and Fall 1910--18-45 days of playing time--for some, anyway. Gunboat games take longer.

    And let's take Eero's suggestion and make Game 6 a Gunboat game. That means no communication and no press for the players on the Diplomacy website. Commentary about the game should take place here--but no negotiations.

    The game won't be anonymous, because user names are assigned to countries. But other than that it should work ok. It's a chance to see what you would do in the absence of negotiations.

    And, in terms of time commitment, games without negotiations may take longer, but potentially less time per day because players don't have to write back and forth to each other.

    Game 5 will still be available for those wanting to join the Diplomacy site. I think membership is a donation. I have no affiliation with the site!

    Mel

    \nI haven't played much of Diplomacy and none of gunboat, but my basic instinct is that, one, the center countries are fucked (or at least at a disadvantage), because their strength comes from a prime diplomatic location and not a tactical one, and two, that a kind of "blood in the water" syndrome will kick in, where the first country to suffer an even minor setback will be gobbled up quickly.
    \n
    \nShould be interesting!

    \n The Gunboat aspect may be deterring people from signing up. If so, let me know. I will leave this game as is for the next week (to 1700 GMT Dec 13). If it is still lacking players, and there are others who would play a classic game, we will open it up as a regular game at that time.
    FYI--there is no trick to signing up for free Diplomacy games. Registration and that's it. So anyone wanting to try Diplomacy can do so at Play Diplomacy Online. I am sure there are other sites as well.
    Mel

    \n\nBill_White \n\n\n

    \n
    \n
    \n Arguably, gunboat games are more ethically defensible than standard games, because there are no hidden or private treaties--it's the Wilsonian ideal of open covenants!

    Of course, the fact that the private channels will still exist will mean that it will be possible to shrilly denounce one's opponents of engaging in covert diplomacy, which will be fun. What would you do if someone sent you a PM in a gunboat game?
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Posted By: Paul T.OK, I joined in.

    Since I'm just trying to learn about the game, I'd be most interested in "gunboat" or a version where all negotiation is out in the open, as Eero suggests.
    \nI hadn't realized that was Eero's suggestion--to do all negotiation here! That's actually quite neat. So it would not really be a 'gunboat' game but a big open convention...That actually adds to the game one thing that can be missing from normal games where the negotiations are one-v-one and the agreements private: reputation.

    This will be interesting.

    Private messages may be, as Bill implies risky. But steganography is encouraged!
    Mel

    \nBill, are you saying that standard games are ethically questionable?
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    Posted By: MarhaultPosted By: Bill_WhiteArguably, gunboat games are more ethically defensible than standard games
    \nBill, are you saying that standard games are ethically questionable?

    Yes I am! I've come to the conclusion that Diplomacy is an instructive perversion, in that it subverts the normal ethics of communication (saying what you mean, meaning what you say) to establish a situation in which the expectation of at least eventual deception is endemic and crazy-making--but also something that you can learn from if you're sufficiently attentive. Now, I recognize that the question of the extent to which strategic communication can be ethically validated is a complicated one--I've even written a paper about it. And I'll concede that it's likely that the "magic circle" of the game implies that its players are maybe only playing at (ethically questionable) strategic communication, so I'm not anti-Diplomacy by any stretch of the imagination--shit, I'm signed up for Game 6--but let me just say that I'm aware of its ethical implications when I play.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n I'll sign up at an opportune moment later, never fear. Will we do a full gunboat (no communication at all) or allow public discussion? I'm cool with both, although open discussion might be more interesting with uneven skill levels. Gunboat tends to be pretty harsh in that regard, as there's no way for the strong player to share his tactical wisdom with the new face. In this regard normal Diplomacy is much more beginner-friendly, as theoretically the optimal game (according to my Diplomacy theory, anyway) requires the players to engage in maximum information sharing - somebody will always benefit of you playing your optimal game, so it's likely that somebody will tell you what to do even if you don't know yourself what would be a good move.

    As for private messages, obviously none should be allowed, that's the whole point of gunboat. Makes no difference whether you use the in-game messaging system, SG forum messages, chat or go and meet the other player in person. No private communication means no private communication.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    \nNot to get this planning thread off on idle, ivory-tower notions, but I would subscribe firmly to this interpretation. Except I guess the boundaries of the "magic circle" get blurry. Hmm.

    \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n

    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n I'm also more in the mood for public than full gunboat, but it's not because gunboat is boring. I'd compare it to simultaneous chess or blind chess or other such handicapped versions of the game in that it still has all the parts of the basic game, but it's just much more difficult to play because you basically have to be able to get by without everybody else drawing you a picture of their intentions and thinking all the time. It's also amusing how horribly people's thinking can get jumbled when they're not checking with each other all the time.

    I joined the game, seems that we have five players now. Needs two more - get in there Peter!

    \n

    \n Looks like the game is started!

    \n
    \n
    \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n I understood that we're doing public negotiation - that is, business as usual except nobody discusses the game with others in private venues. (This goes for strictly occasional small talk as well.)

    For example, I seem to be England, so I'll have my good neighbours in France and Germany know that I'm not planning any aggressive moves that would render either of them non-viable right from the opening. In fact, my moves will be such that if either of those two worthies would choose to attack the other, I'll be in perfect position to support such an attack for a modest consideration (1 SC).
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    \n I'm Russia. Don't mind me, sure I have more units, but they're scattered between north and south with little coordination. Just looking to pick up Sweden and Rumania if it's not any fuss to anyone, and then bring the mighty might of the bear to whomever bothers me.

    \n
    \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n I am playing Austria. Already I feel embattled and overwhelmed. I notice my that old friend Daumantas and I have reversed positions from our last game, where he was Austria and I was Turkey. Luckily for me, Willow is playing Russia, and we've seen her mettle as Germany in a previous game--she is a tough fighter. I will watch carefully to see if their moves portend the dreaded juggernaut, and if so call for aid from the West. Otherwise, I will throw in with the Power that moves most aggressively against the other and the least aggressively against me--to the extent that my powers of perception permit. My immediate neighbors to the west, Germany and Italy, are played by Peter and Paul (neither of whom I've played with before). To Peter, I say that I will as Austria, as in every game I've ever seen, stand back-to-back with you as a fellow central power, and hope that you will recognize how entwined are our interests in the early game. To Paul -- who has expressed some curiosity about how all this will work -- I will say that I have found it useful to consult the various on-line Diplomacy sites about openings as well as strategy and tactics (S&T). Italy has a tough game to play, to be sure. I'm reminded of the commendation of Leonidas to his soldiers at Thermopylae: "Kadmos enjoins your largest efforts, pressed as never told of!" I look forward to a fascinating game between France and England. England is being played by Eero, whom we all know for his long experience and intimate mastery of the game; he is confronted with a player known to us only as "brains," or Calculus on #playnow--monikers suggesting a laser-like focus on the logical, the rational, and the cerebral. High-level play is intimated!
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n Okay, so we negotiate here, in this thread? I can do that (although I probably won't be able to do it very effectively until I watch the rest of you experienced players doing it for a while!).

    I'm curious if the countries were assigned randomly, or through some method. I was the last to confirm, and I am now playing Italy. I've heard that Italy is, in many ways, the least desirable country, to the extent that some play a variant where Italy begins play with a fourth army in Tunis, for balance. If this is true, I may be in for a rough game, starting at a disadvantage already against veterans (this is effectively my first ever game - although I've started another game in "real life", it moves so slowly that this game will move ahead of that one within a matter of days).

    So, am I playing Italy by random assignment, or because I effectively received the "last pick", and no one else wanted her?

    In any case, I'm looking forward to (most likely) having my butt kicked but learning something in the process.
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Posted By: Mel WhiteSome, if not all of the openings Bill mentions are here:Diplomacy Openings Library
    \nOh, dear. I entered the opening I've been thinking of, and the library returns: "This Opening Is Unnamed and No Information Exists For It!"

    Does that mean it's a terrible idea?

    Posted By: Paul T.Posted By: Mel WhiteSome, if not all of the openings Bill mentions are here:Diplomacy Openings Library
    \nOh, dear. I entered the opening I've been thinking of, and the library returns: "This Opening Is Unnamed and No Information Exists For It!"

    Does that mean it's a terrible idea?

    Paul,
    It probably means it will go down in history as the "Paul T. Opening". There's nothing wrong with doing the really unexpected. I'm intrigued though to go see what opening isn't listed. That's a surprise.
    And I am not playing--I remain a neutral commentator. Bill is squaring me away on loading the map.
    Mel

    \n\nWillow \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    Posted By: Bill_WhiteI am playing Austria. Already I feel embattled and overwhelmed. I notice my that old friend Daumantas and I have reversed positions from our last game, where he was Austria and I was Turkey. Luckily for me, Willow is playing Russia, and we've seen her mettle as Germany in a previous game--she is a tough fighter. I will watch carefully to see if their moves portend the dreaded juggernaut, and if so call for aid from the West. Otherwise, I will throw in with the Power that moves most aggressively against the other and the least aggressively against me--to the extent that my powers of perception permit.
    \nThat does seem a bit harsh against me. A Turkish Anti-Austrian opening will look pretty similar to all but the most aggressively anti-Russian openings (expect a move to secure Bulgaria, and either Ank-Bla or Ank-Con, with Smyrna either following to Con or pulling around to Arm.) A good Turkish turn will end with Bulgaria, not threatening any of the Austrian homeland.

    Meanwhile, I'll be aiming for Rumania, which is right on the doorstep of Budapest.

    So in otherwords, all else being equal, "neutral" play from me is more threatening than that from the Turk.

    As we Russians are a peace loving people, I wonder what it would take to garner cooperation from the Austrian in leaving Rumania alone and allowing us to see how the Balkans shake out.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    Posted By: Paul T.Posted By: Mel WhiteSome, if not all of the openings Bill mentions are here:Diplomacy Openings Library
    \nOh, dear. I entered the opening I've been thinking of, and the library returns: "This Opening Is Unnamed and No Information Exists For It!"

    Does that mean it's a terrible idea?

    I am not familiar with the game much, so speaking from, uh, general principles here...

    Probably! Diplomacy openings have been playtested thoroughly enough so that any good enough opening should be on any good enough database.

    On the other hand, Diplomacy openings have been playtested thoroughly enough so that *any* possible opening should be on a database, even if poor.

    Could be that you just need to look for information in a different place.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n Ah, I see. I think it's merely considered too passive an opening - I doubt it would deserve any consideration in the history books.

    Bill, since you're listening (and reading), and concerned about your safety, I'm prepared to start the ball rolling by offering you a long-term treaty: I will support your control of the Balkans (in particular, Greece) from the sea in exchange for peace and Trieste (only once you've secured the Balkans with my help--in 1902).

    We can have peace in the Adriatic, and I'm happy to leave Trieste unoccupied once you've allowed me to step in there. We can allow each other the peace of mind to fight East and West while I build fleets to hold off France and Turkey and you take the majority of the Balkans and then move further East or North, as you prefer. I should be able to support you against Turkey or Germany, if it comes to war.

    What do you think? Is it a naive plan, or worth considering? Playing Italy scares me, to be honest.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nWillow \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n Paul,

    Italy can be tough. Eero did it well, but that's because Eero is Eero.

    I'd be happy to join forces with you, offer support for a few moves, and crush any mutual enemy we might have between us. After all, you're going to be going after either Turkey or Austria, who both happen to border my territories.

    -Willow
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    Posted By: WillowPosted By: Bill_WhiteI am playing Austria. Already I feel embattled and overwhelmed. I notice my that old friend Daumantas and I have reversed positions from our last game, where he was Austria and I was Turkey. Luckily for me, Willow is playing Russia, and we've seen her mettle as Germany in a previous game--she is a tough fighter. I will watch carefully to see if their moves portend the dreaded juggernaut, and if so call for aid from the West. Otherwise, I will throw in with the Power that moves most aggressively against the other and the least aggressively against me--to the extent that my powers of perception permit.
    \nThat does seem a bit harsh against me. A Turkish Anti-Austrian opening will look pretty similar to all but the most aggressively anti-Russian openings (expect a move to secure Bulgaria, and either Ank-Bla or Ank-Con, with Smyrna either following to Con or pulling around to Arm.) A good Turkish turn will end with Bulgaria, not threatening any of the Austrian homeland.

    Meanwhile, I'll be aiming for Rumania, which is right on the doorstep of Budapest.

    So in otherwords, all else being equal, "neutral" play from me is more threatening than that from the Turk.

    As we Russians are a peace loving people, I wonder what it would take to garner cooperation from the Austrian in leaving Rumania alone and allowing us to see how the Balkans shake out.

    Excellent point, Willow! I of course recognize Russia's interest in Rumania, and there are circumstances in which a Russian fleet in Rumania is quite welcome. I look at the totality of the board, of course, and consider what else is going on. Should Army Warsaw invade Galicia, for example, Russian protestations of mildness are ipso facto invalidated. Conversely, should a strong anti-Turkish opening materialize, Austria might be in a position to lend its support to Russia's efforts to take and hold Rumania. Conversely, given the opacity of early Turkish moves, he will have work harder to signal the same level of partisanship toward Austria and against Russia than Russia does contrariwise.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n Willow,

    I appreciate the offer, and would be happy to consider you an ally, should you need support "from the other side" in the cases of Germany and Turkey. Likewise for Austria, if Bill turns out not to consider my friendly offer worth his time. However, due to his relationship to me as a near-mentor in my other game, I will not move against him if he does decide to side with me - I hope you will not see this as an anti-Russian sentiment.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n So, I am Turkey!

    Hello Bill, hello Willows! Chances are I will be laying waste to one of your lands with the help of another, unless you decide to do the same with me... But there is no reason we can not all be civil about it.

    As for my immediate plans and longterm plans?

    Moving my forces to Bulgaria, of course, and then will see what slice of the Balkans I can take, and, much more importantly, keep.

    Also going to take the Black Sea, or go there, at least - place is too important to be left alone. Worst thing that happens is a bounce, best thing that happens is well, a ship in a prime strategic location. Bargaining chip, hoorah!

    I'll leave out any commitments for the next-next turn until we see what's what - it'll be a little while before my turkish lands can even DO anything that affects another nation.

    I do, however, express the required polite sentiment of being open to both sides to help conquer the other side, though, in all honesty, that is quite ridiculous to do when the polite sentiment so expressed is given out in the open with both parties present, no?


    I haven't, uh, read much of Turkey-related material (except as it pertains to austrian plans - due to my prior play experience...) yet, so if I make any obviously stupid moves, do feel free to point them out to me, and I'll try to adjust accordingly, alright?


    Also, hey Paul! We don't have much to talk about yet, but when we do, you know where to find me! Don't commit yourself to the turkish front too readily or too fully, alright?
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n Paul -- This plan intrigues me, and I'm not averse to giving up Trieste in the interest of long-term comity. But I want to make sure that you're aware of the ramifications of what you've suggested for the immediate future. Note that you're implying that you'll move Nap-Ion in the spring, a move that usually presages either Nap-Tun via an Ionian Sea convoy or a straightforward naval assault on Tunis via Ion-Tun. In either case, the Italian fleet normally has a busy first year. You're suggesting that you'll potentially instead order Ion S Alb-Gre or Ion S Ser-Gre in the fall, which means you forgo your 1901 build in the interest of the longer-term strategic partnership. That's a gutsy move (and actually not bad strategy, Tunis is out of the way and hard to reach, so it's in no danger of going to anyone else), but it can be nerve-wracking for Italy to feel itself underpowered in 1902. If you're willing to do it, though, I am absolutely prepared to play that game.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    Posted By: Paul T.Posted By: Mel WhiteSome, if not all of the openings Bill mentions are here:Diplomacy Openings Library
    \nOh, dear. I entered the opening I've been thinking of, and the library returns: "This Opening Is Unnamed and No Information Exists For It!"

    Does that mean it's a terrible idea?

    There's also the Diplomacy Archives strategy articles page, which has lots of materials on opening, mid-game, end-game, and general strategy and tactics. Brian Minter mentioned it when he set up the first S-G game, as I recall.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nDecember 2010 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n Bill, I'm willing to consider that as a possibility, definitely! I will move into the Ionian in the Spring, and then we will have to talk some more: if I feel that I can afford to forgo a build (based on your opening actions, as well as those of Germany and France), it might work out that way. If not, we will have two possibilities: either we make the Trieste trade immediately (which would be a rather trusting move on your behalf, I realize!), in the Fall, or we delay the entire scheme until 1902, when my support in Greece would help you build a stronger position against Turkey or Russia, if either of them prove hostile.

    Given such a plan, what opening moves would you recommend for Italy?
    \n

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1234567\u202619\xbb

    Comments

      \n

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Willow,

      I appreciate the offer, and would be happy to consider you an ally, should you need support "from the other side" in the cases of Germany and Turkey. Likewise for Austria, if Bill turns out not to consider my friendly offer worth his time. However, due to his relationship to me as a near-mentor in my other game, I will not move against him if he does decide to side with me - I hope you will not see this as an anti-Russian sentiment.
      \nHey Paul -- Just as a point of order, this kind of meta-game consideration is actually frowned upon; every game should stand on its own, and players' decisions should not hinge upon personal considerations of friendship or enmity. Now, it is of course permissible to take into account a player's reputation as reliable or tricky or what have you, but decisions about alliance and betrayal should hinge solely upon the in-game motivation of either making it into the draw or winning outright. Eero can elaborate at greater length if necessary--it was in fact to argue this very point that we started playing this game on S-G! -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      Point well taken - and it's solid Diplomacy advice, for reasons that are, to me, obvious (my other game involves my co-workers, so it's especially important there!). Still, I know more about you and your strategic skills than many of the other players, so from that perspective it is logical for me to consider your amity in the game a valuable asset for Italy at this point. No matter: within a few turns of this game, I will know more about all the players than I currently know about you!

      Meanwhile, I've looked at the resources you've kindly pointed out to me. They say some very helpful things:\n
      Richard Sharp commented in his book that "in a high standard game I would put Italy's chances of winning at about zero, I'm afraid." Sadly, that may well be true.
      \nYikes!

      Well, I'm looking forward to it in any case; I'm here to learn much more so than to win.

      (Edited for grammar... And now I must get away from this computer - I'll be away for a while, but will be back tomorrow!)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Nothing has been decided in the west. Both England and France are open for cooperation, and Germany has said nothing, a sign of weak play (or perhaps, of being in a different time zone).
      \n
      \nAustria and Italy are contemplating an allience. Starting as the do, positioned at each other's throats, this would assit both of them in the early game. However the currently proposed division makes an already vulnerable positioning even more so. The first to stab the other would win. Italy will certainly need to avoid attacking all out, and leaving her home cities vulnerable.
      \n
      \nTurkey, though likely to loose the Balkans, has the best defensive position of any nation. It would be a long or impossible slog for Austria to take Turkey out of the game.
      \n
      \nThis means that the main thrust of the Austrian attack, after the easy gains in the Balkans, will be against Russia. This indicates that Russia and Turkey would do well not to start a war with each other. Russia will need to be acting forcefuly and finding allies.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Heh, public negotiation is freaky. I won't be doing much of that at this point simply because the more elaborate sort of things would require some surprise or uncertainty from the victims side. I'll just play one of the conventional openings and see what's what, and once somebody chooses me as their enemy I'll start looking for allies against them. Easy.

      Regarding Paul's Italian alliances, it's very well to say that you're going to ally with Daumantas because you like his hair more, but the actual proof'll be in the moves, what one's willing to do for their partner. In the case of Italy, I'd like to recommend the good ol' Greek opening, it's served me well over the years: just put your southern forces into position to claim Greece by convoy in the fall and arrange with both Austria and Turkey to have them support you into the place. It's a small price for them both when it comes to gaining an ally, and those two have much bigger geopolitical issues between themselves than they have with Italy, so they're unlikely to come to a separate agreement amongst themselves. Greece will be an excellent position for Italy for almost any future developments.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Calculus has a good point about the eastern positions, actually. I haven't been thinking about it, but the open negotiation environment should technically mean that the Power relationships shift in the places where a Power's strength or weakness depends on surprise, synergies of alliance or similar inter-Power details. This effect just might be the most dramatic with the traditional weak monarchy, Austria: Austria can actually give and take quite nicely against any single opponent, so most neighbours might be much more loathe to go at it with Austria when there's no option of hiring a secret ally in advance; whoever chooses to attack Austria will have to survive at least the first round of the struggle alone, until the other neighbours realize what's going on and participate in the traditional feeding frenzy. Well-played Austria might give a bloody nose to such attempts!

      Turkey's going to be just as ass to attack as it always is, though.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPeterBB \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ah, good! The game begins!

      @Calculus: I only get 9 hours before I'm exhibiting "weak play"?

      In actuality, I was driving back from college all day today. In the future, I'll probably be checking in almost obsessively, as I'll have nothing else to do over break.

      @Bill White: I completely agree that we need to work together. I won't be moving against you, and am very open to conversations about future cooperation. I feel like we could form a strong alliance.

      @Everyone: I'm very open to strategic advice. I'm relatively new to the game and completely new to Germany. I know that many of you have an interest in not having me die too soon, and I would appreciate any help you want to give!

      I'm also open to discussions of strategic partnerships. Germany needs allies in the early game, and is in a position to be very useful to said allies. Talk to me.

      -Peter (Germany)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Bill, I'm willing to consider that as a possibility, definitely! I will move into the Ionian in the Spring, and then we will have to talk some more: if I feel that I can afford to forgo a build (based on your opening actions, as well as those of Germany and France), it might work out that way. If not, we will have two possibilities: either we make the Trieste trade immediately (which would be a rather trusting move on your behalf, I realize!), in the Fall, or we delay the entire scheme until 1902, when my support in Greece would help you build a stronger position against Turkey or Russia, if either of them prove hostile.

      Given such a plan, what opening moves would you recommend for Italy?
      \nOkay. I'm not going to specify a move set, but trust that you will find it more enjoyable and more instructive to puzzle your way to a workable set of moves. The chapter on Italy in Sharp's book (available on the Diplomacy Archives site) is worth reading in that regard, as are the articles by Birsan, Hucknall, Swinnerton, and Swanson.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Peter: you'll probably want to start Germany with one of two alternative moves: F Kie-Den is a good move that gives you a lot of influence in the Nordic area (including the opportunity to deny Sweden to Russia), while F Kie-Hol gets your foot into the doorway in the Low Countries that are going to be something of an issue between us western Powers. Regardless of which way Kiel jumps the obvious accompaniment is Ber-Kie and Mun-Ruhr; I never recommend opening hostilities between Russia and Germany during the first year by either moving into the Pru-Sil corridor, as it overextends whichever party decides to try it.

      There is also Mun-Bur to consider; the idea with Mun-Ruh is that it gives you either a claim to Holland, or a claim to Belgium if you're already claiming Holland with the fleet in the spring. However, a Kaiser who decides not to contest Belgium (perhaps because of English alliance) might choose to play into Burgundy to give the French leadership a nasty scare. France has a depth of defense that makes an outright conquest very hazardous business, but moving Mun-Bur-Bel through the first year is a great way to force the Frenchman to consider compromises; for instance, if France can be convinced to try to bounce Spa-Mar in the fall, then the Burgundy attack has effectively denied Spain to France for the first year. Very nice, although obviously politically volatile and therefore not to everybody's liking. (The reason for why this move is not as good for claiming Belgium is that France might well play Par-Bur and bounce; of course, bouncing the French might well be better than having a "claim" on Belgium, Burgundy being the volatile position is. An arranged bounce, perhaps?)

      The Kiel fleet, on the other hand, is a very interesting issue. I would hazard to recommend Kie-Den as the better move insofar as overall stability etc. goes - so if you're uncertain and don't have a particular long-term plan, go with that. Denying Sweden to Russia is an excellent move if you find in the fall that it'll be advantageous to make the Czar cry; Russia has feet of clay, denying their northern build in 1901 has dramatic effect on Russian diplomacy later - it's not unusual to see Russia outright fail as a Power because of this little bounce and some ill luck in the eastern negotiations. (Not that this is necessarily useful for Germany; I don't recommend bouncing blindly, better to talk it over with the eastern triangle Powers and decide on the basis of relative strength: if Russia has a strong alliance and it seems that he's going to dominate the east, then you should bounce him, and if not, then it's probably better for you to give him a bone up north.)

      Note that the British crown concedes and acknowledges German claim to the Dutch Netherlands, so that's not an issue either way; as far as I'm concerned you're free to move up to Denmark with the fleet and take Holland with your armies in the fall, no contest in that as far I'm concerned. Of course you can do Kie-Hol and then follow up with Kie-Den in the fall with the army, so either way you should be looking at a solid two SCs in the first year. It's not a bad idea for Germany to accept these two and not try anything further, but you have the option: you can try claim Belgium as well for a third build.

      Germany is the only central Power on the board with a truly powerful starting position, which makes it an interesting and dynamic country to play. You have almost as much initial growth potential as France and even more mid-term opportunity, but you also have the Austrian problem of many neighbours with limited growth opportunities. Choosing solid allies and acting to mutual advantage helps rein in the flank wars that often decimate Germany: ensure that you do not overextend against one opponent without other neighbours either having committed to other wars or them being on your side to begin with.

      Regarding British relations, I'm expecting a long and fruitful relationship with our imperial cousins on the continent; the key to a successful relationship is for Germany to limit itself mostly to army builds while keeping out of the North Sea - and by association the Atlantic. There's plenty of room for German expansion on the continent, and the British navy can easily provide the necessary naval support for any combined arms operations that might come up. Assuming a German alliance, the natural English interests lie in the Nordic area - we'll see if the alliance is to be, but if it is, we might see a joint push to the east, or an effort at extinguishing the French, or both. Speculative all at this point, of course - we might consider a western triple alliance as well, that might fare well in the open diplomacy environment; I have difficulty imagining how the east could answer the triple even if they knew that it was coming

      I'm not favouring Germany in my personal diplomatic relations, incidentally - just felt like writing a short overview of the German opening opportunitites. As I said earlier, my defensible geographic position leaves me the luxury of choosing my allies, so I'll be happy to just wait and see how France and Germany open before making any decisions. For what it's worth I'm a bit more comfortable working with a Germany that opens to Denmark with the fleet just because that shows a willingness to not let Russia overrun the Nordic sphere, but an opening into the Netherlands is no immediate deal-breaker, either, especially if accompanied by a clear strategic mission proposal.

      While saying all this, I should probably make a nod at the Czarinna as well: no ill intent here, just trying to make sure that the Kaiser keeps onto the best peace pledge he has for now instead of squandering it. Russia can take Sweden insofar as I'm concerned, it's all to the good if the Swedish ore deposits are used to fuel some smiting of our historical Ottoman rivals down south. Just don't open with Mos-StP and I'll be a happy duckling.

      All of the above being said, I think that the western triple is an idea that might be considered further. Anybody up to developing the thought a bit? If we are to plot in public sight, let us at least choose the strategic model that makes counter-plots the most awkward.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero,

      It's great to read your analysis for the German power. However, something caught my eye:\n
      Posted By: Eero Tuovinenfor instance, if France can be convinced to try to bounce Spa-Mar in the fall, then the Burgundy attack has effectively denied Spain to France for the first year.
      \nAre you saying that occupying a country during the Spring, and then moving out in the Fall, doesn't allow you to control both countries? Does this mean that one unit cannot ever capture two SCs in one turn?

      This might be an important point, in terms of rules, for me to understand before we begin this! I've been assuming that if, say, France moves Marseilles - Spain - Portugal in the two moves of 1901, that counts as two SCs won... but does it mean that, in this case, only Portugal would be considered a French conquest?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yeah, good of that to come up - you only take possession of a SC during winter. This is often important for tactical reasons, and it gives rise to some fancy strategic moves as well. A classic is Key Lepanto, in which Italy moves Ven-Tri-Ser in the first year, seemingly attacking Austria but actually travelling through towards Turkey. Another one is the Turko-Russian dream position where they manage to have the Russian Black Sea fleet move through Constantinople to the Mediterranean, thus securing their mutual border nicely and providing the Turk a valuable naval ally.

      And yes, this is also important in the west. You can't, for example, move Kie-Hol-Bel in the first year and just sweep those SCs with one unit; the unit only takes possession of its last position at the end of the year. The same goes for France, who will ideally try to take control of the Iberian SCs quickly and with a minimum of unit time spent, all the time eyeing Belgium as well. In practice France will most conventionally dedicate the fleet to taking Portugal and the southern army to taking Spain, although there are variants, and of course France has the leeway for trying all sorts of other moves as well - for instance, it's viable for France to go Mar-Bur, Par-Pic to bounce a potential German assault while also taking a stab at Belgium, with a good fallback position in Mar-Spa if the first move bounces.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yes, the proof of intentions and alliances is in the dispositions of troops, not in the friendliness of the words.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPiers \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n About Italian openings:

      Although there are a lot of possible combinations, the mix of forces and terrain brings the number of conventional openings down very rapidly.

      Fleet Naples almost always moves to the Ionian: neither coast move is as good as a move to sea. Tyrrhenian sea allows access to Tunis and threatens France. Ionian is more neutral, gives leverage over Greece, and blocks the middle Med.

      Army Venice is the only unit in the game that regularly holds on it's first turn, which should give you an idea of how delicate the situation with Austria. Almost every other forward move threatens someone: Piedmont annoys but cannot really harm the French; Tyrol menaces Germany and Austria; Trieste is an out and out attack.

      Finally, Army Rome usually links up with one or both of the other forces, moving to defend Venice of it is vacated, or heading south to Apulia ready for a convoy. (Apulia allows you to defend Venice if you need to.)

      Most Italian openings are amcombination of these moves, and unless you have a very specific plan the arguments behind them generally hold water. The real question you should be asking yourself is where does supply center five come from. The worry with Italy is that you will get stuck after taking Tunis and then killed at your neighbors' leisure.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPeterBB \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@Eero: Thank you for your sage advice! I take it as a sign of good faith that much of what you said coincides with the articles I've been reading.

      @Calculus: Given that that is true, what moves would you react to strongly, either positively or negatively? I would hate to send the wrong signals due to lack of understanding.

      @Paul T. and Bill White: I realize that I have yet to comment on your nascent alliance. As my safety depends on the strength of my Austrian neighbor, I am all for it. Barring obvious aggression on your part, I will do my best to stay out of your way. I would be amenable to talks of further cooperation as well.

      @Willow: Hello! We have yet to talk. Chances are, I'll be in a position to decide whether you take Sweden or not. We should discuss how to arrange things for our mutual benefit.

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n
      \n This is a fun thread! Peter, Eero and Bill are both very helpful advisors, and intelligent enough not to feed you "misdirected" intelligence, especially in such a public way. You can trust what they write, I'm confident of that.

      In my other Diplomacy game (which is all new players, including myself), we began playing this way unintentionally: the GM was aghast to see all of us begin to negotiate openly, sitting around the table. He told us to break it up and go speak to each other in secret!

      The way things are going here, it sounds like we'll all be good friends soon, with no need for war at all. Only the design of the game is likely to keep us from such an outcome!

      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n

      \n\nDecember 2010 \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n @PeterBB - I was mostly talking to Paul T on that. But as for you and I, it's not too complicated. Just take the neutrals, but don't send a big force towards me. After the neutrals are taken, you position yourself in such a way that if your ally moves towards you, you can move to prevent an SC being taken - but you also position yourself so that you can not have two units attack an allied SC in two moves. This makes it so that both of you are safe. And just watch and make sure the other guy (me) does the same, and that when he gets new reinforcements, he doesn't move them towards you. [Eero feel free to add anything to this]
      \n
      \n@Paul T. Keep your eyes on everyone's troops though!

      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The first year is often pretty slow going due to the traditional double-length turn. Especially in a public diplomacy game we're likely to see pretty conservative moves from everybody, which means that we wouldn't really need several days for this turn.

      If anybody doesn't enter orders before the deadline, that nation's forces "NMR" - that is, do not move at all, just like would happen in a face-to-face game if you submitted an empty orders sheet. This is a sign of great weakness in the leadership of a Power, and while it's been used as a diplomatic ploy, the usual effect is extremely negative as your allies lose confidence in your ability to run your country.\n
      Posted By: WillowEero, since you're insisting that I not move to St. Pete, I have to counter with an insistence that when you take Norway, you do so with a fleet, not an army.
      \nWouldn't a fleet be a bit more aggressive towards StP than an army? It leaves North Sea open for a second fleet after all, and once that's in place there's little motivation for the first fleet to return from Norway. Not that I have any particular plans in this regard yet, so I'll be fine with doing as the empress desires.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nHah, that was interesting. Turkey made a very good call regarding Russia, which made a risky play in not bouncing in the Black Sea. The Italian and Austrian moves are also in great tension, making the east a veritable powder-keg. Austria could push east rather effectively if not for Italy, while Turkey has a definite upper hand tactically, but of course will be in trouble if Austria and Russia play together consistently (and Italy doesn't cripple Austria). There's even room for the old Tyr-Mun surprise twist supported by Burgundy, always good for a laugh - and of course hilarious to set up without private negotiations.

      Meanwhile we have a relatively calm time here in the west, as is usually the case - the Calhamer map encourages conflict in the east and creeping developments in the west. Seems like we'll have to talk about Belgium, but aside from that the situation's relatively clear-cut: France takes her usual spoils in Iberia, Germany gets Denmark (or Sweden) and Holland, we of the British Empire will traipse into either Belgium or Norway - or if the negotiations go well, even both, although I sorely doubt that this'll be feasible without the blessings of both of my western neighbours.

      I like the Italian opening with those two armies up north rather a lot; I think that an Italy with two armies up there is signaling confidence. Lots of options and probably the most influence on the overall board dynamics any single player can have, what with the potential to interfere with France, Germany, Austria and Turkey available all at once. This is the strength of Italy, the ability to balance the other Powers in a way that foils everybody. Of course the open diplomacy environment will make elaborate ploys rather challenging.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n

      \n Eero, I am glad you like the Italian opening: I chose it simply because it's listed as the most popular in the "Openings" library! It does come off as a little more aggressive than I intended, however, now that I look at it.

      Bill, I want you to know that I am prepared to honour the plan I offered you earlier. It looks like you cooperating with Russia, and thus have a possibility of taking both Greece and Rumania. I have already entered the order to support you into Greece (from Albania), should you wish to take advantage of it. The question is, are you willing to allow me into Trieste in exchange for my giving up Tunis? As I said earlier, I do not plan to keep an army there, but will retreat immediately the following Spring.

      Peter, I want you to know that I am not planning a move into Munich; you can rest easy there!

      My goal here as a beginner facing experienced players is simply to forge a solid alliance or two and survive long enough to remain a participant in the game. As far as I can see, any kind of quick expansion for Italy would be a fool's play in any case. I am looking forward to seeing how this all develops, however. Thank you all for inviting me to play!

      \n Well, this is certainly an amusing situation!

      My hat's off to the italian's gutsy move... Certainly shook things up a bit! Can't say I'm rooting for you, though. I know where you'd be going next! Still, talk to you if your gains are not as splendid as they seem to promise to be, alright?

      I myself am doing a happy little dance of having taken control of the BLA, as is quite understandable! However, I would like to make it clear that I am not at all interested in escalating hostilities with Russia - not out of the goodness of my heart, of course, but out of sheer self-preservation... No way am I going to make any gains against Russia anytime soon. No way is Russia going to make gains against me anytime soon (until the situation with Italy and Austria is resolved, one way or another, or until she decides to commit another fleet to the south), either. Willows - getting in a war now means I can't nibble bits off the Balkans and you have to trust Eero not to walk over from Norway to StP with a single army.

      Willows, tell me, how much do you want Rumania? As it is, you are not that likely to get it right now, are you? The situation is threatening to me and I will act defensive. However, I recognise Russia's claim to it, and would be willing to surrender it to you provided that you show willingness to, well, move your troops some other direction than Turkey-wards (A Ukr-Gal, for example). In the meantime, would you perhaps consider allowing a Turkish claim to Rumania? Would help me build a fleet that I could commit to Mediterranean action, which would help me hinder the italian's good fortunes which now seem to be forthcoming... Would also allow a little turkish headstart - long-term turkish-russian cooperation tends to favor Russia, as I hear, so a little nod to offset that predicament would certainly be appreciated.

      Bill... Blood's in the water, my friend! I hope you survive, but judging from an extremelly similar situation I experienced as Austria in my very first game... Well, good luck to you! I'd offer you some help in one manner or another - certainly don't want you out of the game this soon! However, at this stage, and without the possibility of making agreements in secret, I can't really do much of anything without compromising my own strategic options. Hope you manage to come out on top here!

Daumantas, I might be willing to support Bul-Rum this turn; are you interested?       \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Always some interesting choices in Fall. The common theme is the choice between protecting a home center or trying to secure one more.

      I'm interested to see where the Russo-Turkish war goes and the Austro-Italian war. Russia and Turkey would be more inclined to fight if either could gain Austria's assistance. With Austria tied up against Italy, A Turkey-Russia war becomes a long, drawn out affair. Austria can defend against Italy's attack, but gives up a chance at Greece to do so.
      If Turkey and Russia cannot reach an accord, Russia could end 1901 with no builds, depending on relations with Germany. Conversely Germany, while having plenty of expansion opportunities, must be sure of French and Italian intentions or risk the loss of Munich. Similarly, France has to decide between a gain of Portugal vs the possibility of the loss of Brest.
      Well started!
      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n It sounds like everyone is trying to scare Bill into breaking up his plans, by threatening him with imminent Italian invasion. This is understandable, but shows a great deal of mistrust in my character.

      My word is good - deception is not part of my strategy. Bill: You have my support this turn into Greece, as agreed-upon. (And also next Spring, should you like.) I will take Trieste and then immediately retreat. Good luck on the Eastern front! Your back is safe.

      Edited to add: Likewise, Germany and France, Munich is between the two of you. I'll stay out of it.

      Posted By: Eero TuovinenHah, that was interesting. Turkey made a very good call regarding Russia, which made a risky play in not bouncing in the Black Sea. The Italian and Austrian moves are also in great tension, making the east a veritable powder-keg. Austria could push east rather effectively if not for Italy, while Turkey has a definite upper hand tactically, but of course will be in trouble if Austria and Russia play together consistently (and Italy doesn't cripple Austria). There's even room for the old Tyr-Mun surprise twist supported by Burgundy, always good for a laugh - and of course hilarious to set up without private negotiations.

      Meanwhile we have a relatively calm time here in the west, as is usually the case - the Calhamer map encourages conflict in the east and creeping developments in the west. Seems like we'll have to talk about Belgium, but aside from that the situation's relatively clear-cut: France takes her usual spoils in Iberia, Germany gets Denmark (or Sweden) and Holland, we of the British Empire will traipse into either Belgium or Norway - or if the negotiations go well, even both, although I sorely doubt that this'll be feasible without the blessings of both of my western neighbours.

      I like the Italian opening with those two armies up north rather a lot; I think that an Italy with two armies up there is signaling confidence. Lots of options and probably the most influence on the overall board dynamics any single player can have, what with the potential to interfere with France, Germany, Austria and Turkey available all at once. This is the strength of Italy, the ability to balance the other Powers in a way that foils everybody. Of course the open diplomacy environment will make elaborate ploys rather challenging.
      \nLook at Eero's glibness- he's using his famed powers of suggestion here to attempt to 1) pit Italy and Austria against each other 2) encourage Italy to entangle Germany, or cause Germany to overreact, strengthening his own position, and 3) encouraging Germany to bounce me out of Sweden (seriously Eero, if I can't have it, no one will). I know what you're doing Eero!

      I'll make it clear right now, Eero: no armies in Norway. If I see an army in Norway, I'll build fleet St. Petersburg North Coast.

      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdWell, this is certainly an amusing situation!

      My hat's off to the italian's gutsy move... Certainly shook things up a bit! Can't say I'm rooting for you, though. I know where you'd be going next! Still, talk to you if your gains are not as splendid as they seem to promise to be, alright?

      I myself am doing a happy little dance of having taken control of the BLA, as is quite understandable! However, I would like to make it clear that I am not at all interested in escalating hostilities with Russia - not out of the goodness of my heart, of course, but out of sheer self-preservation... No way am I going to make any gains against Russia anytime soon. No way is Russia going to make gains against me anytime soon (until the situation with Italy and Austria is resolved, one way or another, or until she decides to commit another fleet to the south), either. Willows - getting in a war now means I can't nibble bits off the Balkans and you have to trust Eero not to walk over from Norway to StP with a single army.

      Willows, tell me, how much do you want Rumania? As it is, you are not that likely to get it right now, are you? The situation is threatening to me and I will act defensive. However, I recognise Russia's claim to it, and would be willing to surrender it to you provided that you show willingness to, well, move your troops some other direction than Turkey-wards (A Ukr-Gal, for example). In the meantime, would you perhaps consider allowing a Turkish claim to Rumania? Would help me build a fleet that I could commit to Mediterranean action, which would help me hinder the italian's good fortunes which now seem to be forthcoming... Would also allow a little turkish headstart - long-term turkish-russian cooperation tends to favor Russia, as I hear, so a little nod to offset that predicament would certainly be appreciated.

      Bill... Blood's in the water, my friend! I hope you survive, but judging from an extremelly similar situation I experienced as Austria in my very first game... Well, good luck to you! I'd offer you some help in one manner or another - certainly don't want you out of the game this soon! However, at this stage, and without the possibility of making agreements in secret, I can't really do much of anything without compromising my own strategic options. Hope you manage to come out on top here!
      \nDaumantas-

      It's just "Willow." There's only one of me.

      It would be very foolish of me to allow you a "headstart," especially after you tried to sneak into Armenia (never mind that I did the same thing, let's let bygones be bygones.) I won't be supporting any plan that gets you two builds in the south and me none. In fact, you already stand a very good chance of getting two builds by moving BLA-Bul (ec) and Bul to either Greece or Serbia.

      A Russian-Turkish alliance is still salvageable, in fact I think it may be stronger due to the positioning of Italy and Austria: if they are at war, they'll be at each other's throats, leading to a natural triple alliance with Italy. (Hi Italy!) If they aren't, we'll, they're going to be coming at you and you'll need a friend to fend them off.

      So with that in mind, I suggest at the very least you do allow me to keep Rumania, and I'm willing to accede to your judgement whether you'd rather see me take it with a fleet or an army. Meanwhile, we'll see how the Italian moves, and be able to act accordingly (whatever is warranted) in the fall.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: PeterBBNo worries Willow, you're getting Sweden as per our deal.
      \nThank you Peter, let me know if there's anything else I can do for you.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: CalculusEngland, I'll defer to your move into Belgium (Since germany needs to guard Mun). I'd appreciate your Channel fleet leaving (and not going MAO).
      \nDefinitely, that fleet's there just for positioning purposes, not to stay. It seems that the Kaiser is cool with my rolling into Belgium as well, so that seems settled until further notice. If Burgundy has nothing better to do, you could even support me for the sake of the gesture...

      I think that Russia and Turkey should technically be able to salvage a quite nice alliance out of their bounce - it was Russian aggression, but you want a hungry ally anyway, and there's no lasting harm. For example, Russia could simply move Sev-Rum with Ukr in support and end up in a completely normal Juggernaut positioning for the fall, just like the spring moves had never happened. Right now it seems that Austria is slowing down but not out (for what it's worth, I believe that Italy's not going to betray Austria - too dangerous geopolitically), which means that the Juggernaut has plenty of time to set up their play, really, but they should get to it and not let Austria and Italy work out their differences.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Apologies!

      Willow - I would actually be fine with you taking Rumania, but only if our good German friend was not allowing you into Sweden. The more units you have, the fewer of them would vacate my borders, no?

      How about I take Rumania with a fleet and you take BLA? An extra (temporary) build for me, a prime position from which to stab my guts if you so wish. Hell, having BLA means that you can retake Rumania pretty much at your leisure.


      Bill, would you mind supporting that move (F BLA-Rum, specifically)? A fleet in Rumania is mostly a good thing for you, no? Certainly less bad than some other possible outcomes.


      Everyone - Note that, while I am interested in some kind of an alliance with Russia, taking part in a 'completelly normal Juggernaut' seem's like a fool's wager in this game. First - public diplomacy here. Dogpile forthcoming, I would believe! Second - even if that works without a hitch, historically, this kind of alliance ends up with a sword hilt-deep in Turkey's armoured carapace of a back. I've learned my lesson since last I played and can do with a shared win if necessary... But I want to *share* that win, not lose horribly to a spectacular eventual coup of another.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas, after thinking about it, I am indeed willing to allow you to take Rumania, on a few conditions-

      I expect you to take it with your fleet, as you said. I will be moving such that if you try to take it with your army, you will fail.

      In '02, I expect to take the center for myself- allowing the boons of it to be a 'headstart' for you, but not a permanent gain. I also expect to destroy that fleet.

      I expect you to use the gains of your headstart so they will not threaten the Russian homeland. To that end, I'd like to see you order Smy-Ank, and build fleet Smyrna. I have no preferences to what you build in Con- either a Balkan headed army or a Mediteranean headed fleet would be fine by me.

      Hard to get ahead in Diplomacy without friends... but you have to make sure your "friends" don't have too much of an incentive to stab you.
      \n

      \n\nPeterBB \n\n\n

      Oh dear.

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Fall 1902 moves are in. Hopefully someone else will come by to post the map.

      Turkey, Austria, and England are big winners, getting up to 5 each. Germany and Russia are both at 5, but that's typically considered par for the course for either nation. France climbs only to 4, losing a home center, and Italy stays put at 3.

      Good play on the part of the Austrian, fending off Italy's attack and getting two centers. It still remains to be seen what sort of game Italy is playing.

      England is moving to antagonize both myself and France. France, we should talk. The French move to Picardy sets up France to retake Brest- whether or not that was the intent, it's hard to say.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n

      \n Austria takes steps to avoid defend itself from a possible italian attack, leaving Turkey the great gainer with three addtional SC's.

      \nRussia continues a logical move south, but it's going to be a tough slog.
      \n
      \nIn the east, England takes an early stab at France.
      \n
      \n
      \n@Germany. You get to choose now. English allies or French?
      \n
      \nIf you choose England, you'll allways have them behind you, ready to stab you as they just did me. (And they will)
      \n
      \nIf you choose France, I'll let you have the English islands when this is over, in exchange for Belgium.

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n

      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Pete, you're not in a terrible position. I think your greatest threat at the moment is Eero's England- he's effectively taken out France's ability to compete as a naval power in the north for quite some time, thus, you're going to have to build fleets or abandon the seas to Eero. I have some ideas on how I'd like to proceed with my Swedish unit- I'll share them after the Winter builds. In the mean time, if you build fleets, take hold of Belgium, and make good with France, you might find the two of you in a good position to place units on the British mainland- only with you providing the fleets and France the armies, the opposite of what usually occurs.

      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@Willow - Yes, I figured it was very likely that England would stab me this turn. I wanted to give Germany a chance to see it to believe it.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hey Willow, you should know that what you asked re: Norway was unreasonable: I need my fleets in defensive positions against threats close to home. An army in Norway is completely conventional and just as much or little a threat to Russia as anything else I might put in there. With your difficult southern position it seems to me that if anything you should be working together with me now - it's no secret that I do not, generally speaking, hit a Power when they're down, so Russia is in no way a target for me at the moment when I can use that army better as a mobile reserve, to be convoyed freely to trouble-spots along the Atlantic coasts. So chill out, build an army and take back Rumania, eh?

      I should discuss the situation with my more immediate neighbours as well: it seems likely that my visit in Brest cast a shadow on a Mediterranean strategy on the part of the French, a course of events that doesn't seem that awful to me now - Italy played a honorable game and got bitten for it, it seems, so it's fortunate that the French offensive shaping up down in Spain is likely to be cancelled now.

      Peter: If you're interested, I would be willing to work out a long-term alliance with Germany at this point, as it seems that we have mutual concerns on the board here. Specifically, I'd be happy to ensure that you gain and hold the Low Countries with your army strength in exchange for pacification of the French aggression that is likely to occur soon. We might discuss the ultimate fate of the French Republic, of course, but for now it'd be enough for me if you occupy Belgium and perhaps Burgundy; I'm all for it if you choose to put pressure on Paris as well, of course, but perhaps we should listen to what Calculus has to say as well. The important part is that your strength combined with mine would keep the current situation from getting worse, ensuring the security of both our empires quite handsomely.

      We also have joint interests up in the Nordic area, which is another reason for cooperation: if Willow feels strongly enough about me to call for allies against my entirely legitimate interests in Norway, then it might not be a bad idea to note that insofar as I'm concerned, Sweden could as well belong to Germany instead of the Czar - your fleet is in a fine position for it, so if Willow does build against us in StP, I'll be quite ready to support you into Sweden in the interests of balance in the local theater. (In no case am I interested in Sweden myself, it's clearly a matter between Russia and Germany insofar as spheres of interest and national security go; the Baltic Sea is a German sea, as we say here, just like the North Sea is a British one.)

      I know that this suggestion'll be considered pure propaganda by certain Powers, but I'll say it anyway: building two armies is probably the most dynamic choice for Germany at the moment, as it allows you to put in an effective thrust at the traditionally problematic French heartlands while also securing Munich against a trivial Italian visit and other such random eastern occurrences. Both your offensive and defensive needs require a large continental presence. I'm mostly saying this because certain Powers will have a vested interest in a large German fleet build-up that will have no other purpose aside from attacking the British Isles; a fine course of action, of course, but one that is not compatible with my cooperation and one that might in the worst case prove dangerous for your homeland security.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hey Willow, what about the, uh, "move someplace other than Turkey-wards" part of our possible agreement?

      And, as far as I know, it isn't exactly customary for Russia to demand the scuttling of a turkish fleet - rather the reverse. Hell, simple numbers - I've 4 'core' (home + Bulgaria) SCs that are accessible by sea, and you have, at most, two - Rumania and Sev. A Russian fleet, especially unoposed, is a far greater threat to Turkey than a turkish one to Russia.

      Here is a possibility, details later on: how about we scuttle your fleet instead as you take Rumania?


      Bill, congratulations! You're big and scary now!


      Paul: d'aw. Next time, put your game face on! GRR RR RR! Killer instinct!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n (Accidentally Whispered this- posting to all)

      Very true. It also isn't exactly customary for Turkey's fleet to head so far north. But let's look at these issues separately- you know that I'm going to need to take Rumania, and frankly, I don't expect you to have too many places to retreat to. Once it's destroyed, you'd be able to rebuild in Smyrna, getting your fleets closer to where they need to be. Afterwards, I'd be happy to make landfall someplace convenient to disbandment of my fleet- mutual fleet disarmament would be something very useful for both of it.

      I'm going to have to insist on a DMZ in Armenia as a term of any future cooperation- without it, any deals between us are simply a non-starter.
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I thought long and hard about the move set I submitted, but one thing was clear: I:Ven-Tyr, I:Rom-Ven was just too damn aggressive for Austria to be sanguine about Italy's benign intentions. It would have been foolish of me to have done anything other than I did. Now, I want it to be clear that in the absence of Ven-Tyr, sacrificing Trieste would have been within the realm of possibility; in fact, in my opening post, I discreetly signaled to Paul that I was willing to play the Key Lepanto, but apparently he didn't pick up on that hidden message.

      And I'm still willing to give up Trieste, but not when there's another Italian army sitting in Tyrolia like a knife in my back. You point your armies at your enemies, not your friends. What I'd like to see is Army Tyr back up to Venice or Piedmont, with Army Venice either moving to Apulia or standing fast (signaling westerly or easterly intentions on Italy's part). Alternately, Italy could just sit tight and try to take Trieste by storm, but my intention is to defend it in the spring, and Italy won't be able to take it without forgoing the Tunis build, unless I'm much mistaken.

      Peter, your mediation here would be much appreciated: don't you approve of leaving Tyrolia vacant?
      \n
