    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1234567\u202619\xbb

    Comments

      \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n That Turkish situation is really intense, my headquarters staff seems convinced that the Ottomans are striving towards a Turkish Black Sea. This is interesting, let's take a closer look at the decision matrix:

      Turkey can build two, which means that there is no problem whatsoever with putting a second fleet into the Black Sea area while simultaneously driving the conventional Mediterranean strategy. ("Two fleets" is what my chief of staff predicts as the Turkish build.) This is great news for Turkey, as Russia can't counter in Sevastopol, meaning that Turkey will have fleet supremacy in the area in the immediate future. Turkish Black Sea (TBS) follows naturally as Turkey takes control of the complete environs of the sea from a weakening Russia.

      TBS is in my own Diplomacy mid-game playbook a very central idea, practically the best alternative for the over-used Juggernaut play: Turkey does not need to ovextend itself into conquering Russia entire, as the geography of the area allows her to simply fortify Sevastopol, which is in excellent position to support Rumania even as the place acts as a natural bulwark against the Trump Russia that's left after seizing Sevastopol. A weakened Russia should be grateful for a peace arrangement with fine securities, as Turkey that conquers Sevastopol with a fleet is in no immediate position to threaten Russia further. All this means that the TBS solution allows Turkey a very low-maintenance northern border with natural defensive qualities; being in sole control of the Black Sea gives Turkey tactical "stickiness" that allows her to control a rather high number of neighboring territories with a low number of units - it is in fact impossible for external forces to dislodge the Turk from the Sev-Rum-Bul area once Turkey is in naval control, at least not without clear supremacy in numbers.

      Russia has relatively few options regarding the threat of TBS except diplomatical mitigation, as some northern pressure is evident and Willow's probably not going to believe me when I say that I'm not interested in traipsing into a defenseless StP; thus Russia does not have offensive momentum against Turkey, while the Turk can easily put a new unit or even two into the fray to ensure the destruction of the Russian fleet and the conquest of Sevastopol. In fact, Russia might even encourage an ambitious Turkish march to Moscow if she does not yield quickly and gracefully in the matter of Sevastopol. Quite a situation in that regard.

      The only question for the future of TBS is Austria, who is playing a quite strong game as well. Italy will probably want to interfere with the Austrian domain as best as she can now that cooperation proved impossible for the two, but in the main part it seems obvious that Austria will have an interest in the Rum-Bul area, seeing as how it neighbours into Austrian eminent domain and Austrian troops are already in position around there. Russia might act quickly to gain an Austrian ally, and Turkey might be convinced to leave Sevastopol in peace if the Austrian threat looms large enough. Of course this has its own problems for Austria and Russia; a war with Turkey is a no-profit war - a crusade if you will - as any gains will have to be made slowly, riskily and likely non-permanently from an opponent who has both excellent defensive geography and a depth of defense now that Turkey is in clear control of the Black Sea environs and Italy has not accomplished significant enroachment into the eastern Mediterranean areas.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenItaly played a honorable game and got bitten for it, it seems
      \nOuch. I sure did.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      My reasoning for the last set of moves was roughly as follows: agreeing to Peter's suggestion for a bounce in Munich seemed like a good way to establish a favourable relationship with Germany while also protecting both Italy and Austria from Northern attack in future turns. As you can see, the plan was not for a surprise Austrian invasion.

      Ideally, I would feel much more comfortable with that army in Piedmont.

      (Aside to Peter: if you're in agreement with Bill, I'd be a willing partner in a demilitarized Munich situation!)

      However, now that I am down a Supply Centre for being too trusting, I am not sure which way I can turn without being crushed from the East, so I worry that my only plan for survival at this point may be to hold as hard as I can against Austria's borders. Bill, are you really sure you want to make an enemy of Italy?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow and Daumantas, Bill's deception towards Italy worries me a great deal, and he may be in a position to gobble up my puny forces, if that is his future intent. If that is indeed his plan, will you consider supporting Italy by forming a coordinated front against Austria?

      If Austria's intent is a quick demolition of Italy, probably the most I can do is throw my fleet into support of your attacks on the Balkans.

      Bill, I would much prefer the original plan you had agreed to, however... I will not go into war against Austria unless you push me into it.

      Eero, I can only plead that you do what you can to keep France from taking advantage of Italy's state! At this point, a joint demolition of Italy by France and Austria only seems too likely to me... if you could maintain the pressure on that front, Italy would be much obliged in the future, should England need its support.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, you could always try for a Turkish alliance. Italy-Turkey against Austria-Russia is not an awful match-up at the moment, weak as Italy is. Ideally Turkey would help you get into Greece in the near future, for example, and your northern forces would tie down the Austrian; not enough to advance you, perhaps, but enough to prevent Austria from attacking the Turkish Black Sea properties seriously. After you got into Greece you could establish yourself on the Adrian Sea and start working yourself into Trieste, perhaps followed by a peace once you'd established yourself comfortably on the local Mediterranean coasts. Italy is a naval Power by nature, after all, and Trieste is a historical Venetian town.

      I mean to say, Austria is not your only choice of ally if Austria is not willing. Especially if France doesn't come down to Italy; as the situation stands, France would have a very sweet, soft flank to bite into if he had the resources to build a second fleet and send the two of them eastwards into the Mediterranean, but the diplomatical situation up here in the north seems to indicate that that's not going to happen. A secure western flank is a precious thing for Italy, as it makes a bit longer and slower war possible, even against Austria.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPeterBB \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@Paul: I've been assuming you were acting in good faith, and thank you for the bounce. But I'm in agreement that its time for that army to go somewhere less threatening.

      @The West: Hrm, I've really got to decide where to pitch in, haven't I? Seems to me that the england alliance is better short term, but defeating england now might be better in the long run. Arguments? Bribes?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hmm, I suppose I should argue about that, Peter. The following is 85% objective, I'll try to leave the counter-arguments to the esteemed opposition

      The thing about attacking England is that it's a slow and up-hill struggle, England being the most defensive Power in the game alongside Turkey. As I'm not exactly going to make it easy, it's pretty much a given that attacking the island is not a good idea unless you can commit a significant fleet, long-term, while there is no danger of other Powers taking advantage of the slow struggle to stab you in the back. I wouldn't claim that these conditions do not occur ever, but it's something to think about - England is by default a worse target, so you should have a good reason to go for it when you do. Besides, regarding timing, I'd say that the best time to put one over England or Turkey probably isn't right at the start of the game due to that defensive edge; you'll want to wait until everybody's clearly committed somewhere and you know that your other neighbours won't make use of your effective weakness when you attack England. End-game is of course a pretty difficult time as well, but not as difficult as right at the start; if I had to choose an abstract moment to "attack England", I'd probably plan for 1904-05 or so, when my own position had been secured enough to allow me to commit the considerable resources required.

      Meanwhile, attacking France early is a good idea in many ways, the main of which is that France is the strongest Power on the board by default, and therefore needs to be cut down early and often to prevent a simple victory by default as everybody else struggles to keep up. (France wins the most boards in Calhamer Diplomacy statistically; known fact, that.) It's a happy co-incidence that Germany is in excellent position to benefit in this sort of thing, as the continental position matches well. The Low Countries are easy to take and hold, and the same armies built to crunch France in Paris can travel quickly enough eastwards after the situation in the west calms down. Armies also make an excellent defensive unit for the western continental SC cluster ranging from Paris to Berlin, which means that building them is a superiorly flexible choice for the Kaiser, who needs to consider the dangers and opportunities of the east as well as the west, and be able to shift focus between the two quickly and flexibly.

      Long-term England has much to offer as an ally, as Germany and England have several feasible and beneficent SC splits between them: for example, we can arrange our mutual balance in the Nordic and western areas as needed, so that if one advances quickly in the other arena, the other can be helped to equal benefit in the other; I could take Sweden or you could take Sweden, for example, all according to who needs a build and who doesn't. England has a natural interest in Iberia and the Mediterranean area, while Germany has unlimited potential for growth in the east. England naturally builds mostly fleets, while Germany doesn't really need any for anything (except attacking England, of course).

      I don't particularly want to argue here that we need some permanent and in-depth alliance, although there is plenty of potential for long-term development as well. Mostly I'd like it if Germany took the opportunity here in the west for the most obvious gains available: building an army in Munich should allow the Kaiser to easily take Belgium and Burgundy, two positions that secure a western line for Germany even if there is no intent to progress any further. Such pressure doesn't cost you much, but it'll gain you a natural SC gain and a very defensible border - peace for our time with France, essentially, whether you'd choose to advance any further or not. This is very attractive for a central Power that always has to worry about flank attacks whenever anything is tried; two armies in the Bel-Bur corridor will ensure that you'll have security in the west even if you decide to march on Warsaw or down south with the rest of your forces.

      Either way, I don't particularly need promises from you at this point; it's probably more effective if Germany plays this situation with hidden cards. Just consider the facts, get that army into Munich (a no-brainer anyway, what with Italy up your nose), perhaps another into Kiel and see for yourself. I'll be happy to offer specific tactical advice, of course, if that seems interesting. And let me know if Sweden starts looking good, I'm pretty willing to trample on my Russian relations to keep the Kaiser happy.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.However, now that I am . down a Supply Centre for being too trusting, I am not sure which way I can turn without being crushed from the East, so I worry that my only plan for survival at this point may be to hold as hard as I can against Austria's borders. Bill, are you really sure you want to make an enemy of Italy?
      \nPaul, I know exactly what you're going through right now. You feel betrayed and ill-used--every hand is raised against you, nor is any man or woman your friend. I spent half a game feeling like that, as Eero and Daumantas ping-ponged me in the corner as Turkey until I wept bitter tears. "He's going to crack soon," Eero told Daumantas at one point. However, such a mind state is dangerous; it clouds your judgment and leads to self-destructive behavior. There's a book by a sociologist named Thomas Scheff called Bloody Revenge in which he argues that the origins of World War I can be traced to European decision-makers' emotional cycles of shame and rage feeding into each other and escalating so that an initially manageable crisis spun out of control--with the family connections linking the royal heads of state of the various Great Powers contributing to the emotional impact of diplomatic slights and political stratagems. The parallels to a Diplomacy game are uncanny, and it's for that reason that I believe that, fundamentally, Diplomacy is a psychological game.

      So what I'd like to do at this point is de-escalate the conflict. From my perspective, you came in charging hard with an aggressive anti-Austrian opening, and I took steps to blunt that. I was convinced that you were going to bounce me in Greece and either support yourself into Trieste or try for Vienna, too, so I maneuvered to keep you out of Greece and potentially keep my loss to a single SC so that I'd be no worse off than 3 to your 4. Of course, in that case I'd probably have been forced into a Janissary strategy, working aggressively on Turkey's behalf and begging for crumbs off the table, but at least I wouldn't have been down to 2 centers with Italians everywhere. I want you to realize that the stakes were high for me: literally existential. You saw Daumantas's message to me: "Blood is in the water, old chum. Good luck; you're going to need it."

      In your current predicament, however, the danger is not existential. Tunis isn't going anywhere; you can pick it up at leisure. The only unit within striking distance is the French fleet sunning itself along the Spanish Riviera, and you can get there before he does--and he may have pressing business elsewhere, as Eero points out. And you are going to want that fleet build, since if Eero is correct, we are about to see a Turkish naval build-up that, although initially directed at Russia, will soon be looking for trouble in the Med. The situation along the Austro-Italian border is essentially a stalemate. Given that, we should do as good Go players do, and turn our attention elsewhere. For my part, I'd like to worry about events in the East. You might think about putting a little pressure on France, especially since if Germany and England are double-teaming him, you will be the only one in a position to keep Eero out of the Med--and anyone who knows Eero knows that he views crossing the stalemate line (in this case, from MAO to Wes) as a critical threshold on the way to victory. More importantly, your fifth build could be Marseilles.

      Bottom line: We're still in the center, and the sharks are all around.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      Your description of my feelings about the game at this point is apt (even more so when I tell you about my other game, which I will be posting in the other thread tomorrow--I will *really* need your help there, although I suspect my case there might be lost altogether, Turkey done for forever).

      However, in your analysis you are omitting an important detail: I am not in an existential situation... only so long as you do not attack me. As I see it, Austria currently has the ability to utterly destory her Western ally (uh, that is, myself), and I don't see any way I could prevent it. I can only hope that the fear of a Turk/Russian advance against you might sway you from doing so at this particular moment.

      So, I'll extend my hand one more time: will you allow me into Trieste in the coming Fall? If you can forgive my unintentionally aggressive posture at the beginning of the game, I think I have a chance at surviving for long enough to at least do something in this game.

      In any case, right now we are in the build phase, in which I have no decisions to make, so I can wait for your reply until the next turn.

      Daumantas,\n
      Posted By: DWeirdPaul: d'aw. Next time, put your game face on! GRR RR RR! Killer instinct!
      \nOh, dear. As I said earlier, I'm new to this: this isn't even properly my second game of Diplomacy, as the first one just wrapped up 1905, and sees me almost completely destroyed.

      Now that the moment has passed, what would you have done in my place, or what would you wish to have seen Italy do in the last set of orders? I don't really expect to get anywhere near victory in this game (especially given that I'm playing Italy, and this miserable start), so I might as well learn something from it!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Now that the moment has passed, what would you have done in my place, or what would you wish to have seen Italy do in the last set of orders? I don't really expect to get anywhere near victory in this game (especially given that I'm playing Italy, and this miserable start), so I might as well learn something from it!
      \nGet out of the defeatist funk, for a start - most losses in Diplomacy are traced to giving up too early, when a cool head could still have prevailed. If nothing else, fighting well garners respect from the other players, and is a reward in itself afterwards.

      My own play in the fall as Italy would have been to take Tunisia and Trieste by force, no doubt about that; the tempo advantage you gain by getting your SCs quickly is too important at the beginning to waste unit moves on secondary concerns such as your purely diplomatic bounce with Germany. The choice of keeping an important home SC was too easy for Austria, especially when you remember that this whole "Italy takes Trieste as a surety of peace" thing is an exceptional diplomatical plot. (Not that exceptional can't work, but it needs to be clearly superior to the alternatives.) Besides, two SCs is already in the golden territory for Italy, who almost always has to settle for only one.

      Looking forward, though, I agree with Bill in that you're not nearly out of the game yet. Italy is by nature a defensive Power and slow to grow, so a stalled first year is not nearly fatal the way it would be for, say, Russia. Every single one of your potential foemen has other, more aggressive neighbours to worry about, so you're likely to not be even challenged through 1902; use the time to maneuver and lull your target(s), and then strike in the fall to make gains for yourself. Meanwhile be sure to use diplomatic means to ensure that everybody else continues fighting everybody else; you do not have much to offer to others in terms of military strength, so instead offer them viewpoints and ensure that no jingoist argument is left unsaid when it comes to the international conflicts that benefit your own goals. Let others fight for you and use your strength where it suffices as a tipping point, in the places where others cannot spare sufficient forces against you.

      As an illustrative example of this sort of thinking, consider France with the playful assumption that England and/or Germany are going to put the place to the torch. Which forces are in position to mobilize against the northern neighbours? Which will be around if you choose to join in the fray? Which SCs are such that you'll find them easy to hold and keep? How can you mobilize, and when will France realize your intent? When can your first strike happen? These sorts of thoughts will help you craft a plan, perhaps something in the best traditions of the Italian Cha-Cha, with seemingly anti-Austrian forces pivoting on a penny and marching into Piedmont instead.

      Consider Turkey, Austria and France all in terms of their pre-existing commitments on other fronts, and find the place where you can strike fruitfully with a limited operational force for limited gain, preferably in a place that is easy to hold and offers tactical synergies for further developments later. Consider places like Greece or Marseilles or Trieste in terms of foreign colonies you hold at your pleasure, not as integral parts of an expanding empire as the more robust Powers do; relinquish untenable positions to strike at new gains, and be completely opportunistic about it. Italy is just about the worst Power to play for any sort of paladin-like attitudes such as honor and long-term commitment to anything except your own consistently rising SC count.
      \n

      \n
      \n-
      \n
      \nIt isn't a fast thing to deal with England, but a the moment both Austria and Russia are heavily pointed Turkeyward. Both of us will need to keep engough forces on the contenant to discourage aggression from others. The continental situation is favorable.
      \n
      \nShort term, you should build fleets and take Bel in the spring. (Your short term gains are the same in either case.)

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n

      \n\nDecember 2010 \n

      \n
      \n I like the graphic aids, although I don't quite see how I'm going to take Paris I agree with Calculus about Austria and Russia, they're both unlikely to initiate a western strategy for the next 1-2 years even if Germany leaves a blatantly open window in the Mun-Ber area. Thing is, I don't quite expect the conquest of England to go over in just two years, it's a 5-year job at minimum - could be tricky.

      I'm with Calculus on the basic issue, though, which is that it's more important to consider the long-term board positioning than immediate tactical risks. If the existence of England as a Power is a guaranteed problem for Germany and it's just a matter of fighting England now or later, say, then it's probably best to attack the place right away even if it is a bit of a risk in other ways - after all, if England is a priori a problem, then nothing else you do on the board matters as much as killing England before it's too late. I haven't seen many Diplomacy strategists take this sort of a hardcore stance on any single Power, though, as most seem to think that any two Powers can cooperate long-term with proper diplomacy.

      \n "I'm with Calculus on the basic issue, though" - Lol, sounds like Mark Anthony's, "I've come to bury Caesar, not to praise him." But I'll still address the issue you raised.
      \n
      \nMy certainty that England would fight Germany does not come from a "England and Germany must fight in every game mentality". It's you and the board situation.
      \n
      \nFirst, you've injured every every single player around you - on the first year! You've taken a France home SC, denied Germany an SC they could have taken, and put an army in Norway for Russia. Anyone you border is just getting aggressively setup for the kill.
      \n
      \nSecondly, if you take France, you would be wrapping Germany from two sides. The moment Germany is busy elsewhere, goodbye.

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n There is merit to that last argument, Calculus. When I last played Germany myself (last year in a face-to-face game, I seem to remember) I had trouble with my erstwhile English ally, trouble of exactly this sort - England has this amazing defensive position that easily ends up with a one-sided threat where Germany has to invest quite a lot in defending himself from his ally, whether there be any plots afoot or not. I ended up giving him Denmark as tribute just so I wouldn't have to be constantly worrying about him taking it by force, as there was no technical reason for why he couldn't just walze in there whenever he wanted. (I'm a firm believer in alliance justified by momentary positioning, not as an abstract commitment of honor - and I'd taught the player in question to play myself, so he didn't hesitate in pressuring me to give everything I could just because he had the superior position...)

      Anyway, I think I've got some understanding of how to make the Anglo-German alliance more balanced nowadays. For one, it would be ideal for Germany to take Sweden and StP and perhaps trade something to England for Norway as well, so as to make England a strictly western and southern Power, with Germany in full control of the Nordic area. Even if not this extreme (leaves England a minority partner in terms of SCs if Germany is conquering France at the same time as well), merely agreeing to keep English fleets strictly to the west of the Danish straits (including Sweden) is an absolute necessity so as to prevent England from doing a quick mobilization in the Baltic Sea. A North Sea demilitarization is also definitely a reasonable plan when Germany moves the Denmark fleet deeper into the Baltic - Germany can get a lot out of that fleet as a convoy from Kiel to deep east, and demilitarizing the central English route to a German attack pacifies things quite a bit. Meanwhile there's no reason why England can't emphasize a southern strategy, pushing through to the Mediterranean area.

      The point is, I'm definitely aware of the hurdles England and Germany have in their relationship, and I'm interested in working them out. Of course I'm equally interested in working out my differences with France, now that we're talking, Calculus - how about we agree on English control of the Mid-Atlantic and a moratorium on French fleet builds in exchange for you getting Brest back and peace between our great Powers? Seems like a good alternative in case the Kaiser doesn't want to work with us, don't you think? I could go walze in the Baltic areas while you build up an army force and do what comes naturally to continental Powers.



      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul --

      I've already told you what I'm going to do. In the spring, I'm going to defend Trieste. I won't be free to maneuver until your build-up on my borders has re-deployed elsewhere. If I give up Trieste now, you'll be in a position to attack Vienna as well, and at that point I'm chum in the water. So I'm not going to do that. Stop fixating on Trieste. That's done.

      Look at the board and think long-term. You've got France and Russia on the defensive, England and Turkey coiling to spring, and Germany eying up his Western rivals like Eli Wallach in "The Good, The Bad, and the Ugly." You and I should be turning our attention outward, to meet their eventual assaults. Right now you're deployed to attack me, and I'm positioned to defend. Before I can stop defending, you've got to stop attacking. Right now you have the initiative. Read what Eero wrote:\n
      Eero, Pope of PainLooking forward, though, I agree with Bill in that you're not nearly out of the game yet. Italy is by nature a defensive Power and slow to grow, so a stalled first year is not nearly fatal the way it would be for, say, Russia. Every single one of your potential foemen has other, more aggressive neighbours to worry about, so you're likely to not be even challenged through 1902; use the time to maneuver and lull your target(s), and then strike in the fall to make gains for yourself. Meanwhile be sure to use diplomatic means to ensure that everybody else continues fighting everybody else; you do not have much to offer to others in terms of military strength, so instead offer them viewpoints and ensure that no jingoist argument is left unsaid when it comes to the international conflicts that benefit your own goals. Let others fight for you and use your strength where it suffices as a tipping point, in the places where others cannot spare sufficient forces against you.
      \nThat is pure gold. I've got more aggressive neighbors to worry about, so I'd like the wherewithal to worry about them. You're worried about your long-term prospects. The first rule for Italy is to stop fighting wars where the other guy knows he's coming, and sneak up from behind instead. I'd like to see you move to aggressively control the Mediterranean, to counterbalance a rising Turkey. That's the basis for our partnership. Anything else and we might as well fight it out right now.

      -- Bill

      \n Sure, Peter - I'm basically happy to relinquish Sweden to you immediately and StP and even Norway (in exchange for due considerations elsewhere) as soon as practical, considering our on-going relationship with the Russian Czar etc. The main thing on my part is that as long as you don't build more fleets I don't have any security reasons for messing about up north, so I can limit myself in that area to just supporting your working. Just let me know how you want to proceed in that theater, and I'm your man.

      The tactical reality of an attack on England at the moment is really grim due to how France is all but incapable of putting out a significant fleet in the near future, while any German fleet will have to fight its way out of the Baltic region against an England that doesn't really have anything else to do aside from making it difficult. You could do it, I hazard, but it'd take years, and experience dictates that things tend to change in those timeframes: allies decide to find quicker routes to power, other wars elsewhere end and Powers start seeking new targets, that sort of thing.

      \n If I were to build one army and one fleet, with the fleet for the purposes of greater maneuverability in the Baltic area, and possible defense against an English stab, while the army shores up my ground defenses, would that be:

      a) a relationship-ending betrayal
      b) uncomfortable but workable
      or
      c) just peachy?

      EDIT: This goes for both of you.






      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I realized just now that the above might seem like I'm making too easy promises, ones that I don't intend to keep. Thus, to clarify: my offering to withdraw my claims in the Nordic area is a seriously considered proposition, and a weighty, game-changing move if we manage to work together thanks to that. I'm specifically not promising unrealistic moves like relinquishing Norway without making a gain in another place in the same year or other sacrificial moves like that - it's just a long-term agreement on a direction, not a fantasy spiel that I'm offering. Thinking on it realistically, if Germany puts 1-2 armies and that fleet to work in the Nordic area, we might achieve total separation of interests in 2-3 years; not instant, but then real tactics rarely are. The basic idea is solid, however: I won't initiate new projects in the Nordic theater myself, and will support German interests in the area, and will trade in Norway at an opportune moment for something else down south. Tactical details will have to wait contingent on the builds, especially considering the open diplomacy environment.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n One army and one fleet is border-line for England, but we can live with it, especially if we agree that neither fleet leaves comes west of Den-Swe. So that'd be option b) for us. The biggest issue is that while the second fleet will be useful against Russia for a limited time, and it'll increase German security against England somewhat (mostly as something to scare England with; armies defend as well), in the mid-term and long-term the second fleet will be somewhat under-used. Of course there are ways to get rid of units later, but they're awkward.

      But yeah, I won't consider it an end of negotiations if you build one of both. Probably not a bad choice tactically, as it retains some flexibility, although I'd be worried about your ability to wage a massive land-war; continental warcraft tends to rely on massive army lines, it's always nice to have one more army in those. And of course that fleet's going to be worth its weight in gold if you end up in war against England.

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n

      \n\nDecember 2010 \n

      \n
      \n Builds are up. Germany built armies (aimed west), England fleets (aimed east), Turkey fleets (aimed north), France writes off Brest, building in Marseilles, Austria sets up to be a naval power, and I build in St. Petersburg as promised.

      Let no one say I do not uphold my promises, or my threats.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'll be out for most of this coming turn, so I'll put in my moves now - no big deal, I know what I'm doing, and I'll have an opportunity to revise before the deadline. Just so you know that I'm still in the game even if I'm not spreading out my thoughts all over the place here.

      In the interests of tactical security I'll communicate just the spare essentials in the following - everybody can assume that I'll be inputting moves to accord with my suggestions. No need for anybody to confirm or deny this stuff, it's all just extra information for the enemy. Simply do it if it seems like a reasonable idea. And don't worry if I'm telling somebody else stuff that contradicts something I told you, it's all just lies to lull our mutual enemies into a daze; I wouldn't like to you, would I?

      Peter - by all means attack Sweden if you would; that's a good chance of a build for you, and it'll help us rein in Willow, who seems to have decided to make a fight of it in the Nordic area. You'll note that she can't both retain Sweden and take Norway with the same moves. I also recommend moving to Belgium and supporting yourself into Burgundy, or perhaps vice versa - no big deal if there are bounces, as you'll have another chance to occupy Belgium in the fall. You have enough forces to keep Munich covered all the while as well, so it's all looking good for you.

      Calculus - how about if I keep Brest, then, as a surety, but desist from advancing to MAO? We could demilitarize MAO quite easily, and that's a reasonable secure border for the both of us, especially if you desist from building fleets down south.

      Willow - that northern fleet is a problem, no two ways about it. As it happens I sold Norway (and St. Petersburg, begging your pardon) to the Kaiser just now, so in principle it's his problem, but I'd rather not get haunted out of Norway with my tail between my legs. You're a cunning operator and aggressive - reminds me of myself - but perhaps you'd like to negotiate for peace? I'm still not eager to fight Russia, as you have your hands full with the southern situation already; you should be a major player in the eastern triangle, but as things stand you're very fortunate if the strong Austrian and Turkish empires decide to fight each other instead of attacking you. I'd rather see more balance down south, and Russia getting stripped of its northern depth doesn't feel right just yet. I'm open to ideas, although that fleet is ass, much worse than an army would have been. Sort of forces me to bring another unit to the environs just to defend my legitimate interests.

      Everybody else - fight that good fight! I'll be back tomorrow to see what's what, and I expect to see blood and betrayals and spite. Italy should probably forget about any French dreams, and that new Austrian fleet is a curve-ball for the eastern Mediterranean naval balance, no two ways about it. The two Turkish fleets, those speak to me of aggressive Black Sea operations; no need for that Constantinople fleet to go south right away when it can first throw in a support and block the retreat route of F Bla. But afterwards that fleet is coming down to the Aegean Sea, and just in time, too, considering the obvious Austrian move. Exciting times!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill-

      With friends like ours, who needs enemies, am I right?

      I think you and I ought to pursue a Turkish containment strategy. It should be easy enough to take his Balkan possessions- I attack Ukr-Rum, (hopefully with support from Budapest), while you attack Serbia. The attack on Bulgaria this fall is less certain- it depends on Turkey's moves and if we outguess him, so there's no point in publicly discussing strategy- I don't see a perfect attack unless Italy chooses to help with his fleet (a move to the Aegean would give the Turk something to think about!), perhaps to prove his goodwill, but realistically I expect him to move to secure Tunis.

      Willow - that northern fleet is a problem, no two ways about it. As it happens I sold Norway (and St. Petersburg, begging your pardon) to the Kaiser just now, so in principle it's his problem, but I'd rather not get haunted out of Norway with my tail between my legs. You're a cunning operator and aggressive - reminds me of myself - but perhaps you'd like to negotiate for peace? I'm still not eager to fight Russia, as you have your hands full with the southern situation already; you should be a major player in the eastern triangle, but as things stand you're very fortunate if the strong Austrian and Turkish empires decide to fight each other instead of attacking you. I'd rather see more balance down south, and Russia getting stripped of its northern depth doesn't feel right just yet. I'm open to ideas, although that fleet is ass, much worse than an army would have been. Sort of forces me to bring another unit to the environs just to defend my legitimate interests.
      \nPeace would be dandy. Convoy that army out of Norway and cede it to me and I have no problem. I am at a strategic disadvantage- my opening gambit failed to pay off- the only option I have is to fight tooth and nail wherever I can. I'm going to need that build to reinforce my southern front.

      Russia is happy to be the junior partner in alliance- especially if I get to be the junior partner in two alliances, one in the north, one in the south.

      If it comes down to it, I'd rather see the German in Sweden than the English in Norway- one of those borders on my homeland, the other doesn't.

      \n Willow --

      Even if Bud S Ukr-Rum, I would still have to order Ser-Bul to make sure the attack succeeded, and I'd rather not trade a fleet in Rum for an army there that can reach out and touch Budapest. The attack that actually makes sense is Bud-Rum supported by Ukr and Ser; that's a winner, regardless of what Daumantas does. Conversely, your fleet in the Black Sea is doomed no matter what you do, which means that you're looking at an attack from Bla and Arm on Sev next turn; if I was in Rumania, I'd have an interest in blunting the Turkish attack.

      -- Bill

      \n Hey Daumantas --

      You've judged the situation exactly right. While you and Russia are duking it out, I have to worry about whether Italy will press his attack; he seems unhealthily fixated on Trieste. Eventually you and he are going to come to blows in the Med, and when that happens, I want to be in a position to make sure that your progress is slow at best. In the meantime, it is not unreasonable for you and I to reach some sort of understanding where we neutralize Russia as a threat and then each try to convince Italy to partner up against the other. I think I'll have the advantage there, but the tactical realities of the board may be such that he'll see things your way when the time comes. That would essentially recapitulate your fate in our last game together, if I recall correctly.

      -- Bill

      God knows how anyone could win as Turkey with her pace...

      \n Bill,

      I'm willing to retreat from your borders in exchange for peace--you do have lots of worries of your own in the East, so that would seem to make a lot of sense for both of us. (Incidentally, I did entirely miss the cryptic suggestion you claim to have made earlier. Was it the mention of Leonidas? I wondered about that, but didn't have time to look into it in depth.)

      Daumantas,

      We'll see how Bill responds to my suggestion above, but lately his language towards me has been very aggressive. I kept to my stated intentions, but Austria accepted my support without making any kind of concession in return.

      If he follows through in that vein, then you and I will be thrown into the pot as natural allies. Being a Turkey that's completely caged in by Austrian and Russian forces in my other game, I'm very sympathetic to your situation. What kind of moves would you like to see on Italy's behalf if Bill does not show himself to be willing to deal with Italy in a friendly manner?

      Willow, I'd like to hear your suggestions in this matter as well, should you have any advice to throw my way across Austria's shoulders!

      (Note: I will be silent for a while because I will be away from the internet. Will check back in later this evening or tomorrow morning! Cheers, everybody.)

      \n
      Posted By: Bill_White"Kadmos enjoins your largest efforts, pressed as never told of!"
      \nSometimes I am too clever by half; clearly I outsmarted myself here. I suppose it was too much to expect that anyone, particularly an earnest novice, would wonder about the awkwardly pretentious insertion of an invented quotation into an initial message and read it closely enough to notice the acrostic hidden there. When you started asking about openings, Paul, I wondered if you had twigged to it, but your opening moves showed me that you hadn't, because if you had you'd have known that Trieste was going to be open. I even sent you to Sharp's book, where he talks about the Key Lepanto in shuddering tones, so in a way I'm glad I didn't have to live through the careful shepherding of A Ven-Tri-Ser that it requires. But the last time I played Austria, I lost my nerve after agreeing to it and so I wanted to try again.

      \n Bill, it was a worthy attempt! I saw the various hints and wondered if that was what they were. I probably even took a minute to google some basic info on Leonidas.       Had this caught me at a freer time, I might have figured it out eventually. As it was, I was busily preparing for the other Diplomacy game (which took place Tuesday night).

      \n Bill-

      After thinking about it, I think our best set of moves is:

      BLA-Rum
      Ukr, Sev, & Bud S BLA-Rum
      Ser-Bul
      Gre-Bul (sc)

      Turkey can stop one attack or the other, but not both.

      As I said upthread regarding Scandinavia, I'm willing to serve as junior partner in a southern alliance- with Turkey that train has left the station, but you show savvy and judgement- an assault on Turkey is hard going, but I'm willing to give you the favorable end of the bargain, since you've got the better bargaining position.

      Pete-

      You'll not want to attack Trieste, that's for sure. Bill's certain to support it. A better move might be to take a hard look at that Piedmont-Tyrolia corridor, and think about which side you want to meddle with in the France-Germany conflict, and act appropriately.

      I'd certainly appreciate assistance against Turkey, but you need builds right now. Make taking Tunis a priority.

      -Willow

      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul.

      The below is said with an aim to make you angry and frustrated. I could've said it in a way that doesn't do this, but, well, you're enough like a butterfly as is, no?

      If you agree to Bill's current demands, you're basically meat. A meal for him.

      Now that he has enough troops to defend against Italy and launch an offensive against me simultaneously... You are not getting Trieste. Period. Now, if you aren't getting Trieste, why would Bill ask you to remove the troops that are threatening him? Well, obviously, to remove that threat. And what is he going to do when you are no longer a threat?

      Let me tell you.

      Trieste to Adriatic.
      Vienna to Trieste.

      Then, either a convoy to Apulia, or taking control of the Ionian by either of his current fleets... The situation will change from one where your troops border three of his SCs to one where his troops border two of yours. And, given Bill's advantage in numbers...

      Let no one lie to you - as it is, you're going to need luck and/or skill just to survive the coming years. But, when people say that your situation isn't as poor as it seems to be (neglecting to mention exactly how and why it is poor!), they aren't lying.

      The deployment of your forces is great for grabbing Austria by the balls, and that's what you should do. There is only [i]real[/i] thing that's stopping you from it, aside from this now substance-less (how are you going to get your SCs, hmm?) idea of Austria-as-ally, namely, possible French aggression. And that one's a non-issue, or at least a easily diplomatically managable issue, especially given France's own current problems. Change that deployment, and your forces are suddenly good for nothing, surrounded on all sides by those of the ally you went to such lengths to keep.

      So, this is what you do: Demand immediate concessions, then attack him anyway.

      You need an SC and you also need to keep the Ionian - demand Greece. Bill's got enough SCs and avenues for growth as it is, so if he denies you Greece, which is as much an italian SC as it as an austrian one...

      Attack Trieste with support from Tyrolia. One of two things will happen - Bill will defend, and will keep out of the Adriatic for now; OR Bill will take the Adriatic, which is bad, but you'll take Trieste, and either keep it or have him commit to retaking it.

      This turn, forget Tunisia. Go there now, and you have to sit there for the next turn to keep it, and you'll quite likely lose the Ionian (the gateway to everything Italian!) as soon as you vacate it. Power abhors a vaccuum. Either go somewhere useful, or go somewhere not-so-useful where you can expect a bounce back to the Ionian.

      You're small enough now that any sort of petty aggression that you perform isn't aggression at all - it's simply you defending yourself vigorously.


      As for my own requests... Given Austria's and Russia's current plans toward me, I'd like you to order F Ionian Sea - Greece regardless of what Bill's answer to your demand would be. That would stop their attack on one of my core SCs, and would leave my army in position to support you into Greece next year, as well against Serbia, which can be usefil in Trieste-related endevours. It's a zero risk move for you - you either keep the Ionian this turn or get Greece. If you keep the Ionian this turn, you can either take Tunisia the next, or commit it to some other maneuver.

      Don't *be* the thin veneer of politeness everyone is exhibiting here. Be the raging aggression hidden under it!

      Where are my SCs going to come from this year?
      How am I going to show him that he ought to keep his promises next time?
      I wonder if anyone will expect it if I do THIS?

      These are the questions you need to ask yourself before you even begin negotiations with anyone.
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nSo, new moves. Seems generally solid in the west, although I'll be in trouble with the Frenchman if there's no more forthcoming pressure from Germany. Meanwhile Austria assaults Italy in a savage manner; Venice is lost, so Italy'll have to regroup fast, especially as the fleet's stuck in Tunis for the fall. Turkey is sweeping the Black Sea - the east will be a clash between Austria and Turkey after the giants finish with their lesser neighbours, it seems.

      Quick notes for the situation:
      • Italy should at least consider a relaxed stab at Marseilles; it'll be difficult for France to commit a defense right now, as the troops are needed elsewhere, and it's not immediately obvious that the army can actually help out against the Austrian this year. The passive position and defects in the naval defense will come to cost Italy dearly.
      • Germany will have a very strong year, two builds seems like a given. Meanwhile the other western Powers sit on their hands.
      • Turkey can do whatever the Sultan wants this fall, as Austria has other things on her mind. Destruction of the Russian fleet is probably a consideration.
      • Germany is probably going strongest on the board at the moment, with an immense offensive momentum - the French line is completely open, there are already builds in the pipeline and Warsaw is also an easy nut to crack. Nothing can be denied to the Kaiser right now, and he probably should strike when the iron is hot and the opposition scattered.
      • Russia is in trouble: England and Germany are harassing her in the Nordic area, with little diplomatic respite in evidence after the Czarinna chose to send the fleets to the Atlantic coasts. Meanwhile Turkey is pressuring her hard down south; a Russia haunted on both fronts will usually crumble quickly and thoroughly.
      • It'll be interesting to see how Austria plays that Italian war: if there's will to compromise against the Turk there, a move such as Gre-Ion could finish Italy practically immediately. Definitely a knife, meet throat -type situation there.


      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hey, Peter: good moves, but I'm concerned with your lack of aggressive positioning regarding France. As you can see on the map, Calculus decided to fight me for Brest, which means that I'm basically unable to advance against him even as I need to keep the naval front against the Russian northern fleet. Your aid against the Frenchman is dearly needed; what say you, do you intend to move forward on that front to relieve me? The situation is dangerous, as your lack of aggression already forces me to choose between defending Brest and keeping the French fleet bottled in the Mediterranean. Failure in either part will soon close the window you have on the soft continental flank in Burgundy, as France either builds a new army or gets an opportunity to bring army Portugal back home; next year France will be a considerably more difficult a target.

      Good moves otherwise, you're looking out for number one well enough. I'll get back into Norway in the fall and you'll go into Sweden, after which the rest of the Nordic theater is basically child's play; I'll be in haste to turn at least one fleet down south next year, and I might have to ask you to loan StP to me for the year to compensate for my poor fortunes in the French war, but basically there's nothing truly difficult going on in that front.

      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, that was a bit of a Cassandra moment for me... Sorry you weren't around, Paul - or for not having said something earlier. Try talking to the German - ally or no ally, he might not like seeing Austria grow that fast.

      Willows, as I said more than once, I am not interested in extended hostilities with you. The situation is currently in my favour, obviously, and I am expecting to own both Rum and Sev eventually. But I am uninterested in having more than that. Furthermore, I don't see a need to have you surrender them both to me this turn - with my fleet-heavy force, I am unlikely to benefit from your early destruction beyond those two SCs, anyway.

      How about I take Rum with my current Sev Fleet? The only unit you then lose is the fleet that makes me keep such a force against your borders in the first place. That would free up either one or both of your armies for defense against the western incursion.

      You have an alternative of trying to keep both Rum and Sev somehow, but, really, that's only a stopgap solution, and it'd only tie up both of our forces while our common neighbours grow.

      I am worried about Austria, obviously. You probably aren't, yet, as you need to deal with the German and the English before Austria's current growth becomes a problem. Mind though - if you're planning on gaining any new SCs now that the way to Turkey is mostly blocked, you probably won't find SCs more accessible than Vienna or Budapest while the Austrian is dealing with the italian. I myself would be quite content jostling in the Mediterranean, with the help of the italian fleet, if Paul's willing.

      So, basically, I exercise restraint right now, and you either defend, or commit a token force to, say, Galicia.


      Bill, you brilliant bastard! I'm stuck here watching all your carnage and growth and I can't do a thing about it! I am shaking my fist at you vigorously!


      Oh, and a random thought: somebody in the West should think about building some fleets soon, or at least support the Russian's. Eero is very much unopposed in naval power now, which means he can do a pretty convoy dance with the armies he will build later.
      \n

      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm going to do something very un-strategic now, because I want Paul to understand the calculations I made in moving how I did, because I think it will help him as he learns the game. I don't claim to be all that great a player--I've never won a solo victory, for example--but I have some experience and I pay attention whenever Eero talks.

      So my problem at the end of 1901 is that I see Italian troops lined up on my borders, and I don't want them there. As I'm thinking about what to build, it occurs to me that an aggressive Italian player could conceivably mount a credible attack on Trieste in Fall 1902 by ordering Ion-Adr in the spring, standing fast in Tyrolia and Venice, and then using those three units to pound on my city. It would be a gamble for Italy, sure, but if Italy doubled down on Trieste while I marched off to the east, I'd be sunk. I didn't think that was very likely, to be sure, but it was a possibility, and building a fleet was the only way to have the resources to prevent it. By the same token, it occurred to me that if I wanted to have a shot at Venice in 1902, I needed a fleet in the Adriatic, plus armies in Tyrolia and Trieste--because I knew I'd be facing two defending armies. So as long as I built a fleet, I'd have the option of Tri-Adr, either as a defensive or an offensive move.

      But the attack on Venice couldn't happen if Tyrolia was still occupied by the Italians. I couldn't force him out (not if I wanted a fleet, which I did), but I knew Paul already felt like Ven-Tyr in Spring 01 was a little over-aggressive, and so might re-deploy west or south if it felt to him like that was a safe move. So I posted a message that (a) emphasized the belligerence of the Italian posture, (b) appealed to Germany for support for evacuating Tyrolia, and (c) mentioned the Key Lepanto acrostic directed at Paul in my first message, which I thought would be a little disarming. And if I decided not to maneuver against Venice, all of those things would go some distance toward de-escalating the conflict with Italy, which was also a strategic possibility. I sent messages emphasizing the necessity of Italy backing off for any cooperation to take place, and stating definitively that I would defend Trieste, suggesting a static kind of holding the line rather than an aggressive counter-attack.

      However, Paul's reply to me suggested that he was still interested in Trieste, which didn't make me happy, since I thought we'd settled that. And he started talking to Turkey and Russia about combining with them against me, so he might get an appealing offer of one kind or another. Luckily, the Russo-Turkish conflict meant that they really only had eyes on each other. Daumantas' late message to Paul was correct in spirit, although he didn't scope out the actual plan. If he'd insisted that Italy absolutely 100% needed to hold on to Tyrolia, I might have gone back to Plan B, which was Vie S Bud-Tri.

      Once the fleet was built, there were still problems, though. If I decided to push for Tyrolia from Vienna, how would I keep Trieste safe? Conceivably, Ven-Tyr cuts Tyr S Ven-Tri, the most likely Italian attack in the spring (since it sets up Tyr-Ven, Tri S Tyr-Ven in the fall), but it would be embarrassing to charge into Tyr only to have the Italian army counter-march into Trieste. Another defense is Ser S Tri or Bud S Tri, but that means that my fleet doesn't contest the Adriatic if Italy goes that route, so now I need two armies: one to move in, and the other to support the move. All of a sudden this was turning into a big production, and didn't I need forces in the east? Hadn't I committed in a big way to helping Russia?

      As it turns out, not so much. All I needed was one unit to cut Bul S Rum if it were ordered (and as it turned out, it wasn't--Daumantas, knowing where the hammer would fall--the perils of open communication--cleverly abandoned Rum to take Sev). That meant I could use everything else to push easterly, and see where it got me.

      Wargaming the potential outcomes, the most favorable was what happened: I get Tyr and Adr, and am positioned for a 3-to-2 attack on Venice in the fall. A more aggressive Italian might have played Tyr-Tri, Ven S Tyr-Tri without Ion-Adr (either because Ion-Gre or because of anxiety over Tunis), in which case Tri is empty in the fall but still pretty safe. I would have forgotten about attacking Venice and concentrated on stabilizing the line in Trieste, possibly heading to Ion in the fall (expecting Ion-Tun at that point). Adding Ion-Adr to the mix keeps my fleet in port but the Adriatic remains clear, and Trieste is still safe. I'd try again for the Adr in the fall, since at that point Ion-Tun would be a necessity. So the safest course of action, given the enemy disposition I was looking at, was to press hard against Italy's forces with an eye toward setting up an attack on Venice but mainly in the interest of protecting Trieste.

      So that's what happened from my perspective. I don't like revealing so much of my planning process, since obviously it provides insights into my psychology of play, but I think it's important for Paul to see how the situation on the board and the psychology of the players combine in a player's head to shape decision-making. It's not personal; it's just Diplomacy. The moment Army Venice moved to Tyrolia, Paul and I were tangled in a ludic psychodrama in which the moves took place on both boards: the game-board and the message board. Even now, other players' supposedly "neutral commentary" is entirely strategic, intended to highlight the elements of the situation that favor their interests rather than to truly explain what happened. And even this message has a strategic purpose, as much as I might try to disavow it--I want Paul to be open to the possibility that our war is now over, and that going forward on the basis of the reality on the ground might permit us to work together to further mutual strategic interests. That is what I mean when I call Diplomacy an instructive perversion.

      More replies soon!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1234567\u202619\xbb

      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Oh man.

      Bill, I just realized... We're in a battle for Paul's head. I want him to feel cornered, betrayed, aggressive, so he'd take it out on you in any way possible. You, well, you're not so much trying to instill particular emotions as you're attempting a 'cooling' process of sorts, directing him to second order (in relation to the current game) things as general lessons about the game.

      This is quite possibly the coolest thing ever.

      Though, of course, we don't have to depend on psychological means alone while trying to accomplish psychological ends. Take the pure strategy level, for instance.


      Bill, tell us one good reason why you would have to stop your troops where they are and advance no further into Paul's territory.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      If you're serious about setting me up to slow down England in the north, you're going to have to not profit me in the south- I'm very likely to lose ground in the north. If you let me keep Rumania at least for the turn, I can try to scramble some sort of defense up north. If you go one further and vacate Sevastopol (Arm-Ank, Sev-Arm?), it would be amazingly helpful, but it's not really a level of generosity I expect.

      Peter-

      So, what's it going to be? If you go for Sweden, England keeps Norway. Norway falls anyway, but if you leave Sweden alone, I at least have somewhere worthwhile to retreat.

      Fortunately for you, England won't be getting any builds this turn (unless he stabs you for Belgium or Holland). You've got what it takes to outgrow England, and secure a loyal ally in the north, who cannot effectively stab you the way England can.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, does it really matter which I leave at your disposal, Sev or Rum? If I vacate Sev this turn, it remains under your control, right?

      And, honestly, I'd *really* like for that fleet of yours to go. You can't use it for anything but making trouble for me, so insistence on keeping it makes me a bit suspicious. Not too much, though. I doubt anyone really likes the prospect of having a unit scuttled, no matter what the unit may be.

      Limited internet access on parts of Saturday and Sunday.

      If anyone has a plot that hinges on my not being able to make a proper case against it, this is your time for glory!

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdOh man.

      Bill, I just realized... We're in a battle for [i]Paul's head.[/i] I want him to feel cornered, betrayed, aggressive, so he'd take it out on you in any way possible. You, well, you're not so much trying to instill particular emotions as you're attempting a 'cooling' process of sorts, directing him to second order (in relation to the current game) things as general lessons about the game.

      This is quite possibly the coolest thing ever.
      \nThat is a great insight. This is why I love playing with you, Daumantas. By the way, let me just say I loved this:\n
      Posted by DaumantasDon't *be* the thin veneer of politeness everyone is exhibiting here. Be the raging aggression hidden under it!
      \nNow that's a philosophy of play! Back to business:\n
      Though, of course, we don't have to depend on psychological means alone while trying to accomplish psychological ends. Take the pure strategy level, for instance.

      Bill, tell us one good reason why you would have to stop your troops where they are and advance no further into Paul's territory.
      \nAh, now we come to it! But there's a couple of good reasons:

      (1) A potential Turkish push into the Mediterranean. Don't deny it, D. You know you want to. You know you need to. Your navy-heavy force structure makes that the obvious next step for you. Even if you and I try to work something out, the logic of the game and your own aggressiveness means that we'll clash on that issue; to even bring you to the negotiating table means that the reality on the ground has to be such that you can't just take what you want. Notice that in the case of a successful Turkish breakout, the Italian peninsula is right in your path, and so Paul has an interest (even if he doesn't recognize it yet) in keeping you contained.

      More importantly:

      (2) Italy's own armies, and the geography of the Italian peninsula. You make it sound like I just march down the peninsula and grab the peninsular cities with a mere wave of my hand: "Onward, soldiers, onward!" But Rome and Naples are mutually defensible, if Paul can get troops there. It would take a huge commitment of time and force to root out a determined defender--time that I am unlikely to be given.

      Taken together, the two create a compelling case for me to try to make common cause with Paul rather than pursuing his forces to their ultimate destruction. Note that right now what I expect Paul to do is to defend his cities as best he can. Ideally, he'd withdraw south to defend Rome and Naples; something like Ven-Apu, Pie-Tus might allow Tus-Rom, Apu S Tus-Rom in the spring.

      Now, I'm not saying I won't push the attack--just that Paul's moves on both boards still matter.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Very interesting, folks.

      It seems I was away from the boards at the wrong time.

      I would love to hear the other players' thoughts on my situation, as well, and possible move-sets. All in the spirit of education, of course, but make a strong argument for why Italy should do something that's ultimately in your favour, and I may be quite likely to do as you say.

      Peter, we started this game off on a friendly foot, and your position is quite secure. A powerful Austria on your borders is not particularly good for you. Would you consider getting involved on my side--say, to push Austria out of Tyrolia (not a bad thing for him, if he's really as friendly and as concerned about his Eastern war as he claims, but helpful for my defense)? Any suggestions are welcome! But I think it would be more in your favour to have two reasonably balanced powers on your Southern borders than one aggressive giant, so I'd love to hear your thoughts on this topic. An Austrian army in Tyrolia threatens (or at least limits) you almost as much as it does me.

      Bill, thank you for that thoughtful post. It'll be worth a few read-throughs for me! Your various appeals worked quite well on me, I can readily admit, so that's something.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul's position is not hopeless.
      \n
      \nBut first.
      \n
      \nPeter's strategy of allowing his neighbors to continue fighting each other, keeps his neigbors busy enough that they can't attack him, weaker individually, and both needing him - all while allowing himself steady growth. It's is working great.
      \n
      \nIf Peter were to attack Tyrolia, breaking that support, Italy could hold Vience with support from Piedm, and would not be knocked out of the game. Austria and Italy would be locked a long term combat (with Italy picking up an SC, and fleet at the end of the turn.) This would give Peter several years of neighbors fighting each other to both his South and his East, allowing him time to pick up a few more SC's from a dieing Russia. All without still having to commit himself to a major war.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I liked those Austrian moves a lot, that was the sort of play you need in those difficult eastern positions. Specifically, leaving the north-eastern borders unmanned is a solid choice when Russia has plenty of enemies elsewhere and Rumania is being manned by fleets; Budapest fares quite well without a home guard, and the forces can therefore be put to use elsewhere. Building a fleet is also a very promising idea for Austria, who traditionally has a weak naval capacity.

      Trying to get Germany to interfere in Italy's favour is a good idea - it's true that Germany has an interest in reining Austria in long-term, as the two Powers are natural contestants for continental supremacy from the late middle-game onwards. On the other hand, attacking Austria is a very large undertaking for Germany, in many ways much larger than attacking any of his other neighbours due to the geography involved and the lengths he has to go to to score a profit out of the war. Germany has a surplus force next year, so it could happen, and it'd go a long way towards relieving Italy; definitely the right tack for Paul to pursue.

      It's true that Turkey has a naval emphasis to his force make-up, and therefore he has a natural inclination for making peace with Austria and attacking west through the Mediterranean once he's settled the current brouhaha with Russia. This is simply because the fleets would otherwise be left underused, while he doesn't really have enough armies to wage a serious continental war. Austria, on the other hand, may quite reasonably wage war over the Black Sea environs with mere armies, and one potential target for the Turkish fleets is Greece, so it's not exactly a certainty that Turkey would turn on Italy over the next few years. Basically Austria would have to relinquish claims to the Black Sea territories and Greece - then those two would have a very natural set-up for a long-term alliance.

      I've been analyzing the French position, and my current thinking is that France probably can't afford to cover Marseilles on the fall move. It's a bit of a psych game, as covering the place is profitable for France only if there's nigh-certain knowledge that Italy's going to attack there. Italy, meanwhile, has only long-term concerns for the Piedmont army down south; it's a defensible choice to retreat and use the army in the hypothetical defensive land-war against Austria, but it's also a very lucrative option to attack Marseilles and hope for a gain that'd offset losing Venice. It's almost a pure prisoner's dilemma, as the tactical catastrophe for France would be considerable if he misguesses either way. Exactly the sort of situation where you need to make the choice based on the long-term tactical synergy of the resulting position, or perhaps a random roll to ensure that the opposition can't outcalculate you.





      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n

      \n The beauty of A MUN-TYR is that it does NOT require to start Germany in a long term fight with Austria. Austria certainly would want not open a third front.
      \n
      \n-
      \n
      \nEuro says that Marseilles would compensate Italy for loosing Venice - But, I'm not sure I understand how? An army in Marseilles is lost to the cause of defending Italy. It can't support any other Italian SC's, and moving it there would also hand over Rome to Austria.

He actually can't maneuver his units into both home centers this fall, his best bet in that regard is to let A Venice disband when its dislodged and build in Naples.

      \n

      • \n
