    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1\u20263456789\u202619\xbb

    Comments

      \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n That was just adorable all around. Except you, Daniel. Oh, well, I suppose I can get out of MAO after all if it's so important to you. I'll just spend the Christmas-time in projecting anger mixed with desperation and building fleets presumably against you, if you don't mind. (Just be ready to play along later, if you know what I mean.)

      The German position weakened considerably in that Austrian attack, as the Kaiser can't build an unit to stop the raid immediately; he'll basically have to support himself into Munich, and even then he'll have an Austrian raider indefinitely bouncing around in the German space, unless he has time at some point to dedicate 2-3 armies to driving it out decisively. Unfortunate for Austria that the Gre-Ser defensive moves were fucked up (Serbia apparently supported Gre-Ven, which is a tad optimistic for a fleet move), resulting in an actual loss of strength for Austria now that Venice is lost as well. Austria will surely need the friendship of Italy now, so it's fortunate that the two seem to be playing like pros: Venice held and Apulia did the smart thing by bouncing Venice. Prediction: Austria's going to disband the fleet in Apulia, thus laying his disagreement with Italy to rest beautifully, preparing for the hard times ahead. The German Kaiser is unlikely to leave that Munich operation unrevenged, after all.

      Russia played a nice southern move-set that allowed her to keep three SCs, albeit in a somewhat scattered and high-pressure position. Meanwhile Turkey takes a build from Greece; this combined with the fact that there's still a Turkish army in Armenia might mean a reneval of the Turkish Black Sea policy. It is, however, also possible for these two to surprise everybody by having Turkey disband that army on retreat and then build new units in Con and Smy, resulting in a rather tidy peace. Turkey might need this, depending on whether the Sultan interprets the recent Italo-Austrian moves the same way I do.

      Incidentally, Willow, I'm cool with a peace agreement now. Just don't build any more northern fleets and we can be the best of friends. Ta ta.

      Assuming that Austria disbands the Apulian fleet and Italy doesn't stab Austria immediately (my recommendation, incidentally; not smart for Italy to cause Austria to die against a strong eastern Power), those two will have a very exciting position in between Turkey and Germany, who are somewhat naturally both against Austria at the moment. Russia would be foolish to go against Austria when Warsaw is in enemy hands, so we can assume that Russia joins the other two sandwhich-fillings in between the rye loaf of Germany and the unleavened Asian stuff proffered by the Sultan from the other direction. Considering their positions, Austria will naturally dedicate two armies and a fleet against Turkey, while Italy provides the rest of the force in that direction; meanwhile Italy will probably do best to help Austria against Germany by moving to Tyrolia, providing a third army to that particular endeavour. Greece probably goes to Italy's two fleets if this joint struggle is successful, I imagine.

      I'd write more presumptuous hypotheticals, but it's time for the Christmas Goat to visit the house. Later, perhaps.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n

      \n

      \n Eero, I appreciate you saving Paris for me! I knew I could trust you absolutely (to act in your best interests).
      \n

      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n But of course, no problem there. Just remember it when you're deciding between a convoy and a long-term raid up north, if you know what I mean.
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@Paul T, greetings! Kept my word. (Btw, Tyrolia wouldn't be supporting Austria, that's be more along the lines of attacking.)
      \n
      \n@Willow, I appreciate your previous advice on the MOA move. I had written it off, but then rethought it.
      \n
      \n@Bill, Hi, new neighbor.
      \n
      \n@Daumantas - not leaving you out.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, looks like I may finally get a build, which could mean I'm back in the game.

      However, I will not be playing for at least 50% of the time during the holidays. Am I the only one in that position?

      After all, once the Fall is done, we could all just agree on peace everywhere (i.e. all units hold) until the New Year or something like that.

      If not, I can offer that same treaty to my neighbours until I return--no aggression from or towards Italy.

      Or is there a way to give another player command of my armies while I'm away?





      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul, I suggest that you not advertise your specific scheduling weaknesses so openly. If we cannot arrange for a complete pause of some sort, then it'll be really difficult for your neighbours (and everybody else, really, by extension) to decide between exploiting your absense and hampering their own play. For example, your neighbours might actually lose position if they had to not move against you to be fair to you while the rest of the board goes on.

      If we have to do something about the holidays, I suggest that everybody (close to Italy or not) agrees to NMR for the entire year 1904; perhaps the game program doesn't end the game or some such because of that - somebody could even make some meaningless bounces just to make sure the game still goes on. It's also possible that there is some way of pausing the game that I don't know about, of course.

      The best solution overall would be if you could get a reserve player for Italy while you're gone, Paul. You could simply give your account info to your trusted aide, in which case there wouldn't need to be any mechanical hassle with the system, even. I could probably find somebody to play Italy here, but they'd likely have to do it in strict gunboat to ensure fairness, as anybody I'd ask to do it would naturally be a friend of mine. Of course any onlooker can volunteer here - it'd just be for a week, not an onerous obligation. I don't want any of the players in the game to take on the task, it's unfair towards the others.

      The second-best solution is that you simply play calmly, skipping the turns you can't make, without telling anybody else in advance that you'll be NMRing and how long it's going to last. This sort of thing is part of the uncertainties of war in Diplomacy, nobody is obligated to move their units by the rules. Telling about an intent to NMR in advance is deadly in this context, as everybody around you will know about it and will act accordingly. However, a NMRing Power will often survive a year of skipped plays in some shape, as the other players will take some care in case you're just pretending to be away, and still others will take the opportunity to attack anybody seeking to take advantage of you.

      --

      To get the idea of a consentual pause out of the way quickly one way or the other, I suggest that we vote on it immediately. If there are seven AFFIRMATIVE votes before the end of the Winter phase, then nobody makes any undeclared moves through the year 1904; if there is even one NEGATIVE, then we'll play through it and Paul'll have to make other arrangements. I'd prefer to make this completely clear and consentual so nobody can claim afterwards that they didn't realize that there was a pause in the game; we can't probably recover within the game program if somebody does something clever during the agreed-upon pause out of confusion.

      My own vote is AFFIRMATIVE, I'm not in any particular hurry about the game. I just hope the system doesn't interpret everybody NMRing as a reason to cancel the game; perhaps we'll arrange for some specific bounces here and there on the board to pretend that the game is moving forward.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPeterBB \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I vote affirmative as well. I'd rather play the game with full participation of everyone, and I'm ok with waiting in order to do that.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      The order was supposed to be Ser S Gre, by the way; I'm not even sure how I messed up. I should be glad more didn't go south.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Folks,

      Right now it looks like I'll only miss a couple of days, sometime within the next three or four days. If everyone is affirmative, I will post which days.

      If not everyone is in, then I won't tell you, as Eero suggests.
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n

      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n I vote AFFIRMATIVE!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      How about we end our mutual pissing contest? If you disband your army instead of retreating to Armenia you'll get two builds that could be fleets- and if you disband that army, my disband will be my fleet in Sevastopol.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The holiday break definitely needs to be a multiple of whole year so as to not mess with the game structure. I agree with Daniel in that it's better to extend the break over the new year (2-3 years) rather than mess about with vague starts and stops.

      We have six affirmatives, I think, so once Daumantas affirms it's official: the only plays in 1904 will be some formal bouncing to avoid triggering some heretofore unknown automatic game-ending algorithms. (I speculate about those automatic algorithms because other Diplomacy servers I've seen have had such so as to help the system clean out games that have stopped due to lost interest.)

      A year without retreats takes three days, so we'll probably get over the worst with one year. If not, we can extend the moratorium.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n And the yearly European census data...

      Germany takes Warsaw but loses Munich, staying at seven centers, still the top dog but that army in Munich is a powerful threat to cohesion at home. The Turk climbs back to five at the expense of the Austrian- is this a permanent inroad into the Balkans for Daumantas? France manages to hold onto all his centers (five of them), Gascony, and gain the Mid Atlantic, but he's still got to get the German units off his doorstep before he's completely secure. England is back up to five with the acquisition of St. Petersburg- where will his units be pointed next? Italy rallies, retaking Venice, climbing up to 4 for the first time, and our heroes, the Russians, stage a noble defense, clinging tenaciously to three centers.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Go Russia!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n AFFIRMATIVE.

      Sure, Willows. I will be needing to secure those two builds just to erect a proper defense, it seems.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n So Paul, seems we're going on break in 1904. Is that year enough, or should we take 1905 as well?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I`m fine either way. I may miss a phase in 1905, but I should be able to get most of it.

      So it's up to you folks: if you want to play through, then do it! If not, then let's meet in 1906.

      Happy holidays to you all!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Let's play in 1905, then, and see how it goes with Paul. Always interesting to gnaw on the remains of your fingers and see whether your erstwhile ally has remembered to make his moves this time.

      Incidentally, Peter, do you want a tactical breakdown of the German options regarding that Austrian army in Munich? I'm asking because you might not want to have everybody else see what I'm thinking about it, if you already have a good sense of the situation.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Testing, testing.

      Is this thing on? This is an obvious lead for someone to say "Oh, it's on!", by the way."
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ah, we're back on, it seems. 1905, so everybody remember to make your moves now - the game goes on normally.

      Let me know if you need a second viewpoint on those moves, Peter - that's a pretty tricky situation you have there in the middle of the board.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPeterBB \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yeah, I would appreciate that. It's definitely tricky.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n So, what I was thinking regarding the Austrian outbreak in Munich is, were I the German, I'd primarily try to talk the Austrian out of there because that's one hell of a shitty situation to be in. However, assuming that this wouldn't work, my primary tactical play would be to convoy an unit into Kiel while encouraging that Austrian army to stay put for the spring. The logic here is that there is no reasonable play that'd get the Austrian entirely out of Germany in one year, but you could achieve a cordon: if you could attack the Austrian in Munich in such a manner as to encourage a retreat to Berlin, then you could plug in the hole in Munich and force the enemy to the east. The whole idea would be to prevent the supremely annoying possibility of Mun-Kie (or Mun-Ruh; the latter is unlikely, except as a result of retreat), which would lead to the Austrian raider unit getting into reach of the western German possessions in the Low Countries and Denmark. Insofar as Austrian raiding goes, Kiel acts as a sort of watershed: force, lure or convince the raid to go to Berlin instead of Kiel or Ruhr, and you'll be able to get it out of your lands in a reasonable time-frame.

      (If the Austrian decides to opportunistically move to Ruhr, the logic is similar, except you'll need to cordon him to the west: presumably a spring move to Belgium means a fall move to either Netherlands, from which - assuming that he succeeds in the first place - your logical approach would be to occupy Ruhr and force the raider out via the coastal Hol-Bel-Pic corridor, out to France. Basically, the key is to occupy the central German territories in Kiel and Munich to prevent the raider from making a long-term hobby of swinging east and west in turns.)

      The strategic point in the Austrian raider situation for me would be just that - to treat the army in Munich as an isolated raider unit instead of an invasion. Germany will probably be better off by having one unit bounce Munich to prevent a reinforcement from arriving to the scene (Mun-Ruh, Boh-Mun sort of thing) while a second unit secures Kiel, rather than treat the event as a wholesale invasion where Germany would need to call back all armies everywhere for a desperate homeland defense. The latter reaction make getting rid of the raider a bit quicker, but not remarkably so, and it'd relinquish the current German interests elsewhere, leading to larger trouble in the long term. The important thing is to keep a cool head, let the Austrian mess about with his little game as he would, and make sure that the Austrian emperor knows that you're not going to be provoked and that he's basically wasting his time by allotting any force to Germany when his own eastern border is under serious danger from Turkey. The fact is that a lone raider only costs a Power one unit in lost SC count, while forcing such a raider out takes at least three units for several turns; this only makes sense when you don't have interests elsewhere to defend.

      Which units can be spared to treat the Austrian situation is a painful question for Germany, as the choice is basically between a compromise in the western line and endangering the possession of Warsaw. My own choice in this situation would likely be to risk Warsaw, as Russia has other problems to consider, while France does not: the latter can easily take benefit from any easing up of German effort, while Russia might choose to defend the obviously vulnerable Rumanian position, in which case the army in Silesia could be spared off the Warsaw situation without causing immediate losses. This is also true tactically in that one of the more effective defenses in Warsaw is a dynamic attack on Moscow, anyway. Then there is also the consideration of the third French army in Portugal, which might well be coming up to bat this year if France manages to clear Brest or Gascony for a landing; allowing that (as opposed to continuing the siege of Paris to lock down the position) is a somewhat heavy price to pay just to bounce Munich.

      However, overall I have to recommend a diplomatic solution: Austria has a somewhat fragile position in the east, and the possibility of an Italian NMR this year causes furthern uncertainty; Turkey meanwhile has a forward-pointing fleet set-up in the Mediterranean and a quickly shaping infantry line in the southern Balkans. The moment is not very favourable for Austria to start picking a fight with the Kaiser, which might mean that the entire affair could be laid to rest by simply offering Austria a bone in exchange for a retreat from Munich. What might be offered is trickier, as there are no immediate prizes available; perhaps the best argument is that one SC is all Austria can hope to attain against Germany even with an aggressive stance, and therefore the Austrian should hold in Munich for the year, withdraw Bohemia and allow himself to be kicked out of Munich in 1906, at which point the army might find better use elsewhere, anyway. A sort of ceasefire, that. Thinking about it I wouldn't trust this sort of solution nearly enough to not put an army into Kiel, but convincing the Austrian to retreat from Bohemia might be enough to make a bounce in Munich unnecessary for the time being.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n Remember, at this joyful point in the game, England has NO other SC's they can take, other than German ones.
      \n
      \nPeter, if the Baltic sea fleet moves into Kiel, Sweden is lost. And BEL's wide open right now as well.
      \n

      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n

      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: CalculusI've created a new account - after considering the ethics of two accounts on play diplomacy vs "quiting" a diplomacy game.

      .

      \n
      I think that's a good choice, under the circumstances.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Good call, Daniel - that's what I'd have done. Apparently there was an automatic surrender function after all. That's fortunes of war for you, I don't think I've ever played a game of Diplomacy without some sort of orders-related mistakes coming up. In hindsight it's obvious that the system skips the winter phase altogether if nobody has builds to do, which means that our skipped year lasted only two days instead of three.

      Anyway, we have new moves, and they're pretty interesting once more - after the initial opening clash everybody's gotten a breather, and that shows in all sorts of little ways, such as rethought strategies and little mistakes in orders. Italy tried to walk a ship over the peninsula from Rome to Apulia, while the French suffered an upset loss in Paris to the Germans due to the NMR; surely a peace accord is just around the corner? Russians expectedly lose Rumania and are in danger of losing Sevastopol to the Turk as well (who called it, eh?).

      I enjoy the Austrian aggressive stance, that's the way to play this game as a central Power. It'll be interesting to see how the Russian army in Galicia reacts to that Rumanian assault, and even more interesting to see if it's an assault at all; were I the Austrian, this move would just be a bluff and prep for a suprise Rum-Bul attack against the Turk, leaving the Russian position somewhat tenable and the Turkish position in chaos. The Italian disarmament has progressed beautifully, so there's every reason to expect that Austria has a solid ally against the Turk in the naval arena as well.

      My own position against France was improved measurably by the French NMR, as I'll now be able to cover the entire width of the Atlantic while bringing in new armaments from the north, thus securing myself against the prospect of French raids on good ol' England. It'll take a while, but I have all the time in the world, especially as the French will probably have to make a difficult disband choice in the winter, probably between the Spanish fleet and the Portuguese army. That Italian army in Piedmont can't be a happy thing, either; Germany might just conseivably gamble with Paris to proffer a support for an attack on Marseilles, which would surely spell near disaster to France. It's actually such an aggressive move at this point that I'd reconsider as Italy - a dead France is not a long-term advantage for Italy, even if it does secure the western flank temporarily.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n

      \n Now that I've had some time to consider the map, Peter: would you support Eng-Bre from Paris? Let me know if that's available, could be a pretty effective move even in the open environment. Doesn't even matter much if our encryption scheme doesn't work here
      \n

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daniel,

      So, you're back in the game? I hope so!

      In return for your good will towards Italy, how about we arrange a bounce in Marseilles? I'm happy to help you out there.

      Bill and Daumantas,

      Does either of you need some assistance in the Balkans? I could potentially offer one or the other of you some support, if there's some benefit in it for me and the overall board situation.

      (As before, I will be on and off until the New Year, so best of luck to you all while I'm away, if it so happens!)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm amazed that Peter is willing to trade Belgium, Holland, and Munich for a year in Paris.
      \n
      \nWhen this over, I'm going to have to devote several weekends to analyzing Eero's posts to see how the heck he does it.
      \n
      \nPS: Bill, BUR is likely supporting PAR. Meaning MUN could risk nabbing another SC.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul,

      I do believe France is rather hurting for units as it is. Asking for a bounce may be just as painful as just going there!

      If you want to help me out in the Balkans, you can always go A Piedmont - Tyrolia, F Ionian Sea - Adriatic, A Naples - Apulia, F Rome - Naples. That puts you in position to support a convoy into Trieste, or alternativelly take Vienna and support the Naples fleet into the Ionian (you generally don't want anyone else's fleet there unless you're woefully outnumbered and need any help you can get, and then only rarely).

      This is only so you would get some SCs of your own off the bargain. To maintain non-aggressive relations with me, all you really need to do is run a policy of non-interference as far as the Balkans go.

      Though, I would suggest going in force against either France or Austria. Just be aware of the consequences - if France disappears off the map, it means good fortunes for England, which'll likely pick off most of it, plus bits and pieces of Germany... Might leave the west part of the map with a power vacuum you'd be in no real position to fill. You moving against Austria might mean Bill is permanentelly crippled, but you getting in position to profit from that is rather easier, at least. Might also mean that Austria has to pull out of Germany to defend against you, which can be either a good thing or a bad thing depending on what fate has in store for the German the coming year... Don't want him to fail, don't want him to be as strong as the pre-Austrian incursion.

      Decisions!

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n For what it's worth, moving against anybody but Turkey seems pretty hazardous for Italy at the moment. The Turk has one fleet too many at immediate striking distance from the Italian lines, for instance, and if Austria fails there is nobody else to help Italy against Turkey, for whom Italy is the primary target after Austria fails. For these reasons I probably wouldn't get it on with the Turk as Italy, not unless I'd talked him into sending half his fleet to seclusion in the Black Sea, at least.

Daumantas, you're really better off moving that fleet back to Constantinople to get it into the fray where you'll need it, rather than picking up the hatchet with me again.

      \n I've got plenty of other places to go. If Austria falls, Turkey suddenly gets a lot more directions in which it can go to... I can live without going after Paul. But can he live without taking *something* off of Austria, at least? Doubtful. It's a matter of exercising restraint once you're there, is all.

      Willow, chill. The fleet is there solely to support going into Austria while leaving the little Constantinople bottleneck open for armies to go through. As long as Austria doesn't try some crazy runaround through Sev, you should be able to retain possesion of it. And Rumania's currently kind of a lost cause, isn't it?

      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n No surprise on the English-german stab.
      \n
      \nLiv to Moscow! Ballsy move! And a misentered Austian support order gives Mun back to the Germans.
      \n
      \nRussia gets Saint Petersburg.
      \n

      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nAnd here we are again, the fall of 1905. Dramatic as all get-out. Germany gains Moscow and Munich but loses Paris, Belgium, Denmark, Sweden and presumably Berlin, for a total of loss of two SCs. England gains two, Russia stays even, Austria loses one and Turkey gains one. Total chaos in many parts of the board, with shattered lines and enemies raiding the home SCs of mighty Powers.

      As can be seen, we're renegotiating the power balance up north a bit. I'm most concerned with the prosperity of the Germany Power, of course, and therefore will be happy to relinquish the Netherlands back to the Kaiser in his time of trouble here; the Nordic area, on the other hand, is probably better held by the English, as Germany lacks the attention and means to properly police the area. Peter: I suggest that you keep a good handle on Kiel, disband the fleet and see to your defenses - I will not advance against you, and will withdraw from Belgium unless your disbands are dramatically anti-English. My follow-up plan concerns the Frenchman, who is also a problem for you, and thus I am the least of your problems at the moment. The current borders (excepting Belgium, which I'll give back) are easily defensible and natural for both of us, and do not necessitate an excessive border patrol from either of us.

      Willow: I'm cool with you in StP for the time being, as you don't have a fleet presence there. I suggest that you use the position to win back your core possessions, and perhaps consider demilitarizing our border areas like I've done. I will consider swinging up and coming back to StP, but if you act quickly in calming the area down, that might not be necessary at all.

      Italy and Austria will have a fun time dealing with the Turk now, I can see that. The Bulgarian position is rather untenable, while the Austrian home SCs are almost bare to raid and conquest. Unless a concord can be made with Russia and Italy continues coordinating extremely closely, I doubt that Austria will last long in this situation. The situation's not extremely bad from an Italian viewpoint, as now Austria will definitely be a reliable ally who'll be more than happy to help him into Greece next year. The only question is whether they actually can overcome the Turk, even together. The Turkish defensive position with two fleets is, as always, extremely solid.



      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n What an entirely unexpected stab of the German! If only someone, anyone, had seen that coming!

      Seriously though, a massive and well-played stab by Eero. Peter, you're going to be hard pressed to fight on so many fronts- it's probably best to pick one and abandon it. I am biased and certainly hope you'll abandon your Eastern front, disbanding at least one unit and not pushing in any further- that would let me turn my attentions back south, where they belong. It would also be a good idea to make nice with France. He can, and should ally with you to make sure Eero doesn't get any bigger- the question is what can you do for him?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I might be a tad biased, but to me it seems that the only thing France can do is to leverage that large army in a push towards the east; France needs builds for fleets, and the only place to get them is in the Ruhr economic area. A tidy peace with France would be an option by getting rid of the two German armies in France, but I sort of doubt that France would let the matter lie if Germany removed the specific force that's keeping him from ravaging Germany.

      On the other hand, removing the eastern force is quite thinkable for Germany, it seems to me: it's true that a loss of Moscow and Warsaw would be imminent, and that would cause further cascading weakness in the west, but that'd happen a year later - perhaps enough time to get the situation in the homeland under control. Russia would have no particular motivation to go after Germany after regaining War and Mos, too, so it's a politically much more stable solution than removing the western flank.

      The best solution might well be to remove F Bal (which, as I discussed earlier, has no useful function next year) and A Mos, then move A War-Sil in the spring to use that particular army against the Austrian infestation in Berlin. The armies from Warsaw, Kiel and Munich will be able to recapture Berlin without much fuzz while also taking Belgium, which'll compensate for the loss of Moscow and Warsaw to Russia, stabilizing the German realm. The Kaiser could even try for a treaty of controlled retreat with Russia, something where the Russian promises to only take Moscow next year and Warsaw only the year after, giving Germany a valuable extra year of operational time for one of those armies. Little reason for Russia to abide by such a treaty, of course, except for strategic (a wish to see Germany get his house in order) and diplomatic (proof of willingness to work together in the future) reasons, which might or might not sway Willow.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1\u202645678910\u202619\xbb

    Comments

      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n

      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero is proposing that France, while being attacked from the North by England and the south by Italy, is going to send armies away from home, in a way that couldn't even get another French SC for two years? In the best case?
      \n
      \nLol, and Fleet Baltic having no useful purpose. *snort*
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul,

      A lot rests on what you decide to do next year. Up to now, you, me and Austria have been doing our little thing in our side of the board, but from now on, everything each of us does changes the situation for the whole board, and thus, the whole game, and thus, the *endgame*, and thus, who wins this game!

      Why? Because England just went up to 7 SCs. Normally, that wouldn't be such a big deal, as that's an advantage that can easily be countered by an alliance of two or so other powers... But in this case, that simply can't happen - Russia has no northern fleet and has years before she can possibly get one up. Germany will soon be forced to defend all of its coastal home SCs, which again will mean that he will be forced to place his armies onto Kiel and Berlin, meaning that no new German fleets shall be forthcoming either. France is the only western country with anything even close to a naval force, but Eero has enough strength in numbers to keep France in that little corner indefinitelly and jab at her while he does.

      Because of Eero's better strategic position, he'll have a number of 'superflous' units he can throw away on any attacks he wishes - win some, lose some, he now has enough of a buffer to be able to get back up from many small defeats - not that any of those are very likely to begin with. Slowly but surely, he'll take control of the majority of the western coastal SCs, and then will start making his way deeper inland.

      The endgame depends very much on what he'll find there then - a bunch of squabbling nations, easy to pick off one by one, or two or so countries with most of their teritorial disputes long decided, and ready to face any western threat.

      Simply put, of the three of us - Italy, Turkey, and Austria, one has to go for the other two to grow in power and become relevant enough for the endgame.

      You're off the table because neither Austria nor I am in good position to grab up your holdings, nor we will likely be soon, with our forces tangled at our mutual border.
      Turkey's on the table, but my position is defensible enough that it will take a long time for anything to crack my shell, time during which Eero will remain relativelly unopposed.
      Austria, however, is teethering on the edge already, and the only question is if we should give a push.

      And yes, we should. The builds we would gain from the venture would allow us to move against Russia and Germany, respectivelly, while maintaining enough of a force to make attacking each other too costly to consider. At that point, we can shore up Moscow and Munich, effectivelly eliminating Eero's chance for a solo and going for a three or four-way draw.


      Whatever you do decide, I strongly suggest you lay off France. As long as France's fleets exist, England is barred from entering the Mediterranean, and will be forced to move over land, something she is not naturally well-equipped to do. Move against Austria, attack Turkey if you must (futile though it would be), but do leave France alone and consider demilitarizing borders with her - her units are better spent elsewhere.


      Oh, and yes. Bill, the above probably applies to you too, but our current troop placement would make a joint attack on Italy somewhat of a pipe dream... Still, if you could see your way to support Eastern Med into the Ionian, I'd suddenly get a whole bunch of things I could do that aren't attacking you, and would thus cease hostilities against you immediatelly in thanks. Would be a rather insane turn of events, I know! Rather like the ones I believe we both enjoy.

      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n I always forget a bit or so!

      The above is rather why Eero so often makes the seemingly off-hand suggestion of Italy attacking Turkey, or discusses the tactical possibilities of such an endaveavour, or...

      You get the idea.

      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I am clearly insufficiently skilled to play Austria under these conditions; the difficulty of coordinating with allies in the open has driven me to apoplectic paralysis. My attempt to relieve some of the pressure on Russia by tackling Germany was intended to give her a chance to reclaim Warsaw, but Willow saw other opportunities and took them--at my expense, certainly, but I don't blame her for that. And it was clearly foolish to expect any kind of aggressiveness from Italy without prior arrangement, but saying "Hey, Paul, can you attack the Aegean Sea?" would have been tantamount to putting out a welcome mat on the Ionian Sea (although upon reflection that might have been better for me short term).

      So I made some erroneous judgments and tactical blunders, and now I'm on the ropes. Daumantas, I would have liked to have given you more of a challenge, but your superior tactical play has got me flummoxed. I am worried that you will soon grow bored with toying with me, and move quickly now to administer the coup de grace.

      Still, all is not lost! I imagine that everyone else besides Eero and Daumantas are feeling a little hard-pressed right now, so maybe we can work together to salvage something.

      Peter, I am suing for peace. I will evacuate Berlin; you may reclaim it at your leisure. I hope that we can work together to contain the Turkish threat, and that you can reach a similar accommodation with Daniel to deal with England, and with Willow to regularize your lines.

      Willow, I need you order Vie-Tri, Ukr S Bul-Rum in the spring, so that I can support you into Serbia in the fall. I realize that this leaves Sevastopol vulnerable, but if you can work with Peter to do something to protect it--perhaps you can trade Sev for Mos, or perhaps he will agree to support Ukr-Sev in the fall. If nothing else, agreeing to this plan will make Daumantas more likely to build a fleet, which given your current disposition of forces you can only find preferable.

      Paul, I hope I can count on you to help me out in the Mediterranean and the Balkans. For this turn, if you move Rom-Apu, Pie-Ven, TyS S Ion, Ion S Alb-Gre, the chance of a Turkish breakout into the Med is minimized. I don't expect to actually take Greece, but the threat should be enough to keep the pressure on so that when Russian troops occupy Serbia, they'll be able to support you into Greece.

      That's the best I've got; if it's a pipe dream, I'll still go down fighting.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n edited December 2010
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The corner Powers have somewhat of an advantage in the open diplomacy environment, as their diplomacy is, generally speaking, more about propaganda and less about coordinated moves. I, for example, am happy to only advice my good ally the Kaiser in the most general terms, leaving the specific move-sets secret.

      Austria should've retreated to Trieste in my thinking, as it would have been easier to talk Russia into relinquishing Vienna through Vie-Bud-Rum than Vie-Gal-War, perhaps. Austria has great pressure to play Bul-Ser now, which means that the Budapest army will find it awkward to move out of the way of that particular diplomatic stratagem. Perhaps Willow will accept Warsaw in trade for Vienna; I would.

      I agree with Daumantas's analysis of the eastern situation in general terms, it's going to be a bitch to fight against Turkey with both Austria and Russia on the brink of destruction. Still, the alternative is pretty much going to be a strong corner Power growing even stronger at the expense of all neighbours, so perhaps there is no choice in the matter for Italy, Austria and even Russia.

      By the way, Bill, why did you retreat to Berlin if you're going to give it up without a fight? One would have expected you to outright disband in that case.
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n

      \n

      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenBy the way, Bill, why did you retreat to Berlin if you're going to give it up without a fight? One would have expected you to outright disband in that case.
      \nEero -- I hadn't yet decided what to do. Also, it gives me an extra unit elsewhere for a year. -- Bill

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nDecember 2010 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, perhaps the Berlin army will be useful for you. It comes to me that you could easily use it as a diplomatic tool with Russia; regaining Moscow and Warsaw is foremost in a good Czar's mind, I imagine, so an offer of aid from a soon-to-be-dismantled Austrian army might go over well. This is especially true if you can talk Willow into sending one of her three armies deep into Austria to fight a crusade against the wile musulman; that same army could join the Russian forces in their homeland, after all.

      Assuming that Germany wants to go the other way at the same time, you need to discuss which of you'll go to Prussia and which'll go to Silesia in the spring
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPeterBB \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@Bill_White: I've always maintained that peace between us is crucial for our mutual success. I don't blame you for the attack-- I was a juicy target-- but I gladly accept your offer of peace.

      @Willow: As you see, I've abandoned my claim on your territories. I like your style, and have on more than one occasion tried to justify to myself an alliance with you, but the tactical and strategic situation never seemed to cooperate. Perhaps, if we can deal with our respective troubles at home, we will be in a better place to work together in the future.

      @Calculus: We've been enemies since nearly the beginning, and I know I'm not helping matters by keeping all of my Western armies. All I can say is that Eero is clearly the major threat at the moment, and that I have zero intention of attacking you in the near future.

      @Everyone: My strategic priority, obviously, is to somehow contain Eero. I knew I would have to do so eventually, but of course he has better timing and foresight than I do. (Specifically, my strange notion that Austria wasn't going to attack me cost me a lot of momentum and coordination.) Anyone who can offer plans, support, etc. to reach that goal has a good chance of gaining my appreciation and cooperation.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Peter, I have a suggestion on containing Eero: you should relinquish one or both of the Netherlands temporarily to France, allowing Daniel to build fleets against England. This should prevent an English break-through to the Mediterranean, limiting the English influence strictly to the Atlantic arena. Aside from that I fail to see how anything you might do would be remotely relevant to the English situation, what with you being clearly dominant on the continent while England is utterly unwilling to engage anybody in that direction (which can be seen in the builds; a continentally focused England would have built an army, if not two).

      Meanwhile, that power vacuum in Russia is mighty interesting now that it's on the map as a fact. Considering that Russia only has three units available, it'll be interesting to see how Willow'll manage to cover Moscow, Warsaw and the imminent threat to Sevastopol with those. Might not be a bad idea to simply leave taking Moscow back for later; in my eyes it seems utterly obvious that the Turk'll be advantaged greatly by grabbing for Sevastopol and thus securing the northern flank as part of his current expansionist attitude. After all, the alternative is to see Russia gain a build next winter, possibly with Sevastopol open - that could open the Black Sea issue all over again. I could see room for a Turko-Russian alliance, too, but those two might be too proud and prickly for that, considering the past.

      Daniel: if you'll move away from the Atlantic Ocean altogether this turn, I'll be content with demilitarizing MAO instead of occupying it; we could even make it a perennial bounce if you have nothing better to do with your fleets. I'm sure that you'll see how it's one and the same for me, but probably wastly preferable for you to not have me sit in there, threatening half your SCs all at once. You may, of course, simply move your Atlantic fleet to Portugal at this point, which suffices for my security without being any sort of tactical loss for you, as that's where you'd be going anyway in the fall. Note that next turn'll be too late for this arrangement, as I'll already have the conquest of MAO under way then.

      Paul: I think that you should make very certain that Austria does not fall and Turkey does not break through to the Ionian Sea; these are major priorities for Italian security. I'm affirming this evaluation again because it seems to me that you're being unnecessarily conservative about your army distribution; that army in Piedmont is unlikely to make a breakthrough to Marseilles alone, and you can't afford to send one of your fleets to help it as long as the Turk threatens the Ionian with two fleets and the Austrian fleet is in the reach of Turkish armies. Meanwhile there's a certain lack of military strength in the Balkans. It'd probably be a good idea if you moved your armies towards the front-lines with haste, moving through Austrian territories if necessary. It's more important to plug the line in an immediate sense than to respect traditional borders when the safety of the European heartlands is at stake. (Were I you I'd prepare the southern army for a convoy over the Ionian while the northern one moves through Venice to block the imminent Turkish occupation of Trieste, but that's arguable; the situation is complex and near desperate unless Russia gets its ass in gear soon.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill, I doubt very much that Austria's current state is a matter of a lack of skill at your part. Wrong calls, maybe - but we don't always make the right calls, otherwise those'd be called precognition instead, right?

      Half of a center power's strength comes from its diplomatic flexibility - being able to tell three different things to three different people if necessary. In this open diplomacy game, you lost that strength and got saddled with a weakness instead...

      Not only can't you easily pit one nation against another without making it known, even when you have a credible alliance going, you're limited to either agreeing to something I can intercept and make use of, or to just to flail around and step on each others toes... Not a good choice!

      This environment favours the lone fighter with a slight edge, I think.

      I was given mine from start of the game by the shape of the board itself, and was just exploiting it to the best of my ability up to now.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      On the Mediterranean

      \n

      Eero's build is aimed at forcing the Mediterranean this year. The Liverpool fleet build is the key. Moving Liverpool to Irish Sea and London to English Sea, gives England three fleets attacking MOA in the fall. That's more than my two fleets can hold. And I'm not getting more builds before this happens.

      \n

      As Daumantas pointed out, with Eero this strong AND knocking France out of the game AND controling the western stalmate line, it's all over but the crying. After France, Eero would then able to take Italy with fleets and Germany by both land and sea to a solo victory.

      \n

      There's a way to stop it though.

      \n

      Pauls's Tyherrian fleet needs to move to West Med this spring and support MOA in the fall. With three ships, we've locked up that stalemate line.

      \n

      Now this makes Italy vulnerable to Turkey in the Ionian. Therefore, I will make Daumantas this PROMISE. If you attack the Ionian, while Italy's other fleet is backing me up in the west med, I'll let England through.

      \n

      PS: Paul, Eero's advice to you is what's good for Eero. Make up your own mind. (And move from Piedmont!)

      \n

      On Russia

      \n

      England's played a smooth game in the North (or had a happy accident). Russia was emasculated as a threat to England and Scandenavia (no more fleets), and then England retreated, leaving Russia in still in the game as a threat to Turkey.

      \n

      On France-Germany

      \n

      We are the ones most affected by English power. And England would have a very difficult time winning without both of us dead on the way there. The past German invasion of France opened you for stabbing and prevented me from moving against England at sea.

      \n

      This is year is time for peace beween us.

      \n

      England only needs three fleets to force the Mediterranean. Germany can be sure that F Belguim won't be just sailing away without a fight. Take Belgium this turn. England will have support for it in the channel next turn. If you would like me to move into either Picardy or Burgandy in the spring and support you somewhere in the fall, let me know. Otherwise, I'll wait.

      \n

      A retreating Belgium fleet can obvoiusly take Holand, but at least there England can't support it until both next year and if they back off of attacking the Mediterranean.

      \n

      If Kiel attacks Denmark, it will either break support for an attack on the Baltic, or retake Denmark.

      \n

      The turn after this one will be hard for you, with the troop loss from recovered Russian territories.

      \n

      In the long term, to have any kind of freedom of action, you need another fleet. Perhaps someone can give you advice on this.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm not really interested in slogging it out anymore with Turkey, that ship has sailed and sunk.

      I'm eager to be included in any grand alliance- fleets are going to be a major factor in it. My recover is going to be slow going, no denying that, but the possibility of a fleet build in St. Pete is not to be given up lightly.

      I agree with Daniel considering the Mediteranean- he'll need support from the Italian. Italy could stick the wound in France instead, but there's really no point- there's not going to be any territory more defensible than MAO.

      Germany should attack Belgium. No risk, it gets a unit out of France, and puts Eero on the defensive in the Low Countries.

      Austria- I'll be vacating Vienna to move to Galicia to retake my home centers.

      Eero is not likely to lose more than a center this upcoming year, but careful German play could see a fleet build in Kiel. A French build in Brest is less likely unless France gets Belgium, which is risky all around, which is probably why Eero suggested it. Much better to wait until next year for such an attempt.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Come now Willow, I expected better of you - what's the point of this doomsday drumming against England from your viewpoint? I'm not suddenly going to snap my fingers and win this game just because I attacked Germany and incidentally saved your ass from imminent destruction. Now you're directly threatening me with new fleet builds up in StP when I've been most clear in my intent to let you clear your house in peace, even going so far as to grant you back one of your home SCs to give you a base to work from. That's gratitude for you, apparently the next time a central Power is sweeping the board I should just let them.

      Considering my willingness to work with you and the clear consensus the other western Powers have about allying against me, it seems pretty obvious that it's Turkey you should be arraigning against, not me. Apparently it escaped everybody else's attention aside from me and Bill, but Daumantas actually has a very strong tactical position here: he's beating both Austria and Italy all alone even as it is, as anybody can affirm for their own satisfaction by simply considering the current unit set-up. I do not understand why eastern Powers should treat the entirely common disagreements of the western triangle here as somehow more important than their own situation, when I am clearly unable to attack my western neighbours, even as the Sultan is setting up to break through into the Austrian heartlands and the Italian seas both. Of course it's not a done deal (solo victory OMG), but it's certainly of more concern to Russia than whatever happens between the western Powers.

      Supposing I have any say in it, this apocalyptic tone of discussion would be better set aside. Solo victories and Grand Alliances are being flung about when the game has just barely entered its middle phase. All Powers are still on the board and there's not even any clearly superior contender evident for a solo victory. Everybody's writing like I'm suddenly it, but as I noted above, Daumantas is doing even better than I am, what with his actual ability to project force against opponents in disarray, while I'm faced with the single most coherent and least threatened Power on the board in France, all set up to kill me as best he can. I must be missing something tactical here, as I simply don't see why I'm suddenly such a great danger to everybody when I can't even keep hold of what little I currently possess.

      It seems to me that Daniel's not biting on my offer of peace, but this is likely not going to be much of an issue for everybody else; mostly it just means that I'll be seizing MAO by force, after which the French forces fortify the Iberian peninsula and we'll spend a few years sitting tight while Daniel thinks about whether fighting with me is really going to accomplish anything for him. Anybody can certify for themselves as a tactical exercise what it would take for me to make any progress whatsoever against France at this juncture; perhaps considering the tactical situation against the forces I actually have at my disposal will calm any wild visions of great conquest - or maybe I'm myself just not seeing that excellent set of moves that allows me to make any progress against France.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daniel, Paul,

      Regarding the Ionian - while I don't want to throw a wrench into the workings of a credible keep-Eero-out-of-the-Med plan, and recognize the importance of the Ionian to Italian home defense...

      That place isn't only a part of a defensive line for Italy, but a prime locationg for staging an attack on Turkey.

      Would it be enough if I promised to attack with only a single fleet, without support? In that case, Italy would only lose the Ionian if her fleet attacks me, and would, of course, be unable to succesfully support an austrian unit either.

      Alternativelly, since Paul is known for keeping his promises, I would not make a single move towards the Ionian provided that Paul promises me the Ionian fleet makes no aggressive moves against me.

      That doesn't leave the fleet with much to do, I know... But A Pied-Tyr, A Rome-Ven, A Ion-Adr is certainly an option. That's enough troops to take up Trieste and Vienna and keep them both.

      That leaves the Ionian open, of course... But, since it'll be at least a year, maybe more, before the French are able to muster enough fleets to maintain the Med lockdown on their own, Italian cooperation is absolutelly vital, and since I'm certainly an interested party in having the manouvers in the West last longer, not shorter, I would be more than happy to do my small part by simply staying in one place for a year - after which, Italy should be easily able to build enough fleets to easily keep it by its own forces if she so wishes - though I would not be averse to prolonging the agreement if it seems necessary.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      I see your issue Daumantas. And ordinarily I'd be fine with a single fleet attack to keep things honest. However the Austrian fleet could upset the status quo either way. For Italy to be able to support me, Paul will have to be sure that he won't suffer by doing so. So no attack this spring. Depending on the Austrian fleet's actions, we can renegotiate after that.

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Is England's fleet in London or the English channel? I'm not too sure.

      Paul is apparently missing out the one time Italy being the center of everything is a *good* thing for her. That's too bad!

      And Russia apparently has a shot at building a northern fleet this year just so long as she pulls all her armies away from my border and I keep off of Sev?

      Apparently, exercising restraint *can* be immediatelly gratifying!

      \n
      \n
      \n England's fleet is in London. I was stalling for one more season.

      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n And well played by Calculus- you keep the Med another year.

      Who knows what would have been brought by Italy, had he ordered moves.

      It may behoove the German to not make a play for Berlin quite yet- it gives the Austrian some breathing room (assuming the German wants that), and he has the option to retreat there if Eero plays for the Baltic.

      Indeed Daumantas. In fact, getting to retreat to Trieste looks like it opens some wonderful possibilities for you.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daniel,

      If Paul's absence is not a one-time thing, you will likely need outside help against Eero in the tussle over the Med... What are your thoughts on a turkish fleet in the West Med?

      Would put me at a kind of virtual handicap, as the unit will move away from my actual front lines - seeing how I am likely, as now seems, to profit more from the situation east, I can certainly afford to help shift the balance in the west. This, however, would means getting through the Ionian, which means crippling Italy... If you expect her to be of a long-term ally, you probably don't want me trying that.

      So, thoughts?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Peter, Daniel, let me be frank about the tactical situation here: there is no way on Earth for either of you two to make any sort of material progress against England as things currently stand. There is also no reprieve in sight - A Russian fleet build would perhaps destabilize the situation, but that's years away and would benefit Russia in no way whatsoever, as we'll see when I pick apart the whole-board dynamics below. I would therefore like to argue that one or both of you guys needs to start making some real efforts at peace overtures here: the only alternative is a complete deadlock until and unless the Russian Power decides for some unfathomable reason to dedicate half of her forces first to clearing StP for builds, and then to building up a significant fleet force. I do not have, and never have had, the sort of force composition that would allow me to hold and keep continental SCs such as the German Netherlandic possessions or the Baltic coast; you two are absurdly far from the sort of naval force that could hope to conquer Denmark, not to speak of more distant English colonies, as I am fully capable of blockading your building ports even if you did get some magic SCs out of nowhere for enabling those builds.

      Now, having the situation in complete standstill is not threatening in itself for me, say, but it does have drastic long-term implications. Assuming that we three decide to resolve the western triangle by basically sitting still for the next five years (that is, not resolving anything), the only possible outcome will surely be that the eastern triangle resolves itself somehow sooner or later, perhaps with a dominant Turkey or perhaps something else. At that point we will be utterly unable to compose a draw-capable defense due to the undeveloped state of our own forces and the stagnant lines we'd have developed until that point. In this way the choice of simply sitting tight will ultimately lead at best to an uncertain, difficult alliance against a dominant eastern Power, and at worst with a solo victory for the same.

      Considering the above, I find the current outspoken German policy of curtailing England foolish; it would be much better to recognize the tactical reality and consider the past events a fait accompli, mere facts to build upon for future play. Like it or not, the nature of the game is such that one of the three western Powers has to be eliminated for the other two to have a credible chance of victory (drawn or otherwise); like it or not, England is currently tactically untouchable even by a whole-board Grand Alliance (for which there is no motivation whatsoever on the parts of the eastern Powers), so we already know that I won't be that first western Power to be eliminated. Either we get rid of Germany or France, or we sit here until some eastern Power wins the game.

      Looking at the current German policy of maintaining a hostile fleet and warmongering among the neighbouring nations, I'm pretty willing to switch my heretofore most rewarding German allegiance any which way as soon as there is some continental movement of forces and one of you guys takes the initiative in fucking up that pesky third wheel. Because I want the stalemate resolved, I will obviously encourage this development sooner rather than later by electing to make relatively neutral and defensive moves myself from now on; no need to feel like you need to sit around and worry about me, do make your moves whenever you're ready. I'll be happy to support any proactive moves you'd care to declare, of course, but perhaps a complete surprise attack is the better way; your call, and I'll back the one who gets the upper hand first.

      (In case you need outspoken plans, I'll provide suggested deals for both sides: if we're going to kill Germany, I'd like to claim both Netherlands with fleets while France can have the rest, with me staying out of the Baltic Sea to ensure demarcation - France helps me disband a couple of fleets in the long term, of course, so I can switch to a northern army assault. If we're still after France, I'll have the Iberian peninsula while the Kaiser can keep the rest. Obviously I'll be glad to move in a quite conservative and secure manner to ensure that my ally doesn't need to worry about any independent thought on the part of the English admiralty, which is admittedly well-known for its adventurous initiatives. In both of these cases I'd like to request that my ally signs up for a plan of naval control: I can live with a France in perpetual stalemate at MAO with free French fleet build-up on the Mediterranean, of course, but a German ally needs to remain at the current fleet build-up, and keep the fleet in coastal Germany, out of the Baltic waters and the Nordic sphere; I trust that neither of those requests is too onerous, all things considered.)

      If there is some other way the western situation can go, I'd love to hear the concrete schematic. I can sort of visualize some harebrained scheme where the French and German forces help each other disband so you two can build more fleets, but hey, be realistic - any French fleet build-up in Marseilles is already completely irrelevant to my defensive needs (due to the MAO bottleneck, work it out), and Germany will be quite hard-pressed to clear a SC on the Baltic coast for builds the way things are going. England is quite difficult to kill at the best of times, and it's completely fantastic now, so at this point I feel that I deserve that you at least admit that I've fought myself into a position where the ball is firmly in your court: one of you two has to go. (Another hare-brained scheme that occurs to me is that you might conquer some more SCs off the eastern half of the board to get more fleets. Good luck with that, according to my calculations you might be able to detach one whole army for the venture in 1908, once our lines completely stabilize.)

      I will, of course, be more than glad to discuss any specific tactical scenarios if either of you has doubts about my claimed invulnerability or the chances that I might be able to take and hold continental SCs against your current total of seven armies with my three-ish fleets dedicated to coastal skirmish. Total stalemate, I say, and dare anybody to prove me wrong.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Again, Eero sends a thousand words marching to say that France and Germany should fight each other while rolling over and opening themselves up for an English stab. Everyone's seen how this has played out - Germany lost three supply centers. France lost Brest.
      \n
      \n@Eero, next year with the SC loss you'll have to start working hard just to keep your current gains. You want France dead because that would give you a solo victory. It was a risky move you made last winter build, giving up on certain gain to try for the big prize. But that's passed. Now, every season you spend gaining position on France, (but not SC's!), Turkey, Germany, and Russia get stronger. I didn't expect you to build to attack MOA last winter, simply because it wasn't in your best intrest. Your best interest (outside of finishing off a stabed Germany), and what I expected you to do, is St Petersburg. Were you to fight that direction, both Germany and France have alternative profitable courses of action that don't involve fighting England. But if you are attacking us, we'll be fighting you. My trust for you is zero, so if you want to end the MOA fight, you have to be the one to make the first move. I'd be delighted to demilitarize it IF there were no English fleets able to reach it before I could.
      \n
      \n@Peter, I'm glad to see your progress retaking your turf. I'd appreciate if Burgandy moved to Belgium this fall. It's a PITA for me to have Paris and Marseilles constantly threatened. I could have retaken or can retake it in the future, but I'd much rather leave it open (which can only happen if you move.) Open lets us both use armies elsewhere. Either of us there, means that the other has two have armies pointed back to prevent stabs.
      \n
      \n@Willow, just because I think that England "should" attack you, doesn't mean I think they "will". Currenly our interests are quite aligned. Next year an army in Finland could hand you Norway.
      \n
      \n@Damultus (and Paul), if Paul returns, and posts his intention to help me at least an hour before the time limit, the deal will still be on. Otherwise, the deal's off, and you can act as you see best. My preference still would be that you would not attack Italy, but I would't self-immolate over it.
      \n
      \n@Paul, from Piedmont, get thee hence! And your support in the west med would keep you from having to defend Tunsia, Rome, and Naples against the English. Thanks.

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Whoa, it looks like I missed some serious action here. My apologies to everyone! Unfortunately, my inconsistent presence at the battle table may continue for another few days or even another week, but I will do my best.

      Daniel, I'm sorry if I angered you with the attack on Marseilles. As I see it, that arranged bounce kept Marseilles safe from Germany while simultaneously allowing you to keep that fleet in position to support the MAO. So, I thought I was helping you--and I'm not sure why that's not the case, but that may be my inexperience talking. Was there a better way to help you against Germany? I believe Eero when he says that France's downfall is not in Italy's interests--that seems like solid sense to me.

      I'm willing to support you from the Western Med, also, as you suggested, so long as Daumantas agrees not to attack the Ionian. Are you OK with that, Daumantas?

      Bill, how are things looking from your end? That Turkish army in Trieste is almost certainly not making you happy. I suppose we could arrange to bounce him up Northwards or force him to disband, and I don't think Daumantas has too much reason to object to that. Do you, Daumantas? Speak up if you have a different idea.

      As for Eero's situation, I for one believe his claims of invulnerability. I don't see how France and Germany (or even Russia, though in Willow's case I wonder if Eero isn't exaggerating a little for dramatic effect) can do much to attack England at this point.

      \n Eero is correct that his homeland is largely safe, but his extra centers are certainly in play. Whether or not he'll lose one this turn depends on if Germany can outguess him, another fleet in the west makes France safe. Russian intervention would be a spoiler, which Eero knows, which is why he's so eager to prevent it.

      Loss of Marseilles, either to the German or the Italian, might actually be in France's best interests this turn- it allows the disbandment of an army, which then opens the door for a possibility of another fleet build when its recaptured, plus it props up an ally on another front- but it's a risky gambit, because it requires a way to safely leave Brest open- a bounce is the best choice, but France won't have the units to self-bounce and retake Marseilles all in one year. France should probably insist on Bel-Hol, Ruh S Bel-Hol, Bur-Bel if he doesn't pursue this strategy at all, or if he chooses to favor the Italian, who could benefit from a fleet build.

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'll reiterate: the only SCs that are "in play" here in the west are the continental SCs, such as Holland, where I have not pretended for a minute that I would be able to hold the place. Quite probably I will be haunted out of there this year. This does not change the fact that SCs such as all English home centers, Denmark, Sweden... those are not in the reach of the Franco-German alliance. Tough on you, no doubt, but incontrovertible as a tactical fact, too. Holland does not make or break anything here, it's the bare minimum Germany needs to take to not be forced to remove an unit (not that such a disband would matter much; it'd likely be a Bur at this point, I imagine).

      I am not concerned about Russia in this position simply because Willow has strong interests in not interfering in a western stalemate: Turkey is a current, clear threat to Russia as an eastern Power, and any hypothetical gains Russia might make against me would be hotly contested; the very best outcome Russia might hope for would be for me to break off my current engagements against Germany, say, to turn my attentions towards her, resulting in years of warfare and (quite likely) a second loss of StP; the geography just dictates this when Russia is entirely vulnerable to complementary attacks on her southern flank while I'm relatively free to do whatever I want here in the Northern Atlantic. The net result for Russia would be to increase her vulnerability both north and south by making it impossible for herself to commit a credible force in the eastern triangle relations around Rumania, all merely to help the western Powers break out of our paralyzed situation - no sense whatsoever from a Russian viewpoint, when what Russia wants should be for us to be as ineffective as possible here while she strives to become supreme against her more immediate neighbours. Russia wants us to stay in just the positions we are in, no need to rock the boat insofar as she's concerned.

      To clarify, I don't particularly expect any drastic shifts in the Franco-German politics for the next couple of turns; Diplomacy has its inertia, and I'm sure it'll take some time for you guys to be convinced about the ugly tactical reality here. I'll do my best to work towards as static position as possible to sufficiently demonstrate the futility of the current war, and you by all means choose your moment for realigning your efforts, whenever you're comfortable. Right now it doesn't seem that the eastern Powers are that interested in reaching west, either, so we're unlikely to be interrupted for a couple of turns, however you want to play this. (Russia might theoretically make temporary peace with Turkey, at which point a small expedition to eastern Germany would be an option. Not Russia's best move in my mind, though.)

      (And of course, if you have any suggestions as to what I could do to get us out of the current static diplomatic positions, I'm all ears. I make note of Daniel's wish that I'd demilitarize NAO-Iri-Eng in exchange for peace with France, and while I don't see this as realistic or even necessary, it's good to know what you're thinking in that regard.)
      \n

      \n Paul,

      I do indeed have a different idea.

      I'm currently at war with Austria and am doing well enough so that I wouldn't stop unless someone makes me. The army in Trieste is not a random, accidental occurence - it's there because I want it there. Or, well, because I want my troops on austrian SCs in general. I can't just will my troops anywhere on the map, though sometimes I wish I could!

      If or when you and Bill manage to beat me back, I would be more than happy to discuss matters as they are on the board then, but as it is... Peace is just another five-letter world.


      However, I'm not at war with *you.* Since I would rather like you to help with containing Eero in the west portion of the map, I am more than ready to do my part, which means - I do not take any aggressive movement towards the Ionian; I do not take SCs off of you if given the chance by the troop movements on the Austrian front.

      I do, however, reserve the right to have one of my two adjanted fleets to attack your Ionian one - this is an act of defense and not of aggression, as the only things it accomplishes is cutting support to the Austrian fleets or armies you might give, and increases the risk of you moving your Ionian fleet elsewhere, which I do believe you'd only do if you wanted to take one of my current SCs.
