      \n
      \n So apparently a unit can cut support of another unit even if this second unit is supported itself? This is a kind of thing I wish I was aware of when punching in orders.

      And now my position has deteriorated considerably! Congratulations, Bill!


      Annnd... The only place Russia can conceivably build a unit is in Sev. What's the plan there, Willows? Assuage my fears!


      Paul, congratulations. You've helped reach the point where I cannot feasibly annex Austria without your help and you getting a significant portion of it. You can now either help perpetuate the stalemate until either Russia, or, less likely, Austria breaks through and you're left with very little for all of your good deeds... Or we can split her straight down the middle. Trieste and Vienna are natural holdings for Italy, and I'm not too interested in anything beyond Serbia... Leaving Budapest an SC who's ownership should depend on the tactical situation, and which we could eventually trade back and forth depending on how the situation plays out.

      Now, I'm not trying to add pressure here, but if you refuse, I'll be forced to move a fleet into the Ionian. Simply put, the inevitable Russian build puts me on the defensive, stretching my forces thin and making me take risks, and thus making SC loss probable... Meaning I'll need *some* avenue of growth that's more likely than the now crowded Austrian front simply to be able to reliably keep my current forces working.

      Yes, I am still interested in keeping Eero contained. But I can only help you do so from a position of relative strength - which fighting on three fronts isn't. Help me out here, okay?

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n "If the supporting unit is attacked during the turn by some other unit, its support is cut. In effect, the support order becomes a hold order, as the unit must defend its province against the attack. Note that a unit occupying the province into which the support is directed cannot cut support."
      \n
      \nBut yeah - Greece was the ouch for Turkey. And the southern situation just changed quite a bit.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, I was aware of that particular rule, but I just thought that F Aegan's support would 'raise the bar' for cutting Greece's support, so to speak...

      Oh well. Live and learn! Just got to remember this next time... It certainly seems like it can be useful when on the defensive.

      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Don't worry, Daumantas. I'm still on the ropes. I wish I had thought it remotely plausible that Peter was going to leave Berlin alone, otherwise I'd have attacked from Budapest to open it up for a build. That would have improved my position immeasurably, even if only with a unit borrowed for another year. You see what use I was able to make of the one from this year! Of course, Paul's attack Ion-Gre was instrumental; even more critical was the move into Tyrolia to cut off your army's line of retreat into the Austrian hinterlands.

      Paul, Daumantas's offer only makes sense in a short term context. Clearly, you're now in a position to make short work of Austria, and even though I know you're not the sort of guy who would kick a man when he's down, let me lay out the case for staying the course. Turkey's positional advantage and Mediterranean aspirations will always be a threat to Italy; once Austria is dead, Turkey's fleet-heavy force composition make Italy the logical next target. Now, you might convince Russia to help you fight Turkey, but at that point the war in the West will be that much closer to completion, and you'll have to be fighting both east and west. But if we can convince Willow to throw some support down south right now, we might be able to beat Turkey back soon enough to face the victor of the Western Triangle together.

      Willow, Daumantas fought you to a standstill last time, but now thanks to some fortuitous circumstances (to which I like to think that I contributed) and your own intestinal fortitude, you're back on your feet. I think Paul is on my side against Turkey, and it's pretty clear that Daumantas isn't about to offer me any kind of alliance anytime soon. So are you ready for round 2?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas,

      Sorry, didn't get your message in time (it was night where I am). I am definitely open to negotiations!

      At this point, I wasn't sure what to do with that fleet, so I just wanted to keep the balance a little more even between my two Eastern neighbours for now.

      Can you tell me a little more about what you're offering me, and how it will help us in eventual dealings with Eero (and whoever else)?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Oh, I'm open to an alliance with Willows, and would sure like to see at least one of Russia's armies in Galicia - it served her well in the past, at least. It's just that the only build Willows can do is threatening my exposed backside, and I'd be forced to to take some sort of defensive measures just to keep on the safe side. I'd ask her to abstain from a build altogether, but that would be simply unwise at her part, really - while I'm not at all interested in moving there in force, I would certainly take an opportunity to retreat there if given one... And it now seems increasingly likely that I will get it.

      Paul,

      I'm certainly an interested party here, so be sure to use your own judgement on this. That said, I think these are the facts and the options you're facing:

      First,

      You are getting your builds either from France, from Turkey, or from Austria.

      France is currently no good due to her role in the western balance.

      I am a credible target if you want to rebalance the eastern part of the board. However, it would be a tough job for Italy to actually make any gains on Turkey, what with the Greece-Aegan-Eastern Med defensive line. If anyone is going to make gains, it's Russia (and if Russia isn't taking part in the attack at all, *no one* is making gains, period), or perhaps Austria. So yes, I can be 'contained', but it will be a difficult job, and you won't gain any benefit from it aside from a stronger Austria or Russia, which isn't exactly an advantage.

      Austria is a good target because it is a relativelly easy one. Together, we could crack her in two years or so, making the eastern board dynamics simpler and allowing the involved parties to move on to something on the other side of the board. The trick for you here is to manage the partitioning of Austria in such a way that would allow you to receive more or faster gains and me lesser or slower gains. I doubt you would get a better position for this than your current one.

      Second,

      Bill is right. Sooner or later, Turkish fleets are going to attack italian waters. The only question is when - right now, or when you have enough builds to get a credible defense?

      Currently, Italy has a certain diplomatical defense from Turkey granted to it by Italy's part in the western balance. However, if the situation is such that Italy's threat is greater to my continued existance than Italy's usefulness elsewhere (what good is a contained England to me if I'm in no position to take advantage of it?), that is very much void.

      Knocking out the Ionian Fleet the next year is easily accomplished, it offers me both a remarkably less complicated defense and various avenues for growth, and there is no reason not to do it if Italy plans to continue her attack against me.

      However, if Italy deems continued Turkish hostilities unnecessary and helps with the Austrian offense, the relative advantage of staying out of Italian waters becomes much greater than in them - the actual threat of Italy is temporarily removed, I get to make gains against Austria, and the western situation remains more or less stable.

      At that point, you would be strong enough to hold your own in the Med and we'd either tossle over the Balkans or move to strike other countries separetelly, depending what the general state of the board is.

      Not that very good a deal either way, but playing Italy pretty much forces you to make the best of a bad job. I wouldn't fault you whichever way you choose... But now you know what the consequences of your choice would be.


      Speaking of the general state of the board, by the way - as long as your fleet helps the french hold the line for a year or two, we'd likely be looking at something very different by the time Austria is gone. At least one of the western nations is bound to build at least one more fleet, which'll draw some of Eero's forces to it and make keeping coastal SCs more difficult, which will in turn decrease the pressure on the French fleets, which in turn... There's also the issue of the Russian armies - its doubtful that they'll see action soon, but they are currently free to position against just about anyone in range. So, the future shall be full of surprises! I for one can't wait.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      My intent is to build an army in Sevastopol. Not my first choice for where I wanted to build, but it gives me maximum flexibility in this situation. A fleet build would be useful only to annoy you- I don't have any illusions about your ability to defend yourself.

      -Willow
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Peter: to remind you of my diplomatic stance, I'm willing to stay out of the Baltic Sea indefinitely, and to retreat from the Helgoland Bight, if you'll opt to disband the Baltic fleet. That unit serves no practical purpose whatsoever except a threatened attack on Sweden and Denmark, the people of which voiced clear preference for immediate annexation into the Commonwealth of Nations this last year - no reason whatsoever for you to continue in an aggressive stance, and plenty of benefit for us both in scaling back the current hostilities. I don't even have any particular requirements regarding your French relations or whatever, I'm sure you'll draw your own conclusions on where to seek your lebensraum. A central Power like yours will be unlikely to win the game with a sit-and-wait attitude, and you're not gaining anything by aggravating me, so it seems to me to only make sense to listen to the voice of reason on this. You could easily free up 2-3 armies for an actually effective offensive somewhere else by taking my peace; A Bel and A Kie (bouncing in Holland) are sufficient against trivial stabs from Denmark or the North Sea in perpetuity, if that's the sort of thing that worries you.

      Paul: I know that it's useful for you if the Turk really desists from attacking you navally due to your perceived support for the French defensive efforts, but I think you should know what Daumantas probably does: France does not need your help in reality, as I do not have a sufficient force for actually seizing any French possessions or extending my influence into Italian territory - our current war is a mummery with little meaning, and there is no strategic advantage for me in pushing fleets to the Mediterranean without credible targets and the constant danger of a French breakthrough to the Atlantic. Therefore my current stance is one of static defense, and while I would prefer to perform this defense on the Mid-Atlantic due to security reasons, the position in itself would be of no offensive advantage whatsoever against a France capable of occupying both Portugal and Spain with fleets. I don't mind you supporting Daniel at MAO, of course, but do be careful of Daumantas; I don't believe he's as interested in this purported anti-English coalition as he claims. At least, were I playing Turkey here, I would definitely pay lip service to the convenient French scheme to get the jump on Italy.

      Again, I'd be pleased to pick apart any tactical concerns in detail if any one of you actually has irrational fears regarding the potency of the English in doing anything proactive whatsoever anywhere on the board. Personally I do not see a single supply center on the board that the English are capable of seizing in 1907 from others, so this whole idea of blockading England from an imminent victory seems extremely far-fetched.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow,

      Perhaps I could convince you to not build there after all, then?

      It doesn't seem like you would need that army for any offensive manouvers. Defensive ones are also unnecessary (minus the obvious turkish fleet issue, more on which later), or at least wouldn't be helped by a build in Sev. Meaning, you are essentially free to put that build to use a year later in one of your more westward centers without much threat.

      Now, as for defense against me... In the short term, an army in Sev does provide some measure of protection, but it might bog us both down in the long. As long as you build a unit in Sev, I will very like build one in Ankara and then order it to Armenia just in case. You would then either order your army to Armenia and we'd have a bounce (increasing tension on both our sides), or you would get both Armenia and Rumania to border you. In which case, you would probably (quite reasonably) react to this as an attack, and commit one of your other armies to Sev's defense.

      In short, our border would get crowded again and we'd both be back to growling at each other angrily while commiting units to a frontline which won't budge in either direction.

      If you promise to make no build in Sev, though, I'd be able to make one in Const, bolstering up my Austrian lines with no mounting threat to you.

      And, since not having to commit two units to defense is immensely more useful to me than gaining a single build, if you would not make a build in Sev, I would make an unconditional promise (that is, no matter what the situation on my other fronts is, no matter how hurting for a build I am, and etc) to not attack Sev or otherwise try to claim it for at least a year, renewable next year, if you want it, on similar terms - no builds or armies in Sev.

      There is a slight risk on my side - if you build something in Sev and I in Const, I might be unable to stop the Sev unit's run into Armenia and beyond... But, while that would certainly cost me momentum, I would probably be able to defend against that at a not too large cost, so I'm willing to take this as long as I get your word for it.

      Sound okay?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero,

      You're right - I'm no longer worried about a solo victory on the part of the English, but that is precisely because of what you are currently trying to unmake - an alliance and coordinated defense efforts between Germany and France (and possibly Russia?). The situation is still such that, were those defense efforts to crumble and either of the continental powers turned on the other, you would be in position to make relativelly more gains than either of the two sides, and even more if you don't see it necessary to lay off of whoever your notional ally would then be...

      As long as you're free from counterattack, you're not nearly as diplomatically bound as the rest of us, freeing up your hands for all sorts of shennanigans as soon as there's an opening. Turkey will immediatelly forget about the whole english issue as soon as there is a credible european fleet in the water, but as for now, a little restraint now and then to allow others to keep you neatly bottled is certainly not out of the question for Turkey.

      And, while France would certainly be able to defend against the english right now, she would not be able to stop an english fleet from entering the Med - which would be not that important right now, but would be a very important wildcard later in the game. And hell, Iberia surrounded by the English? Sooner or later the French will slip, and England gets her inpermeable defense all over the western waters. I like all of my western powers evenly matched, thank you very much!


      That said - yes, there are issues that Turkey is more interested in, namely either reducing the total number of fronts she has to fight on or, failing that, achieving a more defensible position.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      I'm quite surprised you disbanded your army afield- I would have thought an additional unit in the Balkans would be vital.

      I have scrabbled hard to get back up to four centers- giving up my build is completely out of the question. However, in the interests of mutual security, I am willing to perform an arranged bounce in Armenia, keeping it empty, and who knows? If you build A Smy, You may have some very interesting choices for convoy targets in the fall.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Turkey and England are the top dogs at 6 centers each, with France and Austria holding at 5 (though the later is besieged and has only 4 units), and everyone else at 4. It's a real nail-biter of a game, diplomacy fans!
      \n
      \n
      \n

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

      \n What do the coloured circles mean in that diagram of powers? I can't quite decipher it.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The colour of the circles doesn't mean much, I think. It's just their position that's important. Look at the colour of the lines - they're more or less identical to the colours of the nations on the map.


      Also note how clustered together everyone is in terms of total SCs owned! This is much like year 1901, with the small change that there are now no unowned SCs.

      I can tell this is going to be a frustrating year for everybody. Find some soothing music and ready some hot coco - otherwise, you might just find yourself frothing in the mouth at some point!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yeah, the circle colors have no meaning.
      \n
      \n"A unit may not retreat to an "embattled" province, meaning one left vacant by a bounce/standoff that turn." - Which explains England not taking Kiel.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n So, Willows...

      I've slept on the whole build-in-Sev issue, and apparently my subconscious has it that you wouldn't be reacting in such a way to a request not to build there unless you already had plans for the unit. And since there's not much for you to do there aside from either gunning for turkish home SCs, which probably isn't going to work, or going for Rumania, I'm assuming that that's what you're going to try and take.

      If that's the case - be my guest, I certainly can't stop you. In fact, I certainly wouldn't be against just letting you in there - the fleet doesn't do much for me there, and a Russian army would be just dandy.

      Of course, that leaves me short of a build, so I'd only like to ask that we coordinate an attack on Budapest/Serbia as well. You get two builds, I... well, I manage to stay afloat in the game. Certainly better than losing both Rumania and okay-ish russian relations as they are now.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I've got to say, playing Italy is a lot more confusing than playing Turkey (the only other country I've tried). Any advice (biased or un-) would be appreciated!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nVernon R \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul, I'm not an expert on Diplomacy but I recently drew them in a game on play diplomacy and am doing well so far, your situtation here with open diplomacy might make it tougher. The problem I see with Italy is that you cant make gains very easily because you are so stuck in the middle but on the outside. Your best bet is to be fairly passive and supportive of your neighbors. Be friends with everyone and look to take advantage once things start to fall apart. You dont want to initiate war with anyone you want to help others finish someone off and take small gains that keep you secure.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul -- Here's my honest read on your situation. Right now you are no one's primary target: France is oriented northward, toward England, as is Germany; Austria is increasingly more rapidly being smothered by Turkey, who is content to focus on one foe at a time. England has her shields up, and Russia its eying up its near abroad for targets. That will change as things elsewhere on the board get resolved, and so you want to position yourself to (a) get builds and (b) influence the resolution of conflicts elsewhere on the board.

      Now, Daumantas has suggested that he's willing for you to participate in the dismantling of Austria--that's the carrot. The stick is that he'll come charging into the Ionian sooner rather than later if you don't. However, Turkey is also worried about a newly muscular Russia edging into the Balkans, and his build of an army rather than a fleet suggests that he's interested in shoring up his northern frontier at the very least. The French "nuclear option" of stepping aside and letting England through the Straits of Gibraltar is also only going to be a dissuasion for so long.

      So I think that you want to put your finger on the scale on the eastern side of things. You need to tap Trieste with one of those armies. The other one could support you in--but maybe you'd rather maneuver. A purely defensive maneuver would be Tyr-Tri, Ven-Apu (letting you defend the peninsula in case Turkey does decide to come west). Alternately, you could order Ven-Tri, Tyr-Boh, which gives you a nice central position from which to cast your eyes around. It would give you some leverage over Russia and Germany, and more leverage over me--not, frankly, that you need it.

      The army in Trieste can either hold (at which point I'm forced to disband a fleet that you then rebuild) or attack through to reach the front lines. The other army can continue to maneuver, feint in some direction perhaps, and perhaps help out in the big showdown in the north. Meanwhile, the fleet in the Western Med is supernumerary; bring it back to Tunis so that if Daumantas wants to force the Ionian he can't be sure whether he needs two fleets or three, and if he does decide to break through this turn you're in a position to cover all your exposed SCs in the fall.

      -- Bill

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n It's a game of rock paper scissors in the far east. Anyone attacking in any direction opens vulnerabilities from another.
      \n
      \nThat surprise "no-retreating into the place you were attacked from" rule certainly shook things up. Turkey was poised to kill Austria, and now it's anybody's guess which way Turkey will go. The Russian build in sev was no surprise, and it's not just an anti-Turkey build. That army can move northward to fill in the gaps from Russian movings in other direction. Not building would have put Russia at a disadvantage everywhere,
      \n
      \nDepending on what Austria thinks is going to happen, Galicia could be a possible move for them. It hands them nice choices in two directions, and allows them to build if Germany does not recapture Berlin. Another possibility would be to vacate Trieste in the spring or fall, and keep it clear with a bounce from other places.
      \n
      \nIn the west, Germany is working on recapturing it's own SC's, while not loosing territories. It makes it a little tricky in that there are five territories they would need covered/taken, but only four units. Also Munich is vulnerable to Italy, and would be a pain for Germany to retake with English fleets to the north.
      \n
      \n-
      \n
      \n@Paul, with the unexpected events in Austria you need to get your fleet back pronto. Attacking you has suddenly become a much more attractive option for Turkey. I appreciate the help. You've saved the Mediterranean for Mediterraneaners and kept yourself in the running for winning/surviving the game. (PS: You'll also want to keep an army in Venice this spring. Losing Venice would take you out of the game now because it would be almost impossible for you to retake.)
      \n
      \n@Eero - My fleets aren't moving north.
      \n
      \n@Peter - Your most important priority this turn is to keep the things you've got. Bel, Hol, Keil, Mun. Priority two would be to retake Berlin. Three, nice to get it if you can, would be to arrange the fall so that you can build in Keil. If you want, I could move to Burgundy in the spring which would in the fall let me be able to either support you in Bel, support you back into Munich, or mutual bounce in Munch. Just a word from you though, and I won't make that move. Let me know.
      \n
      \n@Daumantas - I know Fleet Ionian has been a PITA, and cramps your style much. I'd appreciate your non attacking the Ionian this spring with two fleets. After the spring, I'd still not prefer it, but I wouldn't feel obligated about responding to it.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      Would you care for an arranged bounce in Armenia? Or would you prefer to cede Rumania peacefully to me now, and prepare for a joint attack on Austria's holdings in the fall. I quite like any plan that gets me two builds. However, any funny stuff, and I will be certain to instead lend my support to Austria, helping his units in the fall.

      -Willow



      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daniel,

      Quite right. Now that Eero's disbanded a fleet (I assume; maybe I missed it moving away somewhere while I wasn't paying attention to the game), my support isn't needed, so I'll find something else for that fleet to do.

      Bill,

      Do you really not see any Austria-friendly opportunities for Italy? What would you like to see me do?

      For instance, I would love to see your fleet in Albania again, and it would help you push your weight around Greece and/or the Ionian. Can you offer me anything in exchange for agreeing to stay out of Trieste?







      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas,

      If we were to collaborate against Austria, what would that look like? How could we guarantee that it would be a fair deal? At this point I see the fall of Austria is more beneficial to you than to me (which is why I supported Bill in the last year), but I have very little experience with Diplomacy, and my thoughts are guesses at best.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Daniel,

      Quite right. Now that Eero's disbanded a fleet (I assume; maybe I missed it moving away somewhere while I wasn't paying attention to the game), my support isn't needed, so I'll find something else for that fleet to do.

      Bill,

      Do you really not see any Austria-friendly opportunities for Italy? What would you like to see me do?

      For instance, I would love to see your fleet in Albania again, and it would help you push your weight around Greece and/or the Ionian. Can you offer me anything in exchange for agreeing to stay out of Trieste?

      \nPaul -- I would argue that moving an Italian army to Trieste is a critical move for you and not actually that hostile to me. If Turkey gobbles me up (heh), and your units are still sitting in Italy, you are in a bad position and I'm in a worse one, with no one there to help me. On the other hand, if you're in Trieste, you have influence over what happens: you can attack out, provide support to my beleaguered inland forces, and do all sorts of other nifty stuff. The way I look at it, I'm trading a (red) fleet for a (green) army--it's all about boots on the ground, baby. That's why I'd suggest Ven-Tri. I'd also suggest Tyr-Boh, because you heard Willow talk about joining up with Turkey to do some damage to me; an army in Boh lets you contribute to that discussion. The build you're likely to get makes you more defensible both from the east and from the west. Fuck Daniel's suggestion about covering Venice; the only force that can reach that SC is mine, in your line of march, and needs to get out of the way. If we can convince Willow that cracking Austria won't actually be all that easy now that you're in the game, maybe the three of us can combine against Turkey. And then we will see what we can see. -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul,

      To be honest, this would not be so much a collaboration as a rivalry - who gobbles up more Austria faster. This turn, you should definitelly take Trieste if Bill's just giving it to you, while simultaneously putting (or keeping) yourself in position to support yourself into Vienna next year. You should also probably pull back from the French (unless you think you can weasel into Spain and are very very eager to show everyone that you and me are in cahoots) and defend Tunisia...

      So next turn, you are free to do just about anything you like - support Austria if you think you can't get Vienna, and get Vienna if you think you can. With Bill so eager, you are in prime position to use him to your advantage - having him pull all of his forces against me, a natural enough reaction - and get a slice of Austria to call your very own while simultaneously making it impossible for me to get any gains easily.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow,

      After thinking about it again, it seems doubtful that you'd be able to gain two builds this year - owning Galicia is a prerequisite and Bill can counter that very easily. So the only use you actually get from our agreement is me ceding Rumania without a fight - I'd then ask you to attack Budapest so I could attack Serbia.

      So gaining Rumania now is of no immediate use to you and of some eventual use to me.

      If you are fine with that, then yes, sure, no funny stuff.

      If you are not fine with that, then a bounce in Armenia and I'll be obliged to put up some sort of futile fight (succesful only if I can convice Bill that a Russia is a bigger threat to him than Turkey is in the long run, and that he should leave Bulgaria alone) over Rumania in the fall.


      It all comes down to how good a price you're putting on an okay-ish relationship with Turkey, which, since I can't really can't seem to get a read on you, is only for you to know.

      Everything is currently setup for a bounce, which is the safer short-term option for Turkey. But I'll be online straight up to the time that orders are parsed, so I can adjust them once you tell me which way you want to go.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      I'm obviously losing momentum here, and can easily end up losing an SC this year without anything to balance it. At which point, you will likely try and push against me - which is understandable, of course, but I am fairly certain that I could put up a good fight with whatever unit count I have. At that point, you will likely experience a bit of austrian claustrophobia, when you are surrounded from all sides by allies who you can't quite attack because you need their help against Turkey.

      That time, unlike right now, when neither of us really has anything useful to say to each other, would probably be a good time to discuss common interests.

      'till then!
      \n

      France allowing England through the Mid-Atlantic into the Med at a point when England has allowed for French-English fleet parity?

      I'd like to see you try.

      Paul: do that Trieste thing, it's the best Austro-Italian move for setting up a superior force concentration in the Balkans. Also consider Munich - not to hold, but it's an extra unit for a year. Keep Austria alive and try for naval supremacy at any cost, that's the Italian way.

      We'll soon see how this turn goes.

      \n Of course, however, I am aware that this:\n
      Posted By: Bill_WhitePaul -- Notice that id you'd moved Wes-Tun, you could now retreat to Naples and then in the fall possibly order Nap-TyS, Tun-TyS to prevent a Turkish end run on Rome. -- Bill

      • \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n That was pretty interesting all around. The Italian situation is something of a morality on Diplomacy in a way - to me it says that you should always worry of your own nest first, as the western situation Italy chose to get concerned over in fact never was going anywhere (I'll say this again after the game if somebody is still doubting my estimate), while Turkey was certainly waiting for the opportunity. Now it'll be fighting time in the east, as Turkey's put Italy to the defensive and Russia joins the war against the musulman threat!

      Regarding the western situation, I should clarify that the current English policy, as explained earlier, is to disengage and allow my southern neighbours to feel like they have the freedom to truly consider the situation objectively; I'll be glad to receive word from either of those worthies when and if they've decided that I'm not that awful after all - not larger, not more powerful, and not even morally degenerate in any way a Diplomacy player shouldn't be.

      St. Petersburg, meanwhile, continues its time-share arrangement between the Russian and English empires, which I trust won't cause any undue difficulty for the Czarinna. Willow: I'll make the claim with a fleet, so don't feel obliged to mess your southern tactics this coming turn over this; I'm just loaning the place for that bit of extra zing, not preparing for a weird Russian assault.

      Peter: I understand that you've stopped talking to me and all, but I can't help pointing out that you're a smidge exposed on your undercarriage there, if you know what I mean. Your call as to how to react, as always.

      Daniel: MAO-Bre, Eng-MAO, Spa-MAO, probably no need to say more.

      That tactical situation in the Mediterranean is delightful, here's how I see it going: Italy covers the threatened SCs and therefore builds one while moving south with the Venetian army; Austria and Italy set up an infantry line against Turkey (and Russia), while Russia allies with the Turk, maybe, or opts to ally with the others for the demise of Turkey (slow, that - much faster gains against Austria, probably). In the winter Italy builds a third fleet in Rome, and then starts the slow push back: once the new fleet gets to the Tyrhenian Sea Italy can force Turkey out of the Ionian without allowing the unit to slip through the line to the Tyrhenian.

      Meanwhile Turkey has many interesting options. I'm especially considering a quick convoy of the Smyrna fleet to the Balkans - an excellent move if Russia's on-board against Austria, but potentially fatal otherwise. The Ionian fleet does not need a support, really, as it's an open question whether Turkey would want it on the Adriatic or Tyrhenian anyway. Turkey is clearly stymied if the Austro-Italian alliance holds and Russia doesn't join Turkey, so we might see a simple wilting of the Turkish fortunes. Definitely lots to talk about amongst the old enemies with the Black Sea between them.

      Ultimately I'd say that Austria and Italy have managed to stabilize their situation in a way that makes them, united, dominant in the east, capable of fighting the Turk back ever so slowly. However, their alliance might not last if Italy perceives more utility in independence, and Russia might well find reason to throw her weight on the Turkish side to prevent Austria from recovering - as it is, Austria alone is weak, which is definitely to the advantage of the Czarinna as she considers the new extend of her domain.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Oh, the dance, the beautiful dance!

      If only I didn't have two left feet.
      \n

      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Of course, however, I am aware that this:

      Posted By: Bill_WhitePaul -- Notice that if you'd moved Wes-Tun, you could now retreat to Naples and then in the fall possibly order Nap-TyS, Tun-TyS to prevent a Turkish end run on Rome. -- Bill
      \n...is really not for my benefit, but rather an attempt to draw Daumantas into moving West rather than concentrating on Austria.

      What a bizarre but interesting game this is.

      Jesus. I practically have to twist your arm to give you one of my SCs, and this is the kind of crap I have to take? Did you think Daumantas wasn't going to think of Ion-TyS himself? I wasn't the one who told him to go after the Ionian; he came up with that on his own. And now that you've got the care and feeding of Trieste, Ion-Adr is less scary to me than it once would have been (although still a concern). Frankly, Eas-Ion is the first sign I've seen in a long time that Turkey wasn't single-mindedly bent on Austrian destruction; it gives me hope for some kind of (albeit admittedly temporary) rapprochement, which could ultimately redound to both our benefit.

      What I would like Army Trieste to do is either (1) Tri S Ser (i.e., support Serbia to hold) or (2) Tri-Alb (i.e., attack through to Albania). Roll a d6, 1-3 Tri S Ser, 4-6 Tri-Alb. Depending on Daumantas' maneuverings, either course may find you still in Trieste in the fall, at which point my fleet essentially changes colors. If not, my fleet is at your disposal.

      Hey, Daumantas, I have the image of one of those action-movie scenes where two guys are wrestling for the gun--if one of them gets it, he's going to shoot the other, bang. But then a third guy shows up with a machine gun, and he's going to shoot them both. So how about we call a truce, and I help you maneuver against Russia? Think about it: T:Rum-Bla, T:Bul-Rum, A:Ser S Bul-Rum, T: Smy-Arm, and you've got a 2-on-1 attack on Sevastopol in the spring. Meanwhile, Russia loses StP and doesn't get Rum and is down to 3 units this winter. Both of our positions are improved considerably--yours more than mine, of course, but mine too.

      Willow: Obviously I'm just kidding with Daumantas, trying to sucker him into not attacking me for another turn. I have no interest in seeing you debilitated once again after I worked so hard to save you from Germany. Don't worry; my unit in Budapest is going to support A Sev into Rumania, which should leave you at 4 SCs after you lose StP and Daumantas either down 1 or steady depending on how things break in the Balkans. Of course, if you want to keep Rumania, you have to stay the fuck out of Galicia; that shit I do not need again.
      \n

      \nSorry about that - I suppose I could be speaking over my own head. This game certainly makes one a little... paranoid. But whether it was intentional or not, pointing it out now, after the fact, is very much to your advantage. To wit:

      Daumantas,

      As I see it, sending that fleet after Italian territory puts it more or less out of action. I can defend successfully against it, at least for a short time. Unless you're planning to push through towards France, I suppose.

      However, do consider that having your fleet in range of Italy's shores, while unlikely to gain you another SC, *does* make it much much less likely that I'll move against Austria (as that would mean exposing my backside to you). If you want to encourage me to play defensively (in which case there's little I can do except support Austria in place)... well, I'm curious why.

      \n Paul -- No, I'm totally being strategic, but I don't want you to misunderstand the strategy. I wasn't trying to throw you under the bus from Turkey; I was trying to convey the idea that my tactical advice was sounder than Daniel's.

      Why would I want to do that? Because it's not clear to me whether Mar-Pie was an opportunistic incursion in the expectation of Tyr-Boh leaving Venice undefended, or the expression of a sincere if ill-conceived alarm about an Austrian attack on Italy, but either way I don't trust him, and I want you to be disposed to evaluate his advice rather critically. -- Bill

      \n Daniel,

      I trust you.

      Bill,

      In the absence of any interesting offers (and a rather hostile approach, possibly) from Daumantas, I don't have much to do this turn but to support you. You have nothing to fear from me this turn. Good luck! We'll see if it's enough.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Incidentally, I'm very curious to see where this game will go - I find it hard to predict what will happen next.

      The absence of hidden communication makes it difficult for anyone to grow quickly and decisively (although Eero had a good run at it for a moment there!).

      What do you figure the chances we're doomed to an eternal seven-way stalemate? None of us seem to be too happy to let any one player dominate, and I'm guessing open alliances might generate the same kind of all-around fear and inspire their neighbours to turn against them. From what little I know, gunboat games take longer than regular games. Might this experiment be even more stable?

      Any which way, though, it's fun for me to be playing this game with you and learning from all of you. Thanks!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n

      \n Bill,

      I'm not sure why you didn't try for Greece from Albania. The current position of your fleet rather suggests aggression towards Italy... what are you planning there?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul -- I should have ordered Alb-Gre supported by Ser, it's true, but I thought it wouldn't work, since Daumantas has been pretty careful to support Gre up to now. My thinking was that T:Ion-Adr would be a crimp in our defense, since Alb-Tri would prevent Tri S Ser. So I gambled on Alb-Adr, hoping for a bounce; additionally, if you didn't order Tri S Ser but instead ordered Tri-Alb (as per my suggestion to roll a die), then if Daumantas successfully attacked Serbia, I'd have somewhere to retreat. You have to remember, my expectation was that I'd be disbanding a unit this year, and I wanted to make sure that I ended up with three armies on the board. I didn't think I'd have a fleet in the Adriatic past the winter. You are right to be cagey, though: once bitten, twice shy. But I am clearly pointing away from you now, and in fact attacking you at this juncture would leave me open to opportunistic attacks from all directions. My hope is that you will see the wisdom of our continued alliance for the immediate future, and its benefit to you in giving you scope to maneuver. -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1\u20266789101112\u202619\xbb

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      That makes some sense. In exchange, I'm happy to sit where I am, with no threat to Vienna from my "people". I could be talked into eventually moving South to Greece out of Trieste, as well.

      In the meantime, looks like you might have some interesting negotiating to do with Willow on your other "front"...
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul -- Sitting in Vienna is exactly what you should not do; that's like the parable of the talents, where the foolish servant buries the money instead of investing it. "Defending" Trieste is a losing proposition; you need to move that army to where it can help produce more SCs for our alliance. Army Trieste needs to either move south into Albania to put pressure on Turkey or north to Tyrolia to influence things in the center. If you're just going to sit still you're as good as cutting my throat--and yours too, eventually, so I'm appealing to your enlightened self-interest as well. You're seeing threats where you should be seeing opportunities. -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n I follow you, Bill. That makes sense, now that you point it out.

      Daumantas,

      How are you seeing our three-way situation in the corner at this point? I could be talked into some interesting options for you if you'd consider disbanding your fleet Ionian.

      ...


      Italy sure is a confusing country to play: there are very few obvious avenues of gain, and thus it's very hard to formulate any clear strategy.
      \n

      \n

      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul,

      While I am certainly willing to grant you the Ionian, it is mostly because it is already yours, in a way - you get a third fleet to my two and knock me out of there effortlessly. Disbanding army Armenia would be much more useful politically and possibly strategically, too.

      Similarly, whether or not you keep Trieste occupied, Bill can reclaim it - the only issue is how many units he will be forced to put up for that task.

      The only interesting option you can give me that I see is letting me have Serbia (either in exchange for Greece or out of the goodness of your heart or because you really should cut down the number of Austrian units next to Trieste to two). That means you would be giving up alliance with Bill, though, so I'm not holding my breath. Not because that would be a bad deal for you, but rather because you don't seem to be the about-face kind of guy.

      These are just data points, though. I am too scatter-minded to whip up a coherent narrative/strategic vision right now.

      Willows,

      I'd like to ally with you and work out what scarce options of cooperation we have (we basically need Italy's cooperation for attacks on Austria to reliably work), but, when I look back, I see you taking shots at Turkey whenever you could, and I *don't* see you ever adopting rhetoric in which Turkey was anything more than an obstacle, either troublesome or irrelevant.

      Given that we'd have to work together over multiple turns, that seems like a bad track record.

      Tell me that I'm wrong?


      Bill,

      Would you trust me if I said I'd leave Serbia alone if you were to vacate it?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hey Daumantas --

      Why don't you disband Army Greece and then support F Ion there during the spring from the Aegean? Then if you use Bulgaria to support Ser-Rum, it'll be empty in the spring. With the fleet build you'll get from taking Sevastopol in the fall, you'll easily be able to restore a defensive line in the Med.

      Think about it.

      -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      Frankly, we got off to a bad start, and had a relationship soured by mutual mistrust. But in all practicality, any immediate gains I'm likely to have are going to have to come from Austria- and the unit in Galicia makes me as nervous as mine did Bill.

      If you disband that Armenian army (and it sounds like you'd like to anyways), I'd be willing to support you into Serbia, and we'd have a regular Juggernaut ready to go.

      Bill-

      Of course, if Daumantas isn't on board with that, my unit in Rumania will be at your disposal.

      -Willow
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow -- I appreciate that; Daumantas is one tough customer. If Army Greece disbands, Rum S Ser-Bul will help me; if it doesn't, Rum S Ser will take some of the pressure off of Sevastopol, since Turkey will have to use the fleet in the Black Sea to launch a spoiling attack on Rumania if he's at all interested in an attack on Serbia. -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      I'll take that as a no.

      Willows,

      Okay then! I'm assuming a build in Warsaw, then? Would you consider A Rum-Bud in the spring? You would already have a strong enough force to take Galicia without use of that unit, and there is no way I could take advantage of that move (barring the not too likely event of knowingly receiving support to Serbia from the Italian and Austria not doing anything to cut it).

      Paul,

      If you were to now build a an army in Rome, you'd have a continental force capable of manouvering, keeping your current holdings, and having a shot at Vienna (take Tyrolia while covering Venice with the Rome army, basically). If you do so, I would immediatelly remove myself from the Ionian, which we would then hopefully be able to keep demilitarized.

      My other request would be for you to not have army Trieste either move Turkey-wards or support Serbia in place. This is useful to you, but only indirectly - Bill is very likely to try to reclaim Trieste this year, and you want to lower the Austrian to Italian unit ratio.

      These are two separate offers, mind. Getting both would be pretty great, but getting only either of them would work out too.

      Bill,

      I would love to ally up with you at this juncture (mostly because your position is uncertain and common moves would likely leave parts of your lands open) but I'm sure that if I even tried, you would swiftly use such statements of mine to to help bolster one or another non-turkish eastern alliance. Good job at that by this speculative you, but that's not happening! So hah!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      but I'm sure that if I even tried, you would swiftly use such statements of mine to to help bolster one or another non-turkish eastern alliance. Good job at that by this speculative you, but that's not happening! So hah!

      \n
      \n [OOC: It's a snow day here on the US East Coast. The mail got through, but nothing else.]
      \n
      \n@Paul, what happens next turn in your sphere comes down to the Russian build. If they build in Sev, they can keep Sev and Romainia. If they don't Russia could loose both. So russia will probably build there.
      \n
      \nThis means that the only territory Austria can take is Tre. I'd expect that to happen from the Adriatic sea, or Vienna. So make your build with that in mind.
      \n
      \n@Peter. Last fall I was expecting you to do Hol->Kiel, Kiel -> Berlin, Bal -> Kiel. That would have handed you Berlin, and put you in a great place. Oh well. You are still in the game, though. I'm moving to Burgandy in the spring, and can help you retake Munich, if Russia moves there in the spring.
      \n
      \n@Eero, I'd like to continue our relationship of vigilant but sparse border watching and mutual distrust.
      \n

      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      I don't have anything to lose by transparency, so yes, I'm willing to build Warsaw to facilitate a Juggernaut. Rum-Bud is doable.

      Everyone-

      I'm currently accepting "advice" on what I should do with my A Silesia. So many delightful possibilities!

      -Willow

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hey... just to make sure I'm following along and understanding the rules correctly:

      Willow, why are we all talking about you getting a build? Do you get one this turn? I don't understand why. I thought you gained Rumania but lost StP.

      What am I missing?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nGrover \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The army in StP disbanded instead of retreating.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The SC count vs. unit count for builds purposes is made immediately before the build orders, and therefore after the retreats. If you disband an unit in the fall retreats, it doesn't count against your unit count and thus you'll often get to rebuild it elsewhere. In this case Russia has only three units on board and four SCs (three home SCs and Rumania), so it's build-time in Kreml all over again despite the overall downturn. This sort of pro-technique is good for making rabid reversals from one theater of operations to another.

      Turkey had a similar option with the fleet, note - could've removed that on retreat so as to effectively make his disband before everybody else, thus potentially gaining in trust from Russia by proving his intent to disarm on that flank. Perhaps Russia wants to get rid of that army in Armenia more, or Turkey wants to move the fleet to join the Mediterraneans, or he just prefers to keep it around to keep Russia honest. I know I'd keep the fleet if I was the only Power with one on the Black Sea.

      Daniel, yes: seems that this is working for us. Just take care to not fall behind!

      I find that Daumantas is right about the Italian tactical situation in that a third army would be full of opportunity and sparky mayhem, indeed. It's strategically tricky, though; an Italy intent on snuffing Austria better be sure that there is no firm Russo-Turkish alliance in the offing, as otherwise he'll be pretty quick to find that those two will easily overwhelm him in a fight over the Balkans. Basically Italy has the opposite requirements from what Russia would want from Turkey as an ally: A Turkey allied with Italy shouldn't put more than two fleets on the Mediterranean, at most, and even those should ideally be kept at home port; as long as such a Turk focused on building armies and expanding around the Black Sea regions and towards Russia, Italy would have relatively safe prospects for a mid- to long-term alliance. The fundamental problem is that the alliance is not really very profitable for Italy unless he's confidently seizing the Austrian home SCs at the least, but if he's doing that, then the Turk will find very limited benefit in trading an Austrian presence on his border for an Italian one; the border is just as difficult to keep peaceful with Italy on the other side as it is with Austria, and the Balkans simply are not very feasibly divided, especially not vertically. So the long-term strategic cooperation bears thinking about, it's not nearly as obvious as it is with Austria+Italy or Russia+Turkey.

      Mostly as a matter of curiousity, my own play with Italy in this sort of situation might be to talk the Turk into retreating in exchange for me not building a third fleet (a reasonable trade, that), after which I'd use my new-found army strength in opportunistic foreign adventures for a little while. Three armies would allow me to keep one in Trieste supporting the line with the Austrian while another goes for Munich and a third for Marseilles, to pick an arbitrary example. Or, perhaps more interesting, I could send armies on the Italian "long march" towards Warsaw, that seems to always get a surprisingly good reception. Something marginal and relatively neutral towards my main neighbours, and something that keeps my forces close enough to recall in a couple of turns so that when they do seize something and I get more builds, I'll have a tempo advantage when I attack my real target from all sides at once.

      A third army would also be pretty solid in an anti-Turkish play, assuming I managed to convince the Turk to retreat from the Ionian: occupy Albania and the Ionian, then make a bid for Greece with Austrian support. It's not like Italy needs a third fleet for anything if the Turk is willing to retreat from the Ionian environs.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n

      \n
      \nTurkey and Russia turn west!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The one thing I'll say about this public negotiation: It always makes for unusual communications--key element Diplomacy.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Let's take a look at where some of the various nations might get their next SCs:

      France:
      From England: MAO-Nat, Spa-MAO, some sort of convoy to the English mainland- except this is just what the Liverpool build defends against.
      From Germany: Par-Pic, Mar-Bur sets up an attack on Belgium and/or Munich, Par S Mar-Bur sets up for an attack on just Munich but certainly secures Burgundy.
      From Italy: Spa-West Med, Mar-Spa sets up for a convoy to Tunis, or a convoy to North Africa followed by support next turn- rather unwieldy.
      Mar-Pied just doesn't have the force to bust through.

      Italy:
      From Austria: Pretending to offer support, while instead moving Ven-Tyr to take Vienna, then being into position to attack Budapest
      From Germany: Ven-Tyr to make an opportunistic play for Munich.
      From Turkey: Take Ionian with Austrian support, then try to convoy into Greece.
      From France: Move fleets west (Tun-West Med, Nap-TYR, in fall take Gulf of Lyons). Very slow, opens to Turkey.

      Germany:
      From France: Bel-Bur (or Pic) for an opportunistic raid, but Hol-Ruhr or Kiel-Mun are important for a real attack... but completely open Germany to attack by England.
      From England: Keil-Den (with S from BAL) or BAL-Den/Swe, and hoping he catches Eero with his pants down.
      From Austria: Kie-Ber. Easy and simple, but that HEL fleet's still there.
      From Russia: BAL could convoy to Livonia. An attack on Moscow has all the potential downsides of the attack on Berlin, and none of the advantages.

      Austria:
      From Russia: An attack on Rumania has a good chance of success. Hard to make much progress after that, though.
      From Turkey: ADR-Alb to threaten Greece? Attack Bulgaria by going through Rumania first?
      From Italy: Austria has three units next to Trieste, and then would have two next to Venice, or could convoy to Apulia.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hah! Every eastern country but Italy has a unit in retreat.

      The eastern situation seems rather... jumbled, currently.

      The west seems rather more clear-cut. Eero can strike nigh anywhere without much in the form reprecussion... And the only shot at countering it (a long shot at that) is France getting a fleet in the North Atlantic, thus getting behind enemy lines. That's a dangerous move for France all around, though, and if she tries, she'll like try to get another fleet in the water... In other words, Munich? In other words, hastening the decline of the German?

      Well I guess the west problems are just as muddled.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, I'm learning a little more about this game.

      Daumantas,

      I just figured out what your support action was for! That's a neat little tactic I've never seen before. Cool.

      That said, I can't say I'm terribly happy when it comes to our prospects of working together:\n
      Posted By: DWeirdIf you were to now build a an army in Rome, you'd have a continental force capable of manouvering [...] If you do so, I would immediatelly remove myself from the Ionian
      \nI thought you were more trustworthy than that.

      Bill,

      Is there a way to scrape together a mutually-beneficial situation out what's going on in your country? If so, I'm willing to support you.

      Daniel,

      Glad to see we're maintaing friendly relations! Good luck with your fight over there.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul --\n
      Posted By: Paul T.
      Posted By: DWeird
      If you were to now build a an army in Rome, you'd have a continental force capable of manouvering [...] If you do so, I would immediatelly remove myself from the Ionian

      I thought you were more trustworthy than that.
      \nOy vey. Here's the thing about Daumantas, Paul: He'll only do what you make him do. Once you built that army, why should he just sail home? He has no reason to, since he can just wait for your fleets to attack and then slip past them into the Tyrrhenian. And that is absolutely correct play on his part; anything else would have been foolish sentiment.

      Speaking of which, I expect that after this year, my remaining forces will be merely adjunct to yours. Let's see what happens with the retreats, and then we can discuss the options.

      -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.I thought you were more trustworthy than that.
      \nI, er, yes, hmm.

      Paul! I thought we had agreed to leave the Ionian demilitarized! Why would you breach my trust in such a way?

      I salute your attempt at aggression, however. You have various options open to you still! It's a bit of a dance, but what you're facing now is no more than a minor impediment... You now do your best to try and keep it from snowballing.

      Bill,

      I've pretty much gotten everything I can off of Austria's region of influence, and won't be going beyond Serbia. The rest of Austria, as it seems, is pegged for either Italy or Russia. A friendly Russia is more important to me than a non-dead Austria, so won't be of much help in that, but if you want some kind of action plan against Italy, that could certainly be arranged.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      But only one of the retreats is actually in question, is that not so? (Just trying to understand the rules, here.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas,

      I'm enjoying your banter! Although I can only interpret your message above as a clear statement of intent: that Italy is Turkey's next target. Is that so?\n
      Posted By: DWeirdPaul! I thought we agree to leave the Ionian demilitarized! Why would you breach my trust in such a way?
      \nThis is a good try, Daumantas, but not really on point. I never agreed to such a plan (as you will find for yourself if you review our correspondence, above), so it's pretty bad form to call my defense of the Ionian a "breach of trust". After all, I would need to move through the Ionian to defend against Austria, too.

      (I know you were probably just kidding there... but, this being the internet, I do want to make sure there isn't a misunderstanding here!)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daniel,

      As you can see from the above, I'm plenty busy as it is, and not heading your way. If you'd like to make a move against England (support MAO into Brest, then support West Med into MAO, and you have a good base of operations for an English assault), you can do that relatively worry-free (the Turkish fleet, if it goes West, being the only real concern).
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yep, just a bit of ribbing there.

      One day, I'll be as good as Eero and will be able to somehow wade to victory without lying or cheating or stealing. Right now though... Hapless opportunism coupled with about 50% of deals kept to ensure there is a reason to sometimes trust me after all.

      As for intent... Well, I certainly will try to get an SC off you this year, if just for defensive keep-at-same-unit-count. If I can get Bill on the same boat, I'd certainly try to take even more.

      But, even if I tried, I wouldn't be able to do much damage - our forces are more or less on par, and the only unit that can effectivelly attack you is a raider, which you'll probably have to swat around a bit. Plus, I'll get other issues that need solving sooner or later, and those will have to be addressed too.

      That is to say, yes, I'll take what I can - but that likely won't be much and you're very much in position to stop me until things change. So you're a 'target' in a weak sense, but not in the strong sense of "I am out to get you until you are gone from the game." I don't think I ever have targets in the strong sense in Diplomacy, actually... Getting any seems like it'd lead to a troublesome waste of resources.

      So yes. Good luck, Paul! I think your game has noticably improved from when you started.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas is over-all a pretty balanced player, Paul - he does keep solid and well-though pacts, but you probably shouldn't rely on him when the only thing he'd gain is some ephemeral reputation for being overly inflexible about his promises.

      My northern rearrangement doesn't really impact Russia's play, Willow has more than enough armies on the field anyway. We could even set up a bounce in Moscow with Sev-Mos so she can cover both Sevastopol and Moscow with the same unit.

      The German NMR here is a huge development, it's a sign of flagging fighting will on the part of the German people. Might be a prelude to a peace, or a period of anarchy, or even a feeding frenzy on the parts of the neighbours looking to take advantage before others take the best parts. A very powerful sign, and one that allows me to cut Kiel from Denmark, tactically speaking.

      Willow: if you have nothing better to do with the Silesian army, do join in here in the German party. Berlin, for instance, seems like it doesn't entice the Kaiser anymore, so you might as well have it. Munich is also an interesting option, although you might have to work it out with the Italian - were I Paul, I'd definitely consider a free gift like that. Munich is pretty much going to fall to whoever takes it in the German repartition, and while I can't promise Berlin permanently to anybody coming to claim it with just a single army, a temporary possession is also good and can be leveraged to a more permanent position by adding troops or simply moving south to Munich later.

      Daniel, too, obviously has a stake in the German situation; you know my long-term deal, and I'm willing to listen to counter-suggestions, too. Holland won't be supporting Belgium in place this year, I think you can take that for granted. And anything you claim this year I'll be happy to respect, or trade for equal value elsewhere next year as long as you don't increase the fleet build-up on the Atlantic side. Let me know what you think.

      The Austro-Italian situation seems tactically tricky, as the Russo-Turkish alliance has gained a lot of momentum since last year. The naval situation is improving, though; Turkey can basically choose between a raid and a total loss of home port defense (worthwhile option for the resource disparity Italy needs to dedicate to block it, note), or a passive and submissive defense with two fleets against three. Assuming that the Austro-Italian alliance can keep coordinating effectively, the naval situation will only worsen until the Turk brings a third fleet into the fray. This is theoretically balanced by the opposition's superior land-based position, although the trade-offs could get tricky: I see no reason why the Austro-Italians couldn't keep Russian gains to a minimum and Turkish gains at null level while their fleets approach Turkish homelands. This is not a happy place to be for the Sultan as Russia grows stronger and his own enemies get closer.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Bill,

      But only one of the retreats is actually in question, is that not so? (Just trying to understand the rules, here.)
      \nYeah, but it's a big if. Turkey has to decide between audacity and prudence--does he go behind your lines into TyS, or retreat to the Eastern Med? If he retreats, he can hope to do in the southeastern corner what Eero did in the northwestern one: sit and wait for one of his antagonists to go down, and then take advantage; but Daumantas knows that kind of strategic patience ill-suits him. On the other hand, if he goes raiding, he can't be sure of making gains, and it leaves him more vulnerable in the Med than he might care for. As a third option, he might throw the dice and head for Apulia.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero-

      I quite like your idea of a Sev-Mos bounce, although it's a bit disingenuous to suggest the move does not effect me- you could just as easily covered St. Pete with a Finland army.

      Daumantas

      Would you order BLA S Ukr-Rum?

      -Willow
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Germany's NMR puts France in a tight spot. I'll be acting as if the government of Germany has fallen until I see action again, and will be moving to either Belguim or Mun in the fall.
      \n
      \n@Daumantas, while a ship in the Tyhennian would hamper Paul's frontline strenth, Paul's shifting forces south to cover might benift Russia more than yourself.
      \n
      \n@Eero, I won't be building a fleet on the atlantic side. From time to time I may order MOA-ENG, as you just saw, to keep things appropriately mucked up. Trust is as scarce as ever.
      \n
      \n@Paul, Thanks!
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hey, a comment from the audience. I really enjoy watching this, public diplomacy being completely foreign to me. If it's not too much trouble, going forward, would it be possible to post the maps indicating the various moves - it makes for easier reading than scolling up and down to see what's changed. I stress again: if it's not too much trouble!

      Carry on, please.

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n We're on some good stuff, man.

      But this is a very... cooperative version of World War I.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDavid Artman \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I think I'm seeing one of the emergent properties of gunboat: Tallest Sheep Gets Shorn. With all alliances in the open, there's no mystery as to who should be the one getting chopped down. And Diplomacy isn't "tippy" enough for an obvious leader to extend the lead alone, never mind with six (or two) other Powers in coordinated opposition.

      Just an observation... I don't want to start a distraction.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n

      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n

      \n
      \n
      \n Willow -

      Yes, but on one condition: A Gal-Bud.
