      \n
      \n
      \n\nMarhault \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Calculus, how about a time stamp on that map? What season is this?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n We're playing the 1908 fall phase at the moment. There was one full year of break during the holidays, so we've played almost seven years. The game has been pretty well balanced, but it's not growing long in the tooth by any means yet; if we still haven't killed anybody in 1915, then I'll start wondering whether we're not able to do it without secret plotting. As it is, there are several Powers teetering on the brink here, and at least some that are clearly dominant tactically against their neighbours.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hey Paul --

      I don't have a lot of good options, so after this turn I expect my forces will be mere adjuncts to yours, reverse-Janissary style, as long as they survive. Hopefully the prospect of a real live juggernaut will concentrate the attention of the remaining Western powers, and then you can present yourself as an integral part of a pragmatic alliance to contain the Eastern steamroller. A couple of points:

      (1) You should move A Tyr to Vienna; I expect to stay in Trieste. Russia will probably not bounce you there, since A Gal is probably heading for Budapest.

      (2) Knowing that you might decide to attack Greece, I won't do anything that could cut support for such an attack. I will use F Adr to support an Italian unit near me in place, and hope I guess right.

      -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Why wouldn't Adriatic Sea move to the Ionian, again? Seems like a fine endeavour that the Italians in Naples would support as well.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenWhy wouldn't Adriatic Sea move to the Ionian, again? Seems like a fine endeavour that the Italians in Naples would support as well.
      \nSure, I thought about that. But if I do that, then if Paul wants to order Ion S Adr-Gre, I cut that support. So I won't do that unless Paul wants me to, for whatever reason. Truth be told, I wouldn't mind sailing into the Ionian; that would give me a chance of grabbing Tunis and spending the rest of the game supporting units the Ionian, like a Visigoth.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Oh, I suppose that's true about Greece. I discounted it myself because I'm looking at the Italian situation through conservative lenses - it's usually easier for a new player to think in terms of full defense and slow offense, after all. You're correct in that doing something else aside from Ion-Tun (the obvious defensive move) is an option for Italy as long as Turkey takes it as a given that Italy'll play it, and won't therefore go for Tunis himself. Then again, I'm uncertain as to whether Turkey has any better moves than Tyr-Tun to make.

      All that's pretty risky, though; is your situation really so bad that you couldn't just bunker down, clear the uncertainties in the line and then start a slow counter-strike against the east? Can Turkey and Russia put together the sort of long-term, heavy-pressure front they'll need to force their way into Austrian home SCs? It's not an easy situation for them, necessarily, as Russia will seek to benefit at the expense of Turkey at some point, and Turkey is relatively weak navally against Italy as long as the army line in Austria holds.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1\u202678910111213\u202619\xbb

      As for Gal-Bud, of course- I was going to do it anyway.

      -Willow

      \n Yeah, for the record, I'm still trying to take my turns, because it's no good to abandon a game in progress. Now that school's started, however, I don't have a lot of time to devote to talking, and I somehow missed my last turn. :-/
      \n

      gottit.

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n

      \n
      \n So you're still in the game, but not too interested in negotiation, Peter? Balls of steel, I have to say.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nIt's going to take me twenty minutes to figure out what happened here!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n My, that's a lot of colour on the map!

      Peter,

      Ouch! I almost ordered Tyrolia -> Munich, but decided against it. Not that it would have made things much better for you. Hang in there!

      Bill,

      I really appreciate the support! I am sorry things have turned so sour for you, too.

      I almost missed this turn, too: the PlayDiplomacy "clock" was at 2 minutes remaining when I signed in this morning... close call there.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n That was brutal action all around! I especially like how Italy took the risk and seized Greece in trade for Tunisia, that was a bold move. Austria still keeps Berlin, meaning that it's Austria at three and Italy at five against Turkey at five and Russia at five. Grim, but tactically Italy has prospects over there in the Turkish heartlands. It's a shame the other fleet went for the unlikely bounce in Rome, but Italy can compensate by building a third fleet.

      Germany is not faring so well, on the other hand: the loss of two SCs and the continuing failure to reoccupy Berlin mean that Germany's playing with two SCs and therefore two units for the next year. Were I playing there, I'd work hard to see if the English are still amenable to any sort of peace - French probably aren't, considering their prime position for annexing Germany entire.

      England, France, Russia and Italy are building, while Austria and Germany are removing units, and Turkey is remaining the same, unless there's a disband at retreat coming. Austria'll probably disband the fleet, as the naval war is slow and not as important; Germany'll remove the fleet and one of the armies; what the others do is anybody's guess.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero,\n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenEngland, France, Russia and Italy are building
      \n
      Posted By: Eero Tuovinenbut Italy can compensate by building a third fleet
      \nI wish that were true! Alas, Italy does not get a build this turn, unless I am much mistaken.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,\n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenAustria'll probably disband the fleet
      \nConsider disbanding Trieste, instead. We may need each other's help in the waters in the year to come!

      I'm not sure which is best, but I don't think disbanding the fleet is necessarily the obvious choice here. Not sure about Rumania, either; don't have enough experience to predict what that army's survival would do to the board!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ah, yes - you already have five units on the board. Carry on, then, and don't let the Mohammedans bite.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Damnit, Bill. Serbia over Budapest? That's some *spite*.

      Guess I shouldn't be surprised, though. With six neighbouring SCs, five of which are viable targets themselves, Serbia's always surrounded, and is thus a bit of a hot potato. Hee, that probably makes "beyond Serbia? Y/N" a good measure of the success of a Balkan strategy.

      Anyway. This pretty much decimates my entire defensive line, pushes in a clusterfuck of not-mine armies in the area where I would normally expect to be making gains, and reduces my effective SC count down to 4 (how long is Tunisia going to last?).

      Paul, Bill,

      I don't know about you, but I am ready to wave the white flag of please-don't-hit-me-anymore. What are your conditions?

      Willows,

      I now have a pretty good understanding on why Turkey gets the rough side of things in a Juggernaut (in a word - Balkans). While your behaviour in this alliance was without flaw, I am currently likely to not respond to any offers that won't mean immediate gain for me, and am thus not that good an ally, and am a bit vulnerable there on the back, and am thus a bit better of a target, and thus am rather worried about a meaningful Turkish existance. Please point all builds away from Turkey and keep the stabbing to a minimum. Please?

      \n Daumantas-

      Obviously, the first step would be a recapture of Greece (with A Rum cutting possible supports from Serbia), followed up by an attack on Serbia in the fall. There are so many units, in such tight proximity, that speculation on what the board state will look like at the start of Fall '09 is futile. Alb-Gre, AEG S Alb-Gre, Rum-Ser only fails if ION-AEG is ordered AND Bulgaria's possible support is cut, which is why you order Bulgaria to order either S Rum-Ser or S Alb-Gre (and not tell anyone which), so the Austrian doesn't know whether to try to cut Bulgaria's support, or hold with Serbia.

      Alternatively we play the defensive game and wait for me to take Galicia,

      You will certainly want to bring that Black Sea fleet into the Mediteranean- right now it's only useful for 1) issuing defensive supports or 2) stabbing me- either of which is of limited utility to you at this point.

      \n Daumantas's disbanding of both units is a good opportunity to switch gears, granting him two builds. I personally would have retreated to the Aegean at least, but Daumantas now has extreme flexibility.

      My northwestern friends-
      what shall we do about Berlin and the remaining German possessions? It is quite likely that both Belgium and Holland will fall in the spring to an English-French assault. For my part, I am willing to cede my claim to Berlin provided that 1) Eero takes it and 2) Eero moves out of St. Petersburg- it's not necessary to cede the territory, I just want the unit out of my backside. It's presence in, say, Finland to bounce any move from Moscow, should I get a unit there, would be acceptable.

      \n Paul manuvered well last year under difficult circumstances. Even though he lost two SC, he gained two strategic ones. Greece is wonderful prize, as is as solid control of the Ionian.
      \n
      \nTurkey's pleading for mercy seems a bit far fetched. With five centers this year, a well placed raider slowing Paul, and the Russains not in a position to attack her, Turkey's not in grave danger. These cries seem more to be an attempt to lull her neighbor off gaurd, or to break up the Austrian-Italian allience.
      \n
      \nRussia, for all it's new found strengh, is looking vulnerable this turn. Army Ukraine can't bounce both Moscow and Sevastopol in the spring, so a build in Sev would be expected. Army Silesia certainly has to think about covering Warsaw against Galicia, and yet Russia is still likely to loose Budapest.
      \n
      \nTurkey's surprise disband of Fleet Greece shows that Turkey is giving herself the option to reconfigure. A fleet build in Constantinople would give Turkey flexiblity to move either south or if Russia did not build in Sev, to Russia, .
      \n
      \nThe spring, at least, seems likely to go to Austria-Italy. Turkey-Russia only has three units on the front line, and one for support.

      Paul,

      \n
      \n Yar.

      Do what you want, \u2018cause a pirate is free,
      YOU ARE A PIRATE!
      Yar har, fiddle di dee,
      Being a pirate is alright to be,
      Do what you want \u2018cause a pirate is free,

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Tactical recommendation for Italy and Austria on the mainland:

      Tri-Bud (main attack)
      Vie S Tri-Bud
      Tyr-Tri
      Gal-Rum (cuts support)
      Ser S Gal-Rum OR Ser S Gre-Bul (general fuckery)
      Gre-Bul (protects Serbia)

      The point here is to force A Bud to disband on retreat. The important thing is the forced destruction of the Russian army, which reduces the overall amount of force the enemy has available in the fall. These sorts of unit-heavy all-out slugfests are ultimately won by having more force on position more consistently than the enemy, so any moves that allow you to put more of your units into contact with the enemy line while denying the same to the enemy will result in advancement for your side. The reason for the immediate tactical advantage the Austro-Italian alliance enjoys here is that half of the Russo-Turkish army force is out of touch in internal Russia; the situation will balance out in the fall if and when Russia manages to bring more armies into touch, but right now three of Russia's five armies are up north where the only place they can touch is Galicia. From the Austro-Italian viewpoint it's important to move decisively and without trivial mistakes now that there is a window of operations available; if time is allowed to waste and Russia gets the luxury of lining up the full force in actually relevant positions, then the situation won't seem nearly as good for the western clique. Strike while the iron is hot, in other words.

      The naval situation is fucked up in comparison now that Turkey invested so very heavily in fleets. Italy can try to seize Tunis (50% chance) by supporting himself first into Tyr and then into Tun, but then loses the Ionian in trade in the fall if the Turkish fleets are allowed to go to Aeg and Eas unopposed. Opposing them, on the other hand, only delays them - one of the fleets goes to Aeg in the spring regardless, while the other can be supported out in the fall. The long-term situation seems so problematic that I'd probably go for Tunis here, willfully losing the Ionian again; that'd allow me a build in the winter for a third fleet in Naples, which would then at least balance the naval build-up. Turkey will still probably get a pretty good shot at Greece next year, but perhaps the army line has advanced sufficiently before then to allow the armies to withstand the naval offensive for a while on their own. Basically it's going to be Turkey's game in the Mediterranean for now, though - the solution to the problem has to be found in propping up Austria, gaining builds from the continent and pressuring Turkey in Bulgaria.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n

      \n Eero --

      -- Bill

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n That works passably, too, although it's not as annoying for the opposition - my suggestion requires them to consider the supported attacks on Rumania or Bulgaria as well as the Budapest situation. Also note that Galicia will retreat to Bohemia in my plan, so you'll get an unit there regardless; no need to specifically attack there.

      The question of which SCs Austria should own and which Italy should own is a complex one, not the least because both sides no doubt have their own ideas. My recommendation for the most part is for you two to fight hard, conquer more SCs and thus have more of a pie to share between you instead of compromising your offensive unduely for partisan reasons.

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n

      \n
      \n
      \n It may be advantageous for Italy to conspire with Russia and Turkey in knocking Austria out of the game- Vie-Tri (Tyr S) and then Tyr-Ven to cancel a retreat in the fall takes Trieste, Turkey gets Serbia, and then we have a much more manageable three power eastern triangle.

      Otherwise, Paul, your next move is probably just to attempt to retake Tunisia or get Budapest, but can you realistically get Bulgaria or Warsaw? A conflict with France, is probably the best endeavor you can take at this time (and if you can somehow bring Daumantas's fleet to bear in a way that does not threaten you, so much the better!) The tactics would be tricky, but a Italy/Russia adventure against the German home centers and a Italy/Turkey raiding mission against Iberia could be beneficial to all.

      Willow,

      And what will you do if Eero conveys into Norway this Spring, with StP going to Livonia?

      With such a mass of Russian troops headed roughly South-West, I'm pretty hesitant to "turn the other way", I hope you can understand why.

      Right now I feel that I have quite a lot of security to gain by supporting both Austria and France, as I have been doing.

      Eero's advice sounds very well-founded (thanks, Eero!) but also seems aimed at focusing everyone's attention (particularly yours, perhaps?) towards the Balkans, while he stands to make some serious gains this year or the next.

      Daniel,

      Eero may be hoping for Daumantas to, indeed, head West with that fleet from Tunis, forcing you to split your attentions and thereby letting an English fleet into either Brest or the MAO. How will you prepare for that possibility?

      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Euro,
      \n
      \nYour fleet in Liverpool concerns me quite a bit. Moving it to Clyde and further would keep the peace. I'd take other moves by it in the spring as war.
      \n
      \nEarlier you had proposed dividing Germany with you taking Holland and Belguim, and I taking the other three. This seems likly to cause future problems. You'd have nowhere to go but toward me, so I'd like to propose another division.
      \n
      \nI'll take Belgium and stop there, netting me two. You take Holland, Berlin, and Kiel, netting you three. In addition, as long as Hol, Keil, and Berlin are occupied by fleets not armies, I won't bring an army into Ruhr. This should insure a stable, no surprises situation. If your army were to go instead to Denmark in the spring, that could be to your long term advantage and I'd be willing to support you into Holland and Berlin in the fall if needed.
      \n
      \nNo need to agree or disagree, though alternative proposals are fine.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n That's a good idea about the division of Germany, Daniel - that point about the army movements is especially well-founded, and the border you suggest truly is stable. I wonder about whether you are satisfied with minority pickings off the carcass, though. I'm trying to figure out how to have you in Berlin, but it's difficult long-term...

      How about this: you take Berlin and Belgium this year, while I convoy to Denmark. Next year I'll take Berlin and prepare for an eastern offensive (Livonia, etc.), while you set up to do your thing in the Tyrolian area and the Mediterranean. This way you'll at least get a considerable tempo advantage off Berlin, which you can perhaps trade in for permanent gains in 1910 elsewhere. I could even conseivably support you into Warsaw in 1910 as a second semi-stable position, unless you found more use for that particular army down south. Having you in Berlin on a permanent basis seems like a futile gesture (too easy for me to pick off), but a visit could be arranged.

      (That Liverpool fleet should be a non-issue in the long term; I'm considering vacating the English Channel and leaving that fleet in the Irish Sea or thereabouts if an eastern strategy truly flowers.)

      Regarding the eastern situation, I don't have any particular secret motivations about it - I just happened to consider the tactical situation and decided to post my conclusions. Truth is that I'd like to see Austria and Italy survive their current situation, so it'll be interesting to see whether they will; the tactical situation is high-risk in that Austria does not have any room for mistakes, but the immediate position seems playable, assuming no mistakes from the Austro-Italians. It would be a great shame if the Juggernaut were to overrun their positions just because they lack coordination at this critical juncture.

      \n [Eero, I'll write you later.]
      \n
      \nPaul,
      \n
      \nI'm not really concerned about the Turkish fleet affecting France. Spain is occupied, and it would take Fleet Tunisia until next spring to reach Marseilles - easy to bump something down to cover it at last minute.
      \n
      \nFirst, a story:
      \n
      \nYears ago, the sun had set. It was drizzeling and dark and cold and I was hunched behind a tree. Steve and I were the only ones left, crouched on a ridgeline. Accross a creek and up another ridge the enemy laughing was talking, laughing, shining flashlights into the woods, and presumeably drinking hot chocolate.
      \n
      \nTAT-TAT-TAT-TAT-TAT. A stream of paintballs impacted an inch above my head. Fragements of bark hit my hair. I hit the ground, sprayed paintballs wildly behind me, and rolled to other side of the tree.
      \n
      \nThere was silence.
      \n
      \n"What do we do now?!" I hissed. Steve could hear the fear in my voice.
      \n
      \n"Relax. Think about it, he's in the dark, he's alone, and we are between him and all his friends. Let's just kill him."
      \n
      \nAnd we did.
      \n
      \nYou've got two on his one. You'll take Tunisia back eventually.
      \n
      \nFleet Tunisa is a pain, but it's no mortal threat. You've just got to move fleet Rome to Tyr, but you'd be doing that regardless. He can't hurt you any more as long as you have Tyr. Just randomly send fleet Ionian moving to support Tyr or move to the Aegean - that gives Turkey failure options on both sides.
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \nYou wonder if I can be content - I think that's been shown already. I'm fine camping this corner until the game end, neither attacking Paul nor yourself.

      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011

      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Lol - here's what I cut from the front of my last message.
      \n
      \n"You know Eero, the funny thing about your message is that it's exactly what I'd expect to recieve from you, were I getting attacked by you in spring! "
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n How interesting!

      Daniel,

      Your fleet in the Mediterranean should protect you quite nicely from any Turkish, arr, pirates.

      How would you feel about helping me oust that invader from Tunis? Even if he decides to flee to North Africa instead of disbanding, you'll probably have at least one or two builds to cover yourself.





      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Or you could issue support for Tunisia, leaving that unit landlocked and away from Iberia, allowing the eastern stalemate to continue.

      It's not like team BearPirate is doing so well against team EagleSpaghetti right now, anyway.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero, got any suggestions for restablizing our borders?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, let's see... I'd say that the borders are basically manageable due to our largely unbalanced unit counts that prevent decisive action one way or the other. Therefore what mostly needs to happen is for the remnants of the German Power to die off out of the way, after which the rest should basically take care of itself as long as we don't entangle ourselves navally in risky and over-extended operations on the other party's turf. I mean, tactically there's not much in the way of stakes here, unless you start thinking that you can take and hold Kiel by force or something like that. We can just wrassle for a couple of turns, and things should slot down the same way whether we're in agreement or not.

      The ultimate solution to the transient tensions we have in the German areas will naturally occur once better enemies are engaged in the east. On my part the route is pretty obvious, and ultimately you'll have a limited selection of venues as well; we'll just need to both unilaterally make plans and execute them, trusting in the basic impossibility of waging a conclusive war over our coastal border with forces that are largely unsuited to the same. Some possibilities of cooperation against east are present, even, although it's nothing major considering our respective focuses - mainly you might consider allotting the Berlin army to helping out in Poland next year, stuff like that.

      In other words: get Holland out of the way, prepare for an eastern war and execute once it becomes obvious that the other guy can't make a credible war against you anyway. We're not in any hurry about opening new fronts, so let's just pick our moment and look for surprise - any seemingly belligerent action between our forces in the meantime will only enforce the suddenness once an opening is perceived.



      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      Russia, until my brain understands lies?

      Daniel,

      I would, like to, hear your thoughts on your Southern fleet...





      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n@Eero. Okay. Bounce you in MOA.
      \n
      \n@Paul - I moved to West Med in the spring to be in a position to support you into Tunisia in the fall. I didn't expect the chaos in the north to open up. Instead I'm going to have to move Fleet West Med to (hopefully) bounce in MOA. If we bounce, I'll at least be blocking the raider from getting around to TYR.
      \n
      \n@Daumantas - Don't be so sad - the fall looks to go the way of BearPirate.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul --

      I hope you've noticed the tactical ironies of the naval battle around Tunis. You know that TyS-Tun, Ion S TyS-Tun probably fails, since there's nothing else for T:F Eas to do but Eas-Ion, which cuts the support for your attack. Therefore, the obvious solution is TyS S Ion-Tun, expecting to lose the Ionian but gain a build. But if I understand the rules correctly, the obvious Turkish play under those circumstances is Tun-Ion supported by Eas, which means that the equally well-supported countervailing attacks from Tun and Ion bounce. The basic principle of attacking out of a threatened province that you expect to lose applies. Note that using Aeg to support the attack from Tunisia as well turns the bounce into a rout for F Ion, but F Aeg will probably be responsible for launching a spoiling attack on Greece. Ironically, however, if you attack from TyS under those conditions, even without support, the attack from Tunis succeeds, F Ion is displaced as the Turkish fleet sails forth, and F TyS sails into Tunisia unopposed. In that case, Turkey is better off with T:Tun hold, T:Eas-Ion -- but then Ion-Tun, TyS S Ion-Tun is a winner, even though it gives up the Ion. Alternately, since you're going to lose Ion anyway no matter what you do, you might just go ahead and order TyS-Lyo, Ion-TyS, Tyr-Pie and fuck France for not helping you out.

      My point is that what seems like the obvious move on the surface may be exactly what your opponent expects, and the move that seems sub-optimal may work better. I am emphatically not making any recommendation, however. As always, I suggest rolling a die.



      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daniel,

      What's the purpose of that rule? I assume it's not a "handicap", in order to make the game more challenging for you...

      Bill,

      Sorry about that! I was hoping to see you in Bulgaria, as you can see, but it's a shame nevertheless. What the heck do we do now?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I:Tyr-Tri? Oh, that's too bad for me.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Bill,

      Sorry about that! I was hoping to see you in Bulgaria, as you can see, but it's a shame nevertheless. What the heck do we do now?
      \nPaul -- Who's this "we," kemosabe?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      I didn't think I'd be taking out one of your units by doing so! But we need another fleet in the waters at this point, and I don't see any way for you to build one at the moment. At this point, I think it's safe to say that my unit in Trieste will soon end up elsewhere, at which point Trieste can happily return to its usual Austrian owner.

      You didn't answer my earlier questions, so I had to guess which way you were moving. I guessed wrong, thinking you might go for Bulgaria, which is why I tried to support you into there. My attack on Galicia was also aimed at your defense, since it served only to cut support from the Russian army there. But I can see how you actually had other plans, and my move has now royally fucked them up. Not my intent, again: I think moving aggressively against Austria at this point would be stupid and pointless for Italy.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The attack on Galicia was an interesting choice, considering the value of a build in these close-quarters Balkans fights. I'd have expected some move that had a positive expected value in SCs, it being fall and all.\n
      Posted By: Paul T.
      What's the purpose of that rule? I assume it's not a "handicap", in order to make the game more challenging for you...
      \nDaniel refers to the practice of sometimes making unexpected long-shot moves so as to make your play more difficult to predict. After all, if you always use the same heuristic in choosing your moves, then the opponent will also know what you're going to move, and thus they will have an advantage over you. On the other hand, consistently making suboptimal moves that'll only pan out in unlikely circumstances will ensure your defeat, which is why "one in six" or so is probably a pretty good ratio for indulging in foolishness. Just often enough to make the opposition doubt their predictions.

      You might remember that Bill has referenced the similar dictum of "rolling dice" between equally valid move-sets to ensure that the opponent can't predict your moves on a psychological basis. Whether any of this is a good idea or not is a very complex and interesting question of Diplomacy strategy. I wouldn't deny any of it off-hand, but I have to say that I often feel confident enough to try to counter-predict my opponent instead of merely playing unexpected moves myself. Who predicts and who merely optimizes (or randomizes, as the case might be) their moves is a matter of psychological initiative after all, so there's no reason why I couldn't always play on the basis of what I imagine my opponent to be moving instead of merely randomizing my own moves, at least as long as my gut keeps up.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul --

      I get that you expected Rum-Bul to succeed, but as a move it was so obvious that there was no way that anyone who had a stake in it wouldn't have bet money that that's what I was going to do, and taken pains to prevent it. I'll quote myself: "The basic principle of attacking out of a threatened province that you expect to lose applies." I'll admit that I was expecting T:Aeg-Gre to cut I:Gre S Rum-Bul rather than T:Aeg S Bul, but the effect was the same: impossible for Rum-Bul to succeed.

      Now, I could have ordered Ser S Rum, Bud S Rum, but I expected that Willow would play the best move set at her disposal, with A Gal attacking to spoil Bud S Rum and an attack coming from the Ukraine supported by Sevastopol. So I knew I wasn't going to hold Rum, and I knew that Rum-Bul was pointless. Given that, I expected to end the turn with 3 SCs; I needed to decide whether I should allow A Rum to disband so that I could rebuild in Trieste, or attack into Galicia to be in a position to do some central European infighting. I decided it was worth it to attack back into Galicia, since that would go a long way toward protecting newly liberated Budapest. Eero sounds skeptical about the point of Rum-Gal, but I knew my opponents well enough to be sure that I wasn't going to do any better than I'd already done--I was sitting on Budapest, after all, which I'd given up temporarily in order to keep the pressure on Turkey. Once I knew that A Gre wasn't going to do anything stupid like attack Bulgaria (which would have left it vulnerable to a Turkish attack), it made sense to order Ser S Gre, preventing a Turkish attack from having a chance succeeding there. I knew Russia was going to have to disband, and there was a 50/50 chance that Turkey would lose Tunis. I would have been left with three SCs and three armies right in the middle of the fight, and an open home SC to build in if I made any gains during the next year. That was about as good as I could have hoped for, given the tenacity and cleverness of the opposition.

      Now, in the scheme of the larger fight, I suppose you might reasonably assert that an (Italian) fleet in Naples is more valuable than an (Austrian) army in Galicia, but as an alliance move Tyr-Tri is just pointless. If you really thought that Rum-Bul was going to work, with a 4th SC I could have built a fleet in Trieste and brought it into the fight in the Med, and the army in Tyrolia could have warded off the Russian army in Bohemia and kept the door shut on France. And it would have kept me happy, under the illusion that our alliance was working to bring me back from the brink. Deprived of that illusion, I'm no longer motivated to stay on side. So even as a stab I'm not sure that Tyr-Tri was all that smart, although I could be wrong about that; it may work out fine for you.

      Willow --

      Don't disband A Boh! In the spring, I'll support you into Vienna. If you then could see your way clear to supporting me into Trieste in the fall, I'd consider it a favor.

      Daumantas --

      You can expect to be able to attack Greece successfully in the spring.

      -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hey, Bill,

      Don't forget this is all pretty new to me! This is effectively my first game of Diplomacy (while I do have another one on the way, it's also still in 1908, and in that game I haven't had the opportunity to engage in any diplomacy or negotiations, since everyone I could reasonably interact with has been full-on hostile).

      Your logic makes sense to me, now that you point it out, but I don't entirely have the experience with this game to have seen that outcome as clearly. You might have, uh, discussed some of these things sooner with me?

      My expectation for this turn was that you would find a way to hold steady, and I figured I had a good chance of losing Greece (I didn't expect your support there), so I needed another build somehow, or I would quickly be entirely unable to support you at all (as you can see for yourself, if you look at the Southern situation, where Turkey outnumbers me in fleets). Even if you had been the one to reach a new build first, it would have been at least a year further down the road, not in time to stop a potential Turkish advance.

      I need that fleet much more than I need Austrian territory--once I have it (which I now do), I'm happy to return Vienna and Trieste to you. Otherwise, frankly, I don't think we have a chance. From what little I know of Willow and Daumantas's tactics, they're unlikely to leave you alive for too long if you do choose to turn on me, but rather use you to take me down, and then get us both out of the way. I'm happy to keep my supporting role on the mainland now that I finally have a decent navy established, and that includes getting out of the way so as to help you rebuild Austria. I don't really think either of us has much of a chance to survive alone at this point.

      You can also see from my moves ordered this year that I was already planning to trade Vienna for Trieste--I was picturing a potential of my army in Galicia for the same reasons you listed, if you doubt my motives here.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n In case you two need an outside perspective, I think that Italy definitely needs Austria - the situation is very much in tactical equilibrium, the two Austrian armies are more than enough to throw the overall Balkans war any which way (except perhaps Austria's way, sadly). Italy should either think up a very clean, very quick stab, or do whatever it takes to convince Austria that there is a continuous political intent present for Austria's survival. Personally I'd definitely go for a surviving Austria here, as I can't off-hand see how even a clean stab would leave Italy with sufficient traction to oppose the Juggernaut. Only if I had secret knowledge about forthcoming political troubles between Turkey and Russia would I take the risk.

      Tactically it might not be a bad idea to disband the Serbian army. That's a relatively easy hole for Italy to plug from Trieste. Then again, if Russia keeps the Bohemian army, Italy well might have to play to Tyrolia simply to prevent an aggravating raid into Venice. Perhaps getting rid of the Galician army makes the most sense if the Italo-Austrians are not feeling like making a complex offensive push in-land; Galicia isn't that useful without such intent, and in the current situation that sort of thing would be difficult to accomplish successfully.

      Tactically the immediate in-land situation is a stalemate, assuming Austria and Italy can keep it together - they have four inland armies against four Russo-Turkish armies in the Bul-Rum-Gal-Boh cordon, which means that neither side is really going to make much progress, especially as the Turko-Russians have depth of defense in their fleets and support armies that ensure the maintenance of the Bul-Rum positions. What this means is that long-term the situation will either be resolved by Austria cracking (letting the Russians in, basically) or by naval operations - whichever side gets naval superiority will be able to roll up the flank and support their armies in aggression. Russo-Turks have a slight advantage in that they have more depth to take risks with, which means that they can try certain variant offensives that might work with luck, but they don't have unlimited time to experiment with, assuming that the Italian naval war starts moving and Turkey needs to start focusing on homeland defense.

      It occurs to me that it'd be really funny if Russia retreated to Silesia from Galicia. Hilarious, and diplomatically very proactive, considering how it'd take off pressure from Austria and Italy. Could even be an immediate cause for some Italo-Austrian falling-out when the Russian threat recedes a bit, and at least Turkey would start feeling more of the pressure. Going through with it would require disbanding Warsaw, I suppose, but if Austria disbanded Galicia at the same time the board would look totally different from the current situation.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero makes good sense, as always. Paul, ignore my previous outburst.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n This year's big winner was probably England (+1 center, likely prospects next year, unassailable home position): France and Italy both gained a center, but neither has the luxuries that England does. Turkey gets an honorable mention for not loosing any centers in the face of certain danger- he may be able to make some progress in the sea yet, if he doesn't need to dedicate fleets to supporting Bulgaria from the Italian/Austrian breakdown.

      And for those of you who like numbers, our current scores are:
      England: 9
      France: 7
      Italy: 6
      Turkey: 5
      Russia: 4
      Austria: 2
      Germany: 1

      Franco-English aggression seems to be heating up: Eero can't progress much more without building more armies or going through the French. France may be able to catch up, but it will take solid play.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I just ran across some nice "Diplomacy" style public press in the news.
      \n
      \nBackground: HP fired their CEO. Stock prices dropped. So they fire the board members that fired the CEO.
      \n
      \nQUOTE
      \n
      \nThe Hurd debate "took a lot out of this board," said Ray Lane, who joined H-P's board as chairman in November, in an interview. He applauded the board's decision to remove Mr. Hurd, he said, "but it wasn't without some pain, so we stepped back and said let's self examine the board."
      \n
      \nMr. Lane said that the four departing board members volunteered to leave and that he "couldn't single out someone who should go." But he said that some change was both expected and necessary.
      \n
      \nENDQUOTE
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, I admit I'm at a bit of a loss. The Eastern situation appears to be either a total standoff or a total disaster if all manage to miscoordinate our orders due to public negotiation (or, rather, lack of public negotiation).

      Willow,

      Just thinking outloud: what would it take for you to feel comfortable enough to put some pressure on Eero from your end? He's only likely to keep growing at the moment, and you'll have to deal with him sooner or later.

      Daniel,

      You're pretty unlikely to take Kiel this turn, and equally unlikely to lose Berlin. How would you feel about an arranged bounce in Tyrolia? I'm not sure about that just yet, I'm just testing the waters.

      Bill,

      You can absolutely count on my support this Year. I think fighting between the two of us would only throw the balance in the favour of our neighbours, with neither of us coming out ahead--you can't attack me without giving ground to Russia or Turkey, and if I were to attack you, I wouldn't be able to build the strength to maintain your current position quickly enough. I'd like to see any further gains (or retreats) give territory to Austria, since you have the advantage of being able to build in that area. Just to let you know what I'm thinking at this point! Feel free to point out any flaws in my logic, if you see it--I'm just making guesses based on my limited experience with this game so far.









      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n

      \n
      \n
      \n Paul -- Eero has suggested the right tactical plan: hold the line in the Balkans, offer mutual support, and wait for your naval superiority to put enough pressure on the southern front for us to make gains. At that point, there may be opportunities for me to gain a few builds and consolidate my position. I hope so, anyway. -- Bill

      \n Probably not, though. At that point, Germany is no more, and France/England will make themselves heard.

      I don't care directly, here - far away and well insulated by... the rest of you, really.

      But even if they don't move in in full force (probably won't - have each other to worry about, after all), whatever they do may just upset this goddamned delicate balance we've got going in ways I can't forsee and thus profit from.


      ...way things look now, it's a long and meager existance for the turk until the big boys come to play, after which the frustration will be frustratingly cut short.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul, you over-estimate my tactical position; Daniel is in fact currently slightly dominant among the western Powers due to his better force placement and the fact that the German forces have been consistently tripping me up for the last couple of years - I estimate that I'm effectively 0.5 units behind this year, which might be enough leverage for him to make some permanent gains before I can bring my units to better positions. (Depends on tactics at this point.) If anything you should be trying to figure out how to prevent Daniel from overrunning Germany, which well might be the outcome if I mess up my tactics this year.

      As for the eastern position, I concur with Bill insofar as the tactical realities go - you should be able to hold the line on the continent for the 2-3 years it'll take to regain your naval positions. Tactically the immediate naval situation is tricky due to the 50/50 choices involved, but I have confidence that the Italian position is slightly better than the Turkish one. Just don't fear losing Greece too much (trading Greece for Tunisia on the spring move is good for you, as you have a fair chance of retaking Greece in the fall, depending on the particulars), coordinate for an active continental move-set with Austria to put potential pressure on Bulgaria, and guess right on whether Turkey'll support Tun-Ion or not. Consider Tyr-Wes, Gre-Bul and other such liminal moves as well as the more obvious tacks; think over the whole opportunity space to find the moves that will have good outcomes against what you think the opposition will move.

      Ultimately the resolution of the eastern triangle will pretty likely be down to the Turko-Russians - whichever first finds a position for a stab will likely end up splitting the east with Italy, given high-level play on both sides. My money is currently on the Turk, as Russia will have to over-extend tactically to make any progress against Austria at the moment; that makes it very easy for the Turk to make a fall convoy to an empty Sevastopol, for example (at least as long as the naval war has not progressed to the Turkish home SCs, which will in any case take years). Any stab in a trench war like this, where all forces are already most committed, will be decisive. This is problematic from the Austrian viewpoint in that many would consider the correct Italian response to be to use the confusion among enemy ranks for a big push, followed by ousting Austria from the game to run for the finish line alone (or with the Turko-Russian stabber at least, whichever it'd be). Exciting times ahead in 2-3 years, I predict.

      Is there a way to make things more interesting for you? This land war isn't terribly profitable to any of us. Do you have any other ideas? Other tacks we might try?

      I'm all ears, especially since in the meanwhile we're just sort of sitting and waiting.

      Daniel is currently certainly fat enough to spare us a few morcels.

      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.
      Willow,

      Just thinking outloud: what would it take for you to feel comfortable enough to put some pressure on Eero from your end? He's only likely to keep growing at the moment, and you'll have to deal with him sooner or later.
      \nRealistically? I'd have to get a build this year, and feel like it's not needed to defend Russian home centers. If you let me walk into Vienna (perhaps ordering Vie-Tri, Tri-Ven, Tyr, or Alb), that satisfies that, and puts you in position to do other things.

      Oh, and between you and Daumantas, Ion C Gre-Tun, Tun-WMe/Naf, Bul-Gre is definitely the way to go.

      Edited to add: Imagine the possibilities for a convoy for an Italian or Turkish army into the French territories!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas,

      That sounds interesting. You're not concerned that we'll just be giving Eero a big headstart by doing so? In addition, I have a rather good working relationship with France I'm not too keen to spoil.

      You've, uh, not exactly delivered on some of your earlier ideas. So, if you want me to consider such a plan, you'll have to start by showing your good will and vacating Tunisia. If you do, I'll be willing to retreat from Greece.

      I'd much rather see you head North, personally, however. Unless you have some other way of showing me that your massive fleet is not intended as an anti-Italian WMD?

      (Is there a plan of action you can outline for me that would guarantee some safety for Italy? I'd need some concrete assurance, then I'll do it--just like you rolled a 7-9.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      If you instead want to take Greece with the Aegean, it's probably best to take a defensive posture with your eastern units: Bul S Rum, BLA S Bul.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.(Is there a plan of action you can outline for me that would guarantee some safety for Italy? I'd need some concrete assurance, then I'll do it--just like you rolled a 7-9.)
      \nThis type of conundrum is of fundamental interest in Diplomacy strategy: how to proceed from an aggressive posture to a cooperative one without creating undue openings for betrayal, when both sides would probably only need that one good opening for dominating the other? This is further complicated in this particular game by the fact that everybody can follow along on your negotiations, meaning that the only surprise you may have for complex ploys is in uncertainty, which also often transmits to your intended ally... tricky and delighting to figure out.

      Were I playing the position as Italy, I wouldn't consider Gre-Tun, Ion C Gre-Tun, Nap S Ion H, Tyr S Gre-Tun an awful move, all told; Turkey could foil it by attacking Tun-Ion, but that's a danger to Turkey as well in that Italy could be playing eg. Tyr-Tun, Ser-Rum, Bud S Ser-Rum, Gre-Bul (takes Tunis and maybe Rumania) instead. Most importantly, the cooperative option here is unilateral in that Turkey doesn't actually need to make a special spring move to pull off this thing; as long as his move doesn't outright foil the convoy, he easily has many valid moves to consider. Therefore he has ample luxury for trying it out. As for Italy, the convoy is a valid 50/50 move in attacking Tunisia, and if it pulls through, the position is genuinely valid for Turkish cooperation, regardless of whether Turkey trusted Italy to really be going for the convoy a priori; thus, after the fact negotiations may proceed smoothly if the convoy goes through. So overall the convoy is not any worse as a move than a standard offensive move, except for the fact that it trades the security of Greece (which Turkey might or might not attack anyway) for the diplomatic potential gained by the disarmament move. It's only valuable if Italy wants a Turkish peace, but if he does, then an uncertain hold on Greece and Tunis might be a good trade for a firm hold on Tunis and peace.

      From a Turkish viewpoint the plan is excellent, I don't wonder at all why Daumantas suggested it - no reason whatsoever from his viewpoint to not wait and see for one turn, considering the relatively static tactical situation. It's true that Italy might smoothly talk Turkey into some minor discomfort by moving something completely different, but there is no major stake there as long as Turkey makes a solid defensive move (Aeg-Gre, say). The advantage for Turkey is considerable as long as Italy says that it's going to go for it: either Turkey gains a drastically shifting position and a strong ally where he only had a slowly losing naval battle, or he gains the absolute certainty that Italy's going for blood - this latter is important in long and slow trench wars, as this is not a position where betrayal comes trivially: if Italy talks up the trade of Tun for Gre and then uses the goodwill for a minor tactical advantage on the Mediterranean, that'll be a massive power-up for the Russo-Turkish alliance, who can then play for years in absolute certainty that neither may trust in any Italian overtures. (In case you're wondering, diplomatic value is a real thing in this game: it influences the cross-Power tactical relations, which translates into strength or weakness caused by mutual trust or distrust. An Italy that betrays Turkey directly feeds power into the land-war in Rumania, which largely depends on the working relationship between Russia and Turkey.)

      The strategic value of betrayal goes to the other direction as well to some degree; as discussed above, it's not obvious to Turkey that he'll have an advantage by betraying Italy here, as it's possible that Italy is betraying him as well, in which case trying to foil a convoy to Tunis by moving Tun-Ion could be the very move Italy is expecting. However, putting aside the strategic situation, Turkey betraying Italy would obviously affirm for Italy that no further compromise with Turkey is possible: at the moment the two (Turkey, really; Italy has other outlets) have just about as many fleets as they can have and still credibly make peace, but if Turkey betrays Italy, then it'll be obvious to all that Turkey's playing for keeps - it's Mediterranean domination or bust for him. The diplomatic significance here is not as major as it'd be the other way around, as it seems to me that the Austro-Italian working relationship is much better than the Russo-Turkish one, but it's still considerable. If nothing else, a Russia fully confident about Italian motivation in fighting against Turkey will find it much, much easier to make peace with Austria and stab Turkey.

      Considering the above points, I'd be extremely surprised if either of you two betrayed this sort of deal once you managed to make it in a circumspect way that didn't give out too much for third parties. Of course my saying this out loud affects your judgment (for one, it makes the surprise all the greater when you actually betray each other), but it still seems such an irreversible diplomatic action to betray each other at the moment that I'd be surprised if either of you would be willing to pay the price for the minor tactical benefit available. It would only make sense if either of you has already concluded in your private analysis that the other absolutely has to die for you to win, and therefore the only reason to be talking to each other in the first place is to gain those minor tactical benefits from small betrayals. No, the much more credible way of not making the Gre-Tun trade is to outright deny the offer (or perhaps not comment at all), as that leaves open the option of negotiating later, when you do really need to be able to work together.

      All that being said, in practice I'd probably move Ion-Tun, Nap-Ion, Gre-Alb (or Gre H) instead of that convoy, no matter what I promised to Turkey; if the Turk is trusting enough to not even support himself into Greece, that's his failure, and if he does support, then I can retreat to Albania with no harm done and have my fleets in credible positions both for western offense and eastern defense. The convoy plan is non-optimal in that the Naples fleet doesn't get to an effective position during the spring if neither the Tyrhenian or Ionian fleets move. Moving Tyr-GoL would be a heady move for Turkish alliance, but it would also mean that taking Tunis would fail horribly if Turkey didn't move out of Tunis voluntarily; I probably wouldn't take the risk myself unless I had a really good feel for the Turk and he explicitly said that he's going to vacate Tunis under his own power.

      Perhaps the way I'd go if I wanted to pursue this sort of sudden turn would be to be non-committal and then just move Ion-Tun without ceremony - if Turkey is similarly enticed, he'll play along (attacks Greece, doesn't attack Ionian, perhaps vacates Tunis, etc.) without any explicit agreement. As mentioned above, it's 50/50 anyway as to which move would take Tunis and what Turkey should do, so neither side is actually objectively making a bad move by choosing the option that just happens to end up with a clean separation of forces and a chance for peace. If both choose to play along, then it'll happen without any need for talking.

      Whether all this means that Italy and Turkey would be implicitly selling Austria and Russia up the river by teaming up is an interesting topic for some other time
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul,

      T'is no secret that I go where the SCs are. I had hoped to dominate you with three fleets to two, yes - but with a third one out there, getting anything done in the Mediterranean is out of the question - even if I pull another fleet in from Bla, there is simply no room to manouver.

      My options now are to either strike up a deal with you and see how it goes, or sit and wait and play guessing games.

      France has an exposed posterior now, and enough momentum for a loss of an SC to not hurt much. If anything, it'll only concentrate French forces in the region, making Eero's leaking into the Med a virtual impossibility even with good French-English relationships. Leaking into the Med is the only thing we have to worry about, really - the land route is way too long for us not to notice and prepare accordingly. Can't get a fleet-based solo win if you're not controlling MAO!


      As for my moves... I'd normally be loathe to vacate Tunisia on my own volition - you certainly have the fleet power to oust it yourself, fleetpower that could otherwise be easily used against me. But, since you have a track record of keeping your promises, I could certainly bite.

      There's a first time for everything, however, so I'd like a safety precaution as well.

      A Greece - Albania.

      If I betray you, you'll still have three nearby units to my two with which to retake Greece.
      If you enter orders otherwise, I'll know in the fall turn of your intentions instead of after it, and can put up a bit of a fight then.

      Get back to me on this.

      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, since I never got an affirmation of my fairly reasonable request, or even an actual promise, something beyond "do this thing and then we'll see", the orders I punched in that presumed Italian aggression stayed unaltered.

      I'm not going to be making any risky deals in the fall, so how about we slug this one out and see what the next year brings, hmm?

      Russia misclicked! I have some difficulty in understanding Austria's support (forcing an ally to vacate Trieste, if I were to guess?), but it is certainly a shame Willow was unable to take advantage of it.


      Also, hey! France in the NAO! The game just got potentially rebootable - England can now be taken down a notch, and if France succeeds too well at that, she does not have that good a geograpic setup to hide behind.

      \n
      \n
