    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ouch! And crap!

      Mistrust will be our ruin, eh?

      Daniel,

      Yeah, saw that North Atlantic move coming, it was very nicely set up!

      Do you want to talk about Tyrolia? I hope you weren't acting on a mistaken agreement for a bounce--your response sounded like you were calling that off.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n (Daniel, the map with the moves, please?)

      I'm fairly sure that was a contingency move in case you decide to follow through with plan Attack France. Could do a whole bunch of things now that it's there, though -- including of course retreating from that location altogether. Don't think France'd want a real italian war at this point, and the advante of a single SC gain seems rather fleeting.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n That was an intense turn. Turko-Russians now have a definite upper hand in the east; the Austro-Italians will have to guess right on defense to beat back the odds and prevent enemy progress. Italy would in fact have a lot of use for some French support now that a French army is in the vicinity - I suggest talking about it, the downfall if Italy would have extreme consequences for the entire Europe.

      Now that the war turned so heavily to the advantage of Turkey, the strategic tension in the Turko-Russian alliance hikes up to unforeseen levels: Turkey has the very realistic, very powerful option of simply moving to claim Sevastopol, claiming two builds for the year and trusting in the chaos caused by the successful Russo-Austrian war to carry him through who knows how far; Russia is over-committed to the Austrian war at the moment, but will soon recover if Austro-Italian defense crumbles, so now is the moment. The tragic bit for the Juggernaut is that if Russia does not use the opportunity and hammer home the assault on Austrian home SCs, then she can cover himself, but not progress anywhere. It's the classic conundrum of trust for advance and betrayal for resolution.

      Meanwhile France is riding strong here in the west, and it's up to me to prove to Daniel that a northern war is not an option. What fun.

      Tactical notes for the Austro-Italians, you guys should definitely not fail now. (Note that I'll just ignore your recent falling-out - you can of course both lose spectacularly by fighting each other as the Juggernaut rolls over you if you want, but I fail to see a route to victory in that course of action.)

      The junctures between Powers in the trench line are important, as those are spots where an attack cannot be realized without prior coordination. This ensures that Serbia, for example, may be cut, but cannot be taken without prior warning realistically - neither Russia nor Turkey will take the risk of attacking or supporting the attack without knowing that the other is going to help out. For this reason we can say with confidence that only Vienna and Budapest are under immediate danger. The tricky part is that the loss of Greece puts pressure on the Austro-Italians to make commensurate gains; this sort of trench war will be lost surprisingly quickly if losses are allowed to accumulate.

      Bulgaria will practically have to support Greece in place, as it's pretty natural for the Ionian to attack Ion-Gre with Albanian support. Cutting Bulgaria with Serbia is a very natural move here, but do note that it does not guarantee success for the attack; Turkey can defend Greece by attacking Gre-Ion with fleet support, bouncing the attack with an equally strong counter-attack. The counter-attack ploy in turn is foiled by simply allowing Turkey to move out, or alternatively by having Serbia support the attack in. However, Serbian support is foiled again by cutting it from Bulgaria. The end-result is that the war for Greece will be a guessing game that connects with the Tunisian guessing game: F Ion either attacks Tunis or attacks Greece, Tunis either attacks Ion or holds, Eas either supports Tun-Ion or Gre-Ion, Serbia either cuts Bulgaria or supports Gre-Ion, Bulgaria either cuts Serbia or supports Greece. Serbia can do either of those moves and still be useful for retaking Greece, but supporting the attack is of course only useful if the Ionian actually attacks. There is no way for Italy and Austria to communicate the fact of attack in advance without spoiling it, as Turkey has a counter if he knows what's coming.

      Meanwhile the northern defense can be broken down thusly: you can play Tri S Vie H, Vie S Bud H, Bud S Ser-Rum, Ser-Rum, and that'll defend successfully against anything but Bla-Rum, Rum-Bud, Gal S Rum-Bud, Boh-Vie. That particular move-set by Russo-Turks is somewhat unlikely, as they'd have to coordinate it; not entirely impossible if Austro-Italians are very loud about coordinating this particular defense, in which case both Willow and Daumantas might just separately use their heads and opt for the very attack I'm spelling out as the counter Still, rather far-fetched.

      The weakness of the above defense-by-cutting-Rum (aside from its passivity) is of course that it doesn't have much synergy with the southern decision matrix. If Serbia participates in the southern defense instead, then the northern situation is harder: either France needs to help out or the defense needs to outguess Russia. Basically Trieste has to support either Vienna or Budapest in place, and Russia has to make a supported attack on the same place. Note that mutual support doesn't help, as Russia will obviously cut both Vienna and Budapest anyway. A classical 50/50 defense situation. If France helps out (and he should - if I can somehow help convince Daniel, let me know), then both positions can obviously be supported.

      (I should note that there is an external game here as well: Russia might go for Munich, France might go for Venice. Because the Venetian offensive is particularly useless for France in all ways imaginable, I'll not concern myself with these options for the moment; if France wants Italy to fall, you've already lost, and so have us western Powers.)

      There is a black horse option here as well in that Austria can attack Rumania; it's the only position aside from Greece and Tunis down south that may be assaulted by the western alliance at the moment. (The empty spaces in Galicia and whatnot are not worthwhile targets; a war like this lives or dies on material advantage.) An attack on Rumania should probably be made by moving Bud-Rum, Ser S Bud-Rum, Tri-Bud (or perhaps Tri S Vie H if France is not playing along). The attack on Rumania has good chances of happy outcome in that it bounces Rum-Bud and breaks Rum S Gal-Bud, and of course gains a build off Rumania. The weakness of the move (aside from the fact that the Grecian attack probably is not an option if Serbia does not participate) is that Turkey's second-most likely move with F Bla is supporting Rumania on hold. (The likeliest is an attack on Sevastopol.)

      The most favourable Russian attack on Austria at the moment is Rum S Gal-Bud, because that move allows Turkey to support Rumania in place, countering the Rumanian assault in the last paragraph. This does not obviously mean that Russia will play it, as it's much more important to out-guess the opponent in this sort of tight spot.

      The coordination problems in the northern defense are real, as Italy needs to know what to do with the army in Trieste: either it supports a randomly chosen unit in Vienna or Budapest, or it supports Budapest because France promised to support Vienna, or it moves to Budapest to bounce Galicia as Budapest marches on Rumania. Then there is Serbia, too, which has crucially differing options as well. Perhaps Italo-Austrians can coordinate in some clever manner and not give the plan away.

      (I don't cover one variant move-set above, the possibility of playing Ser-Rum and Alb-Ser. It's a bit problematic, and doesn't offer much advantage.)

      Summary:

      Italy can still carry the day down south by guessing right in Tunis and/or Greece, but it's a guessing game. Up north it's 50/50 as well, unless France can be convinced to offer a helping hand. Thus we can calculate that the current expected gain of the Turko-Russian alliance is roughly 0.5 SCs from the south (as Turkey has to outguess Italy to not lose Tunis/Greece back to Italy) and 0.5 from the north (as Russia might take either of the northern Austrian home SCs), for a total expected value of one full SC. The value of a French support here would be 0.5 SCs and a certain ill-defined diplomatic rider: if France publicly commits to supporting Vienna, then Turkey will know that Russia won't gain a build this year, and therefore he'll have an easier time playing eg. Bul-Sev.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hey Daniel, it seems we have an opportunity for a peace plan here. Consider: Berlin is lost to you, and I can't retake Belgium, which means that we're in the initially considered peace plan positions in Germany anyway. The naval situation is sufficiently credible that I think you can be convinced about me being convinced about your ability to defend yourself, if you follow - it's not realistic for me to pursue an anti-French strategy here, at least not without major tactical upsets.

      By making a quick turn-about we will gain many benefits, perhaps the most important of them being your ability to support our Austro-Italian brethren against the imminent disaster coming out of the east; your Tyrolian army is already in position (as is your Berlin army in its way), and it is no trouble for you to move one of your fleets back to Wes to support Italy; perhaps you could have Tunis as your reward, even, if you move before the naval situation breaks apart one way or the other there. It seems to me that tactically your participation at this juncture might be crucial to the balance of the eastern Powers; by participating constructively there you'll play time for both of us to gear up for some serious operations in the area.

      We can, I'm sure, work out a rational fleet positioning and disarmament plan at leisure. I might have perhaps one fleet too many here for a comfortable eastern campaign, but those can be removed if the will is there - move to Picardy and force a retreat from there, stuff like that. There aren't any trust issues that I can see here, either - the fact remains that our ability to project force against one another is rather round-about.

      (It goes without saying that following this plan seriously will necessarily result in the game moving towards some sort of Anglo-Franco-somethingsomething draw. This is a honourable ending for the game, and I'm sure you know that I'm not one to refuse a good draw when soloing proves impossible. I find it unlikely that you would disagree with me if I say that neither of us can be played off the board from these middle-game positions; I know that I'd be confident in my ability to share in a victory were I playing France at the moment.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I was kicking myself allday over the mis-click, and what's worse, I had to go to work right away, so I couldn't formulate a post more than four letters long.

      Bill & Daniel

      Let's soldier on ahead- supposing you both support me into Vienna in the fall, next year we can support Austria into Trieste, and then France into Venice. Tyrolia is a strong position for France to hold at this stage in the game.

      Daniel-

      If you can hold ENG, you're in position to convoy a unit to Wales or London. You'll have to outguess Eero's army of course, but I'm sure you can figure out the potential rewards.

      -Willow
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Jeez, Eero. At least I commit my own units to sowing chaos than trying to use someone else's.

      Re: Taking Russia's stuff. I'm sure all of the wobbly gains in Greece/Tunisia/Sev would make up for a common Italian/Russian front against me, the only thing that can realistically spell Turkish demise. Thanks but no thanks.

      Willow, keep cool. I know we haven't been coordinating much due to the whole Italy deal I was trying to push, which could've inadvertedly sent alarm bells ringing, but that's because our spheres of influence are sufficiently separated for that to be unnecessary.

      Oh, and don't forget to cover your back when you have SCs to spare - England's waiting for chaos until it moves in, and if you're worried about Turkey then, an army in the Moscow environs will act well enough as a turkish deterrant as well. Good?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hey Daumantas, I have to make sure - you do realize that you're the third party in the draw if and when we get our asses in gear with Daniel? It's sort of the default outcome, nothing anybody can do about it aside from stabbing you sideways long in advance. Stay chill, I know what I'm doing.

      I've no idea what Willow's about up there, she doesn't seem to be reading the same map I am.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm the third party to the draw if I can live that long due to Turkey's natural longevity and no good ways for England/France to get at me, yeah.

      It would take either a stab or a long war of attrition with me making a mistake at some point to eliminate me from the real game. I don't especially see the necessity to stir up the party able to do either of those things... Especially given that, without access to the scandinavian hump, Russia as a Juggernaut partner is not as a futile deal for Turkey.

      'sides, I'm not sure if "try and get the most powerful powers to fight amongst each other" would ever be bad diplomacy from a turkish position. Worst thing that happens is I get a two-way draw instead of a three-way one, right?

      Not that my edging on matters much - I think both of you have enough hope for a solo left to try and tussle with each other before things quiet down, if they do at all.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n There is no such thing as a two-way draw. (A pet peeve of mine in Diplomacy, don't read that in an agry voice.) Any minority partner in a prospective two-way will soon find that hey, 18 SCs is half of the board, and therefore my being a minority partner entails a solo victory for that other guy over there.

      Anyways, we have quite a rapport with Daniel - we know quite well what we're doing here, brawling over the Netherlands and all. (Read back on the thread, we're both minimizing communications due to the open environment.) If you're happy with a three-way and don't want to try for a solo yourself, just be ready to act when the time comes. No need to say more, I know you know what steps to take for this ending.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n

      \n

      \nWill be back this afternoon, and post replies.
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      Cool as a cucumber.

      (As an aside, I've always wondered about that saying- I don't find cucumbers to be particularly cool, and they don't need to be refrigerated, either.)

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The great thing about France and England turning their attentions to the rest of the board is that it opens up an opportunity for even just a slight stab. Assuming France and England split the board with a Turkey, with England and France each at 13 centers, Turkey at 8. give or take- a stab on the English/France side for just a handful of centers (let's say 2) puts a party at 15- well within bludgeoning range of a solo victory. One might be able to frame the stab as "just a center between friends, nothing to do about it, let's soldier on, tempo advantage, etc." but the long term ramifications are what's important.

      And Eero's quite correct about the situation on the British isles themselves- I was looking at last turn's board state. Still, in any event, it's a fair point, a convoyed army from one homeland to the other can work chaos.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill and Willow,

      For the sake of education!

      Assuming that predictions of a possible three-way draw between England, France, and Turkey are correctly founded, what would the three of us need to do in order to stay in the game?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n (I'm really enjoying the tactical analysis, by the way, thanks, everybody! Even though it sounds like everyone's discussing how best to flavour and spice this Italy before serving her up for dinner. Still an enjoyable read.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n A draw is predicated on the idea that the game cannot logically progress any further. The three-way draw happens when all three sides agree that none of them can force a solo against the other two, and the four-way draw happens when all four agree that they cannot eliminate one of their number without destabilising the board to tip for a solo for one of them, and a five or six way draw results when they don't have enough intestinal fortitude to play real Diplomacy. The two-way draw, as Eero points out, is theoretically possible, but a 17-17 balance of the board is incredibly precarious- I happen to agree with him that it's in practice a non-reality.

      Ensuring one's place in the endgame is typically done by securing a stalemate line: a position that can be held against any assault. Due to the invulnerability of Switzerland, the traditional stalemate line runs from the Southwest to the Northeast corner of the map. There are essentially three key areas: Gibraltar, the German Homeland, and St. Petersburg.

      Going around Gibraltar can be done though MAO, or Spain itself. F NOA S F MAO, F MAO S F Spa, A Por S Spa, A Gas S Mar, F Spa S Mar can hold out forever against any Eastern attack. Likewise, Bur/Ruh/Kie and St.P + another unit can form an unstoppable line.

      The key in these situations is that they are invulnerable- from one side. Getting a unit past the stalemate line, such as an Italian army in mainland France, or a Turkish or Italian fleet past MAO means that 1) some of those supports can be cut and 2) those units might have to do things other than support in place.

      Also, really, if France and England were going to partner with a third nation, it wouldn't have to be Turkey- just whoever's left. Turkey has an ideal position as a corner power to be in that position, but a triumphant Italy or Russia (for example) could just as easily partner with the last two units.

      Finally, it's my opinion that it's far too early to be discussing a three-way draw: none of the powers have eclipsed 10 centers, and we still have all 7 players technically in the game. E/F is by no means decided- France could land a raider fleet in Clyde, England stands to take Berlin, hold the Channel, and threaten convoys.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Assuming that predictions of a possible three-way draw between England, France, and Turkey are correctly founded, what would the three of us need to do in order to stay in the game?
      \nWillow's summary of the draw issues is good, I like. It's true that a French/English draw pattern does not entail Turkey, it's just a very natural outcome. Assuming a long-term play situation where the eastern triangle remains relatively paralyzed, while the west starts projecting force to the east in an extremely dynamic manner, the practical losses caused by the western assault would mostly be suffered by Italy and Russia as the west-most eastern Powers. Turkey, on the other hand, would be in prime position to exploit their difficulties, forcing its neighbours to fight a two-front war. It is possible (likely?) that Turkey would not make as much of a gain in Italy and Russia as the western Powers when those worthies fall, but it wouldn't have to: the end-game logic dictates that a third Power, no matter how puny, still has as much of a chance of participating in the draw as either of the other two. Really, the only issues Turkey would have in a large-scale western assault would be if it itself had a shot at a solo victory (and thus no wish to move onto the end-game yet), or if it perceived one of the westerners to be so superior that it threatened to solo in the end-game process. Aside from those concerns Turkey is in the position that is very typical for a corner Power: hooray for anybody else who wants to fight him into a solid victory, he'll be happy to join the aggressors in the winner's table.

      The correct Italian play for preventing this particular future, assuming that it is found credible by the Italian leadership, would be to send a small (one-unit, in practice) foray into the French lands to tip the balance ever so slightly - probably not even claim a SC, as the point would merely be in forcing France to divide its attention just enough to cause the French and English players to think that England has a shot at overcoming France, after all. This would then directly send the Anglo-French relations into another plummet that would likely take 2-3 years to sort out, thus giving the easterners more time to resolve their own differences without western interference. This same sort of logic could theoretically work for Russia as well, except perhaps that the distances are greater and at least to me it seems that England is more fragile due to the lack of depth in the defense: it would take great skill to force England to detach forces to the east without also risking a total overrun by the French as things currently stand. (The exact causes are boring, it's to do with the distance from English force concentrations to StP versus French forces to Marseilles.)

      Speculation all, of course, mostly for Paul's benefit and academic interest. We're still solidly in the middle-game here, and will be as long as we so dictate with Daniel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Very interesting, thank you!

      \n
      \n Paul, yes at the last minute I changed my orders and moved there - I figured we'd have an unagranged bounce. Not your fault at all. As happens every turn, those recommending attacking France, are recommending that course of action because it would benefit themselves, not because it would benefit you.
      \n
      \nEero, I'm open to return to non-aggression, however you'll need to aggressively kill my North Atlantic Fleet, since that's my only current counterbalance to your fleets' positioning strength. I'll look to this fall move for your intentions. (Particulary Army London need to move north or east. Your taking Berlin is fine. Don't put three fleets adjacent to MOA.)

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daniel,

      I hear you! Makes sense to me, and thank you for the vote of confidence.

      Would you consider helping me out by supporting Vienna, or attacking Bohemia? No need to respond and thus tell the others what to decide, but I hope you'll think about it!


      Bill,

      It's not too easy for me to judge your intentions at this point, and you do have a history of attacking me. But I'm going to trust that throwing yourself my way at this point is more or less suicidal, especially if you know that I intend to support you (whereas, given the chaos of public negotiation, making an enemy of me, and thus everyone around you, could see both of your armies "accidentally" disbanded depending on what we all choose to do on any given turn). If you'd like to send me a message, I'm sure you can figure out how.

      I would like to see you support me back into Greece (since Daumantas appears to be unwilling to make the trade) or attack Bulgaria, roll a die.

      Eero's suggestion of, e.g., an attack on Rumania are also interesting. It would be possible for me to cover such an attack with an arranged, assuring that you gain a territory and are able to build immediately.

      I am willing to coordinate further support of your forces from my end, or take a guess, as you prefer. Good luck!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n Willow,

      I'm not sure what I can offer you at this point, since I'm really not sure what Bill is thinking. But if he continues to be hostile towards me, I may be able to make you a lucrative offer in terms of helping you into his territories in exchange for a break from all the fighting. Keep that in mind for the future, as if he makes a point of turning on me making some kind of deal with you and/or Daumantas might be my only chance for survival. That's how I see it, anyhow. (Bill, counter-arguments are welcome, as always. I respect your advice on this point very highly.)
      \n

      \n Paul -- I don't want to be too specific, given Eero's tactical discussion above, but don't worry. I don't need a weatherman to see which way the wind is blowing. -- Bill

      \n
      \n\nCalculus \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Tons of fun. I forsee a year of awkward swatting about with loose italian units. Can never really know what that brings...
      \n
      \nCan't say I expected to keep both Tunisia and Greece, though -- at least, not with that moveset. A very conservative play - keep either Greece or Tunisia, sacrifice no positional advantage - Greece and Tunisia only had support orders issued because I hate hate hate having my units do nothing at all. My quarries have only themselves to blame, I would say - in more ways than one.
      \n
      \nAnd... I think Bill may have stopped playing this particular game and instead is playing every other game he's planning to play on SG, now? "No one will fuck with me and live to tell the tale! No one!" A reputation advantage so to speak? Can't say I blame him if that's the case.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Damn, Italo-Austrians, you have to try harder. Otherwise I'll end up in some sort of Turko-Russian three-way draw as the game spins down. I dearly hope that Bill has some amazing plan here. Maybe he's thinking that he can paralyze the Balkans by playing Russia and Turkey against each other, considering that neither should wish for the other to just walk into the Austrian SCs.

      My suggestion to Italy here is that you'll probably have to abandon the Austrian mainland - put the fleet in Adr, remove A Vie, convoy A Alb to Venice in the spring, and huddle down, supporting Austria in place in Trieste in the fall. (He foolishly betrayed you, but any number of betrayals won't change the fact that your destinies are somewhat inseparable here.) The Austrian is too unreliable as an ally, and the situation is tactically too risky; better to clean out and straighten your defensive line where you can hold it credibly with your own strength, as that puts pressure on the opposing alliance to reconsider their priorities. Once Russia and Turkey both see that the war over the Balkans is over and there's just mopping up left, the pressure between the two will again ratchet up: we all know that the one who moves first will ensure their place in any draw on this board (and might even have a shot at a solo), so when the mutual border stretches all the way to Trieste and it becomes obvious to Turkey how dominant Russian armies are in the Balkans against his fleets, then I'll be surprised if the alliance doesn't break down. Heck, I wouldn't keep to it at that point, I'd just put the knife to the other guy and see whether that's enough to take me all the way to victory.

      Obviously this plan sucks if Turkey is committed to an end-game Juggernaut and by implication killing you no matter how long it takes; he might be, as his tactical position is now very dominant, and it's difficult for him to outright convert his fleets to a more fruitful use. Still, resisting Russia in this situation is only useful insofar as you might be able to keep hold of SCs able to support your position against the Turk; this is unlikely once the lines have broken down, as any armies you might manage to put into continental SCs this coming year will merely support themselves by those gains and no more. It's not a very attractive option, but if we view Turkey as your real nemesis for geopolitical reasons, then it makes sense to give way where Russia benefits to focus everything you have in making yourself hard to swallow for the Turk. The ideal outcome is that the Turk realizes that he can't take you quickly enough to matter, sues for peace and goes after the Russian before Willow leverages the Austrian gains into an unassailable position.

      Hey Willow, while I'm here: don't build in Moscow; we both know why you might want to, but if you do, then that motivates me to step up in the environs as well - first something to support StP indefinitely (easiest stalemate line on the board, that), then a convoy at my convenience wherever. Building in Moscow would only make sense if I didn't have a spare unit for supporting StP, but it's easy to see that I do. By building in Sevastopol you'll keep the current situation where we both commit an unit to bouncing each other, which I think is a pretty nice situation for both parties.



      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, I expected to lose Trieste, but somehow I didn't realize that I could lose Trieste and Tunis at the same time. Not sure how I missed that: probably just haven't been paying enough attention to this game.

      Bill, I don't know if you're just being vindictive (taking one territory as a way of supporting your own armies hardly seems like that terrible a betrayal, compared to how you kept Italy from gaining any SCs at all at the beginning of the game, despite my clearly sticking to our agreement - and you can see very well that without that third fleet, you would have been surrounded and cut out very, very quickly, with me no longer able to give you any support)... Anyway, but if not, I'll be really curious to hear your rationale for this particularly choice, even if you don't feel up to revealing it now. Just sometime, eventually.

      It's lovely, for sure. In both games of Diplomacy I've tried so far, as far as I can tell, my neighbours have been turning on me to no apparent gain. Well, at least in this game I've done something to deserve it (although I still really can't see how not building that third fleet could have possibly ended up well for either Italy or Austria in this particular game, and so I think I made the right decision, even from an honest, allied perspective).]

      I don't mind losing to superior tactical play (as is the case with Daumantas and Tunisia in this situation, no hard feelings there, all in good sport), even if betrayal is part of that strategy, but this situation where people work hard to undermine you despite no gain to themselves is just plain frustrating.

      [Edit: This may be coming across as too strong. It's far worse in the other game; in this game play seems quite rational by comparison! If I'm complaining, it's more to do with the other game I'm playing.]


      Eero,

      I appreciate the advice, and was considering that kind of thing anyway, but you've yet again overestimated Italy's actual strength in your analysis. I don't have that many units to play with!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Diplomacy is basically a game of world-view differentials - what seems like unreasonable behavior to one is the best play another player may choose. A large part of the negotiation process is about imposing your view of how the game goes and understanding how the others see it. No matter the quality of play, no matter the accord among the players, I've yet to play a game where players would actually agree about the simplest of things, including such matters of estimation as who's going to win a given war or who benefits due to a given trend. For all we know Bill might have decided that Austria has a better shot at survival with Italy clearly on the defensive and the Balkans split between Turkey and Russia; it's not impossible to survive such situations if you can use diplomacy to impose courses of action on the larger Powers surrounding you.

      Also, yes - Italy's losing two units now. Probably the two outer armies, leaving one army and three fleets to work with. There's been worse, the important thing is to locally balance the opposition so as to not leave any easy choices for the enemy.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero, quite right.

      But some choices are less defensible than others. Bill's choices might be well-founded for a variety of reasons, that I can accept, and he's fighting for his dear life, so desperation can account for all kinds of actions. It's really more in the other game where I have seen odd behaviour, such as someone accepting to help with a unit and then not issuing any order to the unit at all, despite the fact that they would clearly could not have been any worse off if they had done *something* with it.

      This is really not terribly relevant to this game going on here, where all the players at least seem concerned with *playing well*, to the extent that they are capable of it. It's in the other game where I have seen people do weird things without any explanation. I've seen a few players, for example, continue with a war even after it's been pointed out to them that continuing that war is not to their advantage. When asked, "If you see that's it's not a good idea to do that, why are you still doing it?" And the answer is, "Uh, yeah, I don't know. I guess it's not very rational, is it?" And then they continue with that course of action, as though they feel that they have no power to change their long-term plan despite changing circumstances.

      So, in conclusion, it's weird for me to play competitive games with people who do not appear to be playing rationally. (Again, I very much doubt that is the case in this game, no accusations here!) If it's a ploy, and there is rationale behind it, then I can understand that. But choosing to play against reason is... very bizarre.

      This is all really sideline to this game going on here, feel free to ignore me!

      I will keep on fighting, assuming no allies, and we will see what we will see.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n He, ironically enough, Bill and I might have made great progress this next year if we had held our position, since I could retreat into the Aegean and thereby support Austria into Bulgaria and otherwise mess around with Turkish defense. In that position, I think Austro-Italia could have delivered some interesting attack plans!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yeah, different play cultures are different - I can totally imagine how a game of first-timers with very differing levels of commitment will see all sorts of weird stuff. Heck, I've played something like a dozen newbie games around here over the last five years, and we've had all sorts of play ranging from diamond-hard gamesmanship to uncaring sloughing and beyond. Boardgames in general can be challenging socially when the players are mismatched in terms of seriousness, but Diplomacy tends to be even more savage in this regard: the game puts you on the spot and demands that you prove your worth by smart play and right choices, even as other players are clamoring in your ear about what those choices should be. It's not that uncommon for a casual gamer to partially shut down either intentionally or without realizing it themselves, resulting in play that seems like it protects their dignity above all; this is, I understand, a big reason for why people end up on revenge trips in Diplomacy, or latch onto an alliance as a crutch, or throw the game after a minor set-back: they're protective behaviours that help the person construct a narrative about this gaming experience they had, a narrative that avoids confronting the performance as it was - they can say that they were just playing for the larks, or that at least they didn't lie and cheat, or at least the other guy lost just as much as they did themselves.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul, you want to feel put upon because I betrayed you more than you betrayed me, but that's just whining. When you re-took Trieste, you took away my prospects of participating in the draw. At that point, proper Diplomacy would have been to try to assuage my hurt feelings and assure me that, yes, of course there would be room in the draw for me; I was essential to the war effort; there was no way you'd even consider a game where I wasn't one of the winners, no matter what, as long as you had anything to do with it. You would have been lying, of course, but you would have been playing the psychological game the way you needed to. Instead, you offered rationalizations and excuses, saying that an Italian fleet was worth more to you than an Austrian army, and implying that I had no recourse because the Russians and the Turks would gobble me up.

      My goal was simply to show you that you were wrong on both counts: (1) that Austrian army was instrumental to your well-being, because you needed my good will to sustain your position, and (2) everyone always has some recourse, even if it's suicidal. I also wanted to make sure that you understood the ultimately non-rational component of Diplomacy; evolutionary psychologists argue that human beings are wired to punish cheaters, even when it's costly to do so, because otherwise we wouldn't have morality. You have asserted that I "have a history" of attacking you, so I need to disabuse you of that misapprehension: I'm not the guy who ordered Ven-Tyr, Rom-Ven in Spring 01, and I'm not the guy who stabbed his putative ally in the back because I didn't think I could make and hold gains against my enemies. Sure, I tried to make gains against you when the situation on the board permitted, but when circumstances put us on the same team, I was on the team. I let you into Trieste the first time, for Chrissakes, because it was tactically the right thing to do. Frankly, your stab into Trieste wasn't even necessary: if you'd guessed right against Daumantas, you'd have been sitting in Tunisia and would have held on to Greece, putting you and our alliance one up. As far as I'm concerned, I'm more sinned against than sinning.

      At this point, Paul, you and I will both probably lose, but I can live with that, because otherwise you would have learned the wrong things from this game. Eero will probably accuse me of egregious meta-gaming, but I'm just playing the hand I'm dealt. I expect to take a beating next year.
      \n

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Wow, yikes, didn't see a French surrender coming. This could completely change the tenor of the western front- but at least it's a fellow SGer.

      So, Daumantas, shall we be starting our Juggernaut back up? We've been seeing other people, I know, but the time does seem right for you to take Serbia and start hitting the Italian where he lives. No need to make a public response- your Spring moves will speak volumes by themselves.\n
      Otherwise I'll end up in some sort of Turko-Russian three-way draw as the game spins down.
      \nI see absolutely no downside with this, and I'm not sure why you should either.\n
      Hey Willow, while I'm here: don't build in Moscow; we both know why you might want to, but if you do, then that motivates me to step up in the environs as well - first something to support StP indefinitely (easiest stalemate line on the board, that), then a convoy at my convenience wherever. Building in Moscow would only make sense if I didn't have a spare unit for supporting StP, but it's easy to see that I do. By building in Sevastopol you'll keep the current situation where we both commit an unit to bouncing each other, which I think is a pretty nice situation for both parties.
      \nYeah, it must be nice to have nine units, so you can dedicate one a turn to defending three territories and threatening one of mine. Not such a nice situation when one is sitting at four (now five) centers with a Sword of Damocles hanging above one's head, knowing there's a unit you can't do anything with. We had a chance to DMZ both St. P and Moscow; you could have sat in Norway and still been able to bounce me if I made any moves north- you knew that option existed and chose not to take it, and you've been not taking it every time you attacked Moscow.

      Now there's the thing, Moscow sets me up against you, and Sevastopol sets up for the obvious stab of Sev-Arm. If I build Moscow, and threaten Warsaw-Livonia, that forces you to play Bal-GoB or Nth-Nwy. Either of those moves counters mine perfectly, but at the same time, if you move the Baltic away, you lose Berlin, and if you move North Sea, you lose your naval superiority against France. I'd probably do the second in your case, but even so, it means I'm now tying up two of your units with two (or possibly even one, ha ha!) of mine.

      \n And it's a great year for Germany (any year you stay in the game is a good one), a good year for Russia, Turkey, an even year for France, England, and Austria, and a terrible year for Italy. Which puts the counts at:

      England: 9
      France: 7
      Turkey: 6
      Russia: 5
      Italy: 4
      Austria: 2
      Germany: 1


      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm confident that Daumantas will appreciate your reasons if you'll build in Sevastopol now, Willow. Consider: building in Sevastopol allows you to detach Warsaw to a new mission, after which you can continue our bouncing arrangement with A Sev. This is actually an improvement for you, as then you'll have a very effective deterrent for the most obvious Turkish stab of all, a convoy to Sevastopol. As long as Sev is open the Turk can basically just choose his moment; he has a dominant position when he can strike a death blow at you at will. This isn't even a matter of trustworthy alliances or anything like that, it's just basic sense that he'll do it when he considers the time to be right, and you should take the first opportunity to cover yourself when it doesn't cost you in material.

      (Incidentally, I do obviously recognize that our perennial bounce is more of a burden for you than it is for me. This has suited me fine ever since you got the Juggernaut going, as having to commit that one army has been slowing you down ever so slightly against Austria. This in turn is beneficial for us here in the west, as always - we want the eastern triangle to not get resolved before we manage to hash out our own neighbourhood. All very understandable, I'm sure, and not a sign of any particular malice towards Russia.)

      Your analysis as to which units I would likely use in reinforcing StP is correct. Have no doubt that I would do this reinforcement, even as it does cost me a bit in tactical opportunities elsewhere; a secure Nordic zone is too valuable to lose if I have any way to prevent it. It is also true that Russia would currently benefit in a minor strategic way by discomfiting me for the exact same reasons I benefit from discomfiting Russia. However, in this case ramping up the forces on our border would also cost you, and you'd pay more than I would: you need that extra unit even more than I do if you desire to retain momentum and a capability for reaching further into new conquests. Furthermore, once I have two units committed to StP, it will be more effective in the long run for me to make sure that those units are making a profit - it'll be easy to justify adding a third, perhaps making peace with France, and then we'll be in a real war instead of a secure bounce. The StP situation is pretty easy to escalate, I'm saying, but it doesn't seem that either of us benefits from doing so at this time. Perhaps later.

      Also, in case there is doubt - I will, of course, accept a draw with the Juggernaut if and when you crush Italy - taking down France is a natural follow-up at that point, England being as invincible as always. My earlier reference to trying to avoid this was a jocular reference to the better outcome: should the Italian defense succeed (thus slowing down the board enthropy and giving me more time to operate) and should my own play go well, I might be able to take a solo victory. Obviously enough, if this is not available, we'll talk draw. So there's no need to consider England some sort of implacable foe from the eastern viewpoint, I'm just like Turkey in that regard: if the west attacks east, Turkey is the natural draw partner, and England is the same when the shoe is on the other foot.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daniel,

      Sorry to hear you're leaving, but congratulations on the news, and whatever is coming next for you! Anyway, you will be missed. Glad you joined us.

      (I'm borderline drop-out potential, too, due to real-life concerns, but I'm going to try to stick it through, see things to the bitter end. I suspect you're making the smarter decision!)

      Bill,

      I'm not really whining -- and if it comes across that way (which it probably does, I'll admit), it's something I regret. Should have reread my posts before submitting them!

      Although I do disagree entirely with your rationale here: I would never choose lying (never mind making obvious lies) over telling as much of the honest truth as I can, and sticking to it (as I did). The order history bears me out here! Had I been the smarter player, I would have tried to grab as much of your territory as I could once you showed you weren't interested in maintaining our mutual interdependence. I don't see how telling predictable and empty lies would have changed the situation. (Would you really have responded differently? I doubt it.)

      Granted, my attack on Trieste was based on a miscomprehension. I figured that you would somehow manage to maintain your position or gain another SC, as you had done so far. Eero had suggested my moving into Trieste the previous turn, and it seemed like you were in agreement with the plan at that time, so I was acting based on that as well.

      I'm also not sure what "lesson" you're trying to teach me here, because I'm pretty sure I would do exactly the same thing again if a similar situation comes around. With my support from Trieste, you could have held your ground; without it, because you were losing your colony in Berlin, you would not have been able to build in Trieste anyway, and it would have left our common front against Turkey and Russia down an army. Hence I felt it best for the alliance to reinforce both fronts at once.

      Not to mention that, had I been overrun in the Mediterranean, you would have been just as done for (if not more so). I could be wrong about all these things, as I'm not an experienced player, but that's how I saw it then and I don't really see it any differently now.

      You've seen my orders, too: I've supported you every turn, before and after that point (and even this last turn, after you had already turned on me).

      At the beginning of the game, my opening moves may have seemed threatening, sure (although you had agreed to let me into Trieste, so I'm not entirely sure why see armies on your border was all that frightening, unless you were already planning to back out of that plan), but you followed up with betrayal even when the following turn's orders clearly showed I'd been true to my word. Likewise for Trieste last year: if I'd been planning to take you down, I could have done that quite effectively at that point.

      Anyway, it's all good sport in the spirit of a game; I'm not holding it as a personal issue or any sort of grudge. This is what I signed on for, and it's at least an interesting experience! I'll be curious to see how the rest of this game goes down, especially once France is run by a different player (which, as France is my only ally, might be certainly shorten my participation in the game).

      I'm not continuing this in order to argue. That would be quite pointless here! As Eero says, in this game it makes most sense to agree to disagree: our views on the game are clearly different, and that's to be expected. In many ways, that's what this game's about. Rather, I'm really just responding to say: I hear you, but I don't agree. (Then again, maybe you're painting a certain picture for the sake of Diplomacy, rather than for the sake of truthfulness: and that's fine, too! We all have our own ways of playing this sucker.)

      However, if you do feel that I'm making some basic misunderstanding of how Diplomacy is best played (as you imply above), I'd love to hear about it in a more neutral context.

      Game on!
      \n

      \n
      \nWillows:
      \n
      \nFirstly: alright, will do!
      \n
      \nSecondly: Seems like you've already made up your mind, so just my two cents: No, I would not like a build in Sev (for the same reasons I never liked a unit in Sev, compounded by the would-be troublemsome green fleet); And in this case, Eero's bark is likely worse than his bite. Can't push inland to Russia with fleets, can't easily move his second army (doesn't matter all that much even if he would, I'd think), can't negotiate peace with France at a moment's notice.
      \n
      \nAll in all, I'd probably like a French endgame than an English one - France isn't as untouchable to Turkey as England would be.
      \n
      \nAnd, of course, I would certainly like another pathway for you to open up that isn't turkey-wards... My hopes for Russia are basically, um... Eventual success after bouts of protracted fighting? Not that eager, no - don't want to be left in the dust, you see, but not bloodthirsty either.
      \n
      \n
      \nPaul,
      \n
      \nI don't have too much hope for us reaching a peaceful resolution, but there's no reason for me not to try. Mostly due to, say, a vague hope for an eventual solo ('course, as Turkey, I'd need more than my fair share of luck for that to come to pass - so I'm more than ready for any version of a draw if that comes my way), I'm still interested in getting a fleet into Spain, which you could make happen. Trade it for Tunisia, perhaps?
      \n
      \nI wouldn't expect for you to stop the whole war/defense thing if you accept this, but it would certainly be nice.
      \n
      \n
      \nBill,
      \n
      \nWhat can I tell you that wasn't already written on some motivational poster somewhere? There's a circumstance under which we'd have grounds to talk, but it, thankfully for me, doesn't seem to be taking place.

      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.With my support from Trieste, you could have held your ground; without it, because you were losing your colony in Berlin, you would not have been able to build in Trieste anyway, and it would have left our common front against Turkey and Russia down an army. Hence I felt it best for the alliance to reinforce both fronts at once.
      \nPaul --

      I guess we'll have to agree to disagree, but this is sheer sophistry. I can't believe that you're actually chiding me for ingratitude for taking one of my SCs away from me because you were getting outfought by Turkey. From my perspective, you were shoring up your own position at my expense, plain and simple, and then expecting me to smile and say I liked it. Fuck that noise. If you didn't have the stones to fight your own goddamn war and win it, then sneaking in to my city to make sure that you didn't disband and then expecting me to soldier on as if nothing had happened is just bad play. Don't get me wrong: taking Trieste was a good stab. But it was a bad alliance move. And you knew that it was a bad alliance move, regardless of your disingenuous pleas to the contrary, because you didn't warn me, or discuss it--you just did it. Having done it, you need to be prepared to live with the consequences.

      Now, I'm honestly not all that worked up about it. I enjoy the psychological and emotional part of the game--the uncertainty, the treachery, the fear. It's true that I would have lasted longer in the game by sucking it up and fighting on in the line in the Balkans, but what Eero says about narratives is true. I'd even say it goes further than that: it's all narratives--the only thing you take away from the game is the narrative of your participation in it. Now, some narratives are more technically grounded than others, but even Eero's highly technical understanding of the game is mixed in with curious notions of machismo and intellectual worthiness. Ultimately, what that means is that I can play any way I want, and so can you, even if we're both kidding ourselves.

      -- Bill





      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      Agreed! I think, had we known each other face to face, this would have gone very differently. Online, it's pretty hard to judge the intentions of your allies, and we started off on rocky grounds to begin with. It doesn't help that the year in question was one where we hardly communicated: I remember waiting for a reply from you, and deciding to hedge my bets rather than risk ruin. I was fully expecting you to turn back my way at any moment at the time, so I was trying to play it safe and hoped you would play on towards your own survival rather than vindication. Obviously, that gamble didn't pay off. For what it's worth, I was sincerely planning to keep supporting you from that point onwards.

      It's certainly interesting how this game gets into some interesting psychological territory. I can really appreciate your claim that Diplomacy is a--how did you put it?--a psychological perversion? Ah, an instructive perversion. Lots of food for thought there.

      Daumantas,

      I think you and I may have to talk, indeed. I have the potential of seriously stifling any expansion on your part, and it looks like your alliance with Willow at this point is much more likely to benefit her growth than your own. However, that would be changed quite radically if you could, say, convince me to leave my backside open for you to attack, so I'm going to be very careful. I will be happy to coordinate with you if you can point out some way that we can work together while maintaining some guarantee of safety for Italy. What do you suggest?

      A lot depends also on what France will do ("The King is dead! Long live the King!"), so I hope we'll hear from Mel soon.

      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Thanks for your patience! I am at GMT+5 so a little bit out of synch with most of you I would guess.
      I appreciate the chance to play and will have more to say shortly. Must go look at the map! Let me say at this point, though, that Daniel has left me a France that is destined to complete victory and now the task lies on me to complete the mission! If I fail in that regard the fault lies with me!
      Mel

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n

      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.I think you and I may have to talk, indeed. I have the potential of seriously stifling any expansion on your part, and it looks like your alliance with Willow at this point is much more likely to benefit her growth than your own. However, that would be changed quite radically if you could, say, convince me to leave my backside open for you to attack, so I'm going to be very careful. I will be happy to coordinate with you if you can point out some way that we can work together while maintaining some guarantee of safety for Italy. What do you suggest?
      \nAppropos of nothing, I'd just like to say that Paul's written several succint diplomatic openings during this game that have been, I think, rather well done. If you're interested, Paul, we can talk about the play-through after the game; I think that's where your problem lies, as these openings are not weak. Probably the core issue is the open diplomacy environment, it changes the diplomatic land-scape in rather weird ways. Also, Daumantas is cunning like a diseased prairie dog after this series of SG Diplomacy games, so it's not really a wonder that he's leading the dance in the Med. Still, I like the above sort of technique, strong play for a beginner.

      Posted By: Mel WhiteLet me say at this point, though, that Daniel has left me a France that is destined to complete victory and now the task lies on me to complete the mission! If I fail in that regard the fault lies with me!
      \nI agree with you in full, Mel, but for some reason a communal lunacy has seized the board, causing everybody to think that I'm going to spring something brilliant on you any turn now. They've been waiting for it for the last four years or so, I think.

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Actually, I probably should get you on board before 1911 rolls out, Mel. Here's the situation: I have a too fleet-heavy force and you have an extra fleet flagrantly in English space after a long dance that we started with Daniel ten years back, so it'll take some work to sort out the situation. However, sort it we must, for as the situation stands, England is virtually impregnable, and France is not realistically going to face critical losses, either. Neither of those are quite absolute, but it's a given that I currently hold a slight tactical edge, and substantial losses to either party will only come about due to tactical luck or a long, awkward war that takes too much time considering the eastern situation.

      This being the case, we need bold new initiatives to get ourselves in gear against the east! I suggest that the peace settlement outlined by the ancient regime is essentially valid: I keep the coastal German provinces, including Holland, while you keep Munich and Belgium (over which we might struggle a bit, but which you'll be able to keep if you focus on it). You retreat to MAO and Brest, I retreat from the Irish Sea, leaving only the English Channel occupied. I get my army out of France.

      It takes concrete will at this point to realize the above settlement, but the alternative is that we fight against each other while the Juggernaut finishes Austria and Italy. This is not a deal-breaker for me, I can go with that play, as it happens to be the case that Russia will not be realistically able to challenge me up north, and therefore any real assault on the west will come continentally and over the Mediterranean, overrunning your core positions long before I will be seriously threatened. As described earlier in the discussion, the default outcome of us continuing to fight is that Turkey and Russia come knocking on your back-door. Therefore it only makes sense for you to continue the war against me for two reasons: either you have to think that I'll overrun you immediately if you do not defend aggressively, or you have to think that you can actually overcome me before the Berber pirates get into Spain. My own tactical estimate on both of these points is negative - perhaps you'll agree?

      Speaking tactically for a moment, notice how well your eastern army group lines up with the Italian defense if you'll accept for the moment that Berlin's going to belong to me: you'll find it easy to join Italy in holding the Ven-Tyr-Boh area against Russia with A Mun and A Pru, even pushing back the assault; I have no doubt that Italy and the Austrian remnant will be happy to reward your efforts with gains in those wild Balkans fleshpots where every Power can carve out their piece. This opportunity to stymie the Juggernaut comes pretty cheap, it seems to me - the marginal utility of those two units against me is in making some futile assaults on Berlin or bouncing me in Kiel, neither of which is going to amount to much in comparison, especially as I'll be defending against those moves whether you're making them or not. Might as well seek new directions and find out whether you might replace Austria as Italy's partner against the east. I'm sure that Paul will be happy to develop this train of thought further considering his desperate position and the imminent dominance of the Juggernaut alliance.

      Obviously enough my army in Piedmont is both a great motivator in these peace talks as well as their main problem. If you're interested in peace, we can figure out a suitably spectacular means of getting rid of the army; simply convoying it back to England seems unlikely, I confess, but it's also an entirely serious option if we're really wanting to have a peace here. Depending on the Russian moves it might make sense for me to convoy the army directly to Norway, too.

In all honesty, I am currently trying to keep the diplomatic channel open, so to speak, rather than engaging in long-term alliance building. We don't have much common interests in this situation, but, well, situations change, and I wouldn't like you to think that I have some deep personal purpose in seeking Italy's downfall. Apparently I give that impression out a lot!

      \n
      \n A few initial thoughts.

      Paul: The benign nature of Franco-Italian relations to this point seems a good posture to maintain. The attraction of French cities must be there--I feel it, too! The beaches, the cafes, the girls, ooh la la, as we say. But certainly your attention is better spent on the exotic spices to the east, if you know what I mean. The extra forces you will soon have will assist you in your current war, and would be misused starting a new one.

      Eero,
      While I appreciate the implicit offer of the British Expeditionary Force in defending Paris against Germany, I must decline. French pride prohibits accepting such aid. Feel free to withdraw your force with the same speed and audacity that marked its arrival.
      To a large extent, the French naval presence in the North Atlantic was borne of a desire to show it could be done. Having done it, we can now look for other challenges in other directions. There really is not much up there.

      Peter,
      As the saying goes, 'try, try again'. Anything is possible.

      Willow,
      I am sure you will agree that having French and British armies on your borders is disconcerting. You almost have to build that Army in Moscow now, I would think.

      Daumantas,
      I am impressed by your recovery and handling of the early Russian attack on Turkey. It's good that you are keeping a close watch on your erstwhile enemy. It is true chivalry for you to hold open the door to the Balkans for Willow, holding off the Italian fleets while the inexorable Russian movement into the Balkans continues. Luckily, there are a few centers in coastal areas, so perhaps you can maintain growth with Russia.

      Bill,
      My Austrian brother! I enjoy the narrative you're writing--plucky Austrian defenders, beset on all sides, valiant to the end. We'll see how well we can extend the ending. Or maybe wait for the sequel!

      Mel

      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n This has been a very interesting game to watch. Once it is over I must take the time to review what was said versus what was done and see what repercussions there were from false promises, 'misunderstandings', etc. In may ways, although 'diplomatically' this is the opposite of a gunboat game--in which there is absolutely no overt communication--it may be that in an open diplomatic environment, the best moves to make are those moves that minimize the maximum loss a country may face. Eero implies this doctrine when he talks about defending against particular moves whether the moves are made or not. In a gunboat game, that doctrine usually applies as well.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n

      With Sevastopol built partly to free Warsaw for other uses, what other uses could there be...I wonder.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Picardy and Piedmont sure are easy to mix up for some reason despite them being along different seas and in different countries.

      A bounce in the Channel then, Mel? From the fall onwards, that is. We both have sufficient fleets for a persistent bounce, and that'll be easier for the people of London to stomach. Perhaps start with a supported bounce (two units each) and then scale back once the intentions have been affirmed. Another approach would be for you to support yourself into the Channel in the fall forcibly so as to help me rebuild the unit as an army; building in London would help me make sure that there's no temptation for you to stay in the Channel - a retreat in the spring of 1912 would then leave the Channel empty altogether and me with an extra army to use in the east.

      As you say, though, this is all predicated on the spring disarmament being successful; messing about with the disposition of the Channel would be the death of me as long as that NAO fleet remains. You retreat south, I retreat to Denmark, everybody is happy and the west does not fall prey to Turkish hordes.

      Regarding Belgium, that being the actual substantial issue if we set aside that expeditionary army in Picardy - I'm willing to keep my fingers out of the place this year provided you do not offer succour to the German trump government in Holland; I get Holland and you keep Belgium. If the Channel maneuvers go well I won't be in position to threaten the place too badly afterwards, although I'd like to discuss a trade for the place later; I'll help you get another SC somewhere and you give me Belgium, thus enabling us to have a complete separation of interests in western Europe. But that's a concern for later on.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willows...
      \n
      \nWell, you could have taken into account that *I* am not trusting at all! Instead of happily skipping about on the road to further growth, I now have to worry about my ally slipping into the back the second I suffer a setback on another front? What the hell? You tell an ally about this sort of thing *before* you punch the orders in, not after. Geez.
      \n
      \nI guess this could be just a result of a naturally growing mutual mistrust now that a common external threat is gone and we are both free to consider other options. It's still more useful for both of us to keep to this alliance rather than break it, so that's exactly what I'm planning to do.
      \n
      \nThat said, I don't feel the need to hide that what you did and the way you did it - without prior consultation or warning, with no obvious need for secrecy in sight - makes me feel angry and frustrated.
      \n
      \nAnd edgy. I also want to make clear that, while I value the alliance, I don't particularly want to end up the one footing the bill. An army in Sevastopol is exactly as much as I'm willing to take. Anything more - the obvious army movement, wrong orders (be sure to double check!), and I'm done.
      \n
      \nSo here is us, on the raggedy edge. Don't push me, and I won't push you.
      \n(One does not always get to end a missive with a Firefly quote!)
      \n
      \nOh, and as an extra request... It dawns to me that part of the tension could be relieved if we divulged our long-ish-term plans to each other. That way, we can exchange "You lying cheating bastard! That's HARMFUL to me! How dare you not think of that!" for "Hey, are you doing what you said you'd be doing? Doesn't at all look like it!"
      \n
      \nIn my own case, I am basically planning to crunch down on Italy and then, depending on what the situation on the board is, either send out lone raiders and build up a long chain of convoys, solidifying control of the Med, or prop up a solid defense line against whatever incursion comes my way. There's also a plan in case of Russian attack, which involves... Supporting the italian/austrian armies, hunkering down in the turkish mainland, and waiting for Eero to wade in once your back is turned.
      \n
      \nSound reasonable?
      \n
      \n
      \nAside:
      \n
      \nHeh! If France sorts out the situation with Eero, one way or another, she will be sending a fleet italianwards indeed. Sure, there's some goodwill between - neither side has really made any 'sudden moves' so to speak. But personally, I don't see the current situation as anything more than a mutual "more important things to deal with." Once that's no longer true...
      \n
      \nDoesn't mean France won't help out in various italian struggles until England's done with, one way or another, though... S'called keeping your meal fresh.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Insofar as it matters, I agree with Daumantas to a degree about the Franco-Italian relations in this board set-up; obviously enough France wouldn't mind if it could bowl Italy over. However, the situation is also analogous to the one Italy has in the early game with Austria: your primary victim is also your best protection against the Turko-Russian threat. Attacking your buffer state is tricky in this game because much of the defensive effectiveness of a given front comes from the cohesion of action among the participating forces; an attack to the back has to go perfectly, or otherwise it merely causes the fall of your buffer state that allows the opposition on the other side to push through, resulting in a roughly even split on the buffer. Thus it's only smart to attack your buffer state if the situation is so reduced that you can basically just slip in your own troops in lieu of the buffer's, or when you're basically fine with splitting the buffer state's possessions with the guy on the other side. Famously the Italo-Austrian conundrum on the Calhamer board is that even as decades of play have favoured early stabs between them, Italy actually has two strong Powers waiting for their opportunity east of Austria - who's going to benefit in that situation if Austria crumbles?

      Comparing to the analogue, the French situation in Italy is not quite as grim, as France only needs to handle Turkey as competition when it comes to splitting Italy. For example, if France can slip three fleets to the Med and get one of them to the Tyrhenian Sea, I'd say that the tactical realities are pretty favourable for France, assuming he can make the stab thorough enough to not leave a couple of Italian fleets floating about; the Tyrhenian position backed by sufficient fleets provides strong claims on Tunis and Rome, as well as an equal claim on Naples, which is already slightly more than half of the entire Italian sphere of things. Venice might of course be contested with armies at the same time, so overall it's not at all impossible for France to consider a savage split of Italy followed immediately by a trench war with Turkey coming from the other side. It's not like Turkey alone is any more overwhelming than France, so it's possible for the latter to think that they'll gain the upper hand by betraying Italy.

      On the other hand, reducing Powers is always risky business strategically in that it reduces the options and brings the game closer to the finish line. There is always a price when you go from possibilities to realities, in other words. In this case the concrete dynamic consequence is that if France attacks Italy, then he's basically admitting that he's not going to remove England and make a solo out of the game; without Italy in the middle the Turkish pressure will become a constant as both sides pile up their fleets on the Tyr-Ion area, which will tie up the French forces and basically become an end-game position. The favourable part is that France with Italian possessions and a strong position in continental Europe is a shoo-in as a draw partner, while the negative part is that France might or might not want to keep the game in the middle-game phase to seek for soloing openings.



      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      You're right, I should have notified you- one of the challenges for me in this game is knowing how much to say- too little, and you leave your allies in the dark, too much, and your enemies can establish a perfect defense. Generally, I've been erring on the side of too little, but this was certainly a turn where I should have been more open- the knowledge would have been unlikely to impact the Italian's disbands, and England and France were at a standstill.

      Mel-

      I think it's in our mutual best interest to demilitarize the eastern German corridor- right now we have armies on each other's borders, which is a rather dangerous business. I'd like to see Prussia in Berlin and Bohemia in Vienna.

      -Willow

      \n
      \n
