      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n As to a long term strategy, thus far my attention has been solely on survival and maintaining my territories- I'd certainly like to grow to the southwest, retake St. Pete and meddle in northern affairs if the opportunity presents itself, and push against whatever enemy the board dictates- likely France or Italy.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAndy \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n =========================================

      Heya Mel, Eero, Willow, Paul, DWeird: Andy here.

      Sorry, I forgot about 2-3 games ago (was waiting for a pause, but the next one started up quickly), but I wanted to stop by and... well... kill future PBP (Diplomacy, etc) games here. In short, I've had a "no PBP except for rare exception" policy from the beginning, and in fact shut others down from playtesting PBP stuff actively here. I think the first game got a pass due to it being a hot conversation piece at the time, and basically from time to time I meant to stop by (like game 3, game 5, etc) and say "this is the last one, folks!" but forgot until now.

      It's a teensy distracting, these huge super-active threads. Also, I've been seeing spikes in the DB grinding recently: Most of it was due to Game Chef activity, but I'm trying to keep performance up etc.

      Anyway, for this game: Please carry it out in its entirety here, no problem with this one. But let's make it the last one for now.

      Looks like Snail's Pace ( http://snailspace.forgreatjustice.net/ ) is perfect for this sort of thing, and also RPGNet has a PBP forum as well. Keep it up and going and all, just on a forum more geared for PBP stuff.

      Thanks guys. If I ever move over towards a more traditional/vBulletin-style forum replacement for S-G, PBP may one day return, but in its current form the community can't handle the load.

      Thanks! And I apologize for nor mentioning it sooner. Again, I was trying to catch y'all during a downtime between games to say it, but often the next game would start up before I could catch it. My bad.

      -Andy
      ==========================================











      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n

      \n I for one am enjoying the shit out of following this thread. I'd be happy to have the next one on Snail's Pace.
      \n
      \n

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n Oh, also, all future recruitment for further Diplomacy games can be done here (Stuff to Watch threads, etc) as well.

      -Andy

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yeah, I already decided to talk about what Andy once we got this game wrapped up - it makes sense to recruit players here, but play is a bit too intense for those who aren't interested in Diplomacy; the Vanilla forum structure is not ideal for perennial fringe interests like PBP gaming. Obvious, really, but as nobody's actually organizing this phenomenon we've just been going on here by default.

      \n
      \n
      \n Damn Mel, I totally misread you here - I thought you'd continue Daniel's regime of chatting amiably while we fight for our lives. I guess it was just our thing, then. How embarrassing, I never would've opted for this course had I known that you were serious.

      Also, Austria and Italy totally need to get back to cooperating. The positions are consistently such that they could get more out of them by playing together rather than against each other. Perhaps the French intervention force can turn things around.

      It occurs to me that the Russian army in Warsaw is boned unless Willow attacks War-Sil to bounce Sil-War. However, this has a good chance of leaving Vienna in Italian hands for one more year. Most tricky, Mel just about single-handedly brought the eastern situation much closer to an equilibrium. Heck, there's nothing for the Turk to do about Tunis, either. Italy, Austria and France could fuck up the Turk beyond recognition by forcing both Tunis and Ionia at the same time, in fact, by cutting Alb-Gre on the fall move, although that'd probably be too much of a tactical sacrifice elsewhere.

      Oh, oh! I almost missed the Russian "misorder". Just adorable! This game's going places now, no mistake.
      \n
      \n

      Posted By: Eero TuovinenAlso, Austria and Italy totally need to get back to cooperating. The positions are consistently such that they could get more out of them by playing together rather than against each other. Perhaps the French intervention force can turn things around.
      \nPaul -- Eero is right. If you're willing to forgive my fucking with you, I'm eager to live for a few more turns in this game. Consider supporting me into Vienna; the worst thing that happens is that it bounces and you keep control. Think about it. -- Bill

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I considered suggesting that Vienna operation, but didn't because I feared that Bill would take it as pro-Italian; after all, if Russia supports an attack there, then Austria's just helped Italy keep the place. Aside from that it's an excellent move, of course; note how Italy doesn't need to fear that Austria stabs and goes to Venice, as protecting Venice would have a heavy opportunity cost for Italy, ranging from not claiming Trieste (Tri-Ven that goes through) to taking the fleet out of the Mediterranean war just to cover Venice. Unless Italy is totally certain that Austria's going for a vicious stab, it's not worth it to cover Venice.
      \n

      Posted By: Eero Tuovinen Damn Mel, I totally misread you here - I thought you'd continue Daniel's regime of chatting amiably while we fight for our lives. I guess it was just our thing, then. How embarrassing, I never would've opted for this course had I known that you were serious.
      \nEero,
      If only we could all make such fortuitous mistakes! I am all about amity, It's clear that the less is said the better. I chose to ignore my own cardinal rule--minimize the maximum loss. Ah well. As you can see, I recognize that your forces have two paths to the rest of the map. One way is through France. The second is through Russia. If you choose the latter, you do so with French assistance. If the former, it will be alone. That may not be a deterrent for you at this point. But if it is, then re-establishing a Franco-English concord begins in Brest.

      Mel

      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul,
      The interesting thing about Tunis is that it is clearly and undeniably in the Italian sphere of interest. Turkey never seems to understand that.
      Be that as it may, the French fleet in the Western Mediterranean is badly in need of recoaling and refit after the long journey through the Straits. It would be very much appreciated if you would assist the fleet lay up in Tunis for a year or so until our main Naval Yard in Brest is refurbished by the Royal Navy experts.

      That is, of course, unless the fleet limps its way back to the cold Atlantic.

      Merci, mon ami.

      Mel

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Andy,

      Thanks for your patience! It's been great to be able to do this here.

      Bill,

      I hear you. However, that said, your posts have said exactly the same thing for the last two turns, and in both cases you tried to attack me as hard as possible instead of trying to secure your own skin or fight for your own survival. First you suggested "mutual support", then "not to worry", in both cases citing Eero's logic as the reason. So, this new message from you sounds very familiar.

      (If you want to think of it in those terms, you've effectively conditioned me, at this point, to associate a message from Bill saying, "Yeah, Eero's right, I'm back on board, let's cooperate" with a surprise Austrian attack.)

      But I also think that if we can learn to trust each other, this might be the moment (with France potentially helping us out) to secure our survival for a little longer.

      So, convince me. Lay out your reasoning. What are you hoping to see here, and why the sudden change of heart?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Mel,

      Interesting idea! The balance of power seems to have shifted suddenly in favour of England (unless I am mistaken), but simultaneously your aggressive motions Eastward are making me very happy (as you can imagine), so I see little reason not to support you.

      You'll notice that Italy and France have led a very happy co-existence so far, and I'd like to continue that. Turkey, on the other hand, has been talking up an attack on France for quite a while. (Although it is true that his orders suggest that he would like to see *me* make that attack, not to do so himself, which is understandable but nevertheless hardly pro-French.)

      If we're supporting each other at this point, as Daniel and I used to do, can you tell me how I can best stay in the game? What would you recommend?


      Willow,

      Keep your ears open! I'm looking at my options here, and if things go South, it might be in my best interests to simplify the situation by helping you establish a solid border through the Balkans/Central Europe. I've heard that Italy and Russia are traditional allies in Diplomacy, and I'm beginning to wonder if there's isn't a very good reason for that. Good luck this Fall!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow,
      I am, of course, in a quandary. My aggressive seeming (ok, aggressive) moves against Warsaw are offset by the deceitful and devious betrayal from England that we all must recognize as standard English fare (no offense, Eero). So, while I fully intend to do my best to take Warsaw, while protecting Munich, England's future actions may lead to a rapid change of policy in France. So bear with me as much as you can! You sacrificed Warsaw earlier in the name of peace and survival, this may be a similar situation.
      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      His decisions could potentially really change things, if he's still around!

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.

      If we're supporting each other at this point, as Daniel and I used to do, can you tell me how I can best stay in the game? What would you recommend?

      \nPaul,
      Gladly! First, your best chance of staying in the game hinges on assisting France whenever possible. It is well known in Diplomacy circles that France-Italian combinations are the dominant duopoly in Story Game League games.
      Second, you need to prevent further Russian expansion. The problem with continued entreaties (in an open diplomatic environment) to all parties seeking suggestions on how to work together means its hard for anyone to trust you, Ambiguity is ok. Lack of trust is not.
      Third, you must begin to roll back Turkey. You can start now with Tunis and the Ionian. Sure, it's likely that Turkey and Russia will come to some kind of accord in the face of broad pressure. But they hate each other, and don't trust each other. Nor should they, considering how each has betrayed the other time and time again. It is the nature of the geography. (I hope Willow and Daumantas didn't read that).

      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul -- It's your choice. I thought you might see the value of keeping Russia off your doorstep. Notice that eventually the Eastern powers are going to get their act together and take Serbia. At that point, Trieste is vulnerable. It's particularly vulnerable once Vienna falls to the Russians. I came to you first because I thought I owed you for fucking with you, but I don't particularly care. Hey Willow! Support me into Vienna and I'll support you into Trieste next year! I'll be like the Russian auxiliary army! Don't support a Turkish attack on Serbia this year and I'll support you into Bulgaria next year! You can be Queen of the Balkans! -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n

      \n Thanks, Mel.

      By the by:\n
      Posted By: Mel WhiteThe problem with continued entreaties (in an open diplomatic environment) to all parties seeking suggestions on how to work together means its hard for anyone to trust you, Ambiguity is ok. Lack of trust is not.
      \nWhile I've been trying to collect many parties' thoughts and proposals, and then weigh them before making my decision, I think you (or anyone) can look back on the transcript of this game and see that once I openly commit to something, I follow through reliably.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      I rather *like* the idea of supporting you into Vienna. I'm just trying to gauge whether you're still committed to taking us both down for some reason instead of actually playing to stay alive. If you are, you have my support, duh--as you have all along. Just give me some sense of what you're thinking instead of this "I'm a crazed madman!" bullshit.

      As far as your troops go, I think your army Serbia could easily end up in Budapest or Greece at the end of this year, if we play our cards right and actually cooperate for a change instead of throwing all Austria to Eastern invaders.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Thanks, Mel.

      By the by:

      Posted By: Mel WhiteThe problem with continued entreaties (in an open diplomatic environment) to all parties seeking suggestions on how to work together means its hard for anyone to trust you, Ambiguity is ok. Lack of trust is not.
      \nWhile I've been trying to collect many parties' thoughts and proposals, and then weigh them before making my decision, I think you (or anyone) can look back on the transcript of this game and see that once I openly commit to something, I follow through reliably.


      Paul,
      No doubt, no doubt. That was a bit of a stray thought I had. It certainly needs further investigation. I may just do that.
      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hmm, I remember having my own issues with the crazy madman bullshit in some earlier game. I think I remember something about it being a ploy, but I'm not 100% convinced. Difficult to deal with, anyway, as my first instinct with a broken player is to get all empathetic and console the poor guy.

      For what it's worth, the choice of dealing with Austria or not basically amounts to the danger of a stab vs. giving the enemy a two-unit advantage. Such an advantage is pretty decisive, but the stab might be even worse, potentially. Difficult to say off-hand. Perhaps the critical issue is how you see the board dynamics on a 3-4 year time-scale: if your counter-offense stalls due to not being able to cooperate with Austria, are there any trends on the board that will shift the situation to your advantage in the future? If nothing is going to save you, then you have to work with Austria simply because without him your counter-offense is a pipe-dream - Russia'll start besieging Venice long before your naval force can start making gains against Turkey.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I agree, Eero!

      But I could go all madman myself instead, couldn't I? Yarr!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ah Eero,
      If only the BEF had gone to Norway.
      We should meet in Tannenberg to discuss what could have been.
      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Bill,

      I rather *like* the idea of supporting you into Vienna. I'm just trying to gauge whether you're still committed to taking us both down for some reason instead of actually playing to stay alive. If you are, you have my support, duh--as you have all along. Just give me some sense of what you're thinking instead of this "I'm a crazed madman!" bullshit.

      As far as your troops go, I think your army Serbia could easily end up in Budapest or Greece at the end of this year, if we play our cards right and actually cooperate for a change instead of throwing all Austria to Eastern invaders.
      \nNow you're talking.

      Assume I retreat to Tyrolia. At that point, I can order Tyr-Mun, Tyr-Ven, Tyr-Tri, or Tyr-Vie. Tyr-Mun probably bounces, since Russia and France are eying each other up over it. Tyr-Ven potentially bounces vs. Tri-Ven, and makes me look like an idiot. Tyr-Tri similarly potentially bounces, and also possibly cuts Tri S Ser or Tri S Ser-Bud, also making me look like an idiot. So all that's left is Tyr-Vie.

      Consider Russia's options. She can take Serbia with Bud-Ser, Rum S Bud-Ser or vice versa, but doing so leaves a hole in her lines, so she probably won't unless she really trusts Turkey or really thinks she's going to lose Warsaw and is willing to antagonize Turkey even more than she has already. She can support Boh-Vie with Bud, but she has to expect an attack from Serbia, so she could order Boh S Bud-Vie, not expecting anyone to want to attack Boh. But that leaves Bud open unless she slides Rum-Bud, expecting to bounce in Bud with army Serbia.

      In any case, Army Trieste is dispositive. Tri S Tyr-Vie either bounces with Bud-Vie or wins against Boh-Vie. Tri S Ser-Bud puts Austria in Budapest unless Rum S Bud, and potentially causes Tyr-Vie to bounce with Boh-Vie.

      So, the worst thing I can do leaves you no worse than you were before, while the best thing (from your perspective) puts you +1. So it seems like a reasonable gamble for you, from my perspective.

      From my perspective, I'm just looking to end the year with 1 SC instead of no SCs, so I'm not in a position to be playing any cute tricks anymore.

      -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \nJust note - if it wasn't for the french surprise incursion, you'd see me talking to the austrians and the italians right now. Only thing anywhere close to a growth area for you, and if you don't make sure I'm in Serbia at the end of the next year, you'll be stuck with one and a half unit against the italian's/austrian's two or three.

      \nWillow,
      An excellent riposte that certainly is the cause of great consternation in Paris. Consider though what use France could be to you if England continues its aggression on French soil. In this critical moment. weakening France simply strengthens your great enemy, England. The loss of Warsaw, which you were prepared to sacrifice earlier, plus French retention of Munich, simply ensures that England will not be able to roll over France in its continued conquest of the continent. Should English attacks continue, you can be sure France will be willing to sue for peace, at generous terms. Allied French armies in the vicinity of St Petersberg must certainly be an attractive feature for you. Weaken France and those armies go away.
      Mel

      -Willow
      \nBill,
      What of the narrative? What a strange twist in the story should Austrian forces that for 10 years have been fighting for King, country and family in the Balkans against Italy, Turkey, and Russia, now embroil themselves on German soil fighting France. No one wants to read that.

      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas,
      Although Eero has talked often of 'balancing' in Diplomacy, the opposite is an equally valid policy, 'bandwagoning'--or whatever you might call it. For the game to reach a conclusion, some countries must be eliminated. The best time and best way to do that is when allies are certain. Providing assurances as Russia's 'best bet' now, simply reduces your flexibility, and extends the potential that you will have to fight your way west through a strengthened and unburdened Russia. Strike now! Seize the day! Russia won't be grateful for what you don't do, but we will recognize you for what you do.
      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill,

      If you're serious about being back on board, I think this might be the time for you to do it. Turkey has some chance of either being pushed back in the Mediterranean or maybe even attacking Russia. Russia has to worry about losing Warsaw (and if Warsaw falls, Eero and Mel might make common cause over Moscow).

      Turkey doesn't have the leverage to attack your territory unless you decide to stab me in Italy, because then I'd have to disband and Daumantas can get through into the Adriatic--then you're done, I'm pretty sure.

      Overall, I think there's a good chance that Turk/Russian pressure on your "area" could really diminish in the coming year or two, and if you're ready and in position to take advantage of it, you could reclaim your former strength.

      I hope you'll consider this course of action: I'm willing to support you, but at the moment I'm still looking to balance helping you with some set of orders that prevents various possible ways you could try to screw me over (after all that "I'll teach you a lesson!" talk, earlier). That's not exactly 100% efficient, as far as our cause (survival) is concerned: if you show you're willing to work with me, I think we could get establish something a little more lasting.

      I wouldn't recommend the attack on Munich, personally: how are you going to do anything useful with both your armies so far apart? You'd be reliant on other people's support to accomplish anything, and that's sometimes... unreliable in this open negotiation climate.

      Mel,

      You have my support for Tunis.

      \nThe game seems to be wrapping up rather speedily at this point, and there is a good chance I'd never get the time to move on you after I do that.       \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul, the Tunis situation is pretty clear-cut: if France attacks and Italy supports, Turkey can deny the attack by cutting Tyr. However, if Italy attacks with French support, then Turkey cannot deny the attack, assuming Naples cuts Ionian. Now, in this situation the Sultan should be all but certain that you won't be playing Tyr-Tun, as France is under a lot of pressure and probably won't be supporting you right now, as he has his own problems to consider and anything that doesn't net him SCs is not worthwhile for him. Therefore Turkey will either play Ion-Tyr, Tun S Ion-Tyr, or potentially something completely unrelated such as Ion S Gre-Alb (thinking that you can't get a quorum with the Frenchman about Tunis anyway). This all makes your chances of success in capturing Tunis rather dim, and I don't quite understand what Mel's playing at with you - it'd be good for him to take the place, but even trying to do it has a bad expected value for him when it's so likely that Turkey will play a counter-move; thus his best play is to ignore the whole situation, which makes talking you into supporting him useless for anything but confusing you into playing some suboptimal moves.

      Alternatively, France is naive and really wants to try a simple Wes-Tun. Who knows. Either way, I recommend that you not count on a miracle French rescue at this point; rather, try to outguess the Turk - ideally you could push your Naples fleet to the Ionian at some point, as that's the only credible three-fleet position for you to hold and develop once you achieve it. Be patient and don't let either your naval position or the Austrian Balkans position crumble quickly, and often enough your opponent makes the mistakes for you.

      Clever insight about the pre-deadline communications, by the way; risky, though, as the most serious players will likely be watching the communications before the deadline.



      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011

      \n
      \n Fall 1911, prior to retreats

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n A bad start for the new France. Ultimately, based on hope rather than anything else, I expected a benign Spring as potential enemies and friends waited to see which way France was going to go. The mistake in this thinking was that while it was the first year of war for me, it was the tenth year of on-again, off-again war with France for Eero. It's hard to turn off that mindset like a light switch. The mistake cost me Brest.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n edited January 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n deleted
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The Russo-Turkish distrust is reaching critical levels as Russia covers vulnerable positions and Turkey increases force commitment on the mutual border. The current Turkish force is sufficient for a stabbing attack despite the Russian home guard in Sevastopol, but only if the assault can come as a surprise; if Russia is ready, Turkey doesn't really have a very attractive war at hand, except perhaps in mid-length projection - Turkey could support Austria and Italian forces in a land war in Vienna and Budapest easily enough, as those positions are much more critical for the westerners than the Turkish land holdings, which could in 2-3 years result in Russia slowly buckling under the overpowering enemy force.

      On the other hand, assuming that the two can continue cooperating (a view that I personally doubt, but that surely will have to be the official truth now more than ever), the Russian position on the Balkans is now absolutely dominant as the Czarinna reaches the coveted Rum-Bud-Vie front-line; this position is easy to use both for advancing the Turk quickly through Serbia and Trieste as well as advancing Russia's own forces, at least if additional armies can be brought to bear. As the tactical situation stands, Russia needs a fourth army for the frontlines if she is to make a smart advance into eg. Trieste; it remains to be seen if she can spare one. Meanwhile the Turk is relatively stuck and dependant on Russian largesse - an assault on Serbia won't succeed without Russian aid, and Paul has proven a conscientious defender in Italy, belying any hopes of quick naval victory. Overall very interesting times for the Juggernaut as Russia is clearly the more vulnerable of the two in a surprise attack situation while Turkey is near completely dependent on the Czarinna for any progress he might hope to make!

      The Austrian situation is grim, but Serbia is a good position to wait for an opportunity: all three Powers surrounding the position have certain motivation for keeping the place out of enemy hands, and only Russia has a force that can actually make a supported attack without foreign support - and even that requires nigh-suicidal over-extension of the Russian line, so it's not likely to happen on the spring move. Austria is, I think, in a fine position to wait out the current troop congestion on the Balkans; once any of the external flanks of the Italo-Russo-Turkish trio erupts with new disturbances and forces start moving towards more critical positions, the Serbian army might conseivably make a comeback. Even in my typical optimism regarding the chances of minor Powers I do have to admit that the open diplomacy environment does make for an awful handicap for the small fish; were I playing the Austrian position in a normal game I would have no hesitation about arranging for a fall attack on Budapest or Trieste (against the stronger Power, obviously) with appropriate support from the other party, but this is of course much more difficult to achieve in an open environment. From the Austrian viewpoint the ideal year 1912 will be such that the neighbours of Serbia make offers and unilaterally commit to supporting Serbian movements so that he can make a supported maneuver without having to reveal his intentions in advance.

      The Italian situation is clearing up consistently, which might or might not be to Paul's advantage: with Austria weakening and the Balkans falling to Italy, Russia and Turkey the natural moment for a Turko-Russian stab approaches rapidly. However, if the stab doesn't come and the two decide to kill off Italy instead in preparation for facing the west, then Italy's in deep trouble with the Russian armies that are beginning to be in positions that enable them to project force against Trieste and Venice. The continental front is clearly on the defense, so Italy needs to move fast: if France supports Italy into Tunisia in 1912 and Italy manages to keep hold of Trieste, then the position is still mid-term defensible, thus putting pressure on the Turko-Russian alliance. On the other hand, if Italy fails to make gains this coming year and the Turko-Russian war does not begin, then it might be that we've seen the last viable Italian position as a Great Power.


      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm about as satisfied with the results as I can be- it's a shame Daumantas didn't follow up on the Serbian attack, and also a shame that our border relations seem to be stressed- but I'm certain that even with the Ionian falling, you'll be able to give Paul a valuable lesson in just how one retreats behind enemy lines, and proceed to kick much butt.

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ah, now I see!

      Mel's "support me into Tunis" move was just the same thing Daniel pulled earlier: an attempt to disguise a move into the Western Med as something entirely other than playing for position towards a move on the MAO.

      Don't worry, Mel; I won't hold it against you. Would you consider the possibility of some real help in the future, though? Once I'm out of the way, I don't think it'll take too long for Daumantas's pirates (Arrrh!) to get to your Southern shores.

      Willow,

      Yes, I'm fully expecting the retreat to Apulia. That's why I got into position to cover Rome and Venice. It strikes me as interesting, however, that it certainly would be nice for you to have both of Daumantas' fleets far away from home now that almost all his "local" forces are tied up holding territory. Is it... coincidence? ... that you're pointing this out to him now? A little helpful nudging never hurts when it's about moving forces away from a defensive position, I suppose!

      Daumantas,

      Do we really want to bounce back and forth for a while longer here? I don't really see either of us making much headway here. If you can come with anything a little more concrete than your earlier offers (which amounted to, "Why don't you look the other way and retreat from my forces, neighbour?"), I'd like to see if we can come up with anything more mutually beneficial. The local situation is still very much more in favour of Willow (or even Bill) gaining territory than either you or me.

      So, try again?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul\n
      Posted By: Paul T.Ah, now I see!

      Mel's "support me into Tunis" move was just the same thing Daniel pulled earlier: an attempt to disguise a move into the Western Med as something entirely other than playing for position towards a move on the MAO.

      Don't worry, Mel; I won't hold it against you. Would you consider the possibility of some real help in the future, though? Once I'm out of the way, I don't think it'll take too long for Daumantas's pirates (Arrrh!) to get to your Southern shores.
      \nPaul,
      France is not at war with Turkey, nor with Russia, mudslinging and hyperpatriotic journalism to the contrary. France is at war with England, and calls upon all Liberty loving nations to come to our aid!

      The move to Western Med was exactly as it was presented, an effort to de-escalate the conflict with England. The situation at the end of Spring was correctly interpreted by Daumantas--a situation where the Wes Med fleet would have to 'rush back' to the West to defend France. All since then, including discussion regarding Warsaw, has been a deception aimed at England--certainly not at Italy. Wes Med's attention is now entirely on the Atlantic.

      Paul and Daumantas,
      If you are both truly interested in looking for another path forward, let me mediate an Armistice and future plan to counter England's dominance.
      The prize is a split of the Iberian peninsula between you.
      The mechanics involve Turkey's retreat from the Ionian to the Eastern Med--not Apulia. This is a sign of good faith. Subsequently, I invite Tunis to move to NAf. Italy must abstain from seeking Tunis. As Mediterranean powers, we will need four fleets to defend the Straits of Gibraltar, once England masses its forces south.
      The movement to Iberia will be accomplished via convoys conducted by fleets not involved in defending the Straits.
      I accept that this will weaken France in the near term. In return, Brest will be liberated, France will be awarded all of Great Britain, as well as all contemporary English possessions at the time of the fall of London, other than St Petersburg were that still to be in English hands. St Petersburg will be returned to Russia, if Russia has not already reclaimed it.

      In the event Italy does take Tunis following a Turkish move to NAf, France will assist Turkey reclaim Tunis regardless of other demands on French forces.

      Daumantas and Willow,
      Although England would much prefer the resolution of the 'Western Triangle' remain separate from resolution of the 'Eastern Triangle', there is no reason that this need be the case. It is actually not true that the path to England runs through French possessions. That path actually runs through English continental and Scandinavian possessions. I, therefore, have no qualms about encouraging an accommodation between you that frees Russian armies to shift north and west. The only exception with regards to French possessions is Munich, which will be pivotal in Russian offensives aimed at Berlin and Kiel and, as long as it is in French hands, will assist in such offensives.

      Come to some decision on Serbia; whether as an adjunct or possession. Initiate a discussion on equity, to balance Russia's gains in central Europe with compensation for Turkey. For Russia, Note that Italian and Turkish fleets will be necessary in any efforts to counter England, and are well suited to complement Russian armies. Most important, recognize that English forces are growing at a rate neither of you--none of us--can match alone. United, however, there is still time to prevent a Europe dominated by Britain.

      Bill, You and I are in desperate times. Live or die, we will never surrender!

      Viva le France!
      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n All:
      I had been ignoring Jason Morningstar's thread about ignoring threads but I have stopped ignoring it because you never know what might be interesting. I see that it is actually a post about this Diplomacy thread. I did not realize that larger threads cost money. Naive of me, since everything costs money.

      So, despite Andy's forbearance, I propose that we transition the game fully to the Diplomacy web page.

      We can continue there either as a Public Press only game (similar to what is going on here), or we can conduct diplomacy via direct 'secret' messages as in normal games.

      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Just how much of an impact are we making? I'm lazy and don't want to change my habits in the middle of a game, and would rather we just be done with it here. On the other hand, if the existance of this thread is bleeding Andy dry, then we should definitely move.
      \n
      \nAnyway.
      \n
      \nSince Willow's is chill about that army in Armenia, I have absolutely no reason not to get back to a troop positions conductive to a russian alliance - the reason it was put there was to counteract a possible (unlikely) move into Armenia as well as put the army in position in case Russia starts breaking apart at the seams. Neither seems to be happening and Willows is now understandably calm enough about Russia's prospects to not worry about that army's placement.
      \n
      \nThe only question is whether I want to take Mel's offer or continue on pounding Italy. In case of the latter... Assuming russian cooperation, loss of Trieste and Serbia is definite, and loss of Venice is probable.
      \n
      \nMel's offer sparks greeds in my little turkish heart - there is certainly a lot that control of the Iberian can mean for Turkey, both as last-ditch defense and as propping up a window open, so to speak.
      \n
      \nThere are just too many little ifs and buts for me to ponder the offer seriously, though - i) in a long line of convoys, something can always go wrong - both as accident and as italian hindrance (oh, sorry, your army didn't make it!); ii) Italy has no free armies to move to the Iberian. Even if I uphold my end of the bargain, it is contingent on Italy not being dead - something that Russia can work forwards semi-effectively now, too, provided fleet cover for Italy is sparse - which it would be under this plan. iii) France has no free units to help me retake Tunis if it's lost - West Med is pegged for English defense. iv) Precarious gains away from anywhere I can defend them, instead of finally getting the italian issue done with, which nets me a lot more probable SC gain.
      \n
      \nI'm certainly willing to consider a "Stop the english at MAO" strategy, but there are too many variables here that are completelly out of my control for me to support this plan.
      \n
      \nSo.
      \n
      \nWillows,
      \n
      \nTrieste and Serbia next year?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      The move to Western Med was exactly as it was presented, an effort to de-escalate the conflict with England. The situation at the end of Spring was correctly interpreted by Daumantas--a situation where the Wes Med fleet would have to 'rush back' to the West to defend France. All since then, including discussion regarding Warsaw, has been a deception aimed at England--certainly not at Italy. Wes Med's attention is now entirely on the Atlantic.
      \nSo, that means you'll be disbanding A Prussia then?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Mel,

      That's interesting, what you're describing there. I don't understand why convoys are necessary, unless you are suggesting that e.g. Turkish armies are being convoyed all the way to England.

      Would it be a matter of say, a Turkish fleet in Portugal and an Italian fleet in Spain? Daumantas, maybe we can arrange that and still leave you plenty of time and space to kill me.

      I'm trying to imagine a full-scale war between England and France, and Russia throughout the Balkans... can Turkey grab enough territory fast enough not to become a target herself? It'll be interesting to see.

      There are also a number of advantages to weakening both England and France in one maneuver. Because if they start working together, things might not look so good for the rest of us. Keeping the big boys in check is generally a good thing in such a case, no?







      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm generally on board with a "detach a portion of forces for use in the west, continue hostilities" plan. But devil's in the details (for example - taking Portugal by fleet is a near impossibility - you'd have to be in MAO to do that, but MAO will be under French or English control), and I don't yet see anything that I'd be happy with.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1\u202611121314151617\u202619\xbb

    Comments

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Andy is a big boy, I suggest we play by his tune; he said that we can finish the game here as is, so let's do just that and look for alternatives for the next game, should that become pertinent.

      As for the Mediterranean situation, it doesn't seem like a bad idea for the French fleet to support Italy into Tunis, actually - I'm willing to do a short armistice with France to bring this about, no problem. A moratorium on the naval war in MAO, say? The dividents of this action seem pretty good, as Italy likely won't need any more help after the one push, assuming he can keep the position for the fall and thus force Turkey the disband an unit.

      Willow, now that I'm here: once you build in Moscow this winter, I suggest that we work carefully to disengage; I think that you'll agree with me in that escalating our relationship at this juncture would mostly just encourage Turkey to take liberties in the Balkans. To achieve a secure disengagement I'm willing to forego the usual StP-Mos move this spring, thus allowing you to move south from Moscow without having to bounce me; you know that I'm to be trusted in this matter by looking at the map and projecting your own response to a foolhardy StP-Mos stab - I could not hold Moscow in the fall no matter how much force I'd move east in the spring, so it is completely unrealistic to expect me to flagrantly provoke you in this. I will, of course, move to defend StP in the spring, but the move in question will not have offensive capability (you know the move I'm discussing here); once you move Moscow away and we return to status quo, I'll be able to disengage my extra safeguards as well. As always, it benefits us both to keep the price of security low on our mutual border by limiting the amount of force we station in the area.

      All that being said, let me add that I'm happy for the success of our Russian allies in the Balkans, and we look forward to sharing the European mainland with the Romanov family. Keep up the good work!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Keep the italian war going in perpetuity? I see what use England would have of it, but not so for France.
      \n
      \nEven if assigning the West Med fleet for something other than MAO defense was a good idea (and that's a pretty big if)...
      \n
      \nThe faster this gets resolved, the faster whoever is left alive can prop up France with fleets - doubt that there'll be anything else useful to do at that point, anyway. And... I doubt it's going to be Italy - not soon enough to matter, anyway.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdBut devil's in the details (for example - taking Portugal by fleet is a near impossibility - you'd have to be in MAO to do that, but MAO will be under French or English control).
      \nNot so, Daumantas.

      If you moved a fleet into Spain (SC), you could from there slip into Portugal, with my fleet taking your place in Spain.

      I guess we'll have to hear more about this from Mel. Will he accept Eero's talk of non-aggression, or would he rather continue with something like the plan he's outlined?

      Supporting Italy into Tunis could be a solid encouragement to get the three of us on board with this kind of scheme.



      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Although Turkey is not a beneficiary, most other Powers on the board have a vested interest in Italy surviving, including both France and England (and Russia, as a matter of fact). We all like seeing Turkey bottled up and impotent in the corner, you see, and there's not one among us who'd benefit of a Turkey that combines the Italian SCs into his might, lurking in his corner potent, invincible and absolute master of all that is Mediterranean. Much better for us if Italy prospers, pushes back the Turk and refutes resolution of the eastern triangle.

      I'm only too happy to negotiate with France to help transfer some aid to Italy; the Italian situation is in balance, even a small amount of foreign aid could decisively tip the scales against the Turk. I'm sure that Mel would also much rather see a surviving Italy proffering him prospective aid in Iberia rather than a massive, expansionist Turkey with too many fleets to spare, and of course he is as concerned as I am with the Russo-Turkish expansionism on the continent - Italy is in ideal position to constrain such developments, offering constant pressure on the Balkans. I'm only too happy to push strongly for detente with the French over this matter, as a strong Turkey is no more to my benefit than anybody else's at the moment. In fact, the matter is so important that if Mel refuses aid to Italy, I might just have to try to bring help myself somehow.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n France fights for its survival and sovereignty. We will not make war against those who have not transgressed against France.
      We foolishly gave England one year to establish peace. Now, we will fight for French soil to our last breath and last drop of blood.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      While I am not feeling particularly betrayed about your unit in Armenia, I am somewhat concerned about it- after all it's there, why not put it to good use. Thus, I'm going to hold off until the fall to support you into Serbia; I'll need to see you move Armenia away. I'd like it even move if you ordered BLA-Con; that way I can do things with Sev like move it further north and away from our border. You'll probably want to do those moves anyway, what with the Aegean and East Med completely exposed to the Italian.

      -Willow
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenWillow, now that I'm here: once you build in Moscow this winter, I suggest that we work carefully to disengage; I think that you'll agree with me in that escalating our relationship at this juncture would mostly just encourage Turkey to take liberties in the Balkans. To achieve a secure disengagement I'm willing to forego the usual StP-Mos move this spring, thus allowing you to move south from Moscow without having to bounce me; you know that I'm to be trusted in this matter by looking at the map and projecting your own response to a foolhardy StP-Mos stab - I could not hold Moscow in the fall no matter how much force I'd move east in the spring, so it is completely unrealistic to expect me to flagrantly provoke you in this. I will, of course, move to defend StP in the spring, but the move in question will not have offensive capability (you know the move I'm discussing here); once you move Moscow away and we return to status quo, I'll be able to disengage my extra safeguards as well. As always, it benefits us both to keep the price of security low on our mutual border by limiting the amount of force we station in the area.
      \nI am looking into this extremely skeptically- you seem to be garnering quite a bit of utility from that unit in my corner of the map. However, if you feel you need it elsewhere, go right ahead- I'll be here watching, ready to evacuate Moscow when I'm satisfied its safe.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Italy's foreign policy for this coming year depends almost entirely on the diplomatic statements of her neighbours.

      Dear sirs (and lady), we hope to hear from you in the near future.

      Is France interested in lending a hand in the Mediterranean? Or still in need of refueling?

      Will Turkey consider any terms for a ceasefire, with the goal of both nations securing gains elsewhere? Or shall we each plant a raider in each other's backyard and enjoy the havoc?

      What gains are Russia and Austria seeking this coming year, and is either interested in assistance or cooperation?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'll clarify my explanation a bit, Willow: I'm not suggesting that I'd be moving away with my army StP - I'm just going to hold with it this turn to allow you to vacate Moscow, thus making my own position in StP more secure. The tactical issue is that while you have an army in StP and another in Warsaw, you could conceivably try a blitz to Livonia and a supported attack on StP in the fall, routing my stalwart home defense. For this reason I am suggesting, constructively, that we would both benefit if you move away from Moscow, trusting in my promise to hold this spring. You do not need to be certain about my fidelity here as long as you're going to keep two of your armies in the vicinity anyway: if I betray my promise, you can just support yourself into Moscow in the fall, foiling my (stupid) stab. Meanwhile, I will play a defensive move with my fleet in Livonia to ensure that you do not make that attempt at StP, after all. (I'll say it because I'm trying to be as explicit as possible here: my fleet in Livonia has no offensive potential whatsoever against you, but it does guarantee that no amount of force coming from the south is able to threaten StP.)

      I think that our arranged bounce in an empty Moscow serves us both reasonably well, as it ties down only one unit on each side in defense. Moving your side of the defensive line to Moscow unilaterally is not acceptable to me, as it allows the aforementioned quick assault on StP, thus obliviating the point of keeping only a limited force on position. It is true that in the short term your defense is just as effective with an army in Moscow as it is with the bounce we've been practicing, but this is an unstable situation: once you have the army in Moscow, I'm forced to commit a second unit to the defense, and although this unit will be a fleet this year, it won't be that for long: I have no motivation whatsoever to not replace a fleet in Livonia with a second army ASAP if our border situation spirals out of control - if I'm going to commit two units to the StP defense, they might as well be the most appropriate units for local needs, and that means a second army that can threaten Moscow effectively. This in turn means that you need to commit a second army yourself to counteract, and then we are both the poorer for it; we'd have doubled our military commitment to our mutual border for no good reason.

      Note that insofar as the immediate tactical situation goes I'm already committing that second unit to StP this year, as there's no way I'm going to risk the Livonian blitz. This pretty much takes my fleet out of any useful action for a full year, meaning that I won't be losing anything materially by bringing that second army in via Norway next year, should that prove necessary - I can't get my fleet back without bringing in the army, so why not. Thus this potentially irreversible decrement in border relations can be realized in a perhaps surprising short time-frame; I won't be sitting in Livonia with that fleet until some vague future time, it'll be in 1913 when the second army lands and in 1914 you'll have a supported attack on Moscow to contend with. The decision-point for you is not whenever you feel like retreating from Moscow, it's right now: if Moscow's not empty in the fall, I'll be moving my fleets into position for convoy in 1913 and keeping my Livonian fleet in position, which all is just more reason for me to go through with the second army landing.

      In comparison, going with the initiative I'm offering here means that we'll continue as we've done so far: we bounce in Moscow with two armies while the majority of our respective forces concern themselves with other matters. For great Powers of our stature this is basically a peaceful, rational relationship that I see no reason to change; it is, in fact, a perfect set-up for a segue to a clean end-game three-way draw with whoever those Mediterraneans pick as winner in their southern wars. Meanwhile we both have active borders to the south, with plenty of opportunities; further progress in the Balkans or a simple Sev-Arm are moves full of potential for you in comparison to either a futile assault on the impregnable StP position or an aggressive fortification in Moscow.

      I'll add that if the above seems too histrionic to you and you find it incredible that I would go to these lengths over the StP border, consider again: my French relations are well under control, and I am basically guaranteed a position in any draw on this table, but only as long as I keep the StP position well in hand, preventing you from enroaching into the Nordic area or building fleets up there. StP is a geopolitical treasure for England in this position. There is no tactical price I would not pay to preserve my position in StP, and making peace with France is just one of the things I'll be willing to commit if that's what it takes to secure my position.

      I trust that the above detailed argument answers all questions as to why I'm suggesting the course of action I am. If there are any questions, I'll be happy to elucidate. Also note that vacating Moscow is not the only tactical security you can offer here: if you'll move the Warsaw army to Galicia, thus ensuring that you don't have a second army next to Livonia, that works for me just as well. I don't think that it's as good for you as emptying Moscow, as a Sev-Mos bounce is a more effective defensive move in many ways, but it's your call as long as the threat of a blitz on StP evaporates.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow --

      Since you're the only one who can unilaterally kick me out of Serbia, it's clear that my continued existence in the game depends upon your forbearance. You've already told Daumantas he can't have Serbia in the spring; what will it take to extend your mercy for another season? I'm not proud; I'm on my hands and knees here. Literally begging.

      -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Bill, you should ask Turkey and Italy for help as well. Turkey particularly is fully capable of supporting you in place, and this seems like a good move for the Sultan: there is no tactical benefit for Turkey at this point in having Russia overrun Serbia and Trieste while he stands still himself, after all.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n

      \n\nJanuary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenBill, you should ask Turkey and Italy for help as well. Turkey particularly is fully capable of supporting you in place, and this seems like a good move for the Sultan: there is no tactical benefit for Turkey at this point in having Russia overrun Serbia and Trieste while he stands still himself, after all.
      \nThat's a good thought, Eero. Daumantas, Willow has been stiffing you over Serbia for at least a year: a "misorder" here, an outright fuck-you there. It would be a minor bit of insurance for you to support Serbia to hold. I'm just saying.
      \n

      \n Eh.
      \n
      \nUnless Willows thinks Turkey can be easily taken while simultaneously holding back the English, there is no reason for her to deny me builds.
      \n
      \nRussia won't solo unless she can retake StP, which seems rather unlikely at this point, and there are certain preconditions for a three-way draw - no England in the Med, basically.
      \n
      \nFrance is in a precarious position, and a dead Turkey is a Turkey that won't be able to muster enough fleets to prevent England from grabbing a coastal Mediterranean SC or two, which might very well be enough to push England over 17.
      \n
      \nCould possibly be avoided if Turkey could be removed quickly and without a mess (and propping up Italy, for example?), but I for one have not yet seen such a thing happening.
      \n
      \n
      \nI'm not likely to do that, Bill - which is not to say that I won't.

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n

      Would you care for an arranged bounce in Armenia this fall?

      -Willow

      \n

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      You and I should carefully consider our strategy for the upcoming year- assuming attacks on Trieste and Serbia are successful, the next step will be an attack on the Italian homeland. Fortunately for you, you're already well in place- my armies will have a harder time getting into position. We'll want to pursue some sort of demilitarization in the Balkans- if you can get a fleet into the Ionian, and hold it, we can begin to convoy armies out of the Balkans into Italy.

      -Willow


      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willows, I have a mediocre enough of a ground force for a demilitarization of the Balkans to be already be a done deal - doubt a single army in Serbia or whatever ends up to be the troop composition is going to be any dangerours to you.
      \n
      \n'sides, I'm not sure it's in either of our interests for you to push deeper into Italian soil - thems're coastal areas, best held and defended by fleets. Venice you can probably take without convoys - and it'd probably be a bit of a back and forth between who holds it during the actual italian warfare, the way units are positioned. One way or another, it's probably best if you used your armies to begin developing a proper westward european front - if I'm reading the english/french situation right, we might need it soon.
      \n
      \nPaul,
      \n
      \nYou interested in a small anti-English deal? Not that dangerous to you, a bit dangerous to me.
      \n
      \n

      Tell me more! I'm not sure what you're talking about.

      (Of course, given your discussion of anti-Italian strategy, I'm going to be a little skeptical of anything you suggest, so I would appreciate if you could talk specifics: if you want me on board, you'll have to outline some kind of plan that actually makes sense for me to pursue.)



      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Fall 1912 Movement (prior to retreats)

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n And then there were five:
      Eero's England maintains a lead with 10 centers, but Daniel's France, Daumantas's Turkey, and my Russia also have seats at the big kids' table, with 7 centers each. Paul's Italy has but three centers, but he's still in the game.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Sadly, the end of the road for Germany and Austria. Having surrendered, Germany's army in Holland disbands. Austria can retreat to Serbia but with no supply centers, Austria will also be eliminated.

      England masses its forces to take Holland, and once again mistakes Picardy for Piedmont.

      The Russo-Turkish bounce in Armenia was agreed, I believe. Moscow's move to Sevastopol is a sign of distrust between the Juggernaut, designed to counter Black Sea to Sev. And the English move to Moscow is once again England's demonstration that regardless of what may be said, such as "I'll stop at St Petersburg' English promises are nonsense. Russia is fortunate that Turkey, at least, is trustworthy. Had Turkey not moved to Armenia. Moscow would now be in English hands. A trade of Armenia for Moscow. A bad deal! Down with England! Wake up peoples!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: WillowAnd then there were five:
      Eero's England maintains a lead with 10 centers, but Daniel's France, Daumantas's Turkey, and my Russia also have seats at the big kids' table, with 7 centers each. Paul's Italy has but three centers, but he's still in the game.
      \nIt's Mel's France now, please, for better or for worse.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow,
      I will gladly pay you Munich today for Holland on Tuesday.
      I encourage you to start making your way west and north. You may have given up on reclaiming St Petersburg through attacks from the south. That means you will need to retake it through Scandinavia. I will accept the loss of Munich as the price for England's defeat.
      As you move west, consider your timing and your target carefully. Defeating England will require fleets in the Atlantic. Three English fleets bottle up the Mediterranean. A handful of units hold St Petersburg indefinitely if attacked from the south. Until and unless you reclaim St. Petersburg, you will need France to face England. And France will need you! One hundred years ago, in this setting, we French learned a hard lesson about making war on Russia. It is time for the English to learn that same lesson!
      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Keep your friends close and your enemies closer.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The devil you know is better than the devil you don't.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul,
      \n
      \nBasically, I wanted to arrange a bounce in West Med between our two fleets, to deny England access to the Med. A comprise plan, of course - a full one would have been a move to West Med and NAf by both our fleets. Good play by the French made that unnecessary this time, but we may still need to.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nAnd I'm pretty much set for the endgame, if no ugly surprises are forthcoming! A bit more war, a bit more SCs, a bit more seeing what happens, and a bit more reacting accordingly... But all of the major decisions are probably behind me. Ah, the serenity!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Mel, that's... cryptic. Are you sure you didn't forget to turn on the whisper function for the secret communication you're not supposed to do..?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n No whispering allowed!
      It's all mind games.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdPaul,

      Basically, I wanted to arrange a bounce in West Med between our two fleets, to deny England access to the Med. A comprise plan, of course - a full one would have been a move to West Med and NAf by both our fleets. Good play by the French made that unnecessary this time, but we may still need to.




      \nA single English fleet cannot do much in the Med. But, of course, if England really were serious about assisting Italian survival, that fleet could make a difference.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm all for assisting Italy's survival - I considered moving to Med for that sole purpose long and hard here, actually, and only desisted because I knew that the Franc would be quick to take advantage of my selfless gesture.

      I should note that Mel's disparaging me for no reason. We agreed with Willow quite explicitly that our bounce in Moscow would continue in the fall, as is in fact necessary for me to maintain security in StP. Despite third-party propaganda the trust and cooperation between our two empires is at an all-time high, and independent observers are all rather thrilled about the chance of peace in Europe, led and coordinated by the great English and Russian empires. Once the warmongers have been put down like the rabid dogs they are, I doubt that any further reason for mobilization on a continental scale even exists.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n My brave Austrian soldiers begin their long march to the sea, hoping for succor that will not come! It is too, too sad!

      Being knocked out of a game of Diplomacy really makes me consider my own mortality. Ask not for whom the bell tolls, and all that. Brrr.
      \n

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n At least it's not brother against brother.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenI'll clarify my explanation a bit, Willow: I'm not suggesting that I'd be moving away with my army StP - I'm just going to hold with it this turn to allow you to vacate Moscow, thus making my own position in StP more secure.
      \nPerhaps I misunderstood. I often get 'hold' and 'attack Moscow' mixed up.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul --

      Yeah, even if you had tried to keep Russia out of Trieste with I:Adr S A:Ser-Tri (I:Tri-Ven bounces Apu-Ven or successfully retreats) or even I:Adr S Tri, T:Apu-Adr would have cut the support. And even if it had worked, it only would have spared Trieste for one more turn. I thought at first that maybe A:Ser-Bud, I:Tri S Ser-Bud might have bounced R:Bud-Tri, R:Vie S Bud-Tri, since that's two equally well supported attacks wrangling over the same territory. But then I realized that they're not actually directly countervailing (head-to-head), so I guess actually Bud-Tri would have succeeded, dislodging A Tri and cutting its support, which means that Gal-Bud and Ser-Bud would then have bounced, still leaving me nowhere to go but Albania. So I was doomed no matter what I did, and it looks like so was Trieste. Sorry about that.

      I suppose if you had been resigned to losing Trieste you could have ordered Tri-Ven, Adr-Ven, bouncing yourself and keeping Apu out if he had gone for it. Alternately, if your main interest was to get an army into Venice, you could have ordered Tri-Ven, Adr S Tri-Ven, since T:Apu-Adr or T:Apu-Ven would both have had the same effect: letting your army make it in.

      But now you've got to disband and it's a tough choice, since anything you do leaves you highly vulnerable. Were it me, I'd retreat A Tri-Tyr now and disband F Ven in the winter, for reasons that should be obvious upon reflection.

      Anyway, enjoy the exquisite torment of being slowly ground into paste by the twin clubs of the Juggernaut. Truly an experience to relish, in this our jaded post-modern age.

      -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Mel White
      Perhaps I misunderstood. I often get 'hold' and 'attack Moscow' mixed up.
      \nI'm sure that you're just aggravating me here, Mel, but I'm easy that way when it comes to baseless arguments. I know, Willow knows and you also know that it was the spring move when I wrote that piece - and it is easy to confirm that I did not move to Moscow on that turn, just like I promised. On the fall move I continued our bounce, just like we'd discussed earlier. I'm sure Willow will correct me if I actually did something against our negotiation this year.

      This is again pertinent this coming spring, in fact, as Willow's going to be building again in Warsaw. Willow: let's do the same play again, that seems to be keeping the peace between us. Note that I will not move to Moscow in the spring so as to enable you to move out of Moscow then if you want. In the long run it'd be easier for me if you got out of both Moscow and Warsaw (or Sev, presumably) at once, so that you could build new units without me having to commit that fleet into Livonia just because you happen to have units in both Moscow and Warsaw at the same time. Also, vacating Moscow would give you an extra unit down south, effectively; unless you're expecting a Turkish attack, Sevastopol is sufficient both for bouncing me and for preventing a trivial Turkish convoy.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n

      Anyway, enjoy the exquisite torment of being slowly ground into paste by the twin clubs of the Juggernaut. Truly an experience to relish, in this our jaded post-modern age.
      \nI'm really more of a cutlass. Sorry to see you go, Bill!

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas-

      At this juncture I'm willing to see a permanent Turkish garrison in Armenia in exchange for an empty Black Sea: one unit on my border cannot force an attack, and it plugs the hole, keeping Sevastopol locked down as well. I think this offers a more secure border for each of us, at minimal troop deployment.

      -Willow
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenPosted By: Mel White
      Perhaps I misunderstood. I often get 'hold' and 'attack Moscow' mixed up.
      \nI'm sure that you're just aggravating me here, Mel, but I'm easy that way when it comes to baseless arguments. .
      Stay calm, Eero. When you are aggravated you make mistakes. Certainly none of us want that.
      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero Tuovinen Note that I willnotmove to Moscow in the spring so as to enable you to move out of Moscow then if you want. In the long run it'd be easier for me if you got out of both Moscow and Warsaw (or Sev, presumably) at once, .
      \nI also encourage this course of action in any case. An army from Warsaw can be in Berlin in the Fall, and Moscow follows a turn later. France looks forward to the arrival of our Russian comrades on the plains of Germany and into Scandinavia-.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willows -

      I know the fleet bugs you, but in a very real way, it is what held our alliance together for so long. As long as BLA is held by Turkey, I have no need to fear a full-fledged russian assault, which in turn frees me up (more than once this already happened!) to do things with Russia I'd otherwise consider way too risky. Admit it - it kept you honest more than once too, right?

      Obviously, I don't particularly need that fleet right there right now, but nor do I urgently need it anywhere else. How about I phase out the infantry part of the equation, moving my ground troops to the Greece-Serbia-Bulgaria triangle? Eventually, if all goes well, parts of that will go to Tunisia or some other exotic place.


      I don't have any secret plan to stab Russia in the back, if that's what's worrying you - I see no way I could get a solo win, as that would mean getting units either to StP or beyond MAO, both of which seem equally impossible... And if I am to take part in a draw, Russia's continued existance is my best bet - I certainly don't have the means to stop a western land-based incursion, and your capacity to do so alone, without even having to enact it, is very important in stopping from huge strides being made in that front.

      I'm comfy with the current arrangment, as I said earlier.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Whoops.

      Looks like I forgot to order a retreat. Well, that's not too good for me.
      \n

      \n Well, I just gave my last set of orders in this game, and I'm hauling down the ol' Double Eagle. Head for the hills, boys! These colors have never run!

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1\u202613141516171819\xbb

    Comments

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Thanks for all the advice, Bill. Your last bit of advice, particularly, was what I had been planning to do. Somehow I forgot to enter orders for the retreat phase, instead...

      I hope you'll be spectating and/or commentating!

      Those big powers need some hecklers.
      \n
