      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Spring 1913, start
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n So, I'm now the only "little guy" on the board, and potentially near extinction, depending on how things go.

      Any suggestions from you big fellas? It doesn't sound like Daumantas is too interested in Italy's survival (which is understandable), but is anyone else? I'm willing to Ride the Tiger, or whatever it takes...
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.So, I'm now the only "little guy" on the board, and potentially near extinction, depending on how things go.

      Any suggestions from you big fellas? It doesn't sound like Daumantas is too interested in Italy's survival (which is understandable), but is anyone else? I'm willing to Ride the Tiger, or whatever it takes...
      \nTurkey might be interested in Italian survival in return for Italian help breaking out into the Atlantic. Turkey will still want Naples soonest, but might agree to spare Rome for a year or two, depending on how useful the Italian fleet would be. It would be an unhappy time for Italy, as a Turkish adjunct, but anything might happen as long as a unit is on the board. I certainly would like to see Italy survive, with a fleet in the Western Med, ready to help defend or liberate Spain. And Turkish fleets in the Atlantic in order to defeat English aggression.

      The selling point for Italy is that Turkey has only a limited amount of time to break out into the Atlantic before England seals off the Straits of Gibraltar. A French collapse would allow England to bottle up the Mediterranean in 18 months or less. It would be a Pyrrhic victory for Turkey to completely defeat Italy, only to be trapped in the Med.

      Others would suggest abandoning the Italian peninsula and grabbing Marseilles. This would at least leave Italy with a supply center and a unit, which could then be a mercenary to the highest bidder. Not a particularly noble act, but all's fair...
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n All eyes are on the Baltic Sea fleet. With the new Russian army in Warsaw, able to mass on St Petersburg, the British Baltic Sea fleet almost certainly has to shift to Bothnia or again occupy Livonia. The stakes are too high to count on outguessing Russia.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Mel WhiteOthers would suggest abandoning the Italian peninsula and grabbing Marseilles.
      \nMel, how would these mysterious "others" feel about a loan of same lands in the spirit of combined Italo-French defense?

      If certain parties see the game as progressing towards a draw, once I'm out of the way, they may begin to see France as the easiest party to eliminate from the proceeding, being possible to attack on three fronts.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n For what it's worth, I concur with Paul: once Italy falls, France'll be an obvious choice for the last victim before a three-way draw. Turkey's the next-most likely by a wide margin, then Russia and the last is England. This is on the basis of everybody's ability to project force against each other: only France can project against England, for example, while both England and Turkey have strong possibilities against France, and Russia has at least some opportunity as well in Germany.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Posted By: Mel WhiteOthers would suggest abandoning the Italian peninsula and grabbing Marseilles.
      \nMel, how would these mysterious "others" feel about a loan of same lands in the spirit of combined Italo-French defense?

      .

      Paul,
      The others are not so mysterious. Any delays in Italy's defeat gives England more time to further weaken France. So England would be in support of Franco-Italian cooperation, but only so long as the support was from France to Italy. Italian occupation of Marseilles would, of course, be this one-way sort of cooperation.

      Russia will need a strong France in order to push back English conquests in central Europe, en route to gaining Scandinavia and liberating St Petersburg. Therefore Russia would oppose an Italian move to Marseilles. (I discount entirely the possibility of Russo-English cooperation against France. How could it be that Russia would cooperate with the occupiers of St Petersburg? It simply is inconceivable.)

      Turkey's reaction would depend on whether or not he is concerned with being blockaded in the Mediterranean. Cooperation with Italy and France now could see Turkey in the Atlantic this year. After that, Italy's survival depends on how useful the Italian fleet is to Turkey. But it's a future. If Turkey is not concerned about England blockading the exit from the Med, then Italy's survival at French expense is immaterial.

      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenFor what it's worth, I concur with Paul: once Italy falls, France'll be an obvious choice for the last victim before a three-way draw.
      \nFortunately, none of the participants in this struggle are satisfied with the obvious. An alternative, yet strangely enticing scenario, would see Russia, Turkey, and France cooperating to make England the last victim before a three way draw--or even the second to last victim before a two-way Juggernaut victory.

      The scenario would unfold generally along the lines of France's role as a pivot point around which Turkey and Russia would apply force against the English defenses. Turkish fleets, supported by France, swing west and north first into the Mid Atlantic and then beyond, so long as Turkey moves before England has a chance to establish a defense of the western approaches. France, Italy, and Turkey can mass five fleets against the Mid Atlantic this year--versus England's three. Unless England moves now to cover exits from the MAO, further exploitation from MAO will be possible next year.
      Simultaneously, Russian forces shift north and west. Russian armies certainly threaten Berlin, and may take it with French support from Munich. In any case the fleets England needs to block exploitation from the MAO are also the forces England needs to use to hold the central European possessions. He can't do both. From the German heartland, Russian forces--in light of a weakened England, who must disband some forces after losing Berlin and Kiel, and who faces continued pressure from Turkish fleets in the west--eventually breakthrough into Scandinavia to finally liberate the staunch citizens of St Petersburg who are tired of fish & chips and being forced to learn English in school.

      France is key to this scenario. French fleets open the door for Turkish entry into the Atlantic. French fleets provide a means for Russia to conquer or bypass Denmark.

      Russia and Turkey know that the defeat of France eliminates even the slightest possibility of an English defeat.
      Defeat England, however, and the field is wide open. The opportunity for a solo victory for an eastern power once again becomes possible.

      That is why I am sure we should expect the unexpected!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n Daumantas-

      It's cutting it a little close to the deadline, but I wanted to offer a 'reverse Lepanto'- Serbia moves to Venice through Trieste. Budapest follows, to Serbia then to Trieste to make sure there's no funny business, but it would seem like the most efficient way to get your army in Serbia into the Italian front.

      -Willow

      \n Willows - Saw that but thought I'd better not act on in to avoid miscommunication.

      Anyway.

      A Tyr to Venice, supported by F Adriatic + A Serbia to Trieste, to cut off retreat? Nothin' Paul can do to stop this move.

      Paul,

      I'm willing to allow you get into Iberia if you help me into the MAO... I figure France might go for this deal, too. I'd have to stop English fleets from advancing into the Med anyway, and aggression is generally more fun than staying still and trying to outguess the other party. However, I'm not personally that hot for the whole topple Eero plan - at this point, English aggression puts pressure on France and Russia, and an attack would likely do nothing but ease it, to no substantial gain of my own.

      So I guess I may as well poll countries that would be more directly affected by this possiblity (and thus either clumping English fleets around it, diverting forces from elsewhere or causing more direct mischief)... Mel, Willows. Would you like to see a turkish fleet somewhere west? If you care at all?

      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Mid 1913:
      Russian forces are poised to intervene in the West. To what end, the world wonders.
      Stiff French resistance forces England to take some risks, such as leaving St Petersburg isolated and Holland unsupported. The gambles pay off this time.
      Turkey remains constricted mostly in the Eastern Mediterranean and Balkans, facing scrappy Italian defenders that are making good use of interior lines of operation to hold Naples and Rome. Venice is a risk, if Russia and Turkey cooperate for just a little bit longer. But any Turkish efforts directed at Venice delay further conquest of Italy or movement further west.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I've been looking at the board a bit, Daumantas, and I think it's time you start putting a bit of pressure on Russia. As you know, we all need to be able to put commensurate pressure on each other to achieve a three-way draw, and we need to use that capability to restrict and contain each other's capability for expansion so as to prevent any one player from overwhelming the other two. Willow's not in overbearing position yet, but her aggressive thrust at Germany just now means that she soon will be, and the moment is now good for you to take your share: you can easily claim Rumania for yourself this fall, thus balancing Russia's 1-2 SC gains of the year and ensuring that she doesn't achieve total domination against you. You'll still have some capability for pressuring her later even if she grows clearly stronger than you, but if you establish the pressure now, you'll be able to take a concrete SC gain as well, thus making it easier for yourself to keep the border no matter what Russia does. After all, the real remaining issues of the board are Italy and France, neither of which is a Russian concern, so there's no reason for Willow to make too much gain while we have to struggle with the remaining excess Powers with only our own strength. Left to her own Willow might theoretically grow strong fast enough to make an attack on yourself a realistic option as she calls her option on a solo victory (which Russia could theoretically claim by overpowering both Turkey and France) - by acting early enough you'll pre-empt this option and reduce your own grief down the line considerably.

      To clarify, I'm not suggesting that you go any further than claiming what SCs naturally fall to your sphere of influence; there's no need to make a serious thrust at Russian vitals unless you have ambitions beyond a RTE-draw. Just stay aware of the need for balance, and act proactively to preserve it. Besides, any builds gained this way can be leveraged against Italy, thus bringing you to our mutual borderline in Gibraltar quicker.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenI've been looking at the board a bit, Daumantas, and I think it's time you start putting a bit of pressure on Russia.
      \nSee, Willow, this is how it begins. Just a little pressure now. But by 1915 it will be, "Say, Turkey, after studying the map, it occurs to me that we might obtain a two-way draw if we both exert a bit more effort against Russia. What do you say , old chap?"

      I am looking forward to the Russian intervention on the side of France! It is in both of our best interests.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Two-way draws are an illusion of fetid play, Mel. I won't hesitate to say that I would doubt the honesty of any player who manages a two-way draw in a DIAS game; the last few turns of such a game would be so complex and unlikely to orchestrate that the third player would have to be somehow defective to be unable to force a victory for one party or the other - and that's what he should do, as an early thrown (or seemingly thrown, anyway) game for either side should by all rights trigger a war between the two dominant parties, forcing them to acknowledge the third minor Power as a forced party to the draw simply because neither has the strength to remove the third player while simultaneously preventing the victory of the other dominant Power. Remember that a two-way draw would necessarily end in an SC count of 17-17 between the two players, and if either even momentarily ends at 18 SCs, they win the game. I am aware that two-way draws happen now and then, but I've yet to witness it in a DIAS game without metagame collusion: playing towards that draw only makes sense if you've agreed outside the frame of the game to do it with the other guy, not caring about your duty of fighting for victory. Utterly dishonorable, if you ask me.

      The above is not to say that a player might not conseivably use a "two-way draw" as a diplomatic argument in an effort to sneak into a solo victory. That requires a very naive board, though, as the prospective two-player ally is likely to understand the endgame logic just as I've outlined it above - they would never agree to eliminating the third player if they themselves weren't in an even better position to seize a forced solo at some point in the proceedings. In our particular game, assuming that Turkey conquers Italy and I conquer most of France, Turkey will in fact be in a better position to take himself over the solo line by attacking Russia: his home SCs are closer to Russia than mine, and he has a better army-fleet mix in a better initial position. Engaging in that sort of two-way draw plot, even assuming that Daumantas wasn't familiar with the impossibility of the same, wouldn't be smart for me in this situation.

      Mel, I have to say that I appreciate your active diplomatic efforts at finding a roadmap to a future that doesn't involve everybody else killing off France. However, it seems to me that most permutations that involve joint attacks at England are sadly incredible. Would you be willing to consider a peace with England, instead? A future play where we resupply Italy and stop the Russian assault over the Ber-Mun line seems wraught with potential, and where a draw arrangement without England seems like pure fantasy, I could just about see a France-Turkey-England draw as a tenable end to the game. In practical terms I might suggest that you give up Belgium, I give up Brest and while I would have to insist on keeping MAO, I could do it by moving a portion of my fleet to the Med to reduce my overall force concentration in the immediate environs of France. The fact still remains that my ability to project force mostly concerns the coastal regions, which means that relinquishing the Netherlands to me already reduces the tensions between us to negligible levels, and your core army strength will be a valuable resource for our alliance in the end-game when combined with my fleets.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n

      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n

      \n
      \n Hey Daumantas-

      I'm concerned about your movement of armies into the Balkans- that's kind of the opposite of what we talked about.

      How about you support my Tyrolia army into Venice, and move Serbia to Trieste, move Gre-Alb and Bul-Gre. After that, you should be able to take the remaining Italian centers very easily, and I can move Venice north to Munich.

      I maintain that our best position remains one of cooperation.

      -Willow

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow,

      Consider that if Daumantas agrees with what Eero is saying just above, he may indeed be tempted to grab some territory. He can easily take Venice and Rumania, plus the rest of Italy a little further down the road. In addition, in order to free up space to build new units, he can only move those armies in Ser-Bul-Con into your current possessions: Trieste, Rumania, and/or Budapest.

      That sort of position is certainly desirable to Turkey, and likely would cement his position in a possible draw even further.

      In any case, once he takes more territory (which he will, either from you or from me), he will be building more units back in his home centres. With four fleets already in the water, chances are good many of those will be armies. So, you can expect to see a stronger and stronger Turkish army on your Southern flank as this game progresses. This will only increase the temptation for him to grab some more territory, and increase your dedication of forces to that front. (And Daumantas is very openly opportunistic, as he has stated many times in this game: he goes to where the SCs are, not where honour or allegiance suggests is most "proper".)

      If you agree with my logic, you might consider that keeping Italy alive a little longer may be very much to your benefit. It doesn't do much to slow you down, but very much helps you stay ahead of Turkey in any possible arms race/escalation race.

      Just a thought. I hope you'll think about it too. It may have important ramifications further down the road when the Great Powers are choosing which of the four of you will be the first to fall...

      Posted By: Eero TuovinenTwo-way draws are an illusion of fetid play, .
      \nExactly! Exactly. The offer of the 2-way draw is simply the bait. I never said the offer would be fulfilled. It is simply one more ploy to continue the struggle. In this particular game, seeing the history of mistrust between Turkey and Russia, compared to Russia's pliancy at English behest, I have no doubts that the final victor would be England.

      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n

      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenWould you be willing to consider a peace with England, instead?
      \nI am, of course, always amenable to peace. My hands are tied however, with an obligation to free French soil of foreign occupation. Everything else is negotiable. You will no doubt agree that my actions have been entirely defensive (with regards to England) in an effort to avoid exactly the circumstances in which we are now. The next steps towards Anglo-French de-escalation must come from your side of the Channel. I am unlikely to hold Belgium; having offered it before as a token of friendship I will defend it as best I can now but not miss it once gone.You are unlikely to hold Brest but we will destroy that British Army before allowing Brest to fully fall under its sway. The Mid-Atlantic must be French or vacant--at some point--for exactly the reasons you point out. Three French coastal centers border the Mid Atlantic and would have to be garrisoned so long as England could both occupy those coastal centers, particularly as you have demonstrated with convoyed armies, and follow-up with a supporting fleet. But it is all a simple matter of establishing some confidence building measures. I must proceed on the basis that this war continues and will do so until you choose to end it.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n

      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Considering the practicalities, Mel, I can see how MAO is an issue for France. However, it's equally true that your fleet entire is an issue for England - it's large enough to be threatening, and it's all positioned on the Atlantic coast now. I wouldn't have an issue with it were it positioned in the Med, but getting it there right now is a bit tricky. A demilitarized MAO is not impossible by itself, provided I get at least one fleet down south quickly to aid the struggling Italy.

      I'm sure that you'll find my next set of moves pretty conciliatory, if not outright trusting, so perhaps you'll take the opportunity to disarm some of that fleet strength. I could see myself moving down into the Med with my MAO fleet at the next opportunity once I come to believe that the possibility for inter-occidental cooperation exists, provided that my moves go well and remove much of the current negotiation pressure.

      (You probably don't want to take tactical advice, but if you'd attack strongly at MAO this turn, followed by a disband of the fleet that makes the attack in the winter, that might be the most secure and quick disarmament plan available.)

      Posted By: WillowI'm concerned about your movement of armies into the Balkans- that's kind of the opposite of what we talked about.
      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdHow about I phase out the infantry part of the equation, moving my ground troops to the Greece-Serbia-Bulgaria triangle? Eventually, if all goes well, parts of that will go to Tunisia or some other exotic place.
      \nMiscommunication! Apologies, though it doesn't seem like there has been much damage. I doubt I'll be ordering anything else other than F Greece - Ionian, for both attack's and defense's sake, but the A Tyr - Ven, A Ser - Tri part of the equation is good with me, as I mentioned earlier. No problems with that, right?


      As far as I'm concerned, Eero's just blowing smoke - I don't see how removing Turkey from the game would be good for you, and I don't see how you (easily, without exposing yourself on another front, etc.) could do it, either - need fleets and not armies for that thing.

      As mentioned earlier, this game is essentially done with for Turkey if I continue with the preestablished course (some kind of three way draw with Turkey in it, basically?). Only reason to stir the waters is if I think that getting a solo win would somehow be feasible... And it's not, so why bother?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n After staring at the map for a while I decided to give you an opening, Mel - I'll make explicitly cooperative moves here to give you an opportunity to make the right moves yourself in the winter phase. To be explicit, I'll be expecting you to disband F MAO (and a second fleet, ideally), leaving MAO demilitarized and your army strong (read: able to push Russia back), just as discussed. After that you'll have a genuine chance at retaking Munich, building a Marseilles fleet perhaps, and pushing west through the Med (perhaps aiding Italy) while I do my thing up north. This play has the potential to turn out as a EF(T/R) three-way draw, which is nothing to sneeze at in your current, otherwise doomed position.

      In case anybody has any illusions about why I would do the above, the obvious reasoning is that mixing up an otherwise very comfortable three-way draw might open up new options for a solo victory further down the road. Because my own position is supremely secure, draw-wise, I can afford to shake things a bit. For example, the leeway I provide for France now is not enough for him to kill me even should he choose to betray my trust, considering the geopolitical logic of Turkey's moves once Italy falls in a year or two. (Again, to be explicit: Turkey's attack on France's back finishes him off and provides the three-way draw if France opts to take my opening and try a futile counter-attack on me.) The effective default ending for the game, should we all continue playing conservatively, is a ERT draw, but at least I'm feeling good enough about my chances to try and see if that can be changed at this late date. Perhaps this just results in the same draw anyway, or a different draw, or maybe I'll get that solo through some convoluted path that is as yet unforeseen.

      (The above is just the sort of thing that doesn't get said in public without a weird variant like this one. Should be educational.)

      Anyway, let's see what Mel does in the winter - I bet it'll be interesting. It'll also be interesting if he beats the odds and foils my own, supremely peaceful yet efficient play in the fall, thus causing peace to become a non-issue. The irony would be dense enough for a pudding.

      \n
      \n Well well, seems like Russia's making a weak sort of bid here - I wouldn't characterize this as a solo rush, as despite the activity on all fronts, follow-through and focusing of force is lacking. It's more like an aggressive defense than attack against anybody in particular. Willow: my move to Livonia, as you probably realize, was just a defensive move to counter a hypothetical War-Liv. I'll go back to StP in the spring.

      Mel, as you can see, I made a play for the partition I suggested earlier, complete with a relinquished MAO. Think about what I wrote earlier and make your disband accordingly - you can remove one unit here, so make it count. F Wes will gladly dedicate itself to Italian matters next year if you'll allow it. You might meanwhile consider movements through the Piedmont gap and Munich, were you so inclined; lots of useful things to do that do not involve continuing the wrassle for the Low Countries.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hmm, I might as well resolve everybody else's problems while I'm here. Paul, here's what I'd do in your stead: offer to support Adr-Tri with your F Ven in exchange for Turkey moving Tun-Ion in the spring. The carrot is that Turkey gets Trieste, the stick is that England will support you into Tunis if Turkey doesn't find it smarter to cooperate. Note how the Turkish fleet in Trieste serves to stabilize your relations, as it's not any more offensive in that position towards you, while it certainly does offer you some protection against Russia merely by being present. Also, if Turkey should lose the position later, disbanding the fleet would be an excellent peace overture towards Italy. The English part there is a given, I'd be happy to help you haunt the Turk insofar as you find it tactically fruitful.

      The mid-term outcome of the above could well be a stabilization of the Italo-Turkish relations, at least assuming that the Turk finds it better to focus on his Russian troubles for the time being. (It's notable that one of the most effective Turkish moves for dealing with the Armenian army involves going Gre-Aeg-Smy, which only works if he leaves off the Italian war.) Turkey might also find a stable Italy a better bulwark against the west if he perceives himself unable to take full benefit of the Italian weakness while also worrying about the Balkans situation. Turkey might still prefer to keep one fleet in the Ionian Sea, but even that's a considerable improvement from the Italian viewpoint.

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenMel, as you can see, I made a play for the partition I suggested earlier, complete with a relinquished MAO. Think about what I wrote earlier and make your disband accordingly
      \nEero,
      I recognize your actions as conciliation and de-escalating and will follow with similar actions. We have reached a point I had hoped to be at two years earlier, albeit with a slightly stronger France then. No matter. A French fleet will disband, but at this point it is unlikely to be MAO. I intend to move a fleet to the Mediterranean in order to have influence in that region, to possibly cooperate with your fleet, and to provide additional options with regards to the defense of Marseilles. MAO provides the quickest means of doing so. This separation of naval power violates one of my own principles not to split the fleet, for the portions could then be defeated in detail. But two French fleets in the Atlantic is, indeed, a threat to England by its simple existence. One season of caution for you is outweighed by the benefit of the quick separation of the French 'fleet entire'. I think you can judge my intent, at least in some small part, by Army's Ruhr's refocus away from Belgium. To be sure, I expected to lose Belgium but if I intended to disregard the English offer for peace I would have made no efforts to protect Munich from Russia in order to strengthen and further embolden Russia.
      I am not about to question good fortune. Belgium is a small price to pay for French survival, and I have no doubts that Belgium has bought that exactly. The loss of Belgium will soon be countered with growth elsewhere.
      As I have said, everything is negotiable. Except one thing--we will not be dictated to. If Mid Atlantic's presence at the start of Spring before it moves south is too much for you to bear then by all means resume your offensive. As you said, in a three-way draw it is immaterial who your partners are. Conversely, in a loss all that matters is the nature of the struggle. We will be destroyed before we submit.

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hmm, yikes. Everyone was so happy to see me moving into Germany, but now no one wants to welcome me there.

      Daumantas-

      I felt certain that you were going to stab me for Rumania, so I made the best defense I thought I could scramble. I'm glad to see you didn't (the move against Sevastopol aside)

      If we were going to continue cooperation (which again, I prefer to war, but I felt the need to defend myself from the stab I though was coming)- out best option would be a supported attack on Venice, and preparations for a convoy. Tyrolia may have more important things to do in the spring, but should be free in the fall to issue S ADR-Venice, and should you find yourself in possession of the Ionian, a convoy of Gre/Alb-Apu/Nap.

      What I'd really like to do with that Armenian army, in a sort of a-girl-can-dream sort of way, is to arrange for a Turkish convoy to the Italian peninsula- Smyrna through the Aegean is more likely, but Syria through East Med is safer.

      Or we could slug it out, if it's come to that. I'd rather not, as I suspect it'd be messy- you've got the upper hand in the Balkans, but that Armenian army is poised to be quite the pain in the ass.

      -Willow
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Mel --

      Back at you! vgqdpufnfbcpllvgvdckvkllqpudcifbghdfagulmi

      -- Bill
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Mel WhiteAs I have said, everything is negotiable. Except one thing--we will not be dictated to. If Mid Atlantic's presence at the start of Spring before it moves south is too much for you to bear then by all means resume your offensive.
      \nNo no, what you say about the tactical landscape makes sense - separating the French fleets is a safer long-term solution, and it's true that we'll be much more effective in the Med if you bring a second fleet there immediately instead of crawling up from Spa (nc). It is also true that I can withstand a turn's worth of extra excitement, considering my extremely stable strategic position - the very worst you could do is basically a thrust at the Irish Sea, followed by my bouncing you in Liverpool with my new army while I'd continue crunching my way inwards to France.

      I suppose I'll have to move to give way in Wes, but that's not a problem: it'll be more effective to support the Italian to Tunis in the fall, anyway.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n CBHZQEBFKSISELGAHZKZEUEFFEUMDPDZHOUMLBQKUMMBWNVIPSXCMTCHPH
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Sorry, folks, I've been away on a trip for a little while, but it seems I didn't miss any action, due to all the retreating and building and other things that do not concern Italy.

      Interesting negotiations going on here. My take:

      Italian sailors cheer at the English explorers in the Mediterranean! Will Tunisia finally be liberated? Or is there some sense to English occupation of Tunis, while French fleets enter the Western Med?

      Daumantas,

      Eero's proposal to support your fleet into Trieste is an appealing one to me. Willow has other things to worry about at the moment (I'm sure she's looking at gaining either Munich or StP this year), so she is unlikely to support you into Venice until at least the Fall. A Turkish fleet in Trieste, on the other hand, would place all three of us in a fairly safe position in regards to each other. Russia's territory will be bordered by fleets, and thus safe; you and I will not be in any position to mount much of an attack on each other, either.

      Meanwhile, you can take easily take Trieste and Rumania. Since Russia is likely to gain an SC this year elsewhere, this will leave Willow with one disband. It shouldn't be too hard at that point to convince her to disband Army Armenia, leaving everyone happy and you in a much stronger position, as well as without a Russian army in your backside. It's not a terribly unreasonable response to such a move, and would stabilize all your borders while allowing you to build simultaneously.

      From your perspective, a relatively peaceful situation between you and I makes it more likely that France and/or England will sooner or later help you finish off Italy, as opposed to trying to keep me alive against your attacks in the goal of limiting your growth.

      Let me know if you'd like me to order the support.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm looking forward to Bill's mysterious underground (or underwater?) maneuvers.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Spring, 1914 (start)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.I'm looking forward to Bill's mysterious underground (or underwater?) maneuvers.
      \nIt's more consultations with the former Emperor, now penning his memoirs.

      And, as an aside, all the clues necessary to break the code are included in the clear text. A game within a game, if you like.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n 1914 Preview:
      All France breathes a sigh of relief at the apparent peace with England. It may be the calm before the storm, for more English armies are on the continent than ever before--with reserves in England ready ready to embark. Will the British Army finally reach Piedmont? Or reinforce St Petersburg for a drive on Moscow? Or resume war on France in the greatest deception since the Trojan Horse? Only the English know.

      The Royal Navy's entry into the Mediterranean demonstrates English power. It signals possible reprieve for Italy in the short term. The long-term picture is more cloudy.

      Russia's 1913 surge west and south, whether an aggressive defense or a probe to identify weak points puts Russia well in place to act independently in the West or to cooperate with other powers. Like water, Russia will likely seek growth through the path of least resistance.

      For Turkey and Russia, the diplomatic chatter has to be of concern. England, the leading power on the map, is contemplating a draw that discounts one of them. Which one? England and Russia are more likely to come to blows than England and Turkey. But England is already promising help to Italy against Turkey, and making placating noises at Russia with regards to Livonia and St Petersburg. I would say 'as if there were any other choice' for Livonia to retreat to St. Petersburg, yet the last time I said that about the Baltic Sea fleet I was proved wrong.

      As with every year, this one will be more exciting than the last!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: WillowHmm, yikes. Everyone was so happy to see me moving into Germany, but now no one wants to welcome me there.
      \nI believe Berlin has completed its preparations for Russia's arrival.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n TQNCNUIOCLHKTCFHTLCLUMTQDXAZGBEIAGOTATMZUZNAIFQAPTPLDAHMZLGETCPMGM
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Mel, coordination: you can retain Munich forcibly by supporting yourself in there now - I'll move to aid you in the fall, and Russia can't both prevent that and take Munich. Presumably Russia won't contest this, but it's still best to not take any risks. I also suggest maneuvering an army towards the Mar-Pie area - you'll note that I built to prevent myself from convoying from Lon, making your northern coast somewhat safer. Finally, let me know if you're willing to move MAO-NAf, which is better in that Turkey can't bounce it (due to my support) the way he can block Wes-NAf; I'll assume that you're moving MAO-Wes unless you say otherwise, and we can fix any Turkish interference in the fall if it comes to that.

      EDIT: Also, Mel, we can bounce in MAO with your Spa fleet if you want. I'll assume not unless you affirm.

      Paul: do keep yourself together until the fall, we'll help you into Tunis with Mel if you haven't convinced Daumantas to get out of there at that point. It does both Turkey and you a world of good to get his fleet out of its unnatural forward position in Tunis, but in case he won't listen to reason and trade Tun for Tri, we'll be only too happy to help with the peace-building. One would think that all reason for aggression between Italy and Turkey would disappear like the morning mist once you get Tunis back.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n vkugdvbfiknvuzfbcmsnfbulqcfhzmqcdfsnnbgp

      barxeooipugwdxlkgmspdppmmcxa
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Losing an SC does me a world of good?

      Truth is lies, love is hate, peace is war! Is it 1984 at England already?

      Gentlemen, and I adress this to everyone - my only interest now is getting Eero out of the Med. I don't particularly care which way this gets done, but I do think that it has to.

      Mel,

      I'm sure you're aware that Eero can now get four fleets to your two in the area around MAO, provided he gets another build. Might be in your best interest to make sure he doesn't. How are you planning to cover Marseilles, by the way?

      Paul,

      I know when I'm licked - you can expect me to retreat from Tunisia on my own volition. I'm not a big believer in peace through disarmament, however - a fleet in Trieste is lonely, surrounded, and useless. I would not accept anything less than you supporting Serbia into that location if we are to talk terms of peace - which, incidentally, would not mean a big happy family in the East part of the map, but rather you assuming control over the West Med, me retreating my fleets and making some ways inlands against Russia.

      That's a backup plan, though - I'd rather see you out of the game and Italy's lands under control by Turkey and Russia.

      (Oh, and by the way - the day that England "helps" Turkey to conquer Italy is the day that I know the game's gone to Eero.)

      Willows,

      You're last because I have the most to say to you.

      I don't much care about your current actions and see the reasoning behind them. Aside from the fact that this fucked up both our growth curves and made conquering Italy fast enough to be able to effectivelly push Eero out of the Med, of course. That part is a bit frustrating.

      Now, the way I see it, we have two routes - an all-out attack on Italy, thus achieving Turkish control over the Med, or I retreat to a minimal position and do my best to help Italy push Eero out, cross my fingers and pray. Understandably, I'd much rather control Italy myself than hope that Paul is willing and able to perform the task. Whatever you're doing in the west can wait - simply put, it's either turkish control of the Med or english control of the Med, and which of these two happens will be decided very soon... On the other hand, you already have more than enough troops to guarantee your own security and provide a bulwark against the any western onslaught (provided you trust me enough to retreat all those armies at my borders), which is really all that's needed of Russia to secure a three-way draw.

      In short, I want support Russia into Venice right now and get access to Trieste for Serbia for joint operations later (or just to keep my own forces afloat after the loss of Tunisia - nothing that Italy could do to stop Russia from losing Venice once it's there, so you'd be at no SC disadvantage either). Not going to accept anything less. Might accept other variations that allow for swift joint control of Italy, though (convoying A Arm is cute, sure. But it ties up my fleet and is uncertain and... just get it back to Sev and out of my hair).

      Oh, please oh please just stop reading that chaos-mongering in tactical advice dressing Eero's spewing out (so basically, everything that Eero is writing at this phase of the game) altogether. Your relationship with England is purely tactics and guesswork now, and reading it seems to make you too jumpy for me to be able to work with.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero,
      Good copy on the naval maneuvers, north and south.
      I appreciate English efforts to retain Munich for France. Regretfully, the French sympathizers in the city are heading west--both complicating French military maneuvers and signaling some lack of confidence that even the English can liberate the city if it falls into Russian hands in Spring. Should Russia overcome French resistance and take Munich, even combined Anglo-French forces could not take it back immediately...do you agree? Assuming that Russia is willing to risk Warsaw, or give up a chance at St Petersburg. I would not think Warsaw for St Petersburg is such a good deal. Why shouldn't Russia use those three western armies to attack Munich now? I would...but then again, I have been losing units since I started, so perhaps I am missing the obvious.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdHow are you planning to cover Marseilles, by the way?
      \nWe have changed all signs in Marseilles to read 'Piedmont'. England will never find it.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow,\n
      Posted By: DWeirdIn short, I want support Russia into Venice right now and get access to Trieste for Serbia for joint operations later
      \nAn army in Trieste? While the difference for me is minor (a fleet or an army there, it's still threatening Venice, same to me), I'm sure Daumantas would be very happy to have an army bordering on Vienna AND Budapest while you...\n
      Posted By: DWeirdretreat all those armies at my borders
      \nYour border will certainly be in an interesting position then. Surely, I am but pointing out the obvious, but I wanted to let you know why I will not be supporting a Turkish army into Trieste. I hope you will appreciate the gesture.

      Daumantas,

      Tell me more about the threat of Eero in the Mediterranean. You seem to think he could suddenly take over in force. Do you suppose he can do that with one fleet? How? If not, how will maneuver more forces into our part of the world? What should we be concerned about here? You sound like you're worried about a hypothetical scenario: what is it?

      (And, yes, my "happy" view could certainly take the shape of you sorting out your business with Russia while I turn West and do whatever is necessary for world peace, whether it's keeping England or France out of the Atlantic, or something entirely different. Indeed, if I thought you were down with that sort of plan, I would consider supporting your army into Trieste. At the moment, however, I have no reason to believe that you're trustworthy in that sense.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Mel,

      I suspect Eero may have a plan that includes you holding on to Munich. I can see one or two possibilities for that, and if I'm guessing right about his short-term plans, it could work out quite nicely for you (certainly better than the position you're in now). Look at his movements: they suggest he's serious about an attempt to make sure France is not the first of the four powers to fall, but rather survives to a three-way draw.

      We'll see what happens, but the fears you're outlining above... well, I think Eero has at least one trick he can play that will be in your favour.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      Posted By: Paul T.well, I think Eero has at least one trick he can play that will be in your favour.
      \nLike what, teleportation? I didn't get that card in my deck.

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1\u202613141516171819\xbb

    Comments

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n CGRELQXGXLNSFVDRLHMEYSBCHPMPDBQDO
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ha, Daumantas is funny - I like. I do have to clarify for his Majesty's government, though: we do not harbour any intentions towards the Mediterranean Sea, and in fact have great hopes that the French and Italian governments will find a peaceful resolution to the current troubles in the area. Our own fleet is there merely as a peace-keeping force. An end-game push at the Mediterranean (which has been predicted by the musulman for the last five years or so, note) is not in the cards in the foreseeable future, assuming our working relationship with the French government continues improving.

      Mel, regarding Munich: my read concurs about the tactical realities, but it's too expensive for Russia to commit the troops - she'll lose Trieste and potentially Warsaw (who knows what those wacky English generals will do so far from home, eh) if she goes for it. Also note that we can force her out next year even if she goes for it (can't stop me from setting up in Kie-Ber), and she knows that as well. Much more sensible to cover Trieste and maybe Warsaw, as those are SCs she can hold. At the same time letting you get into Mun is not an immediate threat to her - not a threat at all necessarily, in fact - as you don't quite yet have positioning for any sort of eastern adventure. The best Russian play of the moment is not to start a western adventure against a seemingly united western front, but rather to establish herself in the Balkans and wait to see if we have a real western alliance going; if we do, it becomes pretty important for her to ensure that the draw is FER and not FET, and the best way to do that is to consolidate the Balkans, keep me out of Moscow and keep pressure on the Turk to help you cross the Med. Basically, if an Anglo-French alliance exists and is not just a cruel lie, then T & R are in a pinch: the one that survives longest wins the eastern slot in the draw.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero Tuovinenif an Anglo-French alliance exists and is not just a cruel lie
      \nI hate cruel lies. So, no teleportation, then? The Anglo-French alliance exists from my perspective--with caution that a season or two will ease.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdWillows,

      I don't much care about your current actions
      \nWillow (it is Willow, correct?),
      I, on the other hand, am grateful for your recent actions. I believe your surge west has achieved what I had once thought impossible--to establish peace between France and England. Now, with peace established, there will be no need for us to trade Munich for Holland. Each territory can remain in its current hands. Your forces can turn to where they can do the most good--securing and expanding Russian holdings in the Balkans. With a 'jumpy' neighbor to your south, I encourage you to take appropriate precautions.
      Mel
      \n
      \n

      \nEUEFFEUMDPDZHOUMLB

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n LANOIHOINKNALHAOEAGEANPTSZAYXMOINPQABAHDS!

      Daumantas-

      I'm actually not really that interested in taking Venice myself- my goals lay in taking Munich and supporting my good friend Mel into Holland. My plan is to support myself into Munich this fall.

      Feel free to move through Trieste to get to Venice with one unit, but I would want to see Bulgaria hold or move to Greece.

      -Willow

      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: WillowLANOIHOINKNALHAOEAGEANPTSZAYXMOINPQABAHDS!
      \nFresh!
      \n

      Posted By: Eero Tuovinenmerely
      \nThis is the word Eero uses when he's lying and doesn't much care to cover it up very well.

      Willow (apologies for misspelling your name... again),

      Sounds good. Bulgaria will do one of those things. I assume that Budapest will be moving out as well, then?

      Paul,

      Nice attempt to use my words against me, but there is no secret plan here. Laid my cards quite bare - if I can't conquer Italy, I'm retreating to a minimal position, which also means I don't have much else to do but fight with Russia - given that that would mean France remains in the game, I'd then have to whittle down Russia as good as I can. That's a backup plan, though, in case I don't get requisite russian support in the endeavour.

      You seem to have my plan A and B jumbled up into one!

      Be prepared to lose Venice now though, mwahaha and etcetera.

      Eero,

      If you didn't get into the Med before, it's not for lack of trying, no? And it's not so much that I'm worried that you will be able to pull off a spectacular coup that will crush the whole western coastline in one blow - that's out of the cards, right.

      Instead... When I think about what fleets are available to control the english fleet's movements? The answer is "none" - there are fleets in the water, sure, but all of those are preoccupied with other matters (and you are making sure that remains the case for the forseeable future! Fancy that!). That fleet is essentially free to do whatever it damned well pleases. And as long as that remains the case, we will have to trust the player of an essentially uneliminable power to not seize an advantage when one pops up. And will an advantage ever pop up in a region where no fleets are present to contest the english one?

      I do like me some rhetorical question.

      \n You will receive the aid, Mel. The Russian will rue the day she opted to cross the Ber-Mun line; definite bad vibes in having an easterner over the line. Meanwhile, feel free to move back to cover Brest, no need to surround Belgium with a massive army. I'll get my army out of there and replace it with a fleet once you ease up a bit.

      Incidentally, you probably figured it out, but I misread you about which fleet maneuvers we were playing. Probably would be better to be explicit even if it means that the opposition understands us as well. No serious harm about it this time, of course. (I went to GoL instead of NAf because I expected you to cover Marseilles as discussed, and because I wasn't sure if the Turk might move to NAf - it's well that I did, would've been pretty funny if we bounced in NAf.) For the fall move, do move MAO-Spa to cover yourself against me; perhaps Spa (sc) even.

      Paul: seems like your fortunes are turning. Note that the Turk will potentially move Tun-Ion with supports, so it's better to attack Tyr-Tun. I won't move to Tyr if you're wondering, and I expect the good Frenchman to proffer you the support we've been discussing. The Turk will, in fact, do well to consider whether he has even the luxury of Tun-Ion, considering your retreat opportunities; might be better to just disband that unfortunate fleet altogether.

      \n
      \n Also, Paul, while I'm looking at the map: it seems to me that it might be worthwhile for you to consider supporting Tyr-Tri or similar from Venice if you're not finding an accord with the Turk. It is true that not only is Daumantas a rather bloodthirsty individual, but he also has a pretty strong interest in rolling over Italy. Then again, I don't even know if there would be a point doing such a support, as Mr. D might be only too happy to attack Tri-Ven with fleet support just to improve his Russian relations. Insofar as the Turk is concerned, killing off Italy and keeping Russia reasonably controlled is pretty much the Turkish dream scenario, insofar as draw arrangements are concerned. So it might be that you should actually encourage that Turkish army to stick around in Trieste so as to keep the Russo-Turkish relations from improving.

      Either way, as long as you get Tunis this turn, Turkey will have food for thought: his strategy has for a while centered on annexing Italy, but the strong Tyrhenian SC triplet with two fleets and an army in Rome is such a tought nut to crack that he might have to back off entirely and escalate his on-off martial affair with Russia, instead. This is especially true when you consider the western commitment to an independent Italy. Even taking Venice successfully might not be enough if France moves up via Piedmont to help you maintain the line against the Juggernaut.
      \n
      \n
      \n

      Studying the map, it occurs to me that I would not need Tunis if I could recover Munich. A simple spoiling attack from Trieste to Tyrolia would unhinge Russia's defenses of the city restoring Munich to its proper control.
      England will no doubt block any Tyrolian sidestep to Piedmont--we know the Royal Navy is eager to finally set foot there--so you need have no worry of marching away from your conquest before fully realized. And, of course. Russia will make no attack on Trieste since even a successful attack leaves Trieste free to retreat to Vienna; a particularly beautiful city, well worth visiting.

      \n
      \n Mel,

      How amenable are you to supporting me into Tunis? The only other thing that fleet can do is support the Mid-Atlantic, but Eero's general maneuvering seems to suggest he's being entirely honest about his aims to keep France alive.

      Daumantas,

      You'll have an interesting choice to make: if you wish to be anti-Italy, you can move into Venice with your army but lose Trieste. However, take Venice with the fleet and you're up two SCs at the end of the year. Since there's some chance I could retake Tunis shortly, that guaranteed build would be a nice way to guarantee your safety back home. In addition, the army in Trieste gives all kinds of bargaining options (such as asking kindly for Russia to remove that Army Armenia).

      I'm willing to enter into some kind of agreement with you if it would sway you in that direction.

      Willow,

      On the other hand, if Eero and Mel are really aiming at reducing the four-way situation into a France-England-Turkey draw, as they seem to be doing, you might have a lot to gain by ordering something like Tyrolia -> Trieste (works to save Trieste for you if Daumantas is trying to hold on to it, as Eero suggests, with my support), taking Serbia, Berlin, and making an attack on either Ankara or Smyrna. At least one or two out of the four attacks would probably go through. Who knows, it could convince the rest of the Great Powers that England-Russia-France is much more likely that English-France-Turkey, which would be very much in your favour. (It seems to me the others are trying to figure out which of the four is weakest right now, so you're going to have to work hard to make sure that is not the way Russia appears to the rest of the world.)
      \n

      Mel

      And it hurts me very much that you bounced me out of Munich last fall. The question now, I suppose, is what exactly are you going to do about it? Munich will be ordering S Ruhr-Kiel, so do with that what you will. Look out for convoys- Nth-Eng can land an army in Brest.

      Eero-

      And on the other hand, Mel couldn't possible defend against all possible stabs you could make, right- I don't harbor any illusions about England's essential nature in any draw.

      Daumantas-

      Tyrolia will be ordering S Tri-Ven as promised. I'm going to keep Armenia in place as a check against any treachery, much as you have the Black Sea in place, let's hope such moves aren't needed.

      Paul and Daumantas-

      If Venice is taken, is there a situation where it makes sense for your fleets to work together? Daumantas would probably have to transfer Tunis back to Italy, but if it happens with that fleet sailing further west, the gains could be lucrative. Italy would want to hold Naples as a defensive barrier, and both sides would push along the Ion/TyS corridor, probably taking the Gulf of Lyons next to target France, or West Med to stick a finger in Atlantic affairs.

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: WillowIf Venice is taken, is there a situation where it makes sense for your fleets to work together? Daumantas would probably have to transfer Tunis back to Italy, but if it happens with that fleet sailing further west, the gains could be lucrative.
      \nI am not entirely against this idea. However, Daumantas is holding the position of strength here, whereas Italy's existence hangs by a thread. If I were to act on any such plan, I would be opening myself up far more than Daumantas, who would at most be risking one SC.

      Therefore, I simply cannot afford to be the one to make the first move in any such coordinated assault. If you want my help to push into the Atlantic (say), you'll need to be the first to make a gesture of peace: I simply cannot afford to do so.

      (And, frankly, having you two barge into Venice instead of, say, trying to hold on to Munich and/or Berlin does not inspire confidence. If you do think you'd like to see some fleets help you move against England, rather than fight as hard as possible to slow you down, you might consider throwing me a bone somewhere. My fleet in Venice is hardly threatening to anyone, why not allow me to keep it? I could be talked into moving it away from Trieste, leaving that area demilitarized.)

      \n That's a good point about the respective cost of diplomatic gestures there, Paul - it's the same logic I used in my French negotiations, where I bent over backwards because I could afford to.

      Then again, trying to get the easterner barbarians to listen to talk of peace might be a waste of time. Rather, you should lay your trust on your one ally who's stood by you through thick and thin, the good ol' United Kingdom of Great Britain. We'll get you into Tunis, and then further into the Eastern Mediterranean, I believe; our mercenary allies in France might ask for some small tidbit of recompense later, but it is surely a small price to pay when you actually can bicker with us civilized Powers, rather than just begging for mercy.

      \n Eero,

      I have much greater faith in my solid English and French allies, absolutely! You two have been on my side all along, and relatively reliable in that sense. However, I still haven't heard from Mel about supporting me into Tunis, however, and you're no longer in position to do so. We'll see what happens.

      However, in my position I have to grasp for whatever I can. If Daumantas and Willow are really serious about getting my help in the Atlantic area, I won't have too much choice but to help them: I'll do it if suggests a greater chance of survival for Italy, after all. So far all their talk for getting into action against you and Mel through some naval forces has been all talk, though, never backed up by actions. That's why I'm pretty skeptical until I see some actual movement: so far it seems more like Daumantas has been hoping I would agree to such a plan and simply abandon my defensive positions, which is something I'm thankfully not gullible enough to do.

      \n All thanks for the rather beautiful turkish success this turn go to Russia. Many ways she could have caused problems for Turkey - and didn't. And then there is the fact that the manouver would have been impossible without right of passage through russian Trieste and the Tyrolian support.

      My hat's off to you, Willow!

      In case you're worried, Serbia-Bulgaria is a response to the worrying presence of Army Budapest... I've actually wanted to keep an army in Const instead, to cover Smyrna, but today's been a bit hectic (lost my phone in a former monastery after a night of debauchery and spent the better half of the day looking for it, to no luck) and I didn't remember to adjust my orders.

      If Budapest's sole job is to cover Rumania, perhaps it could do it from Galicia instead, where it isn't in position to stage a supported attack on Serbia? I'd retreat Serbia to Albania to not cause similar greviances to you, naturally enough - I'd move to Greece to not have you worry about Trieste, either, but who knows when I'll be able to vacate that fleet.


      In other news... Keeping Tunis is just luck, and I certainly don't expect it to last... But I do certainly welcome any favours the magnificient lady luck deems to grant me.

      \nAs the situation stands, the Italian options have grown rather minimal: he has to retreat to Rome and Naples as best he can to wait for the inevitable. I'll have to hash this fiasco out with Mel, but ideally we'll think up something to allow the Italian to survive the baseless aggression of the Turkish horde. Perhaps support Ion-Tun in the spring as a late attempt at something or other, while also moving Mar-Pie to threaten Venice... grim, really grim from an Italian viewpoint.

      Meanwhile the French lose an unit and Russia gains one; considering the last year's moves, I wouldn't be surprised by a fleet in Sevastopol. In fact, building in Sevastopol is something I warmly recommend to our sister the Czarinna: as we've explained before, building in Warsaw when there is already an army in Moscow is a clear and immediate threat to our position in the free city of StP. As hostilities between our Powers would prove both pointless and dangerous to the Russian responsibilities in central Europe, it is surely wiser to follow the old ways that have served us so well in preserving the peace to this day.

      \n Willow and I are playing on a higher level, Daumantas. She knows that I'm not really assaulting Russia, but rather merely misleading the Frenchman by my moves.       \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n Yes, things are not looking good for Italy. Turkey and Russia are building this turn, at Italy and France's cost.

      Any recommendations for a disband? Adriatic seems like an obvious choice, but maybe it's better to disband elsewhere and let Mel and Eero handle Tunis on their own?\n
      Posted By: DWeirdIn other news... Keeping Tunis is just luck, and I certainly don't expect it to last... But I do certainly welcome any favours the magnificient lady luck deems to grant me.
      \nSo, I've been wondering about this:

      The Italian situation throughout this game has been rife with 50/50-type decisions, where one way would work out and the other would not. (The most obvious being, of course, the continuous assault of Tunis that has gone on now for five full years, with usually a 50/50 chance of success almost every turn of orders. Another example is Venice this turn: Willow made an error in her orders, and so attacking Trieste instead of Adriatic would have left Venice in my hands this turn.)

      However, it seems that I have guessed wrong, every single time. Now, there have been a couple of cases where I can see, in retrospect, that I picked a moveset that was easily countered (like my silly attempt to convoy into Tunis a few years back), but overall it seems to me that the situation has been more or less even in the Mediterranean. Yet somehow Italy has lost out almost every time. At first I chalked it up to simple bad luck, but maybe I'm operating on some tactically-flawed reasoning? I've had great success guessing my opponents' moves in my other Diplomacy game, but here... seem to have missed every time.

      What do you think: bad luck, or am I making some kind of tactical errors I'm not aware of?

      Since I'm just learning to play Diplomacy, I'd love to hear your thoughts on this, more experienced folks!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n

      Posted By: Eero TuovinenI believed that by pretending ignorance of the threat to Berlin I might encourage the Russians to attack there, allowing the French to seize Munich. No luck this time, but fortunately we can force the issue next year.)
      \nThat's what I had been expecting, too.

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n To clarify:

      The reason I would even consider holding on to Fleet Adriatic is to gain a negotiating angle vis-a-vis Russia and Turkey. I could, for example, support Russia into Venice, or Turkey into Trieste, and thereby through the balance in favour of one country over the other. I could also support France into Venice in the Fall, as another example.

      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n In general, defensiveness and keeping to your soil instead of taking the fight to the enemy. 50/50 defense decisions mean you essentially lose 0.5 SCs per turn. 50/50 offense decisions mean you gain that much. S'all about initiative.

      In this particular case - supporting your attack with a unit the support of which could easily be cut. Was there really anything else that F Greece could conceivably do? I wasn't sure why Eero gave you the advice that he did, but I hope you understand me not bringing it up then.
