      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero Tuovinenmisleading the Frenchman by my moves
      \nHey, are you talking about me?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Why, are you French, Mel?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I don't know that supporting France into Venice is necessarily in your best interests, Paul, but having France support you definitely is, assuming that Mel's not simply in fierce disagreement with me on this whole Italian matter. Unfortunately the enemy presence around Venice is pretty dense, which makes it difficult for you to retake the place even with French support if neither Russia nor Turkey decides to support you.

      The problem in preserving Adr is that Naples and Rome are under dire threat here. With Tyr and Ion you can make taking those two an issue, at least, while with just one fleet you're making further attacking an obvious Turkish move. You should probably hold onto both fleets to preserve at least a semi-credible defense in the hopes that Turkey chooses this turn to finally turn on the Russian; if overrunning you does not represent a significant investment for Turkey, then it's an easy choice to hurry up with that, establish a defensive perimeter against France in the Tyr-Ion area and only then reconsider the situation.

      Looking at the tactical landscape in the central Mediterranean area, the first and foremost Turkish concern is decimating Italy quickly so as to build up a coherent defense against the Franco-English fleet before we make it to the scene and turn the tables on him. While our own fleet merely meets parity against the Turk, we can support Italy and together have a majority against the Sultan. For this reason taking Italy down before we can combine forces is so important to Turkey - and this is also why the failure of the Tunis operation this year was so unfortunate, possibly game-changingly so.

      It well might be the case that we'll have to go with NAf-Tun next spring as Italy bounces in Rom and Nap, then follow up with appropriately depending on whether Turkey plays Tun-Ion or not in the spring; his choice is basically whether to allow the Ion fleet to retreat east or leave it where it is. Probably Turkey opts for Tun-Ion, as his new build allows him to constrain the Italian fleet effectively even in an eastern retreat. In this case Nap falls in the fall, while the western fleets progress to the Tyrhenian Sea; 1916 begins with Turkish fleets in Nap and Ion, an Italian fleet in Tus and western fleets in Tyr and Tun. This position is unstable even with an army in Piedmont, so Rome falls in 1916, resulting in a typical end-game Mediterranean pattern with Turkey in control of Italian home SCs and France in Tunis.

      (What I said here is not quite the whole truth, but I won't lay out the entire strategic field for Turkey - it's sufficient to say that something like the above has more than 50% likelyhood, although we might sucker him nicely if he didn't read every tactical suggestion I might make.)

      The above prediction is pretty grim, but better outcomes are difficult to predict here. The main reason for a better result would be a real disagreement within the Juggernaut; this is not as unlikely as it sounds, as Russia is already at the greatest extent of her capabilities within the Juggernaut paradigm, and she'll start actually losing ground from next year onwards. Meanwhile Turkey and Russia both can project like above to pinpoint when the frontlines stabilize, which means that they know when the relative pressure on Turkish lines vs. Turkish gains in Italy leave him at his weakest, just like they can project the defensive requirements a hypothetical English attack on Russia would cause. Once that knowledge is on the table, either player might opt to refuse the simplification of the play-space that destroying Italy represents, instead choosing to turn on their partner in the hopes of affirming their own position in the draw (or in Russia's case, as a bid for a solo victory). They might admittedly choose to race towards the very outcome I'm outlining, but only at the risk that this means their own defeat: assuming a board where Italy is conquered by Turkey and Russia is pushed out of Munich, which of France, Russia and Turkey is the odd man out, considering that a four-way draw is not an option? (The reason for why four-way is not on the table is that even if everybody else is too chicken to play for a three-way, I'm in position to insist on it.) If either Russia or Turkey decides that it's most likely that we'll be pushing them out of the draw, then it is absolutely imperative for them to take steps against their current partner to ensure that the balance changes before the trenches stabilize so much that nothing more can be done.

      Finally, let it be said that I'm all for an in-Juggernaut falling-out, myself. In fact, I'd be only too happy to ally with my good friend the Czarinna immediately, pacifying our mutual borders and allowing her to put all of her strength on the matter of the Turk, if she only took the first step. As we all remember, when massive forces are on the move and Powers are equally strong, the one who moves first wins the war. Turkey is admittedly the second-most difficult of our four Great Powers (after England, that is) to remove from the board due to his corner position, but I'm all for a Franco-Russian attempt at just that if only Czarinna could be made to see how dangerous it is for her to assume that the Juggernaut will bring her the draw. For all we know that crazy Englishman might go through with the French alliance, paralyzing Turkey and pushing at the northern Russian border until Turkey has no choice but to put her out of her misery.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, I can't pinpoint it perfectly, but I think there were a few instances where you could have moved or retreated to the Aegan, threating my largely unprotected home centers... And instead either stayed put or moved closer to home?

      If you're on a roll and can gain a bunch of SCs quickly, losing a single home center isn't that big a deal - you can build right next to the invader and thus repel him, *and* most of your forces will be at the enemy front already - so it's rather useful to keep your home SCs empty and have every unit you can positioned to strike (a strategy not without diplomatic difficulties).


      Sudden insight/disclaimer: I am not sure why I am talking as if I was a Diplomacy expert. This is my third game, and my track record of success is actually not that great. It's perfectly possible that you did, indeed, just get a run of bad luck, compounded by having to play Italy, compounded by the handicap of the first poor years. Which means the stuff I said above may not actually apply, even if I personally find it convincing - we might just have a difference in our play styles, nothing more.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I find the gist of what Daumantas is saying credible, but we'll need to go through the game history in a bit more detail to pinpoint the exact reasons of why Italy's been doing so badly against Turkey. Without referencing the archive my own impression is that it's basically a bit of bad luck and some bad choices combined with good play from Daumantas - he's been fucking with you from day one both diplomatically and tactically as Turkey should if he's to dominate the Mediterranean, after all. It's true that most choices that Italy's been doing have been 50/50 or some variant thereof, but this is always the case with tactical choices: the thing that changes as power relationships change is the stakes of the moves, not their uncertain nature. This is because the certain elements are not a focus of tactical consideration. Basically, while at first the 50/50 might have been about eg. whether Turkey loses a SC to Italy or not, and later on the issue might have been whether Italy loses Ion to Turkey or not, or which one of the two loses a SC to the other, now the situation is increasingly about whether italy loses a SC to Turkey, every turn. It's still a guessing-game on the particulars, but the stakes are constantly more favourable to Turkey.

      There's no way around the fact that Italy's been getting a consistently bad deal from the open diplomacy environment: most other players have ignored the diplomatic elements to a much greater degree than Italy, which is understandable when we remember that Italy is always naturally under constant pressure, and therefore much more receptable to influence. (In fact, this is probably the biggest Italian lesson I have to offer: Italy absolutely has to lead in diplomacy even if he doesn't lead strategically, as otherwise he has no choice but to hang onto any sorry excuse of a plan that anybody else deigns to offer him.) This has made it easier for others to cause upsets where Italy moves according to the publicly agreed-upon plan only to find out that hey, not only is the other guy not following the plan, but Turkey's also specifically playing to counter that move. Fucking up the Austrian relationship was also a major, major hindrance to Italy - I can't emphasize enough the size of trouble Italy gets to by allowing Austria to die against the Juggernaut, leaving Italy with two strong Powers that have many good reasons for working together until the end-game.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n On the other hand, D, your tactical play has always been sharp, and you've clearly learned a lot between your first game and today. So I think there's a lot to what you say.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n So.

      Eero will either take part in a three-way draw or solo.

      Does Eero have a preference for any variation of the three-way draw? Doubtful. Can anything be done to remove him from the endgame? Doubtful.

      Meaning, anything he does say and do now is with intent to solo.

      Already, he can essentially remove France from the map - but not so quickly that Russia and Turkey would not be able to slide in and prop up a defense. Apparently, he will be keeping France alive (and using her as an ally and an asset to contain Turkey! Brilliant!) until he can either cordon France off from russian armies and/or turkish fleets... Or Russia and Turkey come to blows, allowing him to maybe pick a center or two off Russia. Both Turkey and Russia would be alive, of course, but in no shape to stop the map from turning orange.

      The possibility of a russian solo is predicated on Russia breaking through StP and me completelly forgetting to mount a defense. One of those *might* happen, sure, but both of those together? Russia steamrolling not one but two fairly secure fronts? Longshot squared.


      In fact, I don't think there are actually any three way draw variations left - it's either Russia-England-Turkey, or an English solo. France could make a miracle recovery, of course, but I'm not betting on it. (Sorry, Mel... Tell me how I'm wrong if you can, please!)

      Which in turn might mean that very soon we'll be in for a patience game - Eero has no reason to attack France in force, and France won't disappear until Eero chooses to do so... Meaning, yes, Russia and Turkey are contained, and yes, plenty of time for tensions to build, especially with England egging one or the other side on, and mistakes to happen.

      I'm not sure Willow is the best partner for a waiting game for me, but I don't feel like I have a reasonable alternative to a Russia-England-Turkey draw (France can't even hold her own against England now, I think?), so I'll be sticking with that... And drinkin' lots of camomile tea.

      Cools the nerves down.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.Why, are you French, Mel?
      \nOui! In spirit, for now. Sacre Bleu!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdIn fact, I don't think there are actually any three way draw variations left - it's either Russia-England-Turkey, or an English solo. France could make a miracle recovery, of course, but I'm not betting on it. (Sorry, Mel... Tell me how I'm wrong if you can, please!)
      \nI am intending, of course, to solo myself. As the famous captain of a French ship once said, "I have not yet begun to fight!"
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Actually, the French recovery begins next year with France liberating Munich, with English assistance; and with France freeing Tunis from Ottoman rule; again with English assistance. This returns France to its competitive stature relative to the other powers. Why does England do this? Simply because a French collapse in the Mediterranean creates a vacuum that will suck in Turkish forces while most of England's combat power is oriented north. A French collapse in Central Europe puts England on the defensive leading soon after, no doubt, to a three way Rus-Tur-Eng draw. So, France's survival is important to England in order to maintain the possibility of an English solo. The possibility of an English solo is both real enough and tempting enough to Eero that England will spend a couple of years to see if the stars are right. If not, England either falls back on the original three-way draw of Rus-Tur-Eng, or swaps France for one of the eastern powers. It really would be unsatisfying for England to settle for a draw with the Juggernaut, considering Turkish struggles to get past the Ionian, Russia's passive acceptance of English demands, and the incoherent nature of the Russo-Turkish relationship. It would mean, really, that England defeats France on behalf of Russia and Turkey--who couldn't do it themselves. Eero's not going to do that for you, I'm afraid. There is no doubt that included within England's planned 18 centers are 4 or even 5 of the current French centers--I think Marseilles would fall to Turkey. But also included in the 18 are Moscow, Warsaw, and Munich--and England needs a neutral or even friendly France to get those centers. England's route to a solo victory is much easier and simpler through Russia than through Turkey.
      The policy implications for Turkey in all this are clear--shift the thrust of offensive actions north to take advantage of the potential for a double envelopment of Russia, conduct economy of force measures to limit options for the Russian probe in vicinity Armenia, eliminate Italy as quickly as possible in order to convert Italian units to Turkish armies, and shift to the defense on the maritime front to prevent English and French advances past Tunis in the Med.
      By that point, France will be expecting an English attack aimed at a solo, and so both preparing defenses and welcoming Turkish movements west. Faced with resolute Turkish and French defenses--or even the risk of French self-sacrifice, England good-naturedly accepts the France-Turkey-England draw. It is all very clear in my head.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Just between us, Daumantas, I rather like your game analysis - you project to the end-game with clarity, just like one should in Diplomacy, and you don't bullshit when it's not to advantage, but rather choose to deal with facts. Don't tell the others I said that, though. It is the utmost irony if I end up drawing this game because I've taught you too well as regards the end-game logic of Diplomacy, grasshopper

      Mel has good points, too - I can see that happening, definitely.

      I've heard that there are people in the Diplomacy world who play the waiting game mulishly, refusing the obvious game-ending and thus forcing the other players to abandon the game out of boredom. This is, of course, unsportsmanlike, and not the policy of the English crown; should we find ourselves in a situation where our only choices are between ending the game in a draw or prolonging it in the hope of our opposition quitting in disgust, we will definitely take the draw. If and when Daumantas proves his thesis to my satisfaction I'll be only too happy to act on the conclusion. Meanwhile, we will see what happens.

      One consideration Daumantas does not address is this: assuming that the Turkish analysis holds water, why would France not attack east most aggressively, inviting English forces into France? France and England together hold 16 SCs, which means that France is perilously close to being able to force a solo for England with minimal new conquests. A defeat is after all a defeat, and losing to a drawing coalition is no better than losing to a soloist, so these choices are equal for France. By threatening this action or even beginning to execute it the French can force the Juggernaut to break: either they make any concessions the French require, or France ensures that Turkey and Russia follow him to defeat. It's a grim strategy, but were the French premier to find himself convinced that the only alternative is a Turko-English assault on him from both sides, it is perhaps his last, best hope.

      Meanwhile, I find that I disagree somewhat on the tactical realities of who has a chance in the draw. Specifically, France totally has some chance of getting in on the expense of Russia, assuming the Juggernaut doesn't manage to rearrange forces against the logical full-front assault the joint Franco-English HQ can manage over the Pru-Sil-Boh-Tyr corridor. Materially the situation is somewhat even (8 Juggernaut armies vs. 7 westerners with superior fleet support, basically), but I find myself suspicious of whether the Juggernaut is truly able to counter this move due to geographical realities: while the Franco-English forces have no trouble maneuvering in safe and efficient manner, the Juggernaut army force is split in a way that would require Turkish troops to travel over Russian terrain to reach relevant defensive positions. Will Russia be able to allow this when both know that for Turkey the quickest way into the draw is to stab Russia and allow a EFT draw? From Russia's viewpoint, the only way of preventing Russia itself from becoming the battleground is to either imbue an English assault on France or take the initiative against Turkey himself, thus removing the substantial motivation for the joint western assault at the root. The only issues here are timing and the danger of EFT draw considered against the danger of English solo should the Juggernaut break. The former will become clearer and clearer as the battlelines converge, while the latter will become more unlikely as English forces are committed in Russia. However, at the same time the Russian capability for even stabbing Turkey will drop sharply as all his forces are required in defense against the French armies pushing at him in the corridor; the timing is critical, but if Russia doesn't move within a year or two at most, we might reach a point of no return where the only alternatives are a dead Russia or a successful eastern defense that truly leaves us no other choice but to eliminate France to achieve a three-way draw. Of the two I find dead Russia massively more likely; Turkey might say right now that he has no intent to stab Russia once battle is joined, but when the moment is upon us the fact will be that Turkey cares of nothing but forcing a three-way draw with himself in it - should Russia allow a situation where Turkey can achieve this with a couple of turns of maneuvering against Russia, the choice will be easy.

      But aside from those points (and a few other that I'll keep to myself for now), a most cogent analysis. I'd really like to be able to argue for Italy here, but unfortunately I find myself sceptical of the Italian ability to maintain himself despite any western aid at this point. We will do our best, but joint operations with multiple Powers are really rather horridly hampered by the open diplomacy environment, so I fear that Turkey will have a considerable tactical edge in the Italian peninsula for the next couple of years.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      In fact, building in Sevastopol is something I warmly recommend to our sister the Czarinna: as we've explained before, building in Warsaw when there is already an army in Moscow is a clear and immediate threat to our position in the free city of StP. As hostilities between our Powers would prove both pointless and dangerous to the Russian responsibilities in central Europe, it is surely wiser to follow the old ways that have served us so well in preserving the peace to this day.
      \nAn army Warsaw is my best asset in a western front campaign; a fleet Sevastopol signals a poorly conducted stab against Daumantas.

      Daumantas, how about I build that army Warsaw, you build a fleet, and in the spring we move away from Budapest and Serbia as you suggest? Also, how about that Piedmont? I might support you there, I might not- no sense giving Mel too much information.
      \n
      \n
      \n

      Eero, our front runner, has an impressive 11 centers.
      Daumantas and Willow have 8 each.
      Mel has 5.
      Paul only has 2, but they're really good ones.

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1\u202613141516171819\xbb

    Comments

      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ha!

      Interesting all around. It will be especially interesting to see how much of this logic will have its effect and how much is misdirection.

      Does anyone see a possibility for Italy to throw the balance over in one direction or another? I am looking for options, and since my survival doesn't seem too likely, I could potentially be talked into some kind of interesting suicide gambit...


      Daumantas,

      Your logic is sound, and makes sense tactically. However, in this game, I never felt like I had the luxury to be able to risk that kind of maneuver. There were two chances for me to retreat into the Turkish backside: Spring 1907 and Fall 1910. I considered it both times, but it didn't seem wise. In 1907, you had an army which would easily have kept my fleet from making any gains, whereas the same move would leave two of my SCs open to you, so I chose to retreat, not really seeing any possible gains. The Fall of 1910 was a more tempting moment, in some ways, and I still hold that had Bill and I maintained our alliance and had I retreated there, Turkey would have been in serious trouble. Unfortunately, at that very same moment, Bill abandoned his own territory to strike in my direction, and gave me the impression that he would not stop until I was dead, even if it cost him the game. [Edited to add: Not trying to blame Bill here. I did piss him off, so the aggression was entirely justified. I'm just saying that I had to worry about an attack from that side as well as from the sea that turn.]

      I *could* have chosen to retreat into the Aegean at that point, threatening you. However, I chose not to: first of all, you had a build coming your way, which would allow you to easily block any grab I could make from that position (e.g. build an army in Smyrna and then self-bounce in Constantinople). Second, I had just lost two SCs and was surrounded by hostile forces (again, Bill was clearly not an ally at that point), with hardly enough forces to defend what territory I had left.

      So, curious: Do you really think you would have retreated to the Aegean instead of moving in to defense, in my place? Take a look at Fall 1910.

      (My retreat to the Adriatic was aimed fully at regaining Trieste, since I knew I would be losing Vienna the very next turn. I figured (and rightly so) that having that fleet in position would allow me to maneuver into position for another attack on Tunis--and I figured that had to work sooner or later, right?)

      I'm honestly curious! I agree with Bill: what you're saying makes a ton of sense, even if it's skewed to a personal play-style (which is clearly quite effective).

      ...

      Still, by my count Tunis has survived seven consecutive 50/50 attacks, denying Italy a unified front and an additional build for many long years. That has been unfortunate luck, then! Ah, well.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Paul T.
      Still, by my count Tunis has survivedsevenconsecutive 50/50 attacks, denying Italy a unified front and an additional build for many long years. That has been unfortunate luck, then! Ah, well.
      \nPaul,
      I've looked through the order history back to 1909 and I think your luck is less bad than you might think. By my count, four of the recent Italian attacks on Tunis were done unsupported, and in three of those there was no possible supporting unit (a French fleet could have supported in one attack--but was unlikely for various reasons). The Fall 09/Spring 10/Fall 10 sequence is interesting. You were just outguessed. To recap the situation: Italian fleets in Tyr and Ion, and Turkish fleets in Eas and Tun (and Aeg--but concerned with Greece). While it may look like Italy has a numerical advantage relating to Tunis, the Turkish Eas fleet plays a big role. So, in both Fall 09 and Spr 10, Turkey saved Tunis with Tun to Ion, Eas S Tun to Ion; which bounced Ion to Tun, Tyr S Ion to Tun. Fall 10 is interesting. (This is when Italy attempted the convoy from Albania to Tunis). The Italian effort failed because Turkey now attacked and gained control of the Ionian. The Turkish fleet from Aegean had moved to Greece in Spr 10 , in fact forcing the retreat of the Italian army to Albania. It is ironic in that an Italian attack on Tunis the same as in the previous two attempts would have succeeded! Having gained Greece, Turkey was likely 'willing' to lose Tunis in exchange for the Ionian, and retreating to Wes or NAf. I would say this turn's results was less bad luck and more the result of a risky plan. It does remind me that convoy rules in conjunction with attacks hurt my head a little. The bottom line is that the convoy has to be successful before worrying about the effects of the convoyed army. So, in this case, the Ionian convoy supported by Naples was displaced by the Turkish attack of Eas, supported by Gre and Tunis itself!
      In this last turn, Fall 1914, an attack from Ionian supported by Tyr would have worked...exactly the attacks that failed in 09/10. So...Daumantas is going to have to explain what 'tells' you are displaying that he is so successfully reading.
      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Your logic is sound, and makes sense tactically. However, in this game, I never felt like I had the luxury to be able to risk that kind of maneuver. There were two chances for me to retreat into the Turkish backside: Spring 1907 and Fall 1910. I considered it both times, but it didn't seem wise. In 1907, you had an army which would easily have kept my fleet from making any gains, whereas the same move would leave two of my SCs open to you, so I chose to retreat, not really seeing any possible gains. The Fall of 1910 was a more tempting moment, in some ways, and I still hold that had Bill and I maintained our alliance and had I retreated there, Turkey would have been in serious trouble.

      *could* have chosen to retreat into the Aegean at that point, threatening you. However, I chose not to: first of all, you had a build coming your way, which would allow you to easily block any grab I could make from that position (e.g. build an army in Smyrna and then self-bounce in Constantinople). Second, I had just lost two SCs and was surrounded by hostile forces (again, Bill was clearly not an ally at that point), with hardly enough forces to defend what territory I had left.
      \n1907 is actually not the issue; you could not have retreated to the East Med, since that's where the attacker came from. But in 1910, I certainly would have; getting a unit past your attackers line is of considerable worth, since you have freedom to attack centers, forcing a defense, you could have supported attacks against Greece, and done everything considering the Ionian (attacking, cutting supports) that you could do from Apulia or the Adriatic.

      For some examples of the worth of a unit next to the enemy's centers, consider the impact England's A St. Petersburg has had: Russia has had to commit an order every single turn to nullifying its influence (sometimes two). The conflict of England and France has largely been over the strategic advantage of MAO, and you certainly know from experience what a thorn in your side Turkey's presence in Tunis has been.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Mel,

      Quite correct. My multiple attempts at an unsupported attack on Tunis were exactly that: if Daumantas had ordered an attack on the Ionian (which he was likely to do, and had already tried multiple times), any one of them would have succeeded. But otherwise your analysis is right on. Daumantas, if there is some kind of secret or tell in play here, I hope you'll tell me (perhaps afterwards, if not now)!


      Willow,

      Interesting, thanks! Just for kicks, can you outline what a tactical plan for Italy in 1910 might have looked like with a unit in the Aegean? The reason I was hesitant to do so is because I knew I needed to gain an SC somewhere just in order to maintain the strength needed to survive. I would be disbanding two units after that retreat (Fall 1910), and had every reason to expect to disband yet another in the following year (1911: there wasn't any way I was going to hold Vienna, after all).

      I certainly do see the value of a unit behind enemy lines in theory, but in that particular situation? The only unit I could count on supporting was Army Albania, and Daumantas could easily have countered anything I could do with those units by ordering a very sensible and predictable set of moves like this:

      Build Army Smyrna;
      Bul S Gre
      A Smy -> Con
      F BLA -> Con

      ...and then just wait until I'm forced to disband that fleet at the end of the following year (when I lose Vienna).

      So, the possible gains? I don't really see any likely gains. The risks? To mount any kind of potential offensive from my Fleet Aegean, I would have had to disband either Venice or one of my other fleets. Either way, I would be very likely to lose yet another SC in very short order. (Remember that Bill was clearly not on my side at that time, and even if he had agreed to support me into Greece, I would still likely lose Venice and Vienna that very same term, and Daumantas had a number of possible defenses against that maneuver, as well.)

      So, that's why I decided to retreat to the Adriatic: it allowed me to take Trieste (gaining an SC) and thereby stay alive a little longer.

      Daumantas and Willow, if you don't mind humouring me for the sake of education, can you see a different scenario in that situation? What does it look like?

      (Also, since this is the Internet, after all: I'm not trying to be argumentative, just looking to learn, and curious how you might have dealt with that situation from your end!)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Heading into Spring 1915:
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Russia builds an army in Warsaw, signaling both a possible de-escalation in Turkish relations and the intent to go head to head with the British ground forces building strength on the continent.
      Turkey builds a fleet in Smyrna, a similarly conciliatory act relative to Russia.
      Italy disbands the Adriatic fleet, thus maintaining the ability to defend Rome and Naples, at least for a while.
      French troops in Marseilles mutiny over lack of pay, 14 years of war, and a desire to lay on the beach.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n For France, the loss of the Marseilles army leaves southern France open to a possible Turkish or Russian invasion. This makes it vital for the integrity of the western alliance to ensure French expansion in 1915 in order to recruit replacement forces.
      France will be looking for the obvious English assistance with regards to Tunis, and another attempt with Ruhr's liberation of Munich. If these efforts fail, the likelihood of a French collapse increases in a geometric progression of high magnitude.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'd have hoped to see a disband in Brest, frankly - the tactical situation is very tight now, with little room for doubt. As has been discussed, should the west fail in an attack on the east, the default outcome is pretty much that England and Turkey are forced to split France between themselves at their convenience. With these stakes the security offered by a single army in Brest is negligible.

      Following that train of thought, the English forces will support the retaking of Munich and liberation of Tunis, and I'd also like to bring more fleets to the Mediterranean from the Atlantic. Ideally the French fleet in Spain will also move Spa-GoL quickly; we need at least material parity in the Mediterranean, or the Turk simply runs over us no matter what we do. As discussed earlier, I gave it a 87% likelyhood that both Rome and Naples fall to Turkey even with A Mar - without it we'll need to take the southern situation seriously indeed. Take note of the possibility of Tyr-Pie-Mar this year; France needs to bring an army south to Marseilles in the fall, at which point there's ideally a fleet in GoL to support the advance.

      As for Italy, it's a difficult situation. The best play I can think of is to convince Turkey that it's in his best interests to allow Italy to retreat to Rom-Nap and hold there indefinitely; should Turkey choose to prevent this and seize the positions himself, there's not much Italy can do to confound him. This might make sense from a Turkish viewpoint simply because he can calculate the tactical situation as well as anybody else, and thus see how the area in question is going to be the furthest extent of his line anyway. By leaving Italy alive in a conclave between the Great Powers he can mobilize marginally quicker on some secondary objectives without really compromising his defensive arrangement, as Italy can be counted on to simply hold in Rom-Nap as long as it takes for the storm to pass. Besides, Italy in those positions with fleets only does not have a credible assault on Venice or other Turkish SCs, anyway. The difficult part is to convince Turkey that Ven-Pie or Apu S Tun-Ion are truly so much more useful moves for him that this arrangement is worthwhile. Speaking for myself, I would consider Ven-Pie seriously as the Turk, but I'd have to look at the map with care to figure out whether I would take it or not - basically depends on what I'd expect to happen in the naval war in 2-3 years, as well as the utility of having Russia take Piedmont, instead.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The French are most welcome in Tunis, whose locals are smarting under Turkish pirate oppression.

      Surely your troops have some relatives on vacation there, in any case?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow,

      Two things.

      Firstly, the endgame is nigh, and as such, I probably won't be needing that fleet in the Bla - mostly there to make you not even think about building fleets, and I don't think you'll be doing that either way now. It's removal would allow you to retreat all those armies at my borders, correct? Seems like you might need vast land power superiority sooner rather than later, thus disallowing England to establish a foothold on the coasts of Russia.

      Second - upon review, you botched the orders last time. A Tyrolia S A Trieste- Adriatic? Normally, I'd be more than happy to suspect foul play, but in this case, if the orders fell through, you'd be on the receiving end of it - losing Trieste. Do you perhaps have some kind of an eyesight problem? I wouldn't even ask, but this sort of thing... might just matter in the coming years.

      What I say to Mel below also matters to you, by the way! Give it a look.

      Mel,

      I thought long and hard about how to provide a more reasonable route for you than your current one - which is basically supporting and hoping to be supported by a power you know might turn on you any minute. I think there is one such way, even if it is a bit of a longshot...

      England must fall!

      Sure, it is a bit of a longshot, but I think it would provide everyone involved a more natural system of expectations and ways of balancing other powers.

      The plan is basically such - France puts fleets in the western side of the map, harassing England, perhaps swiping a home SC, with the eventual goal of moving to Norway or the Barents Sea, dislodging StP. In the meantime, Russia would put pressure on England so that it would not be able to gain any more supply centers (thus giving France some room to manouver). Turkey's job would be to use the fleet at her disposal to cover French lands, and help the French fleets offensivelly when in position to do so.

      You, of course, face a risk - what if Turkey turns on you? However, doing so would signal quite clearly to everyone on the board, including Russia, that Turkey is trying to go for a solo - I would imagine you could expect English support to counter such movements as well. Similarly, you could expect Turkish support in case of a russian breakthrough, even though it now seems rather unlikely. Plus, given the valuable service you would be providing both of the other countries, why would they choose to provide you with counterincentives to it?

      The gains of this plan are modest, but they are there - firstly, a bit more clarity of the grand scheme of things (everyone against the most powerful player on the board!). Secondly - and this is the reason why you could expect me to commit to this endgame plan rather than another version of a three-way draw - there is a certain reputational advantage to making it to the end of a draw with Eero not in it... As well as a certain giddiness, which I'm not sure you've experienced, but I certainly do treasure, of seeing a fairly crazy plan in action. I giggle like a little girl sometimes, I kid you not!


      Paul,

      I don't feel like I have any insight to the workings of your brain, so if it seems like I do, it's probably the results of one of these, in descending order:

      1) Making as sure as I can that, whatever happens, my position will be at least as good as it was for all reasonable sets of moves the opponent may enter.
      2) Guesswork - "I did that last time, so I'll do THIS this time instead!" or "I changed what I did every season now. He won't expect it if I keep doing the same thing again!"
      3) You are, and I hope you do not take offense of me saying so, green - you reliably take good advice when given such (advice your opponent knows you're going to take is bad advice, in case of tactical issues at least), and make strange goofs with your orders every once in a while.
      4) Lady luck's kisses.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n

      \n
      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdDo you perhaps have some kind of an eyesight problem? I wouldn't even ask, but this sort of thing... might just matter in the coming years.
      \nYou know, I'm starting to wonder, myself.

      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n

      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenI'd have hoped to see a disband in Brest,
      \nMon Dieu! So would we have all! Unfortunately, the citizens of Brest, having been subject to countless (or at least two) invasions by British forces in the last few years and in view of the Royal Navy patrolling offshore, insisted upon the retention of a garrison sufficient to deter another British attack. Ironically, it is the French of Little Britain that are taking the longest to accept the new reality of alliance with Great Britain. Give them time!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdEngland must fall!
      \nThis, too, is the course of action I thought once and sought to engineer. My view point has shifted somewhat since then, in light of Russia's apparent unwillingness to direct action against England. Even now, Russian actions are directed against France rather than the English. The recruitment of an army in Warsaw is perhaps the signal of a change in policy in Moscow. Yet I fear it is too little, too late. In any event, France must reclaim Munich--it is a matter of pride. Russia's actions in support or opposition of this effort will greatly inform our own future decision-making. Also, while I have no doubt of England's long term commitment to the current era of Franco-English unity, I am hopeful that in the short-term we are more useful as a partner than as an enemy. Admittedly, French survival depends upon being useful.
      Finally, the Sultan's plan simply exchanges one problem set for another. It is just as dangerous a course of action to leave French territory at the mercy of Turkish forbearance as it is to leave similar territory at English mercy. I strongly urged you to reach an accord with Italy to allow your combined forces to move west. In France's hour of need, you rejected our broken arrow. Paradoxically, it is the English who both brought France to the brink and pulled us back.
      As an alternative to your course of action I suggest another. Take advantage of Russia's vulnerable position between England and your own territory in order to weaken Russia's position. To fight England, Turkey must go through France; similarly, to fight Turkey, England must do so as well. We are all in contact with Russian forces now and therefore can apply incessant pressure at all points. In the long run, with balanced ground and naval strength, Turkey and France can counterweigh any future English attempts at European hegemony. Thus will peace be established again in Europe.
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \nI believe the former Marseilles army can now be found in Tunisian bars, brothels, and beaches.

      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Spring 1915, pending retreats
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n A stunning turnabout in Anglo-French relations! The world hasn't seen this level of cooperation from England since the days of the England-German partnership...gulp.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Have faith, Mel - I play a solid end-game, and I do not go for war for the sake of war. I admit that I might attack France if it were tactically likely for me to accomplish total dominance in the west without losing any position against the Juggernaut, but this is not tactically realistic: I can't hold the Turk back without your fleet support in the Mediterranean, and I can't hold the Russian back in Central Europe without French aid. I say with no second thoughts that the best, most straightforward French victory plan at the moment is to not try to get cute, but to rather crush Russia decisively - Turkey will join in once our commitment is tactically obvious, and Russia hardly can defend against all three of us at once.

      Speaking of next turns tactics: I'd have liked to see you in GoL at this point, as we could've attacked the Tyrhenian Sea. As it is, we have little to do but to shore up positions; I'll support Tunisia in place and move a second fleet to NAf, while I hope you'll move to Mar and GoL to complete the southern line for us. Up north, meanwhile, we should push against Russia a bit; it's difficult to coordinate without giving away the exact plan, so perhaps we'll try a blind play in the hopes of second-guessing Russia?

      Willow: as you can see, the western alliance is working reasonably well, and while Turkey is more or less impregnable against us (except in the very longest term of carefully conducted trench warfare), the same is not true of Russia. I suggest that you consider carefully the advantages of turning against your ally in a decisive lightning attack that'll provide you with both a superior position and material advantage. It is the well-known long-term commitment of his majesty's government that we will, upon seeing evidence of resumed hostilities between Russia and Turkey, withdraw any offensive elements of our own army from Russian borders to support our eastern friends in their time of trial. Consider this well, for the stakes at the moment are as yet relatively minor: if the wind shifts this coming turn and we normalize our relations next spring, then no major hazard to Russian lands has occurred; the situation in just a year or two will be completely different as the amount of pressure on Warsaw and other outlying Russian SCs increases - in that situation the Czarinna will surely find it difficult to relax her defense against the west at all to conduct the necessary southern operations, which effectively means that this current option will be out of your hands, possibly permanently. I personally find the risk of an entrenched war against Russia and France justified for Russia only if you are certain that you are tactically capable of stopping us; a diplomatic solution is unlikely once everybody's forces have advanced over the point of no return, especially when you consider that the easiest draw of the game still excludes France: whatever else happens, I find it unlikely that the French leaders will desist from this war when they know that Russia's death - and only Russia's death - will automatically bring about their own victory on this board.

      Daumantas: I do not scorn your diplomatic stance, as it remains a fact that the safest and most straightforward Turkish draw involves decimating France, ideally by engaging French and English forces in a war amongst themselves. I promise you that should the French prove faithless I will join you in dealing a quick and decisive three-player draw on the board. Meanwhile, however, tread carefully: your position is second-strongest, it's true, but should the Russian and French forces find concord and decide to turn on you, I will not interfere, and I fully expect that the two will be capable of reducing your lines to chaos with a mere couple of years of warfare. Should you be caught unawares, the situation will be possibly the most favourable of all for myself while being the most perilous for you. I'm sure you will find sticking with the Juggernaut your safest choice, and the one that least requires any initiative, but it also remains a fact that a quick and decisive attack on the Russian would all but guarantee your position on the board: gaining the tactical upper hand could give you a position comparative to mine insofar as tactical invulnerability goes. Also, the fact remains that the French will be happy to kill whoever seems the weakest among the eastern Powers, so directing him against the Russians will be much easier if you take the initiative yourself.

      Paul: Seems like we can do little for you, especially as the French forces remain tardy about advancing. A shame.

      Considering the above viewpoints overall, it seems that my strategy is clear: put pressure on Russia, support a French advance towards the east and see how long the Juggernaut lasts. I'm confident that our forces are better positioned and led (assuming the French tardiness in execution lessens over time), so it's only a matter of time before Russia finds her own survival dependent on serious negotiation with the western forces. After that matters depend greatly on who stabbed who first, and how much advance the western forces gain before the Juggernaut falls.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ah! This is emblematic Eero! Everyone but him is in a painful situation of having to either dance to his tune or pay the piper. It is this kind of bare-knuckle diplomacy that made Mike affix Eero with the moniker, "The Pope of Pain."
      \n

      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, it looks like I'm safely out of this just as the drama and tension reaches an all-time high, not unlike the final around of some kind of elimination contest (are we watching the finals or the semi-finals here?).

      I was hoping to get a few minutes to consider some alternative defenses, and look through the possibilities to see if there was a more effective defense for Italy, but this weekend turned into a busy one and I didn't get the chance. Ah, well!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n This is the finals, Paul - you were the semifinals sacrificial lamb. Once any of the remaining four Powers becomes unfeasible, the other three will have little choice but to sue for peace and make a draw due to the self-balancing nature of the three-player situation. Meanwhile everybody is, of course, jockeying not only to ensure their place in the draw but also for some slim hope of breaking out for a solo victory. The latter is very unlikely at this late date, though; most solos are already evident in the mid-game due to the time it takes to build up the situation, and if play gets to the end-game without a clear Grand Alliance (the formation of which sort of implies that there is a player with a soloing chance), then it's almost certain that there won't be a solo at all. This is not surprising; I at least personally believe that three-way draw is the default outcome of Calhamer Diplomacy, with soloing being a glorious exception that only comes about due to cardinal mistakes by the opposition.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Yes, that is what I meant by "semi-finals":

      Once some combination of factors leads to one of the four of you being eliminated, then there is a chance for a further stage of the game leading to an attempt at a solo victory.

      So, we may be looking at the finals, but the committe may decide later to host yet another, final "elimination round".
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Incidentally, I'll be curious to hear afterwards everyone's thoughts on the open diplomacy environment. As far as I can see, most if not all the players have shown a high level of tactical skill. Is it telling, then, that it is the corner powers (particularly England and Turkey) that have been most successful? (Russia and France have both had rough periods, but still always remained viable.) After all, the success of "corner powers" is much less dependent on negotiation and diplomacy than that of the central powers: Germany, Italy, and Austria all floundered quite early in the proceedings.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenThis is the finals, Paul - you were the semifinals sacrificial lamb. Once any of the remaining four Powers becomes unfeasible, the other three will have little choice but to sue for peace and make a draw due to the self-balancing nature of the three-player situation. Meanwhile everybody is, of course, jockeying not only to ensure their place in the draw but also for some slim hope of breaking out for a solo victory. The latter is very unlikely at this late date, though; most solos are already evident in the mid-game due to the time it takes to build up the situation, and if play gets to the end-game without a clear Grand Alliance (the formation of which sort of implies that there is a player with a soloing chance), then it's almost certain that there won't be a solo at all. This is not surprising; I at least personally believe that three-way draw is the default outcome of Calhamer Diplomacy, with soloing being a glorious exception that only comes about due to cardinal mistakes by the opposition.
      \nThis isn't entirely true; just because there isn't a Grand Alliance yet doesn't mean there cannot, or shouldn't, be one.

      There is one alternative that should be aired: the four way draw. This requires the elimination of Italy (sorry Paul!), but may be the best possible end-game for everyone but Eero.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Huh! Seeing those two armies still at my borders after a rather complete withdrawal on my part, especially given the pressures on Russia's borders elsewhere seems rather... underwhelming.

      Not interested in pulling back any of my units to cover my ass, though - a half-assed commitment is no commitment at all at this point.

      Instead - and I'm only saying this because I know how tempting empty SCs next to your armies can be -, if I'm going to see any russian movement into Turkey, I'm going to exercise the nuclear option - split my forces between defending my homeland and... Supporting Eero into France and Italy. If I can't have it, no one will!


      My very own Muad'Dib moment! I like these quite a bit.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Fall 1915, prior to retreats
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Lots of naval movement.
      Lots of anticipation in Munich and Tunis for attacks that do not materialize--no complaints there.
      Big doings on the Italian peninsula.
      And Really Big News in the East on Anatolia and vicinity!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Oh, boy. Shit's going down now! Things are going to get majorly shaken up in the next year or two. Things could change very dramatically very soon (not at all unlike my other Diplomacy game, incidentally, which took place last night).

      And Italy's still in the game, much to my surprise.

      Daumantas,

      Nicely played! I like your tactical play there.

      Unfortunately, your plan to leave yourself vulnerable while making doomsday threats doesn't seem to have panned out in your favour. All I can say is good luck to you!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The Czarina would like to take this moment to remind everyone that Russia has always been at war with Turkey, since the beginning, even when we weren't. Russia has always been allied with England and France, and we have general warm fuzzy feelings associated with Italy, and promise to liberate the Italian peninsula from Turkish oppression, replacing it with our own brand of oppression.

      Eero-

      The less troops you have on my border (within reason; I wouldn't expect you to abandon your Norway-St. Pete garrison), the more I can apply to swiftly crushing the Turkish home centers, as opposed to defending Warsaw and Moscow. Maybe you can convoy a unit down to NaF where it will be useful for an assault on the Italian holdout.

      Mel-

      If you build in Marseilles, I might see us having cooperation in regards to Venice and Rome.

      Daumantas-

      I'm glad you like these moments quite a bit.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Annual unit count:

      Eero stays on top at 11.
      I lose 1, but gain 2, ending up with 9.
      Mel in France is the year's big winner, gaining 2 to get back up to 7.
      Daumantas, the year's big loser, gains 1 but loses 3, ending up at 6.
      Paul clings onto the game with 1 center left.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, that went pretty nicely! We see again that the mighty pressures of trust and realpolitic surround and subsume the game of Diplomacy, and the iron logic of looking out for number one shits lumps at the noblest intents, noblest Powers. Drama!

      Mel: very nice moves, I especially like what you did with Tun - well guessed! As you left Marseilles free to build, I suggest that you build armies in both Mar and Par; a fleet in Marseilles is something I considered as well, but the truth is that we have a heavy enough fleet mix, and getting armies to Piedmont-Tuscany area as soon as possible is a big military priority, considering how the fate of Italy is on re-bound here. Let's talk more about tactical detail later in the spring, but for now I'll say that I'm happy with our cooperation so far, and will be delighted to ensure that you get a good grip on the environs of Switzerland; that'll be useful, no matter what happens with the Turk. Also, let's talk about convoying Gascony; that might be the quickest way of getting forces to the front.

      Willow: I will, of course, gladly follow the established treaties with the Russian Czardom. Do your best against the Turk, I say. I'll establish a solid defensive perimeter for the west in Germany, but will retreat English troops from the Pru-Tyr line.

      Daumantas: Good luck against your nemesis - disband well! Russia can take both Constantinople and Serbia by force next year, it seems to me, so you'll need suberb tactics here. Also note that you owe me Italy and France now, so feel free to pay up whenever you're ready.

      Paul: were I you, I'd start negotiating for peace with Turkey vigorously. The Turk can disband two units now, and if he'll remove eg. F Tyr and A Nap, he'll be left with the units that are actually able to reconfigure against Russia, while he'll lose most of the pressure on his western flank. We'll happily help you regain Naples from the Turk either way, so one might think that the best solution for Turkey is to leave the Italian peninsula well enough alone and establish a less ambitious defensive line further east. Regaining Naples will give you some flexibility, and at that point you might be able to join forces with Turkey against Russia to retake Venice as well. Much depends on your French allies, of course.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Lessons learned:

      You can't make someone your ally if they don't want to - don't think I could have done anything more to prove my good intentions to Russia, and now we have this.

      Second, you *can* make someone begrudgingly acquisce to your demands as long as you hold them by the throat, which is apparently the state that Russia has been during all this time.

      Third, never, ever eliminate the possibility of a backup plan.


      Anyway! At this point, I stop playing this game and start playing every other game I'm going to play. And while I wouldn't go so far as to say that I owe Eero anything - I'm beholded to my promises about as much as any other Diplomacy player - making my threats count for something certainly sounds like reasonable fun.

      Paul,

      You can expect me to mostly vacate your lands. Enjoy your new status as a single wildcard fleet, right in the middle of things.

      Willow,

      It hurts, but in hindsight, should've been expected. Well-played.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Ok, let's get this show on the road. Mel, check me on this: Mun-Tyr, Bur-Mun, Ruh S Bur-Mun, Mar-Pie, Spa-GoL, Tun-Ion, Tyr S Tun-Ion, Wes-Tun. (Not trying to dictate, just painting an overall picture.) I figure that we want to get you into Naples this year while I take Tunis (temporarily, perhaps - mostly want a build, not possession), and next year we can proceed all the way to the eastern Med area. Meanwhile we'll get you a solid beachhead east of Switzerland, which will be invaluable if/when we need to stop a Russian solo in the last turns of the game - and it doesn't hurt for general influence in northern Italy, of course. Let me know if my thinking is out of line. (Note that Mun-Tyr is not a problem for Russia, as she knows about it and can account for it in her moves; business as usual.)

      Also, Mel: are you cool with secret maneuvers? I think I have a few ideas to give us decisive advantage, but I can't tell you about them without forewarning our eastern colleagues. The play I have in mind might seem a bit bad from your side if we don't discuss it ahead of time, so I won't try it unless you'll tell me you're OK with a secret surprise move that'll benefit us both. (If you can guess what I'm talking about, that's probably it, at least in part.) For what it's worth, I'm cool with surprise moves on your part, no need to run them by me if you don't need specific coordination.

      Daumantas: do relinquish Ion to us - I know what I'm doing, if you know what I mean. Play a hard defense and don't give up hope, I'm relying on you to be the pest you can be.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n We're in solid endgame here, with three real possible ends in sight: a three way French-English-Russian draw, a Russian Solo, or an English solo. I find any other outcome highly unlikely.

      The perils surrounding a tie are the continued survival of Paul and Daumantas, and the risk of a solo by either of the major powers on the board.

      I do not believe that I can solo with the current unit positions; supposing Russia were to capture all of Turkey and the Balkans, that leaves me with 13 units; a strike on Venice is likely, but even possession of say, all the Italian centers leaves me with 16, and my fleetless strategy renders me impotent in striking at Tunis; the Piedmont line is fairly defensible, and St. Petersburg is impregnable. The weak link here is the Mun/Ber line; if France and England hold this, there is no real threat of a Russian solo.

      The English solo, on the other hand, is a much more viable possibility- a likely stab for Eero would net him Brest, Portugal, and perhaps Munich, for 14 centers, and put Paris, Spain, or Tunis in striking distance. Eero's sheer freedom to act here is impressive, with all of the aforementioned centers, as well as the Italian peninsula, and possibly Russian home centers.
      I think it would be in Eero's interest to prove he's not aiming for a solo by voluntarily ceding some ground to France and actually aiming for a disband, to get rid of some armies camped out in the German line, and focus on a fleet based defense of Germany, which cannot be countered by the Russian units, but is less of a threat to the French.

      Really, the three of us should be coordinating at this point; the issue of which great power will fall has been decided (as will be implemented this year).
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Interesting times.

      I'm not in any position to negotiate with anyone, but I can say two things:

      First, Daumantas, as far as I'm concerned keeping Turkey alive is a good thing for me, so if you can allow me to regain a few units, I'm not unlikely to put them to use in your favour.

      Second, I would by far prefer to see France and England move into Venice and allow me to reclaim Naples, since I can do nothing about Venice. I would be willing to build an army, if that makes you all feel safer, should I indeed be allowed to reclaim Naples.

      Italy will be a happy ally to just about anyone at this point, so offers of any kind are welcome, and will be very happily considered, of course.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul: I'll let you into Tunis in 1917 if Mel's cool with the moves I suggested above, and if we can make them work. Meanwhile, hang in there; I think that the Italo-Turkish relations are likely to only improve as the Turkish maritime empire crumbles. We're going towards a new age of peace and prosperity here.
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: WillowIf you build in Marseilles, I might see us having cooperation in regards to Venice and Rome.
      \nWillow,
      I look forward to such cooperation in vicinity of the Tyrol and Northern Italy, now that the unpleasantness regarding Munich is settled.
      I agree with your assessment of this final stage and intend no distraction from your task to the south.
      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero,
      Rather than respond order-by-order to your proposal, let me say that France will support continued English efforts towards the east while making very conservative plans of our own. Any surprises would be unpleasant. The French builds of the past year were explicitly to signal the lack of any hidden designs for a move against England while allowing for the defense of Portugal, Spain, and Brest. If you wish to surprise Turkey, Russia, or Italy; be my guest. We French do not like surprises. It either means bad news or a birthday.

      If Daumantas is serious about supporting continued English expansion then you may as well make an effort to the Ionian and Naples this season. I will certainly be willing to trade Tunis in the future for Naples, once Rome's security is assured. I would like to divest of Tunis, since I cannot afford the units to defend it in light of your naval superiority.

      I would like to begin seeing some English naval movement away from the MAO and English Channel. As I mentioned, a large portion of French strength will be devoted to rear areas so long as English capabilities for occupation of those areas exist--regardless of intent.
      Mel
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: DWeird Lessons learned:
      \nDaumantas,
      It's not over 'til it's over, and you likely will have the chance to apply lessons learned in the remainder of this game as well as others. I appreciate you making note of them as it gives us all things to ponder.\n
      Posted By: DWeird
      You can't make someone your ally if they don't want to - don't think I could have done anything more to prove my good intentions to Russia, and now we have this.
      \nThat's probably true, But Russia wasn't necessarily looking to be convinced, considering that the game started with a Russian attack on Turkey. Plus, Turkish signaling had to be weighed against the reality of Franco-English cooperation and the western message that the first of the eastern powers to defect from the Juggernaut would wind up with an advantage, if not a position in the draw. You will recall, no doubt, that this is a very similar message England sent to France and Germany during the period of Franco-German harmony. \n
      Posted By: DWeird
      Second, you *can* make someone begrudgingly acquisce to your demands as long as you hold them by the throat, which is apparently the state that Russia has been during all this time.
      \nTrue enough. And largely the position of France. Although France would be willing to die first! I have much less invested in the game than Willow does.\n
      Posted By: DWeird
      Third, never, ever eliminate the possibility of a backup plan.
      \nI'm not sure what this means. Certainly always have a plan B, and also recognize that plans, alliances, emotions, everything can change from one turn to the next. Nothing is permanent.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul,
      I'm glad to see you have not responded to England's offer of Tunis, although I am sure we could work something out in exchange for Rome.
      Failing that, considering Daumantas' promise to aid English expansion, your likely most successful courses of action hinge on working with England to liberate Naples. Worst case, a move from Rome to Naples in the Spring leads to Turkish occupation of Rome, while Russia takes Venice. Naples would then have to return to Rome with English assistance--while England obtains Naples--or vice versa. Best case, Venice holds with Apulia support, leaving you with Rome and Naples at year's end.
      So don't focus on an offer of Tunis later--focus on what's possible now. Even if you trade Rome for Naples, the net loss is to Turkey.
      Mel
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenI'll let you into Tunis in 1917

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n OK Mel, but let's take the Ionian Sea, at least; it's pretty much the only way for us to progress anywhere in the Mediterranean area, after all. I'll attack, you support, if you're more comfortable with that.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Mel White
      Posted By: DWeird
      Third, never, ever eliminate the possibility of a backup plan.
      \nI'm not sure what this means. Certainly always have a plan B, and also recognize that plans, alliances, emotions, everything can change from one turn to the next. Nothing is permanent.

      Basically, I had two options - hold my forces, including the BLA fleet at Russia's borders and entangle both of our troops there, which would have very likely have lead to Russia being overrun... Or keep those troops there and stab Russia if I see things going south. I've decided to go all in - mostly because I thought that, if I would keep the forces there, I'd essentially guarantee that Russia *would* be overrun, and that England would thus get a good chance of a solo.

      Sitting on the fence would have been more effective here, and possibly is in a vast majority of situations (i.e., if an ally can't survive an onslaught *and* commit the units to guarantee your mutual security, you're probably stuck in an alliance with someone who is dangerously hurting for extra SCs, and can thus be painfully opportunistic once your back is turned).

      Oh, and another lessoned learned!

      As Turkey, never ever leave BLA once you've gotten into it.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdAs Turkey, never ever leave BLA once you've gotten into it.
      \nQuoted for truth.

      This turn went pretty nicely. My own operations up north were minor, mostly just a bit of friendly harassment to keep everybody honest and Russian thoughts away from soloing; meanwhile, the massive slavic uprising in Anatolia and the Balkans threatens to extinguish the proud Ottoman heritage altogether - hang in there, Sultan! You're surely my most faithful ally.

      Nice plays, Mel. For a follow-up, consider claiming either Tyrolia or Tuscany; the latter might be nice for influence in Venice and Rome, and it'd be a forced success with aid from GoL and/or Tyr. Aside from that, one might speculate about proceeding east of Munich, but if you don't feel like helping me keep the Czarinna humble, no big deal. I'm mostly worried about the prodigious number of builds she's going to be swinging around in a year or two.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n As the spoiler in this drama I am fairly happy with a near balance between England and Russia in terms of forces in play. Large Russian builds are moot if there is no where to build--except Sevastopol.
      I appreciate the English--and Russian--movements that have reduced the possibility of miscalculation with regards to French holdings.
      Turkey's retreat from the Ionian is the next act in the play. Retreating to Greece or Eastern Med complicates Russian plans for expansion and could mean the difference between one more Russian conquest. Retreating to Naples delays the Franco-English movement east in order to liberate the city from Turkish rule but is unlikely to actually hold the city.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eh, I have full confidence that the Sultan, who happens to be a close personal friend, will retreat east to cause maximum discomfort to his sworn enemy. Naples is by right an Italian SC, after all, not a Turkish one, so it doesn't make sense to insist on the honor of the flag when it comes to the Turkish retreat from thence.
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n Eero, do you disagree with my assessment that you have a chance of soloing, and I do not?

      If no, and you genuinely think I could realistically hit 18 centers, could you please line out a plan whereby I can gain a solo victory?

      If yes, please get your units out of my territory, and assist me in the speedy destruction of Turkey- anything else should be interpreted as your own overtures for a solo.

      -Willow
