      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: WillowI'm willing to support Peidmont-Venice
      \nAnd I'm willing to accept it.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Global tensions are high and rising even in the face of Turkey's waning strength as the remaining powers recognize England's geo-political dominance. Intelligence services struggle to find clear signals of England's initiation of the final phase of a plan for European hegemony. Even now, Moscow or Warsaw lie at risk to English occupation if the Russian defenders cannot successfully identify England's main effort--if the attack comes. The question is, will it? England has pulled off some high risk maneuvers so far in this long war; a successful attack on a key Russian supply center now could unhinge the complete Russian defenses. The risk to England is that, successful or not, the attack on Russia once again forces a Russo-Turkish arrangement to work together. Most analysts concede that this risk is very low. The Sultan has made clear he has no intentions of cooperating with the Czarina ever again. Plus, with English fleets in the Mediterranean in good strength, Turkey would face a difficult test of its own. The second risk England faces with an attack on Russia is that such an attack would strengthen Franco-Russian relations. England's freedom of action to maneuver against Russia is partly due to cooperation with France. France would certainly act in its own best interests to prevent a sole power from European dominance--assuming France could do so. The implication for England is that the final phase for dominance would likely have to be executed simultaneously against France and Russia, counting on surprise and momentum to carry the offensive through to complete success. Even now, England could strip Portugal, Tunis, Munich and Spain from an unwary France. Added to either Warsaw or Moscow, and England's domination would be near complete. Although French operations have been described as slow or tardy, it is this reality that forces the French general staff to continually look over their shoulders.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I like Pie-Ven, too, if Russia's in favor. Not that I have votes in the Venetian Republic like you guys. There is a slim chance that Russia would find it favourable to ensure Pie-Ven without any intent to support it (either to set up for taking the place himself as Turkey loses interest in defending the impossible position, or because she wants to see a cut for possible support against Trieste), though, but that's pretty much pure tactics, and may be evaluated by everybody easily enough for themselves, especially as I'm a bit concerned with the real world at the moment.

      Also, don't worry overmuch about your tardiness, Mel - I'm not overly concerned at this stage of the game, as both the Russians and the Turk seem relatively cowed. A couple of turns back it was an open question whether they might mount a spirited attack west; especially Turkey was in position to genuinely dominate the western Med. As things stand I'm not nearly as worried, especially if you really do get into Venice. The main concern at this point is that there is a very small defensive position in the southern Turkish holdings that is impossible to take without fleet support, which means that we can't entirely stop operating in the area, no matter how clear the situation, unless Turkey outright gives up and suicides.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero Tuovinenhe main concern at this point is that there is a very small defensive position in the southern Turkish holdings that is impossible to take without fleet support, which means that we can't entirely stop operating in the area, no matter how clear the situation, unless Turkey outright gives up and suicides.
      \nCan you explain this, Eero?

      It seems to me that those fleets won't be able to hold more than one or two SCs, at which point, if the war goes against Turkey, one or two of them will have to disband. Is there some way they can successfully form a stable defensive position?
      \n

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

    \n
    \xab1\u202613141516171819\xbb

    Comments

      \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Good luck, Daumantas! I'm sorry to see you under the knife.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nMel_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The need now is clear for a Grand Alliance against England, lest we all are defeated piecemeal. This Alliance will require Italian and Turkish fleets, and peace between Russia and Turkey. Without those fundamental elements, defeat is preordained.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nNow now Mel, let's not be alarmist. The English crown is, and has always been, a friend to small animals; both Italian and Turkish nations have their best shot at liberty in playing hardball, looking out for number one and establishing themselves on their own national soil while the larger Powers fight for the balance of Powers in Europe. After all, it's not the small 2-SC Power that is at fault if Europe slides into a hegemony, they have plenty of problems on their own. Better for Turkey and Italy to negotiate hard, establish viable states for themselves once more and hope that the large Powers with actual strength to spare deal with their problems. If they do, then Italy and Turkey are once more in the game, and if they don't, then the loss is not any greater for the small Powers doomed to lose anyway. Neither Paul nor Daumantas can claim that I'd have ever had any sort of ambitions towards their presence on the board, after all.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Out of academic interest, and because it's really fun to be a small Power in a situation like this, let's see what I'd do in their stead...

      Italy: the price of Italian cooperation would have to be Venice, of course; France disbands in Venice and leaves the place empty. Italy builds an army, claims Venice and the Ionian Sea next year. After that a fleet build and Greece; the second fleet deigns to move west. The first fleet holds in Greece indefinitely as a bulwark against further imperial ambitions, while the Venice army supports the Grand Alliance. Italy amasses fleets to take Tunis and southern France. The outcome is that should the Hegemony be averted, Italy will have a viable small Power with its defensive linchpins in Venice, Greece and Tunis in place, and a real option at expanding west. I wouldn't push any further east as Italy here, as Russia needs to be able to not worry about it. France dies in the crossfire, but that's not Italy's problem.

      Turkey: the premise in Turkey would be more difficult; nothing more or less than a total Russian retreat from Anatolia and Bulgaria. I rather doubt that Russia will go for this, but as the alternative is to suffer an absolutely crippling raider presence on the Balkans, it might be worthwhile at least temporarily - and of course I would do my best to convince Russia that it is, were I the Turk. Either way, Turkey has to keep the armies, I expect, as it'd be too easy for Russia to go back on her word without them. In the spring Turkey would basically start moving his own forces towards Anatolia while Russia races north. Greece falls to Italy, most likely, but that doesn't matter as the Turkish armies end the year in Serbia and Bulgaria (or perhaps Budapest and Greece or something like that if Russia tries to betray Turkey). Second year will end in Bulgaria and Constantinople, and only after the third year will Turkey be able to build. The Turkish location does not allow him to project force against the Hegemony, so it might be that the Turk would have to accept that Russia only gives him his home SCs in Anatolia and retains Bulgaria; Turkey wouldn't have any prospects for advance, except perhaps by keeping Greece after all (I wouldn't accept that as Italy, but whatever), as his job in the Alliance would mostly consist of sitting tight and not bothering Russia. The key to long-term survival for Turkey in this situation would basically be to wait and see and stab Russia at the perfect moment: not too soon to swing the war for the Hegemony, but not so late that the threat of Hegemony has completely passed. (If Turkey leaves it too late, Russia can just turn and crush him; likewise if England has already given up on the solo at that point.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Thinking about any kind of Grand Alliance:\n
      Posted By: Eero Tuovinenthe price of Italian cooperation would have to be Venice, of course; France disbands in Venice and leaves the place empty.
      \nEero beat me to it!

      My cooperation requires the return of my duly deserved territories. Italy needs Italy back.

      Willow, I'd be happy with an agreement of peace with you, on the other hand. We can both accomplish more at this point if we don't have to worry about each other for the next little while.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul-

      Done, of course.

      Mel-

      Tyrolia ought to order S Bohemia-Munich; Eero can't defend against the move. (The alternative is supporting Tyrolia-Munich, to get another unit in the theater, but I think you'll need the center more than I will)

      I would also disband Tuscany- you'll need every unit to defend your home centers.

      Daumantas-

      The price of Russian cooperation, and your continued survival, is the disbandment of your A Trieste. Keep two fleets and send them west, and you stay in the game.

      Everyone-

      England 15
      Russia 10
      France 5
      Italy &Turkey: 2 each

      Eero needs three more centers to win, likely targets are Moscow, Brest, Spain and Marseilles, with the Italian centers, Paris, and maybe Greece as secondary targets.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow -

      Hah!

      As is, I am interested less in my continued survival and more in total obliteration of Russia, which, sadly enough, means supporting another power to a solo.

      If you want *my* cooperation for *your* continued survival, how about you give me a deal that doesn't involve me giving up my only bargaining chip and then sending out my fleets away from my SCs to stop a rival power for you while you pick them off as soon as the threat is passed?

      I'd accept nothing more than a full and immediate retreat from the turkish homeland and the Balkans - the composition of my forces is weak enough that you'll be able to pick up the formerly austrian areas as I make way for Turkey right back up, and I really can't ask for anything less and still expect to be able to live to the endgame.

      The alternative? You go into offensive against me and swat my little army around until it ends up near an english one. You probably don't want that to happen.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I have to say that I concur in full with Daumantas, although I wouldn't personally claim to be only playing for revenge, even as a diplomatic tactic - but that's my scruples speaking. The only leverage Turkey has here is the power to raid the Balkans and tie up incommensurate numbers of Russian troops unless Russia gives him a deal; giving up that leverage for promises at this late stage is not a working deal.

      On the other hand, Russia needs to be able to believe that Turkey can be worked with, and that depends on whether the Sultan is willing to still go for victory over revenge. To me it seems that the demand Daumantas made is not berserk-crazy although it might seem snide on the outside: he's not saying that he wants Russia to relinquish the entire Balkans, but only that he wants demilitarization in the area. I have no doubt that Turkey will try something at some point, but it's in his own best interest to not tax the Russian economy too much by expanding greedily while Russia sets up lines against the Hegemony. In this regard I find him pretty reasonable: indeed, Russia should move all forces quickly north and leave the Balkans and Anatolia to Turkey, trusting that the Turk won't take more than he needs off the bounty!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Heh, like I could possibly take more than I need with two units and no chance to build!

      S'not revenge. I don't have anything against Russia or Willow personally - just making good on my earlier threat. Given that my eventual survival seems rather questionable, the only choice I get is between supporting two versions of an endgame - one in which a power that attacked me after I outlined quite clearly why that is a bad idea takes part, and one in which it doesn't. It's not that much of a choice, but it's there!

      All Russia has to do to change my chosen course of action is give me a good chance to survive until the endgame. Doesn't have to be surefire - nobody can guarantee that, I know. It does, however, have to be the best that Russia can do for Turkey. Can't be that hard, can it?

      In short - if I see a good deal, I'll take it and keep to it. Otherwise, enjoy death by englishman!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n All that makes sense to me, Daumantas; that's how I'd play your sort of position. It was a rather important revelation for me when I first realized (around 2002 or so, perhaps?) that a minority position in Diplomacy should be played by pressuring the other Powers against the threat of a soloist; so far I'd believed that the game's end-game for minority Powers is faulty because there's nothing to do there but to submit orders and wait for death. It'll be interesting to see how Willow calls this.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas's stated objectives are exactly why any cooperation must be based on disarmament in the Balkans- until a defensive line is established, his raider unit must be treated as hostile.

      The fleets are not a threat, and I have no real power to build with half my home centers occupied and the other half forming my front lines- I have no reason to take the rest of Daumantas's centers unless it is to eliminate the uncertainty his units create.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n You know, that's not a bad argument, either. Technically speaking Russia might as well allow Turkey to stay on with the fleets if the fleets prove even marginally useful, as Russia would find it difficult to make use of the SCs herself.

      However, how would the Turkish position develop in the future? Assuming that the Grand Alliance succeeds, wouldn't the logical consequence be a quick death to Turkey and Italy anyway? Turkey with its fleets away and home SCs in foreign hands seems helpless to prevent this, unlike a Turkey that insists on a viable defensive position as the first requirement of cooperation.

      Not really my business, I know, but I'm rather enamored of Diplomacy end-game strategy. Should write a book about it or something, I guess.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Can't really make the "that army is oh so threatening to me!" argument when you outnumber me four and a half to one, really!

      Turkey will have to see a gesture of good will, no, scratch that, actual good will, before it does the same to Russia.

      I'm not one to wreck my own chances of survival once there are any, so once I see those coming from Russia, you can expect me to quietly scurry about my business, interfering with the Russian war in no way.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm with Daumantas.

      Us "We're not dead yet!" powers have fairly little motivation to join a Grand Alliance when it seems we're unlikely to live long.

      On the other hand, we would consider signing up for any larger strategy if it seemed to increase our odds of establishing a significant one position for either of us. One strong enough that it had a chance of surviving until a potential draw.

      So, as I see it (looking at it with first-time player glasses), we're in a kind of funny position. The would-be partners in a draw (particularly France and Russia) would probably rather just see us gone, but can they afford to take the time to wipe us out? They risk a solo victory, in that case. So simply wiping us out is a risky venture, as it gives the initiative of the war to England.

      The ideal situation, of course, would be to convince us of the need for a Grand Alliance and hope we meekly do the bidding of the bigger powers. But that relies on a lot of naivete on our part, as far as I can see.

      Convincing us both to get on-board with a Grand Alliance, more realistically, requires some fairly convincing argument for our continued survival (what happens if the board returns to a likely three-way draw state? How can the smaller powers regain enough strength to have a fighting chance under those conditions?). I suppose that would require Italian and Turkish gains at the same rate as those new units support existing Russian and French armies (so effectively some fraction of French and Russian troops at the front becomes replaced with Italian and/or Turkish mercenaries).

      I'd love to hear what Mel and Willow are thinking right now, and what their options are. Since Eero is likely more interested in keeping us alive than not (more chances for something to get screwed up, this way, especially with open diplomacy), Turkey is probably much easier to simply (and quickly) dismantle than Italy, but that could change if Eero suddenly abandons the Mediterranean.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n Daumantas,

      I'm rather confused by your choice of disbands. Intentional strategy, or did you NMR during the Build phase?

      I was half-thinking of moving into the Ionian to help you into Greece in the Fall, but since I'd be stopping you from doing the same thing, it doesn't seem like it would actually give you any more of a fighting chance.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n It's probably a NMR, considering how easy it makes the choice of shutting Turkey down for the Russians; just hold in Anatolia for the year while claiming Trieste and Greece, and it's done. On the moral front, of course, one might argue that the Turk did exactly what the Russians requested, and therefore the Russian should leave the Turk alive to use his fleets against England like she promised - now we'll get to see the true depth of the Russian moral pretensions!

      You could still try for Greece with two units, although it's likely not going to go so well. Perhaps success is more likely for Italy in negotiating with Russia for access to Greece and maybe even Trieste next year; Russia might go for it due to her limited ability to use the builds herself, and it'd go a long way towards improving Italy's chances of sneaking into the draw. I would, of course, personally hope that our friends in Italy would use any such special opportunity to grow into a true contender responsibly.
      \n

      Think about Belgium- it may be worth it to pondering moving there- it makes the attack on Munich uncertain, but if Eero's uncertain about where he can land his London army, so much the better.

      \n Ayup! Keeping track of a game after you're decidedly losing is hard.

      Ah well! Best try and do best with the hand I've... dealt myself.

      Where do you want my fleets, Willow?


      Good will's appreciated, by the way, Paul!

      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Now now, Daumantas. How you play a losing position is the measure of the man in any game. Besides, there's plenty of excitement in a minority position in Diplomacy, as you can set yourself up as a pivot between the camps and thus have almost as much say about the outcome as anybody else. "Ride the tiger", as I memorably characterized this a few games back; force the game to the brink of mutual loss by cooperating with the solo candidate and then negotiate concessions from the other losers in exchange for your help in stopping that solo.

      Of course this is much trickier if you don't have any leverage on the board . I have great hopes of Paul in this regard, though, as Italy is extremely defensible with even just two armies against a continental assault, making him pretty secure against the enroaching Russian. I could see how this game could end as a ERI draw, should Mel not get proactive about getting me off his back soon.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n True enough. I certainly didn't expect to still be alive by this point.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, an interesting set of moves, but nothing too unpredictable. I guessed Eero would try to force a disband of Mel's fleet in NAf, but it's a little far from home to be able to leverage any immediate gains out of the situation.

      Two surprises, though:

      One is that Turkey is still in the running! This reminds me of the other game I'm involved in: it seems mercy has prevailed in Willow's mind.

      Two is the cock-up in Silesia. I'm looking forward to an explanation of that one! (If one is forthcoming, that is.)

      Italy's future concerns:

      In order to help Mel hold up a defense, I may move Venice -> Trieste in the Fall. I do not particularly want to see Turkey destroyed, but taking Venice from Mel by staying in place might be too hard of a blow for France, risking a premature English victory. Yet another disband could be crippling. Daumantas (and/or Willow), would you hold it against me if I did so?

      (Edit: D, if you let me into the Ionian, I'd be very happy to support you into Greece. You may have a chance at taking Smyrna or Bulgaria this Fall, so not all hope it lost, but it's a tough situation no matter what. Let me know what you think.)

      It seems that either way I'm taking territory from a potential ally, so it'll be a difficult choice to make. But I don't think it's in Russia's interests to weaken France, either.
      \n

      Paul--No one will mind your continued move to Trieste--go right ahead.
      Mel

      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nAsk, and ye shall receive.

      As for the Venetian situation and the whole Italian affair, it seems to me that it'd be utterly simple for Russia to outright allow Turkey to take another SC to compensate for the loss of Trieste - Smyrna, say. This way Italy could have Trieste and France could keep Venice. However, more than Venice, I'm concerned about the clearly belligerent messages that are issuing from my most traditional ally in Italy - Paul, surely you will not be raising your hand against me when we've lived in peace for so long? You should remember in gratitude how my maneuverings against your enemies pulled you from the brink and preserved your life against utmost hazards, and then when you lied low I refused to take advantage. Shame on the warmonger, shame on the faithless friend! Besides, as things stand you'll need to build another army and claim the Pie-Ven-Tri-Tyr defensive zone out of purely selfish reasons if you're to surpass the French in feasibility as an end-game Power, and therefore win your place in the draw; this is no time for you to start messing in international politics.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero,

      I have every faith and all due respect in England and the wisdom of the Imperial Crown. Italy owes much to England, who has always championed Italy's cause on the international floor. Italy is most certainly not anti-English!

      France has also been a longstanding ally, and Italy is keen to preserve that bond as well. I have no desire at this time to send France to her death.

      I don't really see any contradiction: should I choose not to take Venice, I don't see how that is likely to cause any kind of terrible defeat for our English allies.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas,

      I'd be to happy to support you into Greece next Spring, if you like that idea.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul-

      I have no objections to you taking Trieste; I would object to you staying there.

      Mel-

      I've got my Tyr unit penciled in supporting you into Munich. (Boh-Mun, please) It's a perfect attack, and we've got to get you more centers. Unfortunately, you've got to decide if you're going to defend Brest or Spain with A Gas.

      -Willow
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n ...add Marseilles to that list!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n You know, Paul, it occurs to me that it's not a given that taking away Trieste from the Sultan is the best material strategy for you and the Grand Alliance. Have you considered that allowing him to keep his fleet might be more useful than the most useless French unit currently on the map?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Sadly for Daumantas, France is where Eero's solo is going to be fought, and won or lost.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: Eero TuovinenHave you considered that allowing him to keep his fleet might be more useful than the most useless French unit currently on the m
      \nThat's not a bad point. However, the question is: "How many other losses will France incur this Fall?" If, say, two other SCs are lost (which is possible), then it seems to me that taking Venice from France could pretty much guarantee a solo victory for England.

      I may end up rolling a die, as Bill always used to suggest.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nFebruary 2011 \n edited February 2011
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n On a side-note entirely:\n
      Posted By: Paul T.Incidentally, I'll be curious to hear afterwards everyone's thoughts on the open diplomacy environment. As far as I can see, most if not all the players have shown a high level of tactical skill. Is it telling, then, that it is the corner powers (particularly England and Turkey) that have been most successful? (Russia and France have both had rough periods, but still always remained viable.) After all, the success of "corner powers" is much less dependent on
      negotiation and diplomacy than that of the central powers: Germany, Italy, and Austria all floundered quite early in the proceedings.
      \nI'm still curious to chat about this sometime. Have Having played the entire game dependent on cooperation with my neighbours, and now having for several years only really been responsible for my own troop movements has made a huge difference. Being able to simply make a strategy and turn in orders is incredibly relaxing in comparison with the negotiations out in the open (which you know your opponents are reading), and I suspect that playing a corner power is more like the former.

      (Even when certain doom is approaching, at least you know that all you can do is to try to sway others and plug in your moves. But when all your moves are dependent on cooperation and planning... man, that's awkward and stressful in this style of play.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Paul-

      Seeing as how Daumantas is true to his word, and only seems interested in attacking me, how about you bring your army down the coast through Albania to Greece and pick up his last center? I suppose I could take it myself, but I think it would be better put to use in your hands.

      Mel-

      Don't give up! I'll be ordering a support of Munich. Hang in there!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      Posted By: DWeirdPsh. I'm not attacking you - I'm taking my home centers back. It just so happens that that's where your armies are, is all.
      \nHa!

      In my other game, Austria offered a tentative peace agreement to me. His first condition, however, was that I (as Turkey) do not attack Austria. I thought this was pretty funny, since at that moment my only remaining units were in Smyrna and Ankara, and there was an Austrian army in Constantinople. What exactly did he expect me to do?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n

      \n

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n

      Paul-

      I'll support you into Greece to make sure you get it. Be vigilant against the encroaching orange tide!

      Mel-

      Once again, I'll order a support for Munich. Defend Paris, please.

      -Willow

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Daumantas,

      Things look bad for you, my friend. But I don't want to see you out of the game just yet, and I could use your support in case Eero's trying to pull something.

      How about we exchange Greece for Naples, and then act effectively as one country? If things change elsewhere and Russian troops retreat, you'd still be close enough to run back home and grab some territory...
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n

      \n

      Naples is all yours.

      \n Hah!

      That sounds like an easy bounce followed by Turkey being wiped off the map, but hell, I'm in no state to not accept charity!

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n Oh, ye of little faith...

      • \n
    • \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The liberation of Warsaw was a major victory for Russia in the East.

      Eero is now at 16 centers, just two away from a victory, with Paris and Munich the most likely targets, but he'll have to fight to get them.
      I climb to 11, but sadly, have no way of building a unit.
      Mel's heroic stand is composed of 3 centers.
      Paul's clever regime remains at 3.
      Daumantas clings on to life at 1 center.

      If Paul and Daumantas must collaborate to block any English gains in the Mediteranean- it's key to prevent Eero from getting an advance on Rome or Naples. The Tyrhenian and the Ionian are the keys to this- the best move is probably for Paul to attack both, and Daumantas to support one of those moves at random.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Willow,\n
      Posted By: WillowMel's heroic stand is composed of 3 centers.
      \nUh, note that Mel actually has 4 Centres, just no way to build a fourth army! That's because he's holding Venice--which, note, is a potential target for Eero. Army Tyrolia might consider remaining in place to cover this.

      By the same line of reasoning, Syria -> Smyrna in the Spring would allow you to self-bounce in Constantinople in the Fall.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Nope. Mel has Paris, Munich, Venice, and that's it.

      Indeed, maybe Greece should move to Albania- to cover Trieste, and should Eero move Greece, we can order S Alb-Gre (and an attack on the Ionian, if applicable) to retake the center.

      -Willow
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n

      \n

      \n\nWillow \n\n\n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Mel-

      Would you prefer to have me order Pie-Mar or Pie S Bur-Mar? The former is my go-to order, but the later actually has a fair chance of succeeding as an attack (Eero's likely to issue Bel-Bur; I know I would). He can't stop the attack without the use of GoL, which he needs for leverage on the Tyrhenian.

      -Willow

      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n

      \n\nMarch 2011 \n

      \n
      \n
      Posted By: WillowNope. Mel has Paris, Munich, Venice, and that's it.
      \nUh, duh. Don't know what I was thinking there.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, things are looking pretty good for England for the coming year, at least as far as I can see. There are a few things Russia and France can try to pull, but the odds are slim. There are quite a few effective attacks Eero can make, and Mel and Willow are going to have work hard to maintain their position.

      What your current thoughts about this situation? Are you all busy with other things, or is the radio silence lately merely an indicator of tactical minds hard at work back at headquarters?\n
      Posted By: WillowThe Tyrhenian and the Ionian are the keys to this- the best move is probably for Paul to attack both, and Daumantas to support one of those moves at random.
      \nThis is a good suggestion. Daumantas, what do you think?

      Another alternative is that I order Apulia S Naples -> Ion, and Rome -> Tyr. Then you choose whether you will support F Rome or attack the Ionian. It's a weaker alternative in some ways, but makes defense of Venice in the Fall easier if F Ionian decides to slip in there.

      Of course, having to arrange all this out in the open is more than a little problematic. Daumantas, I'll go with Willow's plan unless I hear otherwise from you.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I'm mainly keeping silent because there's not much to say at this point. The situation should change in a year or two, I'm confident.

      It's certainly true that the Alliance is hard-pressed to coordinate a truly effective defense in a public environment.
      \n

    [Diplomacy] Story Games League, Game 6

      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n This game i done, after the latest upset turn England can force a solo victory by seizing Munich and Paris. Good game, I had to stretch quite a bit near the end. Let's do some breakdowns of the last few years soon; I'm travelling at the moment, but next week will provide a statement.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Hmmm. Well, the gig may be up now (or almost up, anyway).

      I'd been really hoping to see a liberation of St. Petersburg this year (via Mos -> Liv in the Spring), but of course didn't want to say it out loud. A shame!
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Retreats:

      Indeed, my hunch was correct, it seems. We would have been better off having Daumantas attack the Ionian. Hard to do when your allies don't respond to the conversation, though...
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n For what it's worth, the truly fundamental tactical issue was whether you'd let me enter the Ionian in the first place. There is a very viable stalemate line that runs from Ion-Nap-Rom onwards that I would've found impossible to break had you prioritized holding it and brought an army or two from mainland to support the effort. Letting me into Ionian meant that I could retreat east, and the true meaning of that is not really in random raids but rather in being able to break the Ionian stalemate line at will. I could always stop the Alliance at Tunis, and while I have a fleet east of the Ionian, I could also wage effective war for the Italian SCs.

      In practice all this proved to be of secondary importance of course, as I succeeded in taking Munich; I had two reeds in the wind in this regard, as either taking Munich or getting a fleet east of Ion and slowly grinding an SC from Italy were both viable courses of action for me. This particular outcome was much quicker, though. I would only have lost this end-game if I'd both lost Munich and gotten stalemated in the Mediterranean - both very possible outcomes a few turns back, certainly.

      Also, somebody post the moves for the audience.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Eero,

      It also seems to me that Russia had a shot at St. Petersburg just now, however (not anymore, that opportunity is gone, clearly). Is that not so?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, a bit of a shot, yes. I chose to push my chances there just a bit instead of bunkering down completely because it seemed to me that Willow was rather completely engrossed by the positioning struggle around Munich. Had she tried for Livonia instead, she could have done some potentially serious damage to my lines. In hindsight I probably shouldn't have pushed my luck in this way, but I wanted to win the fight for Munich and needed Livonia to participate in that. A more careful play would have been to simply defend Livonia in place and let Munich work out as it would; I would still have had my Mediterranean position, after all.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nPaul_T \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Thanks for sharing, Eero. I'll be looking forward to hearing some more of your thoughts on this game.

      As I've been trying to learn more about this game, I've been writing out orders for England and Russia (and sometimes France) for the last couple of years. Usually, I guessed pretty close, or sometimes you, Willow, and/or Mel came up with better options than I had considered. But for the Spring of 1919, my scratch pad says "Moscow to Livonia, Warsaw supports; Sevastopol to Moscow, Ukraine supports", and I was surprised not to see it happen. Given your orders for the same year, it looks like it would have cost you St. Petersburg.

      It's funny how tactically this game comes down to a lot of guessing and double-guessing!

      It's been a lot of fun for me to be a part of this: this being my first game to come to an end (the other one is still very much ongoing, just approaching 1914). Thank you all for inviting me to join in, and for all the very helpful advice and guidance (particularly Bill, whose demise I inadvertently hastened--I wonder if he got all me secret messages?).
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n It's all over but the crying now.

      Here's a turn by turn recap for me, as Russia:

      1901: My opening was my biggest mistake of the game, hands down. (Bigger than my many misorders, or the failure to outguess him at the very end.) My intent was to sneakily attack the Black Sea from the side: order Arm-Bla, Mos-Rum, Ukr S Mos-Rum in the fall, with Daumantas having to scramble and order Bla-Ank and Con-Smy to cover his centers. This opening was chosen more for its novelty than any utility, and I feel that I outsmarted myself here- the move to Arm by Daumantas was such an obvious counter, and I'm not sure that the fall moves would even have played out my way if he hadn't ordered it.
      Well, that shows why the Armenian attack is not a standard opening in the Diplomacy lexicon.

      My second choice of openings, a rather standard Two North, Two South opening, Stp-GoB, Mos-Stp, War-Ukr, Sev-BLA would have netted me Rumania and Sweden and kept Eero out of Norway, and even given me a chance at it in '02. The entire landscape of the northern campaign would have been different, and indeed the game- the smallest (or not so smallest) of decisions can have sweeping ramifications. To speculate beyond that is pointless, but I kicked myself over this opening quite frequently.

      Early diplomacy was aimed at courting Germany, vilifying England, and trying to court Italy as a long term partner without being too obvious that I wanted to crush Austria and Turkey between the two of us.

      Fall '01 was frustrating as I realised just how deep of a hole I had dug for myself. Turkey getting two builds, one of them Rumania, is just plain terrible for Russia. The offer of an ersatz Juggernaut, with us moving into the typical positions was genuine.

      The build of a fleet up north was an attempt to regain a North/South strategy, but it was too little too late- Eero's seizing of Brest was a definitive early victory, and I didn't have the resources south to support the campaign.

      1902

      Of course, that was all dependent on German cooperation, and Spring sees him head east. We see bitter fighting over Rumania and Sevastopol (Russia gets an edge in from a timely Austrian attack, but watch out for that Galician unit), and I lose Sweden to Germany

      1903

      Turkey offers me a raw deal; my first instinct is to respond with sarcasm and throw it back in his face; but I decide I see an opportunity to deceive him. Of course, it has to be believable that I would agree to such a deal, and ultimately, it isn't- Daumantas keeps on fighting as I fight him, and makes gains against Austria. Meanwhile I have Germany and England on my back; it's obvious (to me anyways) that England will come to blows with Germany soon, so I try to cut a deal with Germany: Warsaw for support of St. Petersburg, to set up for a stab of England with him on top. Alas, it doesn't happen. I choose to focus my defense on the south, screwing over the person who screwed me the most (that'd be you, Daumantas).

      1904

      This is the year of no movement, since we had an AWOL player.

      1905

      With the fight returned, I manage to hold of the German- fighting defensive wars seems to be what I do best. And then England stabs Germany. If only someone, anyone, had seen that coming.
      Also, we see some grasping for straws: Russia in Vienna, Austria in Berlin, and Germany in Moscow, a giant circle jerk of invasions.

      1906

      Eero's stab of the German- and the German's choice to disband Russian occuping units saves me; I'm able to get back into the game, withdrawing to let Austria and Turkey fight it out while I retake my key home centers. Russia is now right where it was at the start of the game: just my four home centers, though now all occupied with armies. I won't build another fleet for the entire game- I won't need them in the south, and the north, where I want them, is blocked.

      1907

      I eagerly throw myself at Austria and Turkey and accomplish nothing. Would I have been better off keeping Moscow to defend St. Petersburg? I certainly thought about it. I end the year at four centers, but St. Petersburg is essentially lost to me forever. The Bohemian move is interesting because it lets me meddle in German and Austrian affairs, and threaten lots of places.

      1908-1912

      Mostly though, Bohemia ends up being the leverage to move south: first Galicia, then Budapest. Russia and Turkey have a working relationship now, countering Austria and Italy. Both alliances are shaky, with early distrust hindering things, but they are caused by what makes stable alliance in Diplomacy: desperation and need. I needed to work with Turkey because he had his damn boat right next to my home center, (and in some cases, a unit in Armenia).

      This is a period of pretty straightforward play: tactical exercises in cooperation with minimum information exchange. There is also a larger ongoing strategy of encouraging both Turkey and Italy to invest in fleets (the better to oppose each other and not me). The possibility of flipping and siding with Italy remains on the back of my mind, but a situation never truly develops- Daumantas has more to offer me.

      I had many opportunities in here to stab Daumantas, and vice versa. In my case though, it was never worth it. Generally, I could at best make a try for a center or two, but why ruin something good for such little gain?

      The other big thread of these years was the northern defense of Moscow against Eero's St. Pete army- I had not one but two Swords of Damocles hanging above my head (the other of course being the Turkish Black Sea fleet). I used at least one unit every turn protecting my homeland. The biggest scare was the French attack in '11, but France couldn't afford the units.

      1913

      My hope here was a lightning assault on the divided French/English line, to take Munich and Berlin in one turn, and get two builds. With that materiel, I might be able to even get St. Pete back! Sadly, I aim for both and get neither.

      This was also the year of my 'panic stab': seeing Daumantas with three units next to Rumania, I literally panic, and deploy my own unit to Armenia- if I'm getting stabbed, I want to be able to minimize the damage. He doesn't stab me- just makes a defensive move, really, and everything threatens to fall apart.

      1914

      But it doesn't, because ultimately, we don't want it to. I make an overture to Daumantas that's surprisingly honest for diplomacy play- I don't want us to be at war with each other. I don't want to fight a war I don't know I'll win, and the outcome is just too uncertain for both sides. So instead I apologize, plead, and deal, and what do you know? It works.

      Do I pull out of Armenia though? Oh no. Because I'm not stupid.

      1915

      Daumantas and I agree to a mutual diarmament, but it favors me quite a bit more than it does him. So much more in fact, that I see no real reason not to stab him for two centers.

      In Diplomacy, alliances end. They usually end with mutual betrayal, or a one-sided stab. There are two good stabs- one your target forgives as if it never happened, and one your target never recovers from.

      When timing the later, I look for some of the following:
      *If I wait, am I likely to get a better opportunity?
      *If I wait, is my target likely to be able to defend himself?
      *What's the fallout if I do attack?

      In this case, Daumantas had very little strategic support to offer me; the status quo was a EFRT quadrangle; either I or France would need to be eliminated, and I didn't like my odds. Stabbing Daumantas gained me two builds, took two key centers, and he had little ability to effectively respond. Daumantas certainly saw it coming but could not be sure if it would happen or not; going for a bounce and being wrong would have cost him in the battle of the Mediteranean.

      1916

      This year sees me continue to dismantle Daumantas. Relations with France are rough- Eero raised the (frankly ridiculous) specter of a Russian solo to garner French aid; uncertainy rules the day in the center.

      1917

      A snafu over Silesia- if successful, I could have retaken Warsaw a year earlier, and make a more credible attack on St. Petersburg, and prevented Eero from getting enough centers- resulting in probably a EFR or EIR draw.

      1918

      The whole year was intended to set up an attack on Warsaw, by going the direct route- having keep at it in Silesia, I gambled for the direct attack on Warsaw, seeing that Eero's defenses were weak.

      1919

      All but over here. My attack plan for St. Petersburg would have beaten the order set Sil-War, St. P S Liv, Liv S Sil-War, which happens to defeat the theoretical order set posed by Paul. The game comes down to guess and counter-guess, well played by everyone, new and experienced alike.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nA great synopsis, Willow. I have to say that in general I find Russia's game here emblematic of the greatest Diplomacy game that is to be played to a loss; Russia went up and down in the game, got almost killed off, lost all home SCs at least once, but rose to lead the Grand Alliance at the end. A draw was hair's breadth away more than once, and Willow never wavered in victory or defeat - a very moral and uplifting run all around, I find.

      For myself, some notes on the early and middle game:
      • I started the game with a straight anti-French play mostly out of whimsy, as is often the case at the start; the Calhamer board is so well-researched that you can play almost anything as long as you're able to do the necessary diplomacy and understand your long-term goals, and here I had a feel that Daniel, playing France, would be my toughest enemy. This would certainly prove to be the truth: he was an extremely tenacious and properly paranoid opponent after I'd disabused him by the double-betrayal over the first year. My strategic goal in wrassling with France from the start was basically to keep this very strong and unkillable Power weak and divided; I could afford to have a difficult relationship to the south as long as France would be so weak that I could force peace when it suited my needs elsewhere. I do not have much experience playing England compared to the eastern Powers, so I'm pretty gratified by the macro-strategic effects of this low-burn French war.
      • Much of my diplomacy over time was basically about encouraging my neighbours to commit to a fleet-less build strategy, which proved quite possible - I spent the majority of the game in uncontested control of the Atlantic environs, really, and my end-game was very favourable mostly not because of the position I started in, but rather because nobody else had a serious fleet to contest the western Mediterranean against me.
      • I did my best to slow down the progress of the game, meaning that I favoured weaker Powers against the stronger ones and generally did my best to support a stagnated board to offset my own inability to wage quick expansionist wars. The way I relinquished StP in 1905 back to the all but destroyed Russia was emblematic in this regard, as I chose to swing my forces against the then-powerful Germans while Russia gathered strength and kicked back the southern offensive on her soil.
      • My tactics were generally very strategy-oriented and less influenced by diplomacy, I find now that I look back on the early moves. As an example of my thinking, much of my northern strategy, tactics and diplomacy was simply predicated early on on the fact that I'd positioned an army in Finland in the spring of 1902: like a fleet on the Black Sea, an army in Finland is a fulcrum around which fleet movements can happen effectively, and thus my decision to take this position basically entailed the outcome of conquering StP and Sweden. Another similar tactical dictum that becomes strategic in my play here is the way I defended and expanded my marine domination by blockading and then conquering enemy harbors in the north while being relatively rather careful about my southern MAO border; for most of the game a serious French push to NAO and the Nordic area was my biggest concern at all levels of play.
      • When the German stab went through my own position in the draw was basically certain: the next two-thirds of the game was all about maneuvering for a solo victory, for which purpose I would have to finally break France. My play for the last half of the game can basically be interpreted as an extended flanking maneuver that a fleet-based Power needs for choking France; nothing less will do, considering the insane vitality of the French position.
      \nRegarding the other Powers, I found Peter's Germany easy to work with, perhaps due to his relative inexperience; Willow and Daniel were entirely right about how that relationship was going to end up early on, though: it seemed to me that Peter didn't have the constructive tools for encouraging me to stay faithful, which left him with little but waiting for the hammer to fall, especially after he'd committed to a difficult eastern war. Willow and Daniel were in comparison infinitely more difficult; despite the fact that the demise of France loomed big in my plans through the entire game while Russia never was my target, both players managed to be equally challenging as partners, bending to my wishes only when external forces were at their height and forced their hand.

      Daumantas played a very strong game as Turkey, only falling prey to the merciless end-game logic at the very end; I admired many of his moves, although I would have taken Russia to back of the shed in the middle game myself before finishing Austria if at all possible. Paul and Bill as the weak sisters both showed a lot of admirable fighting spirit, so I found it unfortunate that the spirit was so often directed against the other; had they managed to coordinate better (and they probably would have in a closed environment!), I do not doubt that they would have fared much better with the skills they displayed. In general I have to say that the level of table discipline here made me quite happy, it's a rare treat to get to play a game of Diplomacy where nobody quits in the middle and everybody tries their best to the very end.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nEero_Tuovinen \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nThe endgame

      A few words about the end-game are warranted, as it was the longest part of the game, and the part that had the least amount of chaos and random events. This phase of the game basically started from my viewpoint (a privileged viewpoint as it happens) in 1908 or so, when French betrayal of Germany and the Russian western initiatives made it clear that Germany was finished as a viable Power. At the same time the Juggernaut alliance had pretty much finished Austria, meaning that the Balkans would thence not be the core of a Power but rather a battleground of competing interests out of which the eastern contender would rise: I would have to start moving with cunning, for France, Russia and Turkey easily had sufficient strength between them for the purpose of stopping my Hegemony from rising.

      As you all remember, the tact I chose at the time was to browbeat France into a grateful alliance against the east. Russia made this relatively easy for me by acting up very imperially (consider 1912-14 for example, when she operated almost half-dozen armies against German SCs with apparent impunity) and giving strong signals about commitment to the Juggernaut: the more Willow denied my suggestions and demands of anti-Turkish movements, the more obvious it was from the French viewpoint that England would be the natural ally in resisting the forthcoming eastern assault on the west. As I described at the time, the virtual immunity England enjoyed made the situation difficult for France: the only major Power that might expect to get eliminated if the eastern situation developed freely would be France, as Turkey would attack from the south even as England would be able to assist the easterners from the north. In these lights and with the Juggernaut as firm as it was France was left with no options, really.

      My second barb was frankly a lot weaker: my main argument for why the Juggernaut would need to break down before the game's end was that the established Anglo-French alliance would necessarily have at least initial tactical supremacy against the Juggernaut, enabling us to crush Russia as the more exposed partner, which would in turn encourage Turkey to turn on her as the situation became clear. This argument was weaker in that considering the situation circa 1915 we would not in my best judgment been able to do what I threatened; obviously Willow thought otherwise, and I understand that the diplomatic history between Russia and Turkey had been difficult, which was probably why she decided to take a pre-emptive strike against Turkey in the fall of 1915. My third barb was also involved here no doubt: I had been arguing since the Russian assault on German soil in 1913 or so that Russia was a credible soloist, which meant that Turkey would need to help me rein her by stabbing her at the right moment; although the moment in question was not even close once we started cooperating with France, the presence of this argument might have made a Turkish stab on the strong Russia more likely.

      With the power of hindsight we can say that Russia should not have attacked west in the early noughties: the extremely aggressive detaching of forces from the Balkans in 1913 (shown in the picture) that directly led to her short-lived possession of Munich had the direct effect of driving France solidly into my arms; so far my attempts at sneaking and cajoling and outright fighting myself into dominance in France had been slow - I had in fact lost my hope of soloing and was just playing the odds at the time - but the major Russian offensive was such a threatening move that France did not have much choice on the matter: the very best outcome would have been that Russia would have overrun the German area, Turkey would have stabbed Russia to balance the equation and then I'd have finished France off. The worst outcome would have been the admittedly nebulous Russian solo. Had Russia chosen a different tack, such as holding in place or even attacking Turkey with Italy as ally, I doubt I could have overcome France in sufficient time to prevent the east from resolving their affairs and presenting me with a draw accompli.

      However, Russia did attack, and I did get the French alliance that allowed us to turn up the pressure on the Juggernaut: once the Anglo-French alliance had firmed up the Juggernaut was in a difficult position, and I don't think things could have turned out very differently: Russia could have opted to trust Turkey and fight, of course, but I was very comfortable waiting out the slow war: we could slog it out for a while to see if a tactical upset might allow us to take Warsaw, after all, and as France did not have the capability to stab me, the only issue was really whether the Juggernaut would fall to a Turkish stab or a Russian one. A four-way draw would have been a fantastical prospect, of course: had the Juggernaut proven completely impossible to break via force of arms or betrayal I would have been forced to turn on France in the end myself.

      Once Russia turned on Turkey in 1915 the moment of truth for France came up, and I was certain that my good fortune could not continue any longer: once Turkey lost its feasibility as a Power in the Russian stab the correct French play would clearly have been to move to defensive positions against me, thus signalling that France intended to enforce a three-way draw between France, England and Russia. Instead Mel continued to play happily along in our "let's conquer eastern Europe for France" plan; this was not irrational of him in that had one accepted the tactical possibility of a Russian solo, then it would have made sense for me to retain the French alliance as a counter-balance. However, as it happened, the Russian fleet was non-existent and Italy was clinging tenaciously to life, and I had a solid hold on Tunis, which were all points that led me to believe that there was no way for Russia to fight for a solo even if France decided to throw the game her way. Thus my 1916 stabbing France, at which point I really was within reach of a solo victory!

      The last three years were purely tactical play, really, although I did my best to keep the small Powers happy and willing to look after their own well-being: as I said at the time, it's no different losing to a draw coalition or a soloist, so a small Power might as well ensure that the price of their cooperation is a true shot at survival. (In case you're wondering: small Powers become more important instead of less near the end because the forces are nigh inevitably balanced between the soloist and the Alliance: even one or two units basically have the capability to throw the situation either way then.) My victories in this small-Power diplomacy were relatively few in that I couldn't get Turkey to preserve the armies that would no doubt have been problematic for Russia while ensuring that nobody had sufficient fleet power in the Mediterranean to oppose me. However, I did convince Italy to build an army in 1916 to go after Venice, and the Alliance never cohered enough for Russia to take a clear leadership role in assigning areas of responsibility and ensuring that tactical goals were met. It's difficult to say without tedious replays, but I'd estimate that had Russia been able to move with full force towards the west from 1916 onwards instead of leaving forces to secure Anatolia the fight for Munich might have ended differently.

      Looking at the situation in the spring of 1917, at the time I was still uncertain about my chances: losing Warsaw was a fait accompli, and retaking Munich was uncertain; my soloing attempt would fail if I could neither break through the Ionian or take and hold Munich. At the time there were still ample fleets in the Med as Turkey had two and Italy could soon build a second one; considering that two fleets could hold the Ionian from the east against the west, I was doubtful of my chances there. As it happened the Alliance had somewhat different tactical priorities from mine, which helped me achieve multiple quick successes: France fell to tactical miscalculations, Italy chose to remove a Turkish fleet instead of claiming Venice and being in position to pressure Marseilles, and up north I was really in sync with Willow, as I outguessed her multiple times in a row regarding the tactical goals of Moscow, protecting Warsaw and setting up to retake Munich. Especially the latter went through spectacularly in the fall of 1918: had the Alliance appreciated the immediate danger War-Sil and Hol-Ruh presented for Munich, they likely could have kept Munich and thus possibly beaten me back. I felt good enough about my read on Willow and my position down south that I went for the kill by keeping position in the spring and finishing up with a forced capture just now.

      In summation, I had a lot of fun here, and would like to thank everybody for their patience and fighting spirit. The game was a fight to the end as Diplomacy tends to be when everybody's doing their best. Everybody's play was of good quality and I doubt that I would've done any better in your positions. We have clearly done a lot for the overall quality of the Story Games Diplomacy scene with this series of games
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nDWeird \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I don't have the memory to recall the whole game in detail, so I'll just give my thoughts on what I do remember.

      For most of the early game, I was, first, lucky, and second, did not let any opportunity slip by.

      I got a fleet into the Black Sea, which pretty much decided the nature of my Russian relationship early on - there were struggles in the BLA environs, I'd sometimes win and sometimes lose, but my core would remain untouchable while Willow's would remain contested.

      More importantly, during all of this early slugging, Italy and Austria kept at each other's throats... And by the time they resolved their differences with, I've done the same with Russia - the net result being that I, during the whole of the game, did not even once have to fight on two fronts at once. Yes, I did have to fight both Bill and Paul at a point, but my units were close enough to support each other if need be, and the two were hampered both by the open diplomacy (an ally is only truly useful in open diplomacy when he can fight against the enemy separatelly of you, it seems), and by other considerations - both each other, and, to Bill, the growing power of Germany.

      Around that point that I was feeling pretty good about my long-term prospects, and thought to myself "Hey, crap! I didn't even once think about the other side of the board! What's happening there?"

      That was the point at which my anti-Eero campaigning began - it was clear to me that the Scandinavian hump is going to fall to England if there are no fleets present to counter it, and that it would all slowly go downhill from there, with Eero picking off coastal regions and maintaining an unassailable position.

      But the powers that mattered did not care all that much - Germany was being cocky about its prospects of expansion and saw an ally rather than a rival in England, and Russia was fighting in the Balkans against me at the time and thought that the whole thing was a ruse (which, honestly enough, it might've half-been - were Russia to invest in northern fleets, she might have kept the Scandinavian hump and I'd possibly have moved into Sev or Moscow when given a chance). I missed a diplomatic opportunity to lay off and let Russia stop England its tracks then, I'd think - for some reason I thought I can fight Russia and convince her of the English threat (which turned out real, at least) at the same time.

      After the fall of Germany, my long-term strategy became to muster enough fleets to block off the Med when England comes, which I believed it would eventually... But I was feeling pretty cool about everything as long as France stayed afloat. I kept my options open to maybe moving into Russia sometime (as long as I had the BLA fleet, all I really had to do was to build two armies in Const and Ankara, really), but the grind against Austria and Italy was slow and a good opportunity never came, especially as I knew that Eero would move in as soon as I would, and I didn't want to move against Russia unless I knew I was able to definitelly secure Moscow as well.

      And then France took a hit. It was then that I felt a bit panicky, and my, uh, strategic horizons became significantly narrower - the only thing I really cared about was occupying Italy as soon as I could. I wanted to help France at that point, but that involved cooperating with Italy and easing the pressure on her. Possibly another diplomatic/strategic blunder at my part here - I decided France could likely fend off on her own and focused on taking out Italy instead. I never for a moment had any hostile intentions towards France, and tried to hash out terms of an eventual mutual defense, but France was apparently as threatened by the advancing Turkey as she was by England, and took none of it.

      I stopped thinking about a Russian attack at that point and did my best to foster a genuine alliance, mostly to make sure that England was not making any more gains up north while I finish up with the Italian business and get my fleets into a position where I could personally make sure England was countered properly. I tried both carrots and sticks of varying sizes and eventually deluded myself into thinking that I convinced Willow we're on the same boat - all the signs were there warning me to be cautious, with misorders on every turn and a conspicious lack of Willow ever actually saying "okay, we're in an alliance now."

      France wasn't doing well, though, and the second she let that english fleet into the Med I started thinking of France as a non-entity (which was another mistake - the future dead are not dead yet).

      At that point, I was certain I made a compelling case about the DOOM that England stands for. I wanted to do two things: stop England at the north and stop her at the maw of the Med. One of those I could do under my own power, the other had to be done by Willow... But her northern line was patchy at best and wouldn't have survived a prolonged combined English-French attack. So, even though I didn't really need to tactically, I decided to unilaterally move all of my border troops away to free up the Russian armies to bolster the northern line...

      And we all know how that went down.

      I'm still not sure what Willow was thinking there, in terms of the endgame. I could have been eliminated with little risk from my side, sure, but at that point, France and parts of Russia would be easy pickings too... Unless you believe Eero when he says that he won't hit Russia and France on their backs as soon as they turn on me, but that's just silly. Maaaybe something effective could have been arranged by feeding Italy parts of formerly Turkish soil and letting it build the fleets necessary, but that wasn't even tried.

      Willow, I'm honestly confused! Was the presence of the Bla fleet so antagonizing that you just had to eliminate Turkey when the chance arose? Did you think the then near-fleetless France was strong enough to counter an English advance? Was there anything I could have possibly done to keep the kinda-sorta alliance going until the end?


      Anyhoo! Good game, I certainly enjoyed it - being a corner power in an open diplomacy environment is certainly relaxing, at least if compared to the regular stuff. A shame I didn't win, of course, but... While a loser is a loser is a loser, at least I can derive a certain bitter smug satisfaction from the fact that I [i]totally called it.[/i]

      When we're all toiling away under the English whip, we will at least have the pride of knowing that we fought against this world order! Well, had genuine plans to fight against this world order. Good intentions count for something, right?

      Annnd there goes the smugness.

      ~signed, the Pirates of Sicily.
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n\nWillow \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n A note about my misorders: they were all genuine. Towards the end of the game, I took to onerously checking and rechecking my orders.

      Daumantas-

      My motive is just as I state upthread: I was not confident of my ability to defeat France in a EFRT endgame. In fact, as soon as Italy was in the ground, I was prepared to offer a four-way draw. However, Italy held out longer than expected, and I was presented with a golden stab opportunity. I believed France could be secure enough to last to the end- but as we saw, that was not the case.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nBill_White \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMarch 2011 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Well, I lost fair and square. I was hoping to pound on Italy quickly while Russia and Turkey were at each other's throats, but they reconciled too quickly and I lost my nerve when Willow moved to Galicia. The public diplomacy environment had me wrong-footed, too, and I couldn't get the hang of it. When Italy stabbed me, I knew that I wasn't going to make it to the draw, so I started playing for personal satisfaction rather than with any long-term plan, and ultimately my enemies found me more valuable dead than alive. *Poof* Good-bye Austria.

      Still, it was fun, with some tense moments and some wild ups and downs. Good stuff.
      \n
